HEADLINE: Control Data's Net Off

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 31

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation said today that its earnings fell 47 percent in the second quarter because of the weak economy and lower demand for computer products. The computer services company earned $5.9 million, or 14 cents a share, in the three months that ended on June 30, compared with $11.2 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier. Its revenues fell 8.5 percent, to $371.3 million from $405.6 million. Results a year ago included revenues and losses from several operations that have since been sold or discontinued, as well as a pretax gain of $4.3 million. The company's stock closed at $9.375 today, down 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange today.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Media General Forecast

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RICHMOND, July 31

 BODY:
Media General Inc. said today that it would probably post a third-quarter loss because of the poor performance of an affiliate. The company attributed the projected decline to losses sustained in the second quarter by the Garden State Newspapers Company, which owns 14 daily newspapers and several weeklies. Media General owns 40 percent of Garden State Newspapers. The affiliate's operations in northern New Jersey in particular have felt the brunt of the recession, Media General said. In the third quarter of last year, Media General earned $7.3 million, or 28 cents a share, on revenues of $152 million. Its third quarter ends on Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: Edward C. Prehn, Education Professor, 81

 BODY:
Edward C. Prehn, a professor of education and author of economics textbooks for high-school students, died on Saturday at his home on Staten Island. He was 81 years old.
He died of a heart attack, a friend, Michael Rosenfeld, said. 
 Dr. Prehn taught at City College, Wagner College and in several Staten Island high schools. He was also a member of the Board of Examiners. He retired in 1972.
His several textbooks included "The Modern Economy in Action" and "Teaching High School Economics."
There are no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: METRO DATELINES;
Slowing Is Reported In Pace of Job Loss

DATELINE: MANHATTAN

 BODY:
Although the New York City region lost 90,000 jobs in the first half of this year, the pace of that job loss is slowing, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. In the last half of 1990, job losses in the 23 counties in New York and northeastern New Jersey amounted to 116,000.
"We're beginning to see the first glimmer of light," Mr. Ehrenhalt said yesterday. He cautioned that it was "no more than a flickering candle in a long, dark tunnel," but he called it significant because it was the first such sign in two years and came as the pace of job losses at the national level was continuing to mount. 
 The industries in which job losses showed signs of abating were trade, manufacturing, finance, insurance and real estate. But in the services sector, which has been one of the only areas of employment growth over the last two years, the growth came to a virtual halt.
Government jobs were down by 20,000, the largest decline in 15 years. Mr. Ehrenhalt said those job losses were concentrated in the Federal and state work forces and did not reflect the recent layoffs of city workers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Decline On Concern Over Recovery

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell broadly in light trading yesterday after two economic reports failed to ease worries about the durability of the United States recovery.
The dollar, after falling in overseas trading, continued to slide when the Government's main economic barometer, the index of leading indicators, showed a less-than-expected rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in June. It was the fifth straight increase for the index, but only 5 of the 11 forward-looking elements advanced. 
 An accompanying report said American factory orders fell 1.4 percent, breaking a two-month advance.
The numbers were disappointing to dollar traders because reports of economic weakess tend to hurt the currency by raising the possibility that lower interest rates will be needed to stimulate growth. Lower United States interest rates make dollar-denominated investments worth less.
"People were looking for further indications that the U.S. economy had bottomed out and was back on the upswing, and today's numbers didn't give an indication either way," said Bob Morrissey, senior trader for the Bank of Boston.
 
Jobless Data Awaited
 The numbers raised fears that a report on July employment, to be released on Friday, might be equally disappointing and bolster concerns that the recovery might be stalling.
In New York, the dollar fell to 137.36 yen from 137.90 yen on Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 137.83 yen, unchanged from Tuesday. Later, in London, the dollar finished at 137.40 yen.
The dollar also fell against the British pound. Sterling settled at $1.6860 in New York, compared with $1.6770 on Thursday. In London, the pound rose to $1.6845, from $1.6810 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, were: 1.7440 German marks, down from 1.7535; 1.5233 Swiss francs, down from 1.5308; 5.9310 French francs, down from 5.9640; 1,302.00 Italian lire, down from 1,310.00, and 1.15125 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15225.

HEADLINE: Indicators Up 0.5% for Fifth Straight Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The Government's main economic barometer, released today, continues to point toward recovery, but analysts said an accompanying report on slumping factory orders illustrated the sluggish, choppy nature of the turnaround.
The Commerce Department said its index of leading indicators rose five-tenths of a percent in June, its fifth straight increase, despite drops in several components, including factory orders for consumer goods. In a separate report the department said orders to factories fell 1.4 percent, breaking a two-month advance. 
 The string of gains in the leading indicators "pretty much confirms that the recovery began in the second quarter," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
 
5 of 11 Indicators Post Gains
 Still, only 5 of the 11 forward-looking indicators posted gains. One was virtually unchanged.
"The increases are less than we've been accustomed to in a recovery, but we've been saying it will be a weaker recovery than average," said Robert G. Dederick, economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
The Bush Administration and many private analysts project that the economy will grow about 2.5 percent to 3 percent for the rest of the year, compared with a 6 percent average growth rate in the other eight recoveries since World War II.
But some analysts express concern the economy could even dip back into recession after a period of growth.
Mr. Sung, for instance, said: "The probability of a double-dip recession is not exactly negligible. If anything, it is increasing."
Richard Rahn, an economist with the United States Chamber of Commerce, also contended the revival could be short-lived.
"At best, the numbers support a rate of economic growth of only about 1 percent -- hardly fitting anyone's notion of a significant recovery," he said.
Since the end of World War II, five of the eight recessions have experienced the double dip, in which the economy expanded for a quarter before resuming its contraction.
Still, Mr. Dederick, speaking of the drop in factory orders, said, "Such decreases are not uncommon in the opening stages of a recovery."
Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, said that whenever the leading indicators performed similarly coming out of previous recessions, "it's been pretty much clear sailing."
 
6 to 9 Months Ahead
 The leading indicators are intended to forecast economic activity six to nine months ahead. The biggest contributor to the index growth in June was a longer average workweek.
Other positive factors were an index measuring consumer confidence, a drop in initial weekly unemployment claims, an increase in building permits and longer delivery times, indicating a pickup in orders.
Another indicator, stock prices, increased slightly, but its contribution rounded to zero, the department said.
Indicators with negative readings were a decline in factory orders for consumer goods, fewer unfilled factory orders, a drop in the money supply, a decrease in prices for raw materials indicating lagging demand and a drop in orders for new plants and equipment.
The various changes left the index at 143.6 percent of its 1982 base of 100. Although the index has fallen 1.8 percent from June 1990, it has risen 3 percent in the last six months.

HEADLINE: STATE DEPT. BACKS PERU AID PACKAGE

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
After months of internal debate, the Administration has determined that Peru has improved its lackluster performance on human rights enough to release $94 million in aid, largely intended to combat the cultivation of narcotic coca plants, State Department officials said today.
The move immediately drew strong condemnation in Congress and among human rights groups who asserted that the Peruvian Army had the worst record of summary executions, disappearances and torture of any military in Latin America. 
 Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, immediately announced his intention to block the Administration's move.
Administration officials did not dispute that the Peruvian Army continued to violate human rights, but they noted that Lima deserved special consideration given that it is under siege from drug lords, a cholera epidemic and the most violent guerrilla movement in the hemisphere. They also said that as long as Peru is the source of 60 percent of the cocaine imported into the United States, Washington must try to develop growing cooperation with the Government in eradicating coca plants.
 
Human Rights Factor
 "This was a difficult decision for everybody," said a State Department official who monitors Peru. "We're very concerned about continuing problems there and we've made it clear to the Peruvians that we expect further progress in human rights and counternarcotics."
Under the International Narcotics Control Act, the Administration cannot provide anti-drug funding to the four Andean governments until it issues a determination to Congress that they have gained effective control over their police and armed forces to improve their human rights conduct.
The Administration determined in January that Colombia, Bolivia and Ecuador fulfilled the criteria, but it delayed its decision on Peru until late Tuesday because of persistent reports that the army was repressing peasants while protecting coca planters.
In the formal determination, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger wrote that Peru deserved military and economic aid because it had provided wider access to international human rights monitors, purged the security forces of many implicated in abuses, and "virtually eliminated" paramilitary activity.
 
$34 Million in Military Aid
 Juan Mendez, executive director of the human rights group Americas Watch, disputed the decision, asserting that the army and police still "commit egregious human rights violations on a systematic basis."
Peru stands to gain $34 million in military aid, much of which would go for helicopters and helicopter training that police and army units could use to eradicate coca plants that grow through much of the Andes.
The $60 million in economic aid would be earmarked for balance of payments relief and projects intended to give farmers who grow coca plants alternative sources of income. Congressional foreign policy and appropriations committees have 15 days to object to the Administration determination in order to block the disbursement.
Saying the decision "flies in the face of every international human rights group," Senator Leahy said he would put a hold on the disbursement. One of his aides that under Senate procedures, he could negotiate a compromise under which some of the money would be withheld. The Senator is to meet with Administration officials on Thursday.
The Administration made its determination after a three-day trip to Peru three weeks ago by Richard Shifter, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, in which he consulted with Persident Alberto Fujimori and senior military officers. Mr. Shifter won promises from the officials that they would reform the military and civilian judicial systems and extend human rights training within the police and armed forces.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW;
Bush-Gorbachev Comments: Specific Spheres of Cooperation

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 31

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the news conference held today by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as translated by his interpreter, and President Bush:
 
OPENING STATEMENTS
 GORBACHEV: We see the official visit of the President of the United States to the Soviet Union as a big event in our relations, as a really global event.
And I want to say that these days we have done a great deal of work which I think will create difficulties for me and the President in order to present it in condensed form. 
 Nevertheless, this visit, to some extent, sums up the last stage of our cooperation at a very fundamental, dramatic, time of developing of events in the world when both the President of the United States of America and the Soviet Union were placed in very difficult circumstances, unusual ones which demanded from them great feeling of responsibility in taking very important decisions, which have had consequences and will have consequences in the further development of our cooperation in events in the world. . . .
The President showed great interest in the events taking place in our country, our domestic processes. I tried to satisfy his interest and did this on my part with a great deal of satisfaction since in his interest I felt a desire to understand even more of what is going on in our country and moreover I felt also a feeling of solidarity in this.
We had an interesting, substantive discussion, and perhaps for the first time, it covered the following in our bilateral cooperation. For the first time over the past period we probably accented rather strongly what our economic relationships should be like, how we have to work together in this important sphere so that relationships in this area would be appropriate to the international dialogue which we have reached in other areas.
And here we have noted on the basis of neutral understanding, if not, President Bush will say so, that there must be movements in accommodation as well. Obviously one can do a lot in the area of reform so that we can include ourselves in international economic ties, to play by the rules of the game -- like this expression, I haven't invented any other one for the time being. That's why I use the term I'm familiar with.
 
Soviet Revisions
 We have to do a great deal, and we have made our choice to continue reforms, democratic changes, and especially now to move decisively forward to the market relationship, the relationship of property.
It is clear that our success in these internal affairs is tied to a great extent to the process of reform in the federation, and I hope that I have satisfied the interests of the President about the state of this as of today. We both understand that this is very important for the success of our work. And thus, we must change, we must understand and well understand here in the Soviet Union that the basic responsibility for the fate of this country, for reforms, for the making of decisions which are very important, is our prerogative, our responsibility.
And obviously, we are very interested in a more fruitful cooperation with the countries of the West and in the light of continuing the discussion which we had in London, within the framework of my meeting at the G-7, we spoke also about this subject, as well, and I tried to develop the thesis which I expressed in London, that we hoped to see accommodating movement of the Western countries because they, too, in their approaches in a spirit of economic cooperation must accommodate us. . . .
For the first time we talked substantially about specific spheres of cooperation in implementing certain projects on the basis of bilateral cooperation.
To speak about this briefly, we spoke about cooperating in the field of energy, especially in the area of conversion. We have great possibilities here. And specifically in a sphere in which we are very interested, that is, the agricultural sphere, especially food distribution.
In this regard, I transmitted certain materials to the President as in an aide-memoire. The same was done by the Foreign Minister. Comrade Bessmertnykh gave this to the Secretary of State, Mr. Baker, an aide-memoire about those projects in which we could cooperate fruitfully. This is a very interesting and substantive project. We would want to act in such a way that in implementing these projects, in all of them, to give a possibility to each other to earn money. Otherwise, the process won't go forward unless there is benefit of it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Then the President and I thought about the following. And what do we do next? We've signed the treaty and what next? We've congratulated each other and our peoples and the world with the fact that such great progress has been accomplished. And as a result of almost a decade of work, and what next?
 
Disarmament Issues
 And we did not want simply to be pragmatists here. We wanted to look at the problem of security, stability from the point of view of the present-day realities, or should we simply continue the negotiations which are already taking place, and there are many problems which still need to be discussed? Or should we also look at the world from a somewhat different position, from today's heights, with the new reality which exists? . . .
Nevertheless, we also examined very many specific issues of disarmament without -- we did not leave unattended problems of the Middle East. And I must say, and if the President considers it appropriate he could name certain things, and if you have questions, we could discuss this. We have worked out a joint document on this. I have in mind our position, our common position with regard to the Middle East.
I think that this is a very important result of our joint work and I think that the fact that this position will be publicly announced will have serious influence on this process, and we consider that it is in a decisive stage and we should not, and here I want to use what our ministers use, to have a window of opportunity, in order to really achieve progress in this very sensitive area of international politics.
The President and I talked about the situation in Europe in the context of implementing the agreement, the Helsinki agreements, the Paris charter, and especially with regard to the processes taking place in that region, and specifically noted the situation in Yugoslavia, and expressed our position, our understanding, approach to the resolution of this issue, a very serious one, which worries many of us -- also in a joint statement we expressed this.
I must say that we also moved forward and discussed other things. We tried to also look at many global processes.

 	 	 		. . .	 	And thus I want to ask the pardon of the President and the press. I am the host, and I have maybe misused it, but perhaps I could listen to your comments as well -- I'm speaking so much.
I understood that you were almost in agreement.
BUSH: What I heard I liked.
GORBACHEV: Thank you for being honest.
BUSH: Once again -- this might be an appropriate time for Barbara and me to thank the President and Mrs. Gorbachev for this fantastic hospitality. And yes, I couldn't agree more about the productive nature of the talks, the enhancement of mutual understanding. This is not diplomatic language, in my view, this is fact.
You know my views on the Start agreement. Indeed, it's the culmination of a long and historic negotiation, and I happen to believe that the winners on this are the young people, not just in the Soviet Union, not just in the United States but all around the world.
And we are taking major steps in transforming our economic relations. President Gorbachev touched on some of this, but we're going to send up the trade agreement to the U.S. Congress. We're going to grant most-favored-nation status, now that the technicalities have been worked out. We have fulfilled thus our Malta goal, Mr. President, of normalizing our economic relationship.
We agreed here to tackle the next challenge. President Gorbachev talked about that -- furthering economic reform in the U.S.S.R., and seeking to integrate the Soviet economy into the international system.
 
Points of Cooperation
 We're going forward with space cooperation, cooperation in the environment, and we have several joint projects in mind there. Building on our historic cooperation during the gulf crisis, discussed, the President and I discussed our partnership in resolving longstanding regional programs. As mentioned, they're putting out statements on Yugoslavia, Central America. And indeed, I want to comment now just briefly on the Middle East before taking your questions.
We did reaffirm our mutual commitment to promote peace and genuine reconciliation between the Arab states, Israel and the Palestinians. And we believe there is a historic opportunity right now to launch a process that can lead to a just and enduring peace and to a comprehensive settlement in the Middle East.
We share the strong conviction that this historic opportunity must not be lost. And while recognizing that peace cannot be imposed, it can only result from direct negotiations between the parties, the United States and the Soviet Union pledged to do their utmost to promote and sustain the peacemaking process.
And to that end, the United States and the Soviet Union, acting as co-sponsors, are going to work to convene an October press conference designed to launch bilateral and multilateral negotiations. Invitations to the conference will be issued at least 10 days prior to the date the conference is to convene. And in the interim, Secretary Baker and Foreign Minister Bessmertnykh will continue to work with the parties to prepare for this conference. And I am today asking Secretary of State Jim Baker to return to the Middle East to obtain Israel's answer to our proposal for peace.
And again, my thanks to you, and I'll be prepared to take questions, along with you, sir.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. One question to Comrade Gorbachev. You said that you talked with Mr. Bush about Yugoslavia. What is the essence of that conversation about Yugoslavia? . . .
A. The essence of the conversation. I will then make use of the fact that I will relate the content of the U.S.-Soviet statement on Yugoslavia. This is the result of our conversation on this subject.
We, both countries, with deep concern, have noted the dramatic development of events in Yugoslavia. This is a translation from the Russian. And we have been against the use of force and call upon all sides to abide by the agreements on cease-fire.
We, the Soviet Union and the U.S., proceed from the premise that the resolution of issues must be found by the peoples of Yugoslavia themselves on the basis of democratic principles, through peaceful negotiations and constructive approaches.
We emphasized the necessity of having all sides respect the basic principles indicated in the Helsinki Act and the Paris Charter. The U.S. and the U.S.S.R. support the efforts undertaken by the C.S.C.E. countries, specifically the European Community, steps to resolve the problem. This is the essence of the statement.
BUSH: And I would only add, sir, that inasmuch as that was a joint statement, that expresses our continued position as well.
 
Israeli Stance on Talks
 Q. President Bush, could I ask you -- the fact that you're going ahead with this peace conference, does that mean that you have Israel's acceptance of the outlines of your conditions for a peace conference, or is there still a hang-up, or have you got a commitment from Mr. Shamir?
BUSH: Well, I would wait and let Secretary Baker answer that question after this next meeting. If I had to express a degree of optimism or pessimism, I'd say I'm a little more optimistic today. But the visit for Jim Baker now is, for what we said here, to obtain Israel's answer to our proposal for peace. And if I had the answer in my pocket, or he did, I expect that we would say so.
 
A Future Meeting
 Q. (through interpreter) I have a question to both Presidents. You discussed many questions of international issues, bilateral issues. You signed a unique agreement today. What did you leave for the next meeting, and can we say when you're planning to have it?
GORBACHEV: You know, I think that what we discussed today and what we have set in motion, both with regard to a political dialogue and a continuation of the disarmament process and new subjects in the area of economic cooperation and trade, interaction in the resolution of important issues, including regional conflicts, which unfortunately still take place, and especially since we have begun a significant discussion about the concept of future strategic stability, that means that we have many issues to discuss for many meetings ahead. So I think that our contacts will continue. But I would express myself in favor of the following.
Perhaps not always can we go, and this makes the positions of the Presidents very specific, that it's harder for them than for the Ministers of Foreign Affairs to unravel and discuss issues of foreign affairs. But nevertheless the President and I have developed a method of conversation. We exchange opinions by telephone. As soon as we have a need, concerns, or simply to exchange something -- opinions about something important -- we do this by telephone, and this takes place on a regular basis.
And, secondly, we regularly exchange letters. And this exchange of opinions has not ceased even in recent days when we have already reached agreement with the President, we were expecting him here. . . .
BUSH: I would only add to that that though no date is set, it is my view -- and I haven't always held this view -- that a meeting without an agenda is a good idea from time to time between the Soviet President and the President of the United States.
And with this -- President Gorbachev talked about arms control and regional problems and other problems -- but as this dynamic economy begins to move, the chance for a dynamic economy here, there's going to be much more to talk about on the economic side than we've ever had before -- cooperation, partnerships, joint ventures, the whole approach to economics that he has endorsed that is going to benefit I believe the Soviet Union and I think has enormous potential for the United States.
So it is my view that we have got plenty to talk about, and I for one would be prepared, as I've stated before, to have a meeting where there is not a crisis out there to be managed. Rather we can be sure that we're not two ships passing in the night -- the analogy I used I believe in Malta, appropriately -- and I look forward to future meetings.
Because you get a lot done where you can't put out -- sign a 3-point program or a 20-point protocol -- but a lot is done just by the kinds of conversations we had today.
 
Lithuania Strife
 Q. President Gorbachev, there was an ugly border incident in Lithuania last night in which a number of Lithuanian border guards were killed. I wonder if we could have your reaction and any explanation you might have of it. Also, President Bush, any reaction from you in light particularly of your call yesterday afternoon for freedom for the Baltic states?
GORBACHEV: You know, we received this information when we were talking outside the city, and the first information was such that the incident was between -- on the border between Lithuania and Byelorussia, and when one of the citizens of Byelorussia went in the direction of Lithuania, and at the customs point where he was approaching, he saw two wounded people, and four died.
He quickly related this information and now the state security agency of Lithuania and Byelorussia, the chairman of the State Committee on Security, offered also to help in the cooperation. So now we are investigating this.
I must say that in addition to regret, it is -- we must simply sympathize with this, sympathize with the families of the people that died. And I must also say that we are doing everything in order not only to take actions, but also to avoid such excesses, such conflicts, on the basis of resolution of basic issues.
And we have taken such basic decisions, mutual decisions with regard to issues concerning Armenia and Azerbaijan, there's a dialogue. And the faster and more productive the dialogue is, the more incidents, efforts there are to break it down.
Not everyone likes this process that it develop in such a direction. And it's hard for us to say what happened. We heard versions, the President and I, but these are versions, this is not important at any rate. I will be monitoring this and we will tell you what it was that happened in reality.
Q. I just wanted to get your reaction, sir, to the incident in light of your call yesterday afternoon for freedom for the Baltic states?
BUSH: Well, I don't think there's a connection, but I do regret the violence. I think -- I listened to what President Gorbachev said about discussion. We clearly favor negotiation. He knows that, that would lead to a reduction of cross-border violence on both sides. And obviously I'd like to join in expressing my regret to those families whose loved ones are lost.
But the President immediately got on this and said they're conducting an investigation. I think there's hope that the investigation will be cooperative between the Lithuanian side and the Byelorussia side. And so we can't prejudge the incident, but I had an opportunity to express my views to President Gorbachev on the whole question of the Baltic states.
I don't think it's fair to link a border incident before you know what happened, to that question, however.
 
Soviet Economic Integration
 Q. (through interpreter) How far did you go after London in moving ahead in the integration of the U.S.S.R. into the international community? Was there progress reached in this area? To both Presidents. Perhaps you can begin.
BUSH: Well, let me say that's a serious objective to start with.
Secondly, I believe that active participation in these international financial institutions, in the status that was deemed best by the G-7 is the most important thing that the Soviets can do right now.
I have freed up, as you heard today, certain trade benefits or normalizing of trade procedures that in my view will help. And we've done that since the meeting in London.
But the answer is full benefit of these international institutions require full knowledge and steps towards the privatization and towards convertibility. All the things that I believe the Soviet Union wants. . . .
GORBACHEV: I understand that I'm supposed to comment on this as well since the question was to both Presidents. I will be brief, since I have already expressed my opinion about this. London was the beginning of a very important process. This was the meaning of the London meeting and no one must judge about this in that light.
It's very important that after London there was a desire on both parts to work out a mechanism which would permit the shifting of this cooperation given the political will of the leadership of the Western countries.
In the Soviet Union we think that we should have special structures which would keep tabs on the cooperation between the Soviet Union and the G-7 countries, and first of all, in the area of investment. So the process would be easier in the taking of decisions of mutual interest.
And it's good that the mechanism has started to be implemented, which we discussed in London and the Minister of Finances of England is already here. We first talked about the fact that there would be visits of the Minister of Finance, Secretary of the Treasury of the U.S. and the representative of the F.R.G. So in other words, there would be the mechanism of implementing specific areas of cooperation, and this is very important, that there be a mechanism for real interaction.
And finally, the President mentioned that on the part of the U.S. an important decision will be taken to make trade between our countries easier. I would say that I mentioned this in passing, but we often discuss this with the President, asked and we agreed to study the question of Cocom restrictions today because many billion-dollar projects which are ready to go and even signed are not being implemented because of the fact that they have elements that come under Cocom restrictions. . . .
 
Nuclear Deterrence
 Q. I would ask both of you to think back to the 1986 Reykjavik summit when Ronald Reagan horrified quite a few American nuclear experts and almost all of the European leaders by giving serious consideration to your proposal, President Gorbachev, for a ban on all nuclear weapons. . . . Why now are the two of you not saying we will now work towards a total nuclear ban? Do you still believe in the efficacy of nuclear deterrence keeping the peace? Particularly, sir, I ask you, President Bush, given the fact that some of these breakaway republics, they have nuclear weapons in there and who knows what would happen if they declare independence.
BUSH: In fact, I wouldn't suggest that a breakaway republic is going to use a nuclear weapon against the United States but I would suggest that we have every reason in the world to be concerned about renegades, not in these areas perhaps -- I hope not -- getting hold of nuclear weapons. And that's one of the reasons I strongly support our G-Pals program that is being debated in the Senate right now.
But in my view, other countries do possess nuclear weapons. It's not just the Soviet Union and the United States. And I do believe that we are on the right path, by the path that President Gorbachev has outlined today, on following on on existing agreements.
So rather than try to have a ethereal or a utopian answer, let's follow through practically as he suggested, and then as far as the U.S. is concerned, I'd like us to go forward with a system that puts nobody at threat, nobody at risk. The only thing at risk is an errant nuclear missile aiming at a country.
And that's why I support the defensive approach. And that's why I think one of the lessons out of the Iraq war, and maybe President Gorbachev reads this differently, is that defenses work. And though we're talking about a different concept now, an expanded concept, a more high-tech concept, I think a lot of lives were saved by defense.
So that's my reply.
GORBACHEV: I will say a few words.
I think that the argument which you want to ascribe to me that in my policy I look upon nuclear weapons as a element of deterrence is not true. I have not said this.
Yes, we got involved in the arms race in a very serious way. Thank God, as we say in Russian that we stopped this and turned it back, and this is a great accomplishment since we understood where we were headed.
But it's hard to resolve all these issues which have piled up, all these weapons that have piled up.
And I think that there is still a lot that we have to do.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Rise as Taxables Dip

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with tax-exempt funds moving higher and the taxable ones declining.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue, which regularly monitors funds, said that the yields on tax-free funds rose considerably, because of the increased supply of municipals offered recently. He mentioned the large offerings yesterday by New York State and New York City. 
 The rise in yields follows a period "when they were driven down by lack of supply," said Mr. Frank, who attributed that increase to seasonal factors like the end of fiscal years on June 30 and budget delays by some state legislatures.
"Now, supply is catching up," he said.
 
Outlook for Rate Shift
 As for the outlook, he commented: "The latest economic and money supply numbers have at least raised the possibility that the Federal Reserve could conceivably take another bite at the lower-interest-rate apple. We think the odds are low but it cannot be ruled out."
Assets of the tax-exempt funds, which totaled $88.5 billion a week ago, now total $87.6 billion, which he called "quite a sizable drop." He continued, "I suspect that as yields go up, more people will go back into the market, perhaps into longer-term municipals." The average maturity of securities in the tax-free portfolios remained at 58 days, he said.
The seven-day simple yield for the tax-exempts was 3.98 percent, and the seven-day compound yield was 4.06 percent, compared with 3.71 percent and 3.77 percent, respectively, a week earlier. In the case of the 30-day compound rate, the latest simple yield was 3.68 percent, and the compound yield 3.75 percent.
 
Fund's 14th Week at Top
 For the 14th week in row the highest-yielding tax-exempt fund was the Strong Municipal Money Market fund, distributed by Strong/Cornelison Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee, reporting a yield of 4.99 percent, somewhat better than the 4.84 percent of a week before.
The highest-yielding New York fund continued to be Salomon Brothers' New York Municipal Money Market fund, which reported a 4.50 percent yield on a seven-day compounded basis.
For New Jersey, Calvert Tax Free Reserve, N.J., was the leader, turning in a yield of 5.09 percent, while in Connecticut the highest-yielding fund was Dreyfus Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with 4.26 percent.
 
Taxable Fund Assets Off
 Assets of the taxable funds were down $2.7 billion, to $448.7 billion, with the public accounting for most of the decline once again. The institutional ownership was down only $596 million, to 110.7 billion.
The simple seven-day yield reported by Donoghue's was down a basis point, to 5.45 percent, while the compound yield was off 2 basis points, to 5.59 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the case of 30-day simple yields, the decline was a basis point, to 5.46 percent, while the 30-day compound yield dropped to 5.61 percent from 5.62 percent.
The average maturity of portfolio holdings was unchanged at 53 days for the taxables.
Among the taxable funds, the top-yielding one for the second week in a row was Riverside Capital Money Market fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 6.42 percent, slightly higher than last week's 6.38 percent. The fund's distributor is the Winsbury Company, Columbus, Ohio.

HEADLINE: Stocks Manage a Small Gain; Dow Up 8.50

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The stock market posted a small gain yesterday, as worries about the pace of an economic recovery returned to the market after a strong rise in the previous session.
Analysts said that the market, which was down most of the morning, after an initial gain in the opening hour, was affected by a Commerce Department report that the index of leading indicators rose only five-tenths of a percent in June, a smaller gain than had generally been expected. 
 Analysts said that the bankruptcy filing of the Columbia Gas System, a major supplier of natural gas in the Northeast, contributed to the lackluster market. The company's problems center on long-term contracts to buy gas at prices that far exceed current market levels. But stocks began surging after 2:30 P.M., when the Treasury Department announced the size of its quarterly refunding.
"Even though the size of the $38 billion refunding was not unexpected, it was a record," said William M. LeFevre, a market analyst with Tucker Anthony. "It affected the bond market, and that, in turn, affected the stock market."
 
Advances Beat Declines
 Advancing issues outpaced declines by about three to two on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Dow Jones industrial average was up 8.50 points, nearly three-tenths of a percent, to 3,024.82. The Dow Jones utility stocks were down 2.27 points yesterday, with the Columbia Gas bankruptcy responsible for about two-thirds of that decline.
The Nasdaq composite index was up 3.77 points, to 502.04, an increase of three-quarters of one percent. The American Stock Exchange's composite index was up 1.28 points, to 368.28, an increase of less than four-tenths of a percent. The New York Stock Exchange's index was up 0.70 point, to 212.34. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.12 points, to 387.81.
 
Columbia Gas Leads Losers
 The most-active issue on the Big Board was Columbia Gas, which dropped 3 yesterday, to 14, the biggest decline on the exchange. The second-most-active issue was Pepsico Inc., which was up 3/8, to 31 7/8.
The top gainer on the Big Board was the Student Loan Marketing Association, which was up 3 3/8, to 65 5/8. The stock moved on positive comments by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The second-largest gainer on the Big Board was Imcera Group, a producer of health-care products for people and animals. The stock, which rose 3, to 111 5/8, has been up since it signed a marketing and manufacturing agreement with American Cyanamid.
The second-biggest declining stock was Capital Cities/ABC, which was down 2 1/2, to 455. The broadcasting and publishing concern's stock is still reeling from last week's announcement of lower earnings.
In over-the-counter trading, Bioplasty Inc. fell 6 1/2, to 10. The decline came after the Food and Drug Administration said that it had taken about 500 breast implants from one of the company's factories, saying that Bioplasty had not been approved for marketing and that the company had issued unsubstantiated medical claims about the implants.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Fall by 1.4% In Sign of Erratic Recovery

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Orders for manufactured goods fell 1.4 percent in June after a two-month advance, the Government said today in a report that was seen as confirmation of a below-par, erratic economic recovery.
"The tenuous nature of the revival clearly can be seen in orders for manufacturers' goods," said Richard Rahn, an economist with the United States Chamber of Commerce. "This indicates that production and employment gains may be uneven and weak for the remainder of 1991." 
 Still, other analysts, while agreeing with that assessment, pointed to a section of the report that showed that inventories had fallen four-tenths of a percent, the sixth drop in the last seven months.
"That means you're going to get momentum coming out of the recession," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. Manufacturers, he said, would increase production as businesses restock to meet consumer demand.
The Commerce Department report showed that orders for both durable and nondurable goods fell to a seasonally adjusted $233.3 billion from $236.5 billion in May.
The advance in May was revised to 2.3 percent, which was weaker than the 2.9 percent first estimated. Orders grew 2.1 percent in April, the first advance in five months.
Orders for both durable and nondurable goods dropped 1.4 percent in June.
The decline in durables -- relatively expensive items expected to last more than three years -- was revised from the 1.6 percent estimate first reported last week. They had risen 2 percent in May.
Orders for non-military capital goods excluding aircraft -- a barometer of industry plans to expand and modernize -- fell 4.5 percent, erasing a 2.9 percent gain in May.
 
Military Orders Plunge
 Military orders, an often-volatile category, plunged 15.6 percent after surging 22.3 percent a month earlier. Excluding this category, orders were off eight-tenths of a percent in June.
Among the durable goods, orders for transportation equipment, led by aircraft, rose 3.8 percent after gaining 4.8 percent the previous month. Excluding the transportation sector, orders were down 2.1 percent.
Primary metals also rose, up 3.8 percent after falling 1.1 percent in May.
But orders for electronic and other electrical equipment were off 9.8 percent after falling 2.4 percent in May. Orders for industrial machinery and equipment were down 4.2 percent, wiping out a 3.5 percent advance a month earlier.
All major industries except apparel, petroleum and coal products, and rubber and plastics contributed to the decline in nondurable goods. Nondurables had posted a 2.6 percent gain in May.

HEADLINE: Lending a Hand to the Small Latin Entrepreneur

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
Flecked with bronze dust from burnishing guitar parts, Luis Ibanez switched off a buffing machine in his backyard metal shop here and praised the magic wrought by small-business loans that were once nearly impossible to get.
Using past loans, he hired his son-in-law, Jeremia Eremias Perez, as an assistant and started exporting banjo and guitar parts to Venezuela. With new credit he has applied for, he is planning to buy more machinery and to hire two more workers. 
 Mr. Ibanez and the scores of self-employed shoemakers, carpenters, seamstresses, food market vendors, mechanics and others make up what economists call the informal sector of Latin American industry.
Their role in stabilizing and reviving the region is quickly growing. Because of rapid urbanization in recent decades, 75 percent of Latin America's population now lives in cities. In a continent with virtually no welfare or unemployment benefits, small businesses soak up an average of 50 percent of the work force.
 
Bypassing the Loan Sharks
 Traditionally, though, bankers have passed over people like Mr. Ibanez, as well as the Ciudad Bolivar area where he lives, a sprawling shantytown of 1.3 million people, largely immigrants from the countryside.
The banks saw no profit in making small loans, typically $200 to $400, for short terms to poor, often illiterate people who had no collateral and no influential sponsors. That left Latin America's small entrepreneurs like Mr. Ibanez with the costly alternative of borrowing from loan sharks at rates three to four times those charged by banks.
But now, a United States-based aid group, Accion International, is using a formula across urban Latin America to weld hundreds of small-business credits into consolidated loan portfolios. These portfolios are winning financing from Latin America's commercial banks at market rates.
"We were talking about real interest rates -- no subsidies," said Carlos Castello Holguin, Accion's Colombia director. The organization's name is the Spanish word for action. The group's philosophy is that development will occur when Latin Americans' business acumen is matched with credit and business training.
That belief is gaining rapid acceptance as more and more economists recognize the economic importance of Latin America's grass-roots business people.
Encouraged by its success with the banks and in the barrios, Accion has set ambitious goals for mass marketing small-business loans in Latin America in this decade. By 1995, the organization, based in Cambridge, Mass., plans to administer loans to 800,000 businesses, nearly all of which have fewer than 10 employees.
Last year, Accion provided loans to 68,000 small businesses, generating 40,000 new jobs.
Of 13 countries participating in the Americas, Colombia has the largest program, with 25,000 small businesses receiving loans through the program.
Setting its sights on making the program a significant force for improving income distribution in this nation of 30 million, Accion hopes by the end of the decade to be administering loans to 250,000 Colombian "micro-entrepreneurs."
And, in contrast to their Governments, Latin America's poor have built a strong track record of repaying their loans on time. While many Latin American governments have defaulted or rescheduled payments on large portions of the region's $400 billion foreign debt, the repayment rate through Accion International Programs is 98 percent.
"We have to show the bankers that development is good for business," said Mr. Castello, who has a master's degree in economics from Georgetown University.
In Colombia, 17 private foundations administer loans in the nation's 12 largest cities. During a four-year start-up period, the foundations are making small-business loans by drawing on subsidized loans from Accion or from local supporters. Already three Colombian foundations are self-sufficient, relying entirely on commercial banks for credit.
In the United States, Accion has tapped a new movement among churches, unions and individuals interested in what they call socially responsible investment. Investors in Accion's Bridge Fund get lower rates of return, but have the satisfaction of knowing that their dollars are being used to help small businesses.
In Latin America, the loans tap entrepreneurial instincts among the poorest of the poor. A recent survey of Colombian loan recipients found that 77 percent earn less than $40 a week. Two-thirds have five years or less of education, and two-thirds are peasants from Colombia's rural interior. Recipients support an average of three family members.
Gustavo Aldana is typical. In 1984, Mr. Aldana, a street vendor from Tolima, came to Bogota to collect a bad debt. He never collected the debt, never went home, and to make ends meet started making candy.
Working alone in 1988, he took out his first $50 loan through a program administered by Actuar, one of Accion's Bogota affiliates.
Today, he is handling $3,000 loans and employs six neighbors mixing, cooking and cutting $200 worth of candy a day.
At Actuar's headquarters, in Bogota's western industrial zone, Oscar Jiraldo Valencia, the agency's executive director, explained the formula for channeling credit into small businesses in Latin America.
"The Solidarity Groups are based on friendship, knowledge and trust," he said fervently, sounding like an evangelical preacher. He was referring to the core of the loan program: solidarity groups consisting of four to six self-employed people who know and trust each other well. Trust is essential because each member co-signs on each loan. If one member does not repay a loan, the other members are obliged to repay it.
A nearby wall chart showed that Actuar's goal is to increase its recipients tenfold in four years, reaching 20,000 by the end of next year. The loans start small -- invariably far less than requested -- so that participants can build a credit record.
In Ciudad Bolivar, Rosa Parra, a 42-year-old seamstress, paused from sewing a curtain to say she regretted choosing two men for her solidarity group.
"The bad ones were the men," she said, recalling that one was unable to pay his loan and that another was killed.
Today, her group consists of four women. Nationally, women account for 55 percent of the loan recipients.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Small-business loans, once nearly impossible to obtain in Colombia, are helping artisans like Luis Ibanez expand their businesses. Working from his backyard metal shop in Bogota, Mr. Ibanez has hired additional workers and is exporting banjo and guitar parts. (James Brooke/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Submarine Contract Is Voided

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
A Federal judge yesterday voided the Pentagon's award of a submarine-building contract to the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division and ordered the Navy to hold a new competition on terms more favorable to a competitor, Tenneco Inc.'s Newport News shipyard.
The ruling, by Judge Robert Doumar of the United States District Court in Norfolk, Va., gives Newport News another shot at winning the contract to build the second SSN-22 Seawolf attack submarine. 
 Electric Boat, which won the competition to build the first Seawolf several years ago, won the contract for the second submarine in May with a $615 million bid, compared with the Newport News bid of $688 million.
 
Factors Other Than Price
 Newport News filed suit soon after the contract award in May, contending that the Navy had failed to consider factors other than price in selecting Electric Boat. Newport News argued in particular that the Navy, in its request for bids, said the Pentagon would look favorably on a bidder other than Electric Boat because it would prefer to have two companies building its Seawolf fleet.
In his ruling yesterday, Judge Doumar agreed with the Newport News argument. "It is clear that Congress did not intend a pure price competition" in authorizing money for the second Seawolf, he wrote.
The Navy said that it would probably appeal the ruling. "We believe that the initial award was proper and that ultimately it will be upheld," a Navy statement said.
 
Political Maneuvering
 The battle over the Seawolf contract has involved considerable political maneuvering by elected officials from Virgina, the home of Newport News, and Connecticut, the home of Electric Boat, which is based in Groton. And it illustrates one of the most difficult problems facing Congress, the Pentagon and the military-contracting industry as the nation cuts its weapons purchases: how to spread contracts around to maintain a healthy industry and encourage competition without unduly favoring companies or paying higher prices than necessary.
Electric Boat and Newport News are the nation's only submarine builders.
In his opinion, Judge Doumar said: "A competitive acquisition strategy for the entire program, if adopted, would require establishing Newport News as a second source so that there could be competition over the life of the program. However, it is and was a foregone conclusion that Newport News could not win a competition on price alone."
Electric Boat, which relies almost solely on submarine work, had warned that it might have to begin closing down over the next few years if it did not win the Seawolf contract. Newport News, which also builds other types of ships, said that it was in no danger of going out of business, but that it would not remain a viable competitor in submarine building without the second Seawolf contract.
The Navy had originally planned to buy three or four Seawolfs a year, and to split the purchases between Newport News and Electric Boat. But the program's size has been cut sharply, so that the Navy will buy no more than one Seawolf a year, a level that many analysts think is too low to justify maintaining two producers.
 
Issue of National Security
 Beyond the economic implications of forcing one company or the other from the business, there is a potential issue of national security, Pentagon officials and industry executives said. In wartime, they said, the country could find itself short of submarine-building capacity if there is only one producer.
Concerns about the nation's industrial base have also spread to other types of weapons programs, including tank-building, where General Dynamics is the only remaining manufacturer.
Jack A. Garrow, a spokesman for Newport News, said the Tenneco division was pleased with the ruling. "We trust and expect that the new solicitation will be conducted on a level playing field, which recognizes the industrial base factor," he said.
In Groton, Electric Boat issued a statement suggesting that it would probably appeal the ruling.
"We believe that our bid, which was awarded only after a thorough and exhaustive review by the Navy, offered the best value in terms of cost and value to the American taxpayer, as well as maintenance of a critical industrial base," Electric Boat said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Networks Are Putting the Pressure on Pressure Groups

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
FOR the first time, the three leading television networks are taking a stand against pressure groups that demand that advertisers withdraw commercials from controversial programming.
In a letter scheduled to begin going out on Monday, the Network Television Association, a trade group, urges marketers and their advertising agencies "not to be intimidated" by such groups, which it calls representative of "vocal minorities with agendas inconsistent with the views of most Americans." 
 "Freedom of expression is an inalienable right of all Americans," the letter states, "vigorously supported by ABC, CBS and NBC" -- the network members of the association that was formed in April 1990. The letter, an advance copy of which was made available by the association, goes on to refer to boycotts of advertisers whose commercials run during programs cited by these groups as "attempts to manipulate our free society and democratic process."
The three-page letter, signed by Peter Chrisanthopoulos, president and chief executive of the association, will be sent to more than 7,000 executives at 600 consumer-product companies and 100 ad agencies across the country. It is the latest development in a vexing issuethat periodically roils the television industry.
Since the late 70's, organized groups claiming to represent Christian, pro-family or anti-violence points of view have been taking one-two punches at programming they deem objectionable: They write and call the networks, then identify sponsors, and also complain to them. This summer, agencies have been receiving postcards from supporters of the conservative American Family Association, warning them that consumers will boycott products advertised during programs they disdain. The letter does not identify by name any of the groups it criticizes.
Recent well-publicized incidents in which advertisers pulled out of series episodes with story lines perceived to be touchy include a 1989 telecast of the drama "Thirtysomething" showing two gay men in bed, a scene that cost ABC a reported $1.5 million in advertising revenue, and an episode this year in the NBC drama "L. A. Law" showing two women kissing briefly.
In the 1991-92 season, programs that could potentially provoke additional incidents include an episode of the NBC sitcom "Dear John," in which a character tells of his wife leaving him for another woman, and further episodes about one of the women on "L. A. Law."
"The bottom line is that network television programming is advertiser- and viewer-friendly," Mr. Chrisanthopoulos said in a telephone interview from his offices in Manhattan, "and has been for a long time." The programming the networks show "reflects our society and culture," he added. "It does not push the envelope over the edge."
Disagreeing with that view is Vicki Riley, president of Concerned Viewers for Quality Television, a group based in Wilmington, Del., that is co-sponsoring a "Turn Off TV Day" on Oct. 29 along with organizations like the American Family Association, Morality in Media and the National Christian Association.
In two weeks of monitoring television this spring, Ms. Riley said she watched or heard "nudity between gay, lesbian and heterosexual couples, talk of anal and oral sex, profanity and a complete mockery, it seems, of traditional family values." Her turn-off day, which seeks participation from advertisers as well as viewers, is "a way to get the American public to speak out to the networks," she said.
The opinions expressed in the network association's letter are "something the majority of advertisers believe in," said Bob Zach, senior vice president and media director of Chiat/Day/Mojo, New York. "Unfortunately, when a letter from a pressure group winds up on a chairman's desk, it is easy for the advertising guys to feel the heat.
"In an industry that is risk-averse," he added, "the easiest fall-back position is to avoid any decision that would seem inappropriate." As a result, Mr. Zach does not think the letter will "change anything in the way companies, especially public companies," respond to pressure.
There is no special reason for sending the letter now, Mr. Chrisanthopoulos said, neither in terms of timing -- the approach of the fall season and its related sale of commercial time -- nor of economics.

HEADLINE: Pakistani Official Rules Out Extradition in B.C.C.I. Case

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 31

 BODY:
The ailing founder of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International will not be extradited to the United States or elsewhere to face fraud and embezzlement charges, a Government official said today.
The official, Jam Sadiq Ali, the Sindh Provincial Chief Minister, was the first Pakistani official to make a statement about the issue since B.C.C.I.'s operations in several countries were seized and the bank and its Pakistani founder, Aga Hassan Abedi, were indicted on Monday by a New York grand jury. 
 The Interior Ministry, which rules on extradition requests, declined to comment. Pakistan has an extradition treaty with the United States, but so far Washington has not requested Mr. Abedi's extradition, a ministry official said.
 
West and Israel Accused
 Mr. Ali's comments reflected the widely held Pakistani belief that the Arab-owned bank was brought down because of its meteoric success. B.C.C.I. opened in 1972 and rapidly expanded to 69 countries, mostly in the developing world. Mr. Ali accused the West and Israel of engineering B.C.C.I.'s closure.
"Mr. Abedi's only crime was that he stood up and fought the disciples of the evils in the developed world," Mr. Ali said. "B.C.C.I. was a third world bank, and it took to the challenge of breaking a hegemonistic control of the Jewish lobby on the world's financial institutions."
Mr. Abedi lives in Karachi, the nation's financial hub and the provincial capital of Sindh. Mr. Ali is the highest elected official in the southern Sindh province and once received financial backing from the bank.
On Monday, a New York grand jury indicted B.C.C.I., four affiliates, Mr. Abedi and a former deputy, Swaleh Naqvi, on charges of fraud, falsifying records and stealing more than $30 million. The bank's worldwide operations were seized on July 5.
Mr. Ali said Mr. Abedi only sought to help the Islamic world acquire scientific and technological independence. "This, I suppose, was too much for the Zionists to stomach," he said.
Mr. Abedi would be willing to stand trial in any court in Pakistan, Mr. Ali said, but would not be extradited to the United States or any other country.
Mr. Ali has acknowledged getting support from B.C.C.I. while living in exile in London during martial law in Pakistan from 1977 to 1988.
"I am deeply grieved by the malicious, racist and baseless campaign against Mr. Abedi," he said. "I can say from my personal knowledge, without fear of contradiction, that he is a great benefactor of the wretched of the earth and ailing humanity in the present century."
Mr. Abedi was forced to give up control of B.C.C.I. after suffering two heart attacks in early 1988 that led to brain damage and his use of a wheelchair. He retired from B.C.C.I. in September 1989 after having a heart transplant.

HEADLINE: Gunmen Kill 6 Lithuania Border Guards

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, July 31

 BODY:
Six Lithuanian border guards were killed today and two were critically wounded in a machine-gun attack on a customs post near the breakaway republic's border with Soviet Byelorussia, officials here said.
The Lithuanian authorities said the identity of the attackers was not known. The customs stations, symbols of Lithuania's claim to independence from the Soviet Union, have been frequent targets of violent raids by Soviet troops and "black beret" police units loyal to Moscow. 
 Soviet security officials here and in Moscow denied any responsibility for today's attack and said they hoped it would not disrupt the cordial atmosphere of President Bush's Moscow summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Mr. Gorbachev, speaking at a joint news conference with Mr. Bush at the end of the their two-day meeting, said an investigation of the incident was under way, and he extended his sympathies to the families of the victims.
 
Bush's Nod to the Baltics
 Mr. Bush, who on Tuesday publicly urged Mr. Gorbachev to "find a way to extend freedom to the Baltic people," said the violence was regrettable. He expressed hopes that negotiations would bring an end to the long-running border clashes.
Also early this morning, a powerful explosion blew out most of the windows at the headquarters of a division of Soviet Interior Ministry troops in central Vilnius. Col. Aleksandr V. Malinin, a spokesman at the site, said there had been no injuries from the explosive device, detonated at the building's doorstep by unknown assailants.
There have been similar mysterious explosions at military and Communist Party buildings in Lithuania and Latvia in recent months, all without injuries. Hard-liners attribute the attacks to nationalist "terrorists," while Baltic officials say they suspect the K.G.B. or the military has set off the explosions deliberately to create a pretext for their campaign against Baltic separatists.
The border killings were the most serious eruption in the Baltic republics since Jan. 13, when a tank column of Soviet Army paratroopers and K.G.B. special troops stormed television installations here, leaving 13 civilian dead and scores wounded.
That raid, witnessed by a large contingent of foreign reporters, dealt a powerful blow to Mr. Gorbachev's reputation as a reformer. Soviet journalists and legislators have produced evidence that Mr. Gorbachev approved the attack and authorized an official cover-up.
Vytautas Landsbergis, the Lithuanian President, told reporters here that the two most likely suspects in today's violence were Soviet forces bent on intimidating the pro-independence leadership and organized criminals whose smuggling operations have been interrupted by the customs controls.
But he said Mr. Gorbachev was ultimately responsible for the recurring mayhem in the Baltics, and he criticized the United States for not pressing the Kremlin more forcefully to recognize Lithuania's independence.
"Every time the United States shows a more favorable disposition toward the Soviet Union, the Baltic states, and especially Lithuania, are struck again by Soviet armed forces," he said.
"In fact, the United States is giving in by not forcefully demanding that the Soviet Union punish those guilty for the killings in Lithuania and Latvia in January, to return the buildings seized by Soviet forces and to pull the OMON terrorists out of the Baltic states," he added, referring to the "black beret" police units.
Those killed today at Medininkai, about 25 miles southeast of Vilnius, included two customs officers, two highway patrolmen and two members of an elite Lithuanian police unit organized to provide extra security for Lithuanian government installations. A third customs officer with bullet wounds to the head was reported near death tonight at a Vilnius hospital. A fourth customs official was said to be in stable condition after surgery, but officials have still been unable to question him about the attack.
Lithuanian investigators said it appeared that the guards had been forced to lie down and then were shot execution-style. Tonight, Lithuanian television showed graphic footage of the bodies lying in the customs shack in pools of blood.
Officials said that four of the eight Lithuanian guards would have been armed, but that their guns were missing and there was no sign of an exchange of fire.
Moscow has repeatedly declared the Lithuanian customs posts illegal. Since May, the outposts along the borders with Byelorussia, Poland and Latvia have been attacked more than a dozen times, customs guards beaten and buildings burned. Witnesses to many of the incidents said the attackers wore military khakis or black berets and drove military and police vehicles.
Some Lithuanian officials and journalists speculated that today's attack may have been a response to the treaty signed on Monday between Lithuania and the President of the Russian republic, Boris N. Yeltsin. The treaty was viewed here as an important step toward recognition of Lithuanian independence. Others suggested that it was timed to embarrass Mr. Gorbachev during Mr. Bush's visit by demonstrating his inability to control tensions in the Baltics.
Last month, as Mr. Gorbachev prepared for a trip to London to seek economic aid from Western nations, black beret troops broke into the Lithuanian telephone building in Vilnius and cut off communications with the outside world for several hours.

HEADLINE: Upper West Side Journal;
A Muslim Leader Visits, And a Hotel Is Reeling

 BODY:
In a city of immigrants, the Senegalese say they have found their niche. They drive cabs, vend goods, work in offices.
What they have not found is a community; their few thousands are scattered throughout New York City. 
 But for one week the Narragansett, a modest and informal 12-floor residential hotel on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, has become an unlikely Mecca.
Cheikh Mourtada Mbacke, an aging, contemplative scion of Senegal's venerated Muslim leader and anti-colonialist, Ahmadou Bamba, has arrived on Broadway. And his people have followed.
The choice of the Narragansett Hotel, a home to many college students during the school year, was not the Cheikh's; his followers in New York picked it for him.
"We were looking for two weeks," said Mouhamadou Lamime Diagne, a trade analyst who picked up the Cheikh at the airport. The Narragansett, a mostly single-room occupancy hotel near 93d Street, "was the one we found so he will be near the community," Mr. Diagne said. Most Senegalese in New York live in Harlem.
Cheikh Mbacke's visit, lately an annual event, has become a spectacle. When he emerges from the hotel each morning, he is surrounded by a security team. They have to contend with some of the Cheikh's followers waiting outside who rush toward him, hoping to touch his clothing. "We keep telling him he should move to Central Park West," said one security officer with walkie-talkie in hand. "It's impossible to protect people here."
The 74-year-old Cheikh then climbs into a limousine and goes off in a motorcade that takes him around the city.
Inside the hotel, hundreds of visitors arrive in the course of a day -- some in bright robes, some in gaudy T-shirts, some in business suits. Many pack the elevator to see the Cheikh, who is on the eighth floor with his retinue of about 15 people, most of them older men. When visitors arrive, he retreats behind a veiled doorway to greet them.
One floor above, a room is set aside for food -- cafeteria-scale pots of rice, fish and chicken, all delivered. In the hallway, shoes accumulate in front of doorways -- as they do at entrances to mosques -- and Muslim chants resonate from a tape player.
Many of those who see the Cheikh arriving and departing are struck by the devotion of his followers. "One thing I can tell you," said Joseph Toon, the man behind the hotel's glass-enclosed reception booth, "is that his people will die for him."
Some of the hotel's long-term residents are bemused by all the commotion. David Magid, who lives a few floors from the Senegalese contingent, pointed to the elevator, already over capacity, as he waited. "This is the fifth one that has passed," he said. "If he's such a big deal, why is he staying here?"
Cheikh Mbacke represents the Muridist tradition of Islam in Senegal, in West Africa. The Murids are one of a host of mystical Islamic sects with wide followings often based around one pious family.
But even to scholars of Islam, the Murids are rather unstudied. One encyclopedia of Islam reduces its discussion of the Murids to one clause of a long sentence, saying their "collective discipline has worked wonders and has been responsible for great developments, notably in ground-nut growing."
To the Murids, their discipline has produced more than agricultural advances. Their tradition, they say, fosters common characteristics like seriousness, devotion to family and a willingness to work hard.
But the Cheikh has little practical counsel to offer his people navigating the shoals of an unknown economy.
"We do not talk about this world," said El-Hadji Gueye, a 38-year-old yellow-cab driver. "We talk about prayer and love."
The Cheikh's visit has become the focal point of a community religious effort: to found a Muridist mosque.
Most Senegalese Muslims in New York City belong to the Malcolm Shabbazz Mosque on 116th Street and Lenox Avenue. The Cheikh's arrival there on Friday was befitting a visiting dignitary: police barricades were set up, and worshipers craned their necks to see him, some rushing forward, trying to touch him.
After the service, the Cheikh held a brief news conference:
How does he like New York?
"He knows that it is a place created by God Almighty," his son, Moustapha, said, translating. "He has come to greet his people."
How are his people doing?
"He sees that his disciples are quite well-behaved as far as the teachings."
At the Narragansett, the stream of visitors never lets up. "Eighth floor," Mr. Toon often answers before he is even asked at the reception booth.
"No celebrities have stayed here before," he said. "They once filmed a Kojak episode here, though."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cheikh Mourtada Mbacke, center, arriving at the Malcolm Shabbazz Mosque in Manhattan during his visit. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

The Banking Scandal
The C.I.A. prepared a report in 1986 saying B.C.C.I. had acquired control of Washington's largest banking company in 1982, the agency said. Fed officials have said they would never have permitted it to own a U.S. bank. [Page A1.] 
 B.C.C.I. used a Saudi-born, Harvard-educated financier in Argentina as one of its leading front men in a host of acquisitions, American investigors say. [D1.]
The ailing founder of B.C.C.I. will not be extradited to the U.S. or elsewhere to face fraud charges, a Pakistani official said. [D11.]
