HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW;
BUSH AND GORBACHEV SIGN PACT TO CURTAIL NUCLEAR ARSENALS; JOIN IN CALL FOR MIDEAST TALKS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 31

 BODY:
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union signed a far-reaching treaty today that is designed to scale down their nations' stocks of long-range nuclear weapons, then joined in a bold bid to stage a comparably momentous Middle East peace conference in October.
The two leaders inscribed their names on the 700-page arms reduction treaty at a solemn 30-minute ceremony in St. Vladimir's Hall in the Kremlin. The treaty still needs approval by the legislative branches in both countries, but with the signing, after nine years of negotiation, Mr. Bush said, "We reverse a half-century of steadily growing strategic arsenals." 
 Declaring the arms race over, Mr. Gorbachev commented, "Thank God, as we say in Russian, that we stopped this."
 
6 Lithuanians Killed
 A joint statement issued by the two Presidents said they "will work to convene in October a peace conference designed to launch bilateral and multilateral negotiations." [Excerpts from the Bush-Gorbachev news conference and the text of the joint statement on the Middle East are on pages A10 and A11.]
But the politicial strains that continue to plague the Soviet Union as it tries to define a new place for itself in the world were dramatized for Mr. Bush and his aides by the news that six Lithuanian border guards had been killed in an attack on a customs post in the Baltic republic. [Page A8.]
It was the worst such incident in the Baltic republics since January, and its timing embarrassed Mr. Gorbachev, who quickly announced an investigation. "We are doing everything to avoid such excesses," he leader said, apologizing for the incident and offering sympathy to the victims' families.
 
Mideast Given Prominence
 The signing of the arms treaty, so long awaited, was all but overshadowed by the Presidents' decision to join in calling for the equally long-sought Middle East peace conference, in which Israel has not yet agreed to take part. Clearly, they hoped their announcement would prompt the Israelis and Palestinians to overcome their differences over the composition of a Palestinian delegation at the projected conference.
"This historic opportunity must not be lost," Mr. Bush said.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is to fly to Jerusalem on Thursday "to obtain Israel's answer," Mr. Bush said. By limiting the language of the statement to saying they would "work" to convene a conference, they avoided an ultimatum to Israel that would have resulted if a firm date had been announced.
Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Foreign Minister, is to follow Mr. Baker's visit a bit later, carrying papers to open full diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Israel. Moscow has said that could be done only when peace talks were agreed to.
Mr. Bush, who announced on Tuesday that he would ask Congress to approve favorable new trade terms for the Soviets, continued to press for economic reform as a condition for large-scale United States assistance.
"You must define your own branch of democratic capitalism," he told an attentive group of fledgling Soviet businessmen in a breakfast speech. "People must be free -- to work, to save, to own their own homes, to take risks, to invest in each other and, in esssence, to control their own lives."
Mr. Gorbachev, for his part, has been pressing the United States to ease restrictions on high-technology exports to the Soviet Union.
The two leaders spent much of the day at a government retreat 20 miles west of Moscow, known as Novo Ogaryevo, discussing political issues that still divide their nations. On the agenda were Cuba, the size of the Kremlin military budget and the Baltic republics' desire to be independent. There was no indication that the talks were anything but cordial, and Soviet television showed the two leaders smiling, tieless and wearing pullover sweaters.
But what made this week "a dramatic time," as Mr. Gorbachev put it, was the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start, and its symbolic termination of the race by the United States and the Soviet Union to amass weaponry with which to blow each other up.
Start will reduce the superpowers' stocks of long-range missiles and bombers by about a third. But that will take them back only to roughly the level where they stood as negotiations began in Geneva in 1982 on this, the last of the major arms-control agreements conceived in the tensions of the 1970's and 1980's.
Nonetheless, it is the first agreement ever that calls for the two nations actually to reduce their holdings of the most deadly weapons, instead of merely reducing the rate at which those holdings have expanded.
At the joint news conference concluding the two-day summit conference here, the fourth in the last two years between the two men, they were asked why they had not agreed to scrap all their nuclear missiles, as Mr. Gorbachev proposed at his meeting with President Reagan at Reykjavik, Iceland, in 1986.
Both said that would not be practical, given the nuclear weapons in other countries' hands, and Mr. Bush said he worried about "renegades."
The agreement was signed with pens made from metal taken from medium-range missiles scrapped under an accord signed four years ago. The other major arms treaty signed in recent years was the 22-nation conventional forces agreement approved last fall, which covers units across Europe.
With East-West tensions eased, the United States is reluctant to begin another round of detailed, count-every-weapon negotiations like the Start talks. Washington and Moscow are to hold talks in the fall to "take stock of where we are," said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, but he added that it was hard to say whether any initiatives would result.
 
Gorbachev More Hopeful
 But Mr. Gorbachev was more sanguine, commenting at the signing ceremony, "Come on, let us undertake new efforts for our own security and that of the whole world."
The Soviets are believed to want to negotiate limits on naval weapons, which the United States has thus far opposed, and Mr. Bush is trying to impress both the Soviets and Congress with the virtues of a scaled-down version of "Star Wars," Mr. Reagan's proposal for a space-based missile defense system. Moscow argues that it would violate an existing treaty that bans anti-missile weapons.
Even after today's treaty, which was agreed upon only two weeks ago in London, the superpowers will retain tremendous firepower, with huge numbers of weapons trained upon each other's principal cities. According to one estimate, by the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament in Britain, the treaty will leave 40,000 nuclear warheads capable of prompt usage.
Still, Mr. Gorbachev spoke in soaring terms of the Start treaty, describing it as "a moral achievement" and asserting that it marked the "dismantling of the infrastructure of fear that has ruled the world." He added, "Normal human thinking will now have to replace the kind of military-political thinking that has taken root in the minds of men."
 
No 'Unilateral Advantage'
 Mr. Bush, less triumphal, said it "represents a major step forward for our mutual security and the cause of world peace." He emphasized that "neither side won unilateral advantage over the other."
The Soviet Union will be required to cut its ballistic missile warheads by more than 35 percent, to about 7,000 warheads from about 11,000, and the United States will have to trim its ballistic missile arsenal by about 25 percent, to roughly 9,000 warheads from about 12,000. The Soviets will also have to destroy half of their heavy SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles; the United States has no weapons in that category, and under the treaty is not permitted to build any.
Complicated verification measures, including snap inspections at strategic weapons emplacements, are expected to ease the treaty's approval. Leaders in the United States Senate and the Soviet Parliament have predicted relatively little opposition.
There have been two previous strategic arms treaties between the Soviet Union and the United States. The first was signed by President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev in 1972, limiting the expansion of nuclear arsenals. A follow-up, drafted by Mr. Brezhnev and President Carter, was never approved by the Senate.

GRAPHIC: Photos: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a news conference after signing arms treaty. (Reuters) (pg. A1); President Bush attending a wreath-laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Moscow (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A11)
 
Chart: "New Arms Pact: The Highlights"
 
Goal
 To reduce strategic offensive arms by approximately 30 percent in three phases over seven years.
 
Central Limits
* 1,600 Strategic Nuclear Delivery Vehicles (deployed intercontinental ballistic missiles and submarine-launched ballistic missiles and their launchers, and heavy bombers.)
 
* 6,000 "accountable" strategic warheads on these systems:
 
 No more than 4,900 of them on ballistic missiles.
 No more than 1,100 on mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles.
 No more than 1,540 can be on SS-18's, the Soviet Union's 154 heavy intercontinental ballistic missiles.
 (To achieve these limits, the Soviet Union must eliminate half its ballistic missile warheads, half its SS-18 missiles; and decrease the aggregate throw weight of its missiles by 46 percent.)
 
Counting Rules
 
* Ballistic missile warheads will count as one warhead each under the 6,000 limit.
 
* Warheads delivered by air will count less than one:
 
 Heavy bombers with bombs and short-range missiles will count as carrying one warhed each, regardless of bombs or warheads carried.
 
 U.S. heavy bombers may carry no more than 20 long-range air-launched cruise missiles each. The first 150 count as carrying 10 each.
 
 Soviet heavy bombers may carry no more than 16 air-launched cruise missiles each. The first 180 will count as carrying 8 each.
 
Other Provisions
 
* Sea-launched cruise missiles with ranges above 373 miles will be limited to 880.
 
* Soviet Backfire bombers will be limited to 500.
 
* The treaty will run for 15 years, with the option to extend it for successive 5-year periods.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW;
Ukrainians Await Bush With Skepticism

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 31

 BODY:
On the eve of his first venture into the heated world of Soviet politics in the provinces, President Bush was denounced today by the Ukraine's leading independence movement as having been "hypnotized by Gorbachev" at the summit meeting.
The Ukrainian popular movement known as Rukh, the umbrella group for more than a dozen of the republic's opposition parties, offered Mr. Bush an advance sample of the sharp-edged politics that await him in this rich, sprawling republic, which the President will visit on Thursday on his way home from Moscow. 
 Ukrainian politicians cautioned him today to expect the six-hour visit to be no easy, folksy photo opportunity.
Ivan Drach, the Rukh chairman, said Mr. Bush was so supportive and uncritical of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that Mr. Bush would arrive here as the Soviet leader's "messenger," with no real appreciation of the suffering that the Ukrainian republic has seen under the Kremlin because of its yearning for independence.
"We must remember that as President, Bush has consistently snubbed the democratic movement" in the republic, Mr. Drach said at a news conference as officials of the United States consulate here listened in the audience.
 
Bush's Touchy Touchdown
 Forewarned, the President will be touching down in one of the nation's most important and politically fractious republics, one that accounts for a quarter of the nation's food and a third of its industrial production.
Mr. Bush will be visiting a rapidly warming caldron where the President of the Ukrainian Parliament, Leonid M. Kravchuk, has been among the fastest to rush to the head of the nationalist parade and hedge his allegiance to the Kremlin with increasingly militant demands for sovereignty.
As insurgent politics have taken hold in the Ukraine, few Communists have been so thoroughly born again as the popular Mr. Kravchuk, the son of a peasant who rose to initial power as ideology chief of the Ukrainian Communists. Mr. Kravchuk has adapted by dropping the Russian language from his public appearances and speaking only Ukrainian.
More painful for Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Kravchuk's Parliament has blocked the Soviet leader's hopes for early adoption of a treaty of national unity with the sovereignty-hungry republics.
For decades the Ukraine has seethed with the memories of Soviet economic exploitation and wholesale terror. An estimated 10 million people perished in the famine that resulted from Stalin's policies 60 years ago.
Nowadays, with politics opened up by the reforms of Mr. Gorbachev, the Ukraine seethes with outspoken ethnic groups and dozens of political parties that broadcast every variety of independence and sovereignty demands.
A year after the republic's Parliament declared its sovereignty over the laws of the national Government, the Ukraine is taking the first steps toward forming the officer corps of its own army. Officials are trying to produce the first Ukrainian currency.
Mr. Bush will find few stops free of controversy on his itinerary through this city, the third-largest in the nation, with 2.5 million people.
Some Ukrainian Jews complain that the nearby memorial at Babi Yar, the Nazi killing ground that Mr. Bush will visit during his tour, offers scant recognition that tens of thousands who died there were Jews.
The Parliament where he will speak still has a Communist majority, but it is one that recently scrambled to stay abreast of the sovereignty fever, rejecting the party's call to vote for the speedy debate sought by Mr. Gorbachev for the proposed union treaty.
Instead, the Parliament, mindful of the public's growing militancy, has refused to even consider the measure until September.
 
Miners Court Intellectuals
 With 52 million residents, the Ukraine is the nation's second-most-populous republic. Long divided politically between the Russianized and conservative eastern provinces and the Western bastions of independence, the Ukraine is busy with change: the disgruntled, underpaid coal miners of the east have began making alliances with the independent-minded intellectuals of the west.
Even Communist hard-liners are talking of independence, if only to avoid being swept up in the reshaped national union that they fear President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic will come to dominate with his increasing anti-Communist policies.
"The biggest mistake President Bush can make is if he does not pay full attention to democratic movements in republics, and supports only Gorbachev," said Aleksandr Burakovsky, chairman of Rukh's council of nationalities. Such sentiment, heard frequently, points to Mr. Bush's political problem in needing to pay credible heed to nationalist movements yet avoid seeming to be a severe critic of Mr. Gorbachev.
President Bush had best avoid any sign of stopping here as if it were a colorful outpost of Mr. Gorbachev's Soviet realm, said John P. Hewko, an American lawyer working as a consultant on the problems of reforming the center-dependent Ukrainian government into something more sovereign.
"The most important thing about the visit is that it will put the Ukraine on the map," Mr. Hewko said. "The whole world will finally be paying attention."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Trading Has a Way of Proving the Last Shall Be First and Vice Versa

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Earlier this month, Brook Jacoby started only one game and played briefly in three others in an 11-game stretch. After that, he related: "I was asked would I like to sit on the bench or would I like to be traded. It was a very easy question to answer."
Whereupon Jacoby was liberated from the lower depths of the standing and catapulted into a pennant race. The Cleveland Indians traded him to the Oakland Athletics last Friday, and he instantly gained four places and 18 1/2 games in the standing. 
 A flurry of trades late last night elevated Roger McDowell from last-place Philadelphia to first-place Los Angeles, Jim Clancy from last-place Houston to second-place Atlanta and Ron Darling from fifth-place Montreal to the Athletics. Only 16 days earlier, Darling thought he had bid farewell to the pennant race when the Mets traded him to the Expos.
In earlier trades, Jacoby's former teammate Tom Candiotti escaped last-place Cleveland for first-place Toronto; Montreal traded two of their pitchers, Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd and Tim Burke, into pennant races, Boyd to Texas, Burke to the Mets, and Garry Templeton leaped into the pennant race with the Mets, courtesy of the San Diego Padres.
Midnight last night was the deadline for trades without waivers. If any races remain a few weeks from now, someone may trade, in time for post-season eligibility, for a veteran player who has cleared waivers, the way Oakland did for Harold Baines and Willie McGee last Aug. 29. Contending teams make such trades to bolster themselves for the stretch run, but the benefits can extend beyond game-winning hits and shutouts.
"When we got Baines and McGee last year, I think it wiped everybody else out mentally," said Sandy Alderson, the Oakland general manager. "They were stunned that we were able to get the two of them."
While the team acquiring the player hopes to benefit from his addition, the player himself can benefit, too. Alderson cited Jacoby as an example, noting that in his second game with the Athletics last Sunday he went hitless and hit into two double plays.
"If he does that with Cleveland, they probably would have lost the game and it would've been negative for him," Alderson said. "But we won and it means nothing. That makes it easier for him to go out the next game. When you have people covering your mistakes, it's easier to go out and play."
Jacoby played for the Indians for seven and a half seasons. It was seldom easy to play for a team that never contended.
"I was getting ready for the game," said Jacoby, relating the way he learned of his liberation. "I was in the lineup playing first base. At about 6:30, they called me in the office and said they had made a trade. I said where. They said Oakland. I was real excited."
Jacoby was not long for Cleveland. He can be a free agent after the season. "I was just hoping I wasn't going to be left in Cleveland and finish the season there," he said. "I was hoping something would happen because it was getting kind of frustrating."
Not that he needs any help knowing how to feel now that he is with the Athletics, but Jacoby could always ask one of his new teammates about coming to a drastically different environment.
"It's definitely fun when you go somewhere that you know you have a chance to win," Baines said.
 
No Regrets Over Sanderson
 When a team makes that type of trade, though, someone goes in the other direction. Thus, Tim Teufel (for Templeton) and Glenallen Hill and Mark Whiten (for Candiotti) lament that they tumbled out of pennant races.
Then there are Mitch Webster and Jose Gonzalez. They were traded for each other recently, but they neither leaped into or fell out of a race. They went from one first-place team to another: Webster to the Dodgers and Gonzalez to the Pirates.
Even with the collapse of the Athletics' vaunted pitching staff and Scott Sanderson's success with the Yankees, Alderson said he wouldn't retain the team's 17-game winner of 1990 if he could make the decision over again.
"It's unfortunate that we couldn't have a $2.5 million pitcher holding down the fourth spot," Alderson said, alluding to the team's record $36 million payroll. "It's not economically feasible."
"I don't think he would have had the same year with us," Alderson added. "He wouldn't have had the same bullpen with us. He benefited tremendously with us last year because of our bullpen and with the Yankees this year because of theirs. This isn't a knock on Sanderson, but he's not a nine-inning pitcher. He's a six-inning pitcher."
With Oakland, Sanderson averaged six innings a start, pitched two complete games and had a 3.88 earned run average. After losing his fourth consecutive game last night, he was averaging six innings and had two complete games and a 4.40 e.r.a.
 
Sax Experiment Bought Time
 The Yankees' experiment with Steve Sax at third base earlier this season was not, it turns out, an act of desperation. It was an act of stalling. General Manager Gene Michael said that by moving Sax to third, the Yankees were simply buying time until they thought they could put Pat Kelly, their rookie second baseman, there.
"We didn't know Sax couldn't play third base, but we didn't think the chances were very good of him being successful at third," Michael said. "We said we've got to get the kid playing second base first. We couldn't ask him to come up and play third without having played third. We wanted to get him here playing his natural position, which is second. He did O.K. Quickly we moved him to third."
Michael said that he wanted to send Kelly back to Columbus for 10 days to let him play third and then bring him up again. But, he explained, Graig Nettles, the first-base coach and former third baseman, said that Kelly could play there because "he's an athlete." Brian Sabean, the player development chief, said the same thing, Michael said.
"We put him at third and he took off," the general manager said. "He is an athlete."

HEADLINE: CRITICISM LEVELED AT MEDICARE PLAN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
An independent Federal advisory committee said today that a new Medicare fee schedule would substantially cut payments to doctors and could make it harder for elderly people to gain access to health care.
In a report to Congress, the 13-member panel, the Physician Payment Review Commission, sharply criticized details of the nationwide fee schedule that the Bush Administration plans to put into effect in January of next year. 
 The panel said the fee schedule would reduce the level of Medicare fees 16 percent in the next five years, compared with what they would have been under the current payment system. The commission, created by Congress in 1986, is composed of economists and experts on health policy.
The fee schedule designed by the Administration "could pose serious risks to beneficiaries' access to care," the report says. "Medicare fee levels would be substantially lower than fees paid by private insurers, and would be lower than Medicaid rates in many states."
Medicare finances health care for 34 million elderly and disabled people. Medicaid covers 27 million low-income people.
 
Sweeping and Significant
 The new nationwide fee schedule has been described as one of the most sweeping and significant changes in Medicare since the program was created in 1965. The Department of Health and Human Services set forth its plans for the fee schedule in proposed rules that were printed in the Federal Register on June 5. A final version of the rules will be adopted in the next few months.
Gail R. Wilensky, who supervises Medicare and Medicaid as head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, had no immediate comment on the substance of the commission's report. But in response to the report she issued a statement saying, "As we prepare our final regulation, we will carefully consider the commission's comments along with other responses we have received thus far on our proposal."
Federal officials say the fee schedule would save the Government a total of at least $6.9 billion as it is put into effect from 1992 to 1996. Dr. Wilensky told Congress last month that "it was not our intention" to reduce Medicare spending in this way. But she said that "the proposed rule is based on the correct interpretation" of a 1989 law intended to overhaul Medicare's complex system of paying doctors.
The chairman of the commission, Dr. Philip R. Lee, said in an interview, "My overriding concern is that decisions made by the Administration threaten the integrity of the physician payment reform approved by Congress in 1989." But "there is ample time between now and January to resolve the problems if the Administration chooses to do so," said Dr. Lee, who is director of the Institute for Health Policy Studies at the University of California in San Francisco.
The commission's report, in effect, endorses complaints of the American Medical Association, the American Academy of Family Physicians and other groups of doctors. Many of those groups, including the A.M.A., supported the concept of the fee schedule, assuming it would make payments more fair, but they contend it has been misused by the Administration as a device for saving money. In establishing the fee schedule, the goal of Congress was not so much to reduce total spending as to redistribute the money, providing more for family doctors and general practitioners and less for some specialists, including surgeons.
 
'Physicians Being Penalyzed'
 In computing the new payment amounts, Federal officials assumed that doctors losing money under the fee schedule would increase the volume of their services to recover half the income they would lose. The advisory panel criticized the Administration for making that assumption. Doctors say there is no basis for the assumption, which was responsible for nearly two-thirds of the 16 percent cut.
"In a sense," the report says, "physicians are being penalized before they have had a chance to show how they will behave."
The commission said the Medicare rules drafted by the Administration would cause "steep and permanent fee reductions" for doctors treating Medicare patients.
"It is not credible that Congress intended substantial budget savings" when the law stipulates that spending under the fee schedule should be the same as it would have been under the old payment system, the commission said. Medicare is expected to cost $104 billion this year, of which $32 billion is for doctors' services.
The core of the new fee schedule is a computation system under which the Government, for the first time, assigns numerical values to all services performed by doctors. These values, ranging from 1 for a typical office visit to 119 for a liver transplant, take account of the complexity of the work, the amount of time required for the service, malpractice insurance costs and the doctor's office expenses.
The Government said in June it would use a monetary conversion factor of $26.87 to arrive at the price for a given service, multiplying the conversion factor by the numerical value assigned to the service.
The fee schedule will be put into effect over five years. It governs about one-third of Medicare payments to doctors in 1992.

HEADLINE: Workers on Strike Deserve Job Protection

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Strike at Your Own Risk" by Prof. David Westfall of Harvard (Op-Ed, July 16), opposing the workplace fairness bill that has been passed by the House of Representatives (news article, July 18), is loaded with misconceptions and false conclusions. The permanent replacement of strikers, although declared legal by a 1938 court decision, is anything but a "long-established practice." Indeed, it was almost unheard of before the Reagan Administration used it to crush the air traffic controllers' union in 1981. 
 Mr. Westfall states that because of the threat of permanent replacement, "unions are less likely to make unreasonable demands at the bargaining table." Doesn't he know that more than four-fifths of recent strikes were responses to the insistence by employers on cutbacks in employee health benefits or making employees pay for their own medical insurance? Whose unreasonableness caused those labor disputes?
Mr. Westfall and the Bush Administration make much of preserving worker "freedom of choice" to become scabs. But largely due to the Administration's economic policies, more than eight million Americans are out of work, have run out of unemployment benefits and have only the "freedom" to choose between starvation, welfare or taking a job on any terms an employer might offer. Sadly, many are glad for temporary work, so struck companies can keep running, even without offering scabs permanent jobs.
The article slanders the American labor movement by implying that workers don't "participate in the decision to call a strike." Unions rarely, if ever, take this difficult and painful course before the affected workers have voted to reject a last and final management offer.
 
JOHN GLASEL
President, Associated Musicians
of Greater New York
New York, July 18, 1991

HEADLINE: U.S. Has to Back Human Rights in Peru

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 14 Week in Review article "10 Die a Day, or Disappear, and Peru Goes Numb" evokes the tragedy of innocents caught in the crossfire between two brutal adversaries -- the Shining Path guerrillas and Peruvian security forces. You quote the father of Carlos Rodriguez, a slain medical student, on the bitter reality: "There is no difference between the police and the Shining Path when both are the ones who kill us." 
 But you seem to share the Bush Administration's mistaken view that applying United States human rights laws -- which preclude aid to Peru -- would make matters worse. Our assistance to Peru is conditioned on respect for human rights. You help demonstrate why Peru does not qualify for aid. Yet you suggest that if the United States enforces the law and withholds aid, Peruvians will be further alienated, and Shining Path will be the major beneficiary.
But respect for human rights is a profoundly practical policy concern. We have found in case after case that ignoring the abusive practices of our allies around the world undercuts our long-term goals. If the people of Peru have trouble distinguishing between Shining Path and the Peruvian military, we will not win over the populace by appearing to endorse the brutal tactics of one side. Indeed, we may unintentionally give momentum to the guerrilla cause.
The Bush Administration maintains that only through "engagement" with Peru's armed forces can the United States gain leverage to moderate their behavior. Last Tuesday, the Administration submitted a transparently fraudulent human rights report that claims Peru's military and police forces are not engaged in a consistent pattern of human right abuses. This shameful whitewash will clear the way for more than $30 million in military aid.
If the President fails to enforce our laws -- that is, if United States aid flows to Peru regardless of abuses -- then we lose our credibility, and any hope of leverage at the outset.
The best way to achieve our goals in Peru is to remain true to our own highest principles and to enforce our human rights laws.
 
TED WEISS
Member of Congress, 17th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, July 31, 1991
 
The writer is a member of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittees on Western Hemisphere Affairs and Human Rights.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Shipping Executive Gets A.T.&T. Post

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The American Telephone & Telegraph Company named as its new chief financial officer Alex J. Mandl, head of one of the world's largest shipping companies who also has an extensive background in applying telecommunications technology to business.
Mr. Mandl, 47 years old, has been chairman and chief executive of Sea-Land Services Inc., based in Edison, N.J. Mr. Mandl was hired through an executive search service and has no previous experience with A.T.& T. 
 In an interview, Mr. Mandl said that he would like to concentrate on "bringing some financial perspective to A.T.& T. and growing the business over all," but he declined to be more specific. "I have a few ideas, but that's really something Bob Allen and I will work out over time," he said, referring to A.T.& T.'s chairman.
Effective today, Mr. Mandl replaces Morris Tanenbaum who retired earlier this year at age 62.
CSX, the parent company of Sea-Land, replaced Mr. Mandl with John Clancey, who has been at Sea-Land for 21 years and was most recently executive vice president. CSX had revenue last year of $8.2 billion; A.T.& T.'s revenues were $37.3 billion.
Sea-Land is the largest American-flagged operator of container ships, which carry cargo by transporting it in single huge containers rather than numerous parcels.
CSX also operates the nation's third-largest rail system and is the nation's largest barge operator. Mr. Mandl had also held senior financial and planning posts with CSX.
At Sea-Land, Mr. Mandl spent more than $300 million on telecommunications and information systems. Sea-Land must coordinate and schedule ships, trucks, and freight trains through 80 terminals around much of the world.
"We can take a container from a warehouse in Hong Kong, carry it across the Pacific by ship, drop it at Long Beach, Calif., put it on a train to Chicago, then take it by truck and put it back in a warehouse," he said.
An economics graduate of Williamette University in Salem, Ore., Mr. Mandl got his master's degree in business administration from the University of California at Berkeley in 1969.
Mr. Mandl's wife, Sue Bailey-Mandl, is a psychiatrist practicing in Washington. They have three grown children.
Born in Austria, Mr. Mandl came to the United States at age 15 when his father, a professor of German literature, came to teach in the United States.

HEADLINE: Imelda Marcos Assails Manila's Terms for Return

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Calling it "unbelievable and cruel," Imelda Marcos, the widow of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, said yesterday that she would decline an offer by the Manila Government to return from exile unless she can bring her husband's remains back with her.
 The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino lifted its five-year-ban on her return Tuesday. But in doing so, it also announced that it would not permit the return of the remains of Mr. Marcos and that it would charge Mrs. Marcos in 25 criminal cases. 
Still, Mrs. Marcos left some doubt about her intentions, saying that "if my presence is imperative to go home without my husband to face trial, I will do so."
 "It will be up to the lawyers."
 Her lawyer, James Linn, said he would advise her not to return.
 "To tell you the truth, I don't think she should go back," Mr. Linn said. "She would not get a fair trial. But she's wanted this for a long time."
 Mrs. Marcos expressed her dismay at the offer at a news conference early last night outside a townhouse she rents from the Nigerian Government on East 80th Street in Manhattan.
 It recalled the commotion that surrounded her trial in Federal Court last year, on charges that she helped her husband steal more than $200 million from the Philippine treasury. Mrs. Marcos was aquitted.
 As her lawyers did at the trial, Mrs. Marcos yesterday depicted herself as "just the widow," and said she had no political ambitions.
 Prsident Marcos died while in exile in Hawaii in 1989,
 Earlier yesterday, the Aquino Government in Manila said Mrs. Marcos, who is 62 years old, would be eligible only for one-way travel documents to the Philippines and would probably be placed on a list of political figures barred from leaving the country.
 Mrs. Aquino's executive secretary, Franklin Drilon, said the Government had prepared more than 25 charges of criminal tax fraud against members of the Marcos family, including 11 cases against Mrs. Marcos. [Formal charges were filed by the country's Solicitor General, Francisco Chavez, Reuters reported from Manila.]
 The Government accused Mr. Marcos of stealing more than $10 billion through extortion and kickbacks during his 20 years as President, and keeping much of the fortune in foreign bank accounts.
 The announcement by the Aquino Government comes at a time of distress for the Philippines. Unemployment has passed 15 percent, inflation is near 20 percent, and some Filipinos feel that Mr. Marcos set the country on its economic decline.
 The conditional offer to return, they say, is a sign of the vengefulness that Mrs. Aquino's Government continues to feel toward the Marcoses.
 But many doubt that she could become a political force.
 "It definitely is already the post-Marcos era," said Jim Paredes, a Philippine songwriter now on tour in California. "It's even hard to make anti-Marcos jokes now. People are just tired of it. Imelda is already peripheral."
 Still, the possibility of a return by Mrs. Marcos, and the chance that she would seek the presidency, caused a flurry of concern among some politicians in the Philippines.
 "You cannot discount Mrs. Marcos," said Juan Ponce Enrile, an opposition leader who served as Defense Minister in both the Marcos and Aquino Governments and whose turn against Mr. Marcos early in 1986 was a major factor in his ouster.
 Mr. Enrile was later dismissed from the Cabinet by President Aquino, who suspected him of a role in coup plots against her. He is now a declared candidate for President.
 Mrs. Marcos said last night that a trial in the Philippines would focus on the same documents as the trial in the United States. But she said it would constructive if it could "terminate the Marcos issue."
 "It is the responsibility of every widow to bury her husband," she said.
 Mrs. Marcos has maintained a kind of vigil for the late President, beyond his death. His body has been preserved in a refrigerated, glass-enclosed crypt in Honolulu.

HEADLINE: B.C.C.I.'s Flashy Man in Argentina

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 31

 BODY:
After I understood the country, the people and the culture," Ghaith R. Pharaon once said after arriving in Argentina in 1981, "I realized that the future was right here, and I decided to stay."
 For a while, it seemed his perfect homeland. The Saudi-born, Harvard-educated financier arrived with an impressive bankroll backed by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, which, American investigors say, used him as one of its leading front men in a host of acquisitions. 
His penchant for flamboyance -- he regularly landed in town on his private Boeing 737 -- played skillfully to an Argentine weakness for gaudy displays of money and fast living and a wistful fascination with political power. In a country whose current President, Carlos Saul Menem, is of Arab background, Mr. Pharaon (pronounced far-OWN) seemed a welcome guest. He was often referred to as the "Arab magnate" or "the modern Pharaoh."
 
B.C.C.I. in the Shadows
 Mr. Pharaon initiated a string of investments, ranging from the opening of B.C.C.I.'s office here to a five-star Hyatt hotel in downtown Buenos Aires to a huge plantation in Salta, a northwest province. His affair with Argentina even led him to apply for citizenship in 1988.
 The Ghaith Pharaon story in Argentina is almost a paradigm of B.C.C.I. in third world countries -- the courting of top officials, the hiring of prominent economists and the weaving of a web of investments, or seeming investments, with B.C.C.I.'s presence always in the shadows.
 But as the sprawling empire of B.C.C.I. collapses amid charges of fraud, money laundering and weapons trafficking, and as regulators, governments and investigators try to sort out who came under its influence, Argentines are turning their backs on Mr. Pharaon.
 Just this week, for example, the Argentine central bank closed B.C.C.I.'s offices here. And a court investigating President Menem's in-laws yesterday ordered the seizure of B.C.C.I.'s records, raising suspicions that the bank and Mr. Pharaon might have been involved in a money laundering scheme involving drug deals.
 Almost every political figure who has come into contact with Mr. Pharaon over the years -- including President Menem and the former head of Argentina's central bank, Javier Gonzalez Fraga -- are distancing themselves from him.
 Earlier this week, the Federal Reserve Board in the United States proposed to bar Mr. Pharaon from owning or being an officer of an American banking institution.
 And his hotel, which is nearly completed, has become the brunt of jokes throughout this city, with newspapers referring to it as the "White Temple," the "Narco Hyatt" and "The Five Stars of Narco-trafficking."
 
'Really Delivered'
 Some offered a modest defense of Mr. Pharaon. They noted that he had not been indicted, that when he had begun investing in Argentina the Government did not know anything about charges of laundering drug money and that his investments represented fresh funds for the capital-starved country.
 "Over the years I have heard many promises by investors that they plan to put money into Argentina," said Alberto Kohan, former chief of staff to President Menem. "And Pharaon is one of the few who after promising really delivered. The funds were not brought in suitcases, and he abided by the laws of Argentina."
 But Mr. Pharaon's history of investment in Argentina might best be described as many promises and many plans but most likely only modest amounts of real cash.
 His two biggest projects, the Hyatt Hotel and the plantation, were financed through debt swaps, in which B.C.C.I. bought Argentine foreign debt at a huge discount and cashed it in with the central bank at a sizable profit. While the face amounts of those investments were $37.5 million and $1.2 million, respectively, it is not known how much they really cost the Saudi financier.
 Lawyers close to some suits involving Mr. Pharaon say his total Argentine investment may not exceed $10 million.
 Efforts to reach Mr. Pharaon through his hotel corporation in Argentina were unsuccessful.
 And Mr. Pharaon has not helped his own case recently.
 In April, before a judge who was questioning him about money laundering, Mr. Pharaon blurted out that while indeed B.C.C.I. had laundered money, so had other banks. "All, all of them are equally criminal," he said. "But only B.C.C.I. and the Arab banks are identified with laundering drug money. All are guilty and delinquent."
 Then, in an interview in a newspaper in Chile, where he has also been building a hotel -- but with few delays -- he dropped a not-so-gracious remark about doing business in Argentina.
 "It is clear that in Chile, as opposed to other countries, there isn't corruption," he told El Mercurio in April. "Outside, unfortunately, you cannot do business without political favors."
 
Citizenship Application
 But perhaps his biggest mistake in Argentina might have been his citizenship application. In June 1988, he filed the document and made it very clear he was still intimately involved in B.C.C.I.'s affairs and that he was a big shareholder in the bank.
 Since then, he has tried to distance himself from the bank by saying that he sold his 16 percent stake in the institution in January 1986, more than two years before the time he listed in his citizenship papers.
 Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau has that document and is likely to raise the discrepancy to challenge Mr. Pharaon's credibility, according to a lawyer here who provided Mr. Morgenthau's office with the document.
 Mr. Pharaon's most controversial investment has been the Hyatt hotel in Buenos Aires, which he has said will have suites that cost $2,500 a night. He received permission to build it in late 1988 under the Government of Raul Alfonsin, but not without a battle from some prominent citizens.
 The site of the hotel had been park of sycamore trees that were at least 100 years old just next to the city's famous wide central strip, La Avenida 9 de Julio. The night Mr. Pharaon received permission to build, the trees were cut down.
 The land also included a mansion built in the 19th century by the Alzaga Unzue family, a three-story building considered one of the great monuments to Argentina's days of glory. Although Mr. Pharaon has promised not to demolish the mansion, the hotel will dwarf it.
 The oppositon succeeded for a time, until in the final hour of the city government's 1988 legislative year, a bill was mysteriously swept through chainging the status of the land to commercial. Suddenly, Mr. Pharaon had clearance to build.
 His initial investment in the hotel immediately soared to $12 million from $3.5 million, and many wondered if someone had been paid off.
 In the process, Mr. Pharaon cozied up to as many top officials as he could. Twice he met with President Menem on the project. Mr. Pharoan also employed Mr. Gonzalez Fraga who subsequently became head of the central bank under Mr. Menem. Mr. Gonzalez Fraga has denied that he had been an assistant to Mr. Pharaon or that he was hired by the financier to work on the financing of the hotel.
 The hotel is nearly completed and officials of Mr. Pharaon's Hotel Corporation of Argentina said there was no danger of halting construction.
 
Accusations of Money Laundering
 As for B.C.C.I.'s operations in Argentina, bankers here said it never took deposits and functioned more as a financing arm for Mr. Pharaon's activities.
But the suspicions that Mr. Pharaon was engaged in money laundering continued to dog him. In mid-1989, Rogelio Garcia Lupo, a prominent journalist, published a book on the Paraguayan strongman Alfredo Stroessner and included a chapter on Mr. Pharaon's dealings there. It concluded that Mr. Pharaon was engaged in money laundering.
 That quickly generated a libel suit, which is still pending, and resulted in the declaration last April by Mr. Pharaon that B.C.C.I. and other banks had been engaged in money laundering.
 Where it ends is anyone's guess. Today, Argentina's Attorney General called for an investigation by the central bank into the financing of B.C.C.I. in Argentina. Mr. Pharaon's picture is in the newspapers daily. Several members of Argentina's opposition party in Congress are also investigating, but it will be hard for them to turn the issue into political gain since the Alfonsin Goverment gave the initial go-ahead on the hotel and the chartering of B.C.C.I.'s offices here.
 And Mr. Pharaon's love affair with Argentina has obviously cooled. Last September, he withdrew his application for citizenship, and he is now believed to be vacationing in southern France.

HEADLINE: Education Chief: at Eye of Diversity Storm

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
When he tries to explain what is wrong with New York State's social studies curriculum, Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol often uses the example of Christopher Columbus. Teaching that Columbus "discovered" America, he says, ignores the Indians who were already here.
 But the state syllabus has for many years been blending the story of Columbus with Indian history. Textbooks used by the very Scarsdale schools that Mr. Sobol headed before becoming Commissioner in 1988 spend a chapter on Indian civilizations before turning to Columbus, who gets 13 paragraphs. 
To Mr. Sobol's critics, his haste to criticize the syllabus for something it is not doing any more betrays the essentially political nature of the quest to make the curriculum reflect a broader spectrum of cultures.
 
Commissioner as Lightning Rod
 But to Mr. Sobol and his supporters, the Columbus example is nothing more than a handy way to illustrate a complex scholarly issue that he considers pivotal to the future of education and even society itself.
 The sharply divergent views of Mr. Sobol's use of a small anecdote reveal the degree to which Mr. Sobol has become a lightning rod in the fiercely emotional storm raging around multicultural education. In many ways, his conduct has become almost as large a part of the debate as the curriculum's philosophical and educational merits.
 It was largely because of his enthusiasm that the Board of Regents, the policy-making body for the state's public and private schools, voted 12 to 3 on Thursday night to let Mr. Sobol push ahead with a curriculum revision.
 But to Mr. Sobol's critics, his leadership on the issue in the months before the vote betrayed an exaggerated sensitivity to the feelings of black and Hispanic legislators who had questioned the appointment of a superintendent from overwhelmingly white Scarsdale. The result, they say, threatens to be a distortion of history that overstates ethnicity at the expense of a common European-bred heritage and democratic values.
 "He has misrepresented the curriculum as if the argument is whether we should have multiculturalism," said Kenneth Wade, who resigned in March as head of the Education Department's social studies bureau largely out of frustration with Mr. Sobol's handling of this issue. "New York has been a pioneer in multiculturalism. It's been a case of setting up a straw man and knocking him down."
 
'Really a Great Vision'
 The critics also say that Mr. Sobol has inflamed the ethnic tensions his proposal was aimed at healing. They say he has closed his eyes to remarks hostile to whites and insensitive to Jews that have been made by some advocates of revision.
 Mr. Sobol's admirers, including Dr. Walter Cooper, a regent from Rochester, say that the tensions surrounding his work reflect ethnic tensions in the larger society, although some seem to acknowledge that greater diplomacy might have been helpful. "I think he has a really great vision of where education should go," said Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association. "I think sometimes he thinks so much about that vision, he doesn't stop to think about ways to implement it that won't disrupt the entire system."
 The 59-year-old Mr. Sobol is a courtly man of slender build whose speech bears strong traces of Boston, where he grew up. He admitted that "short term, yes," his effort "may seem to have had a polarizing effect."
 
Society at a Crossroads
 "But that underneath tension has been there right along," he said. "And what we're doing is bringing it to light so we can deal with it."
 In an interview in his stately mahogany-paneled Albany office, where the peals of a grandfather clock interrupted sentences that occasionally bordered on the apocalyptic, Mr. Sobol said he had undertaken his mission with a sincere belief that American society was at a crossroads. "I think you can make a very convincing case that the future of this country is being written right now in what happens or what fails to happen to young people in the large cities," he said.
 Without a thorough education for these youngsters, he warned, we will "continue to have an underclass consigned to relatively bleak lives on their own and constituting certainly a drag on, if not a threat to, the well-being of the dominant social order." To educate them well, he said, "you have to know what they think, what they feel, where they're coming from, what they aspire to, what they resent."
 
A Revision 4 Years Ago
 Mr. Sobol, the son of a boxcar loader, conceded that he had managed to be successful without learning much about his father's Polish roots. But he said the world has changed. The diversity of America's population is no longer purely European in origin, and ethnic consciousness has replaced assimilation as the American ethic.
 What has bothered officials within Mr. Sobol's department about his position is that the social studies syllabus was revised four years ago with the aim of studying non-Western and nonwhite cultures. They wonder whether he is basing his misgivings on a curriculum remembered from childhood.
 Women and minority figures are laced throughout, to a fault, critics say. An eighth-grade Scarsdale textbook, adapted to the syllabus, gives six paragraphs to the literary movement known as the Harlem Renaissance, sketching portraits of Countee Cullen, Langston Hughes and Zora Neale Hurston. It gives no more space to Hemingway, Fitzgerald and Sinclair Lewis.
 In general, said Dr. Edmund W. Gordon, the Yale professor who was the co-chairman of the second of the two committees that reviewed the syllabus, teachers on his panel concluded that the syllabus was not adequately multicultural because it was repeatedly being flouted in the classroom.
 Mr. Sobol bristles at accusations that his motives are political, suggesting that his biggest liability now is the barrage he has taken from conservative critics. "Show me the political mileage I am gaining," he said.
 
Supports a Common Heritage
 Moreover, he said, the recommendations he last submitted to the Regents strongly affirm the teaching of a common heritage, as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo urged. Mr. Cuomo assailed the second curriculum panel, charging that "the worthy aims of multicultural education are being pushed to such extremes that the casualty is common sense."
 Mr. Sobol said he has not criticized the second panel or the more extreme points voiced because he has preferred to avoid "polarizing rhetoric" in an effort "to enlarge the area of consensus, not only for the sake of this debate but for the sake of this society."
 The debate has been haunted by strong ethnic resentments, some of which were voiced in front of Mr. Sobol.
 
'Owned the Slave Ships'
 In a November 1989 discussion, a regent, Adelaide L. Sanford, a former Queens principal who is black, told a consultant to the first committee, Dr. Diane Ravitch, who is Jewish, "some of your grandparents owned the slave ships that we came on," according to a tape and transcript of the discussion.
 Dr. Ravitch, now an Assistant United States Secretary of Education, informed Ms. Sanford that her grandparents were poor Jews in Poland who never owned slaves. Ms. Sanford replied she was "speaking ethnically." Ms. Sanford did not return several calls to her home and was said by an acquaintance to be out of the country.
 Mr. Sobol said that in recommending a curriculum overhaul, he had distanced himself from both committees. He ignored the second committee's call that schools prepare students for "promoting economic fairness and social justice" and that the curriculum help lift students' self-esteem.
 "There's enough altruism, enough folly and enough wickedness scattered right throughout the human race to cover us all, and what we need to tell kids is the full truth about history, not to make up things to make them feel good, not to engage in ethnic cheerleading," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Rebate Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company changed its incentive program for its 1991 model cars and trucks by raising the cash rebates on some vehicles. The company will now provide $2,000 rebates on its three Lincoln models, for which rebates were not previously available. The company also increased rebates in the Northeast for Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable cars, Aerostar mini-vans and Econoline vans. Rebates on the two models of the South Korean-made Ford Festiva will be lower in the Northeast than the rest of the country. The various Ford rebates will range from $500 to $2,000 depending upon the vehicle.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Decline in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday in active but uneventful dealings.
Gold prices declined slightly in the United States after rising overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current deliver settled at $363.20 an ounce, down 40 cents from Wednesday's level. The Republic National Bank said gold lost 30 cents an ounce for a late bid price of $363.40. 
 The dollar held to a narrow range, with little news to spur activity ahead of today's release of United States unemployment data for July.
Analysts expect the unemployment rate to hold steady at 7 percent, with non-farm payrolls posting a slight gain. The Labor Department report, which some say already has been discounted in the markets, is expected to underscore the belief that the recovery is slow.
Still, an increase in non-farm payrolls "will be positive for the dollar," at least in the short term, said John Marchese, chief economist at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Still, currently there "isn't enough news to make the dollar break out of its current ranges," said Andrew Busch, a trader at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Traders said there was minimal reaction to a survey of purchasing managers, which indicated that the economy grew in July for the second straight month.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 137.20 yen from 137.83 on Wednesday. Later in London, it rose to 137.65 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 137.55 yen, up from 137.36 on Wednesday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.6725, from $1.6810 late Wednesday. In New York it dropped to $1.6745, from $1.6860 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, were: 1.7570 German marks, up from 1.7440; 1.5335 Swiss francs, up from 1.5233; 5.9700 French francs, up from 5.9310; 1,312.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1498 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1513.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $363.50 an ounce, up from $363.00 late Wednesday. The markets in Zurich were closed for a national holiday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.52, to $365.44.

HEADLINE: Jordan Badly in Need of Peace Accord

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 1

 BODY:
When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrives here on Friday to seek King Hussein's renewed support for the American peace initiative for the Middle East, he will find the Jordanian King eager to improve ties with America and badly in need of a settlement with Israel.
But while the King has already accepted the American proposal in principle, Mr. Baker will also find Jordan's support limited by the suspicions of many of the nearly two million Palestinians who live in Jordan. The influence of these doubters has been enhanced by the recent democratic openings here. 
 King Hussein is personally eager for a Middle East peace settlement for a mixture of political and economic reasons, Jordanian officials and foreign diplomats here agree.
With Palestinians making up about 60 percent of the country's 3.4 million inhabitants, the King and his Government fer that without a quick peace agreement, Israel will soon be forced by the continuing influx of Soviet Jews to annex the West Bank, leaving no real prospect for the peaceful establishment of a Palestinian state.
 
Fear of a Dumping Ground
 "Jordan could become the dumping ground for millions of Palestinians from all over the world," Prime Minister Taher Masri warned Parliament this week.
In a recent interview, King Hussein described the American initiative as "the last chance for a peace future generations can live with."
A settlement would also help stabilize Jordan's internal political situation, many diplomats and officials here say, by removing an irritant that has provoked insurrection in the past.
In 1971, King Hussein sent his army to expel Palestinian Liberation Organization guerrillas from the country in a struggle that came close to civil war. And last month, the Government reported unearthing a large arms cache belonging to a Muslim fundamentalist group it accused of planning bomb attacks and assassinations.
Jordan also badly needs a peace agreement with Israel to shore up its crisis-torn economy. Peace now would allow it to reduce the military budget, which absorbs more than 30 percent of government spending. A jointly negotiated Arab settlement with Israel might also improve relations with Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf Arab countries, officials say, restoring aid that was cut off after Jordan refused to join the military coalition against Iraq.
The country is in serious need of a new infusion of foreign aid to help it absorb the more than 250,000 expatriates who have fled Iraq and Kuwait since the invasion of Kuwait a year ago. Their return to Jordan has lifted the country's unemployment rate from 16 percent of the labor force to 25 percent.
But Jordan's position as home to so many Palestinians means the King and his Government can deal with Israel only on terms acceptable to the P.L.O., diplomats say. And it remains uncertain how far the P.L.O.'s executive committee will go toward endorsing the American peace approach at talks still being held in Tunis.
In Algiers today, a member of the P.L.O. executive committee, Abdallah Hourani, was quoted as saying the organization insists on naming the Palestinian part of a proposed joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation to a peace conference and that it must include residents of East Jerusalem.
He also said that the P.L.O. wants international guarantees that a Middle East peace conference would lead to Israeli withdrawal from all occupied Arab territories as well as an end to Jewish settlements in the West Bank.
The Israeli Government rejects a P.L.O. presence in the delegation to the peace talks, sticking to its policy of refusing to talk to what it considers a terrorist group. Neither does it want to sit down with any residents of East Jerusalem, which Israel has annexed.
Faced with Israel's strong stand on principle, King Hussein and his ministers are appealing to the P.L.O. leadership to put principle aside. This week, the King said in an interview that P.L.O. leaders should now give top priority to alleviating the suffering of Palestinians in the occupied territories instead of pursuing policies for appearance's sake.
 
Commitment to Democracy
 The King has considerable power under Jordan's Constitution, but a new commitment to promote democracy is making it more difficult for him to exercise that authority against the wishes of the Palestinian majority in the country, diplomats here say.
Jordan held its first elections in over 20 years in 1989. The 80-member Parliament has adopted a skeptical approach to the American peace initiative, arguing that it is asking more from the Arabs than from Israel.
On July 18, Prime Minister Masri won a parliamentary vote of confidence in his Government, but by the relatively close vote of 47 to 31. This was seen as reflecting dissatisfaction among fundamentalists and Palestinian hard-liners with the King's interest in opening peace talks with Israel.
Three days later, during Secretary Baker's last trip to Jordan, Parliament passed a resolution rejecting "a peace conference that would enhance Israel's occupation of Palestine and bring to an end its enmity with surrounding Arab states" just as the King was agreeing to cooperate with the American plan.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-Bonwit Chairman Joining Bloomingdale's

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Less than two months after joining the swelling ranks of merchants without stores, Frank Doroff, former chairman of Bonwit Teller, is expected to join Bloomingdale's as its executive vice president and general merchandise manager.
He will become the chain's top merchant, with responsibility for women's ready-to-wear apparel and accessories, a large chunk of the Bloomingdale's business. 
 Mr. Doroff, who was at his home in Harrison, N.Y., declined to comment. But industry sources say the highly regarded retailer will begin work at Bloomingdale's, which is owned by Federated Department Stores Inc., later this year.
Mr. Doroff, who was with Federated before joining Bonwit's, was once rumored to be a possible candidate to replace Marvin S. Traub, Bloomingdale's chairman and chief executive. Michael Gould, 48 years old, has been named Mr. Traub's heir-apparent. As executive vice president, Mr. Doroff, 42, would be Mr. Gould's right-hand man.
He would step into the shoes of Russell Stravitz, who became president of Federated's Rich's/Goldsmith's chain of department stores based in Atlanta.
Mr. Doroff gained a reputation for taking innovative risks to turn stores around while he was a senior vice president for Macy's in New York and Bullock's department stores in Los Angeles, where he was president.
Two years ago he left Bullock's to become chairman of Federated/ Allied Merchandising Services, the companies' New York buying offices, after Robert Campeau, the Canadian developer who owned the department store companies, promised him the top operating post at one of the chains. But Mr. Campeau's connections with Federated were severed after the company's voluntary bankruptcy in 1990, and the promise was unfilled.
Mr. Doroff started his retailing career in Macy's executive training program in 1972, after graduating from Washington and Jefferson College with a degree in economics and then earning a master's degree from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.
Although he has spent almost 20 years in the retail business and comes from a retailing family -- his father was executive vice president of John Wanamaker Inc. in Philadelphia -- executive recruiters say his youth works against him.
When he announced his resignation from Bonwit Teller, Robert Nesbit, managing partner of Korn/Ferry International, a New York executive search company, said: "I think he would have to revert to his real forte, merchandising, rather than administration. I think he is still unproven as a president with its multifarious disciplines."
If he takes the executive vice president's job at Bloomingdale's, he will be following that advice.

HEADLINE: Banking Legislation in Doubt Before Congress Recesses

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Senate Banking Committee moved at a snail's pace today through a series of votes on amendments to a bill overhauling the nation's banking laws. The slow deliberations threw into doubt whether the panel could complete the effort before its August recess, a delay that would be a political setback for the legislation.
For the second day in a row, the committee members spent more time bickering than voting and put off debate on most of the key elements of the legislation, leaving them to further negotiations behind closed doors. 
 The postponement of the votes on scores of amendments and the complete lack of consensus on many major issues appeared to make it unlikely that the lawmakers would be able to meet a deadline imposed by the committee's chairman, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, to complete work on the measure by the end of this week, when Congress goes into recess until after Labor Day.
The deadline was imposed because of the prevailing political view on Capitol Hill that chances of passing a broad banking overhaul diminish as the lawmakers face their final stretch of the term this fall with a full plate of other pressing issues.
The banking legislation, which was proposed by Senator Riegle, would permit banks to open new branches across state lines and also allow investment banks and commercial banks to merge. But it rejects the Administration's recommendation to permit industrial enterprises to own banks.
"The legislative window is closing on us," Mr. Riegle said at the outset today.
To be adopted, any measure that passes the committee would face a debate on the Senate floor and must be reconciled with action decided upon by the House. The House Banking Committee has already adopted a measure that more closely resembles the Administration's proposal. But it still faces serious obstacles in the House Energy and Commerce Committee, whose chairman, John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, has raised objections to most of it.
 
New Auditing Measure
 The committee approved a measure by 15 to 6 that would require bank auditors of the 2,000 largest institutions to report directly to regulators on the adequacy of management and soundness of the banks that they audit.
The proposal, which had been recommended by the General Accounting Office after it found serious accounting lapses in many institutions that have failed, was sponsored by Senator Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado.
The committee rejected an attempt to take out a provision in the legislation intended to limit the Federal Reserve from lending money to weak banks that ultimately fail. Such loans are fully collateralized by bank assets. But some lawmakers and critics of the Fed have asserted that the loans make bank collapses more costly by allowing the banks to stay afloat long enough for the largest customers to transfer their deposits.
The legislation seeks to discourage such loans, made through the discount window of the Fed, by requiring the loans to be uncollateralized.
Since earnings of the central bank are returned to the Treasury, opponents of the legislation have said the proposal giving the Fed the authority to decide to lend money without collateral would commit taxpayer funds for bailing out institutions.
 
Termed a Fundamental Change
 "We are voting here today on whether to fundamentally change the way the Fed operates," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, who sponsored the amendment to delete the provision. "If we enact the provision, we guarantee that the first person to lose money is not the insurance fund but the American taxpayer."
But Senator Riegle and other Democrats said Fed lending had already contributed to the taxpayer costs of the bailout of the nation's savings associations. Mr. Gramm's amendment failed 12 to 9, with the votes cast along party lines.
The banking measure approved by the House Banking Committee would continue to permit the central bank to make short-term loans that are fully collaterized to weak banks. It is supported by the Fed.
By voice vote, the committee adopted a measure by Senator Alan J. Dixon, Democrat of Illinois, that would set up a three-year pilot-project of pricing bank deposit insurance based upon a bank's financial health. Now all banks pay a flat rate of 23 cents for every $100 in deposits. The project, which would involve 50 banks with more than $1 billion in assets, would for the first time also involve the participation of private insurers to help set rates.
A similar measure has passed the House Banking Committee, but it does not rely on private insurers.
Like its counterpart committee in the House, the Senate committee also adopted a measure to provide $180 million in Federal loan guarantees to help bail out the failure last January of the private insurer of credit unions in Rhode Island. The measure, sponsored by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, was adopted by voice vote.

HEADLINE: U.S. Judge Blocks Bridgeport From Bankruptcy Court

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Connecticut succeeded today in blocking the City of Bridgeport from bankruptcy court when a Federal judge ruled that the city, despite its financial troubles, was able to pay its bills.
Declaring that Bridgeport was not insolvent, the judge, Alan H. W. Shiff of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Bridgeport, said the state's largest city "has no choice but to continue with the budget and collective-bargaining processes." 
 Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said the ruling protected the state's commitment to help all of its distressed cities with its "full faith and credit," which would have been jeopardized had Bridgeport won and become the nation's first major city to enter bankruptcy court.
He spoke, however, at a news conference at the Capitol dominated by the threat of state offices shutting down next week because Connecticut does not have a state budget.
Judge Shiff's ruling, in any case, was strongly sympathetic to Bridgeport's financial problems and left open the door to bankruptcy court if the city's finances worsened. The city's lead lawyer, Richard D. Zeisler, said the opinion carried a strong message.
 
Need to 'Find a Solution'
 "The unions, the city and the state better get to the table in good faith and try to find a solution," said Mr. Zeisler, a partner in the Bridgeport law firm of Zeisler & Zeisler.
Bridgeport filed for bankruptcy protection on June 6, the day before a state financial review board was to set a budget requiring an 18 percent property-tax increase.
The city's Mayor, Mary C. Moran, said she hoped to avoid the tax increase by using bankruptcy court to reorganize the city bureaucracy and break "onerous and economically burdensome" union contracts. She pledged to continue paying the city's bills and bond payments.
The state board, which had ordered Bridgeport not to seek bankruptcy protection, responded by instructing State Attorney General Richard Blumenthal to block the bankruptcy bid.
The case attracted national attention as Bridgeport portrayed itself as a city abandoned by industry, left to bear alone the poverty and social problems of Fairfield County that its suburbs turned their backs on.
Judge Shiff, in ruling that Bridgeport was not eligible for bankruptcy court because it could still pay its bills, nevertheless was sympathetic to its problems and ruled against the state on important points.
In an opinion issued in July, the city won a major point when Judge Shiff ruled that Bridgeport did have authority to file a bankruptcy petition and that the state board, the Bridgeport Financial Review Board, lacked authority to bar it from doing so.
In his opinion today, Judge Shiff recalled that earlier ruling in saying that Bridgeport could return to court when it could show it would run out of money soon.
The judge also wrote that the city had "demonstrated that its ability to provide even minimal services to its residents is strained, and that its financial condition might get worse if drastic steps are not taken soon."
But, he wrote, "the flaw in Bridgeport's argument is that financial difficulties short of insolvency are not a basis" for relief under Chapter 9 of the bankruptcy code.
 
Ability to Pay Debts
 "I agree with Bridgeport that a city should not have to wait until it runs out of money in order to qualify for bankruptcy protection," Judge Shiff wrote. "It must, however, demonstrate, as a condition precedent to filing, that in the near future it will run out of money and be unable to pay its debts as they become due."
The state's victory rested on its argument that Bridgeport had a $27.9 million cash reserve as it filed for bankruptcy protection, enough to operate at a $16 million deficit through the current fiscal year and still begin the next one with cash to pay its bills.
The city argued unsuccessfully that the reserve fund had to be repaid at the end of the fiscal year, and so it would be unable to pay its bills sometime in the following year.
Judge Shiff said Bridgeport was projecting too far ahead to be reliable, given the factors that could affect its financial condition, from the health of the economy to the level of state and Federal aid to labor-union concessions and a more efficient bureaucracy.
 
'Unwarranted Intrusion'
 "I conclude that to be found insolvent a city must prove that it will be unable to pay its debts as they become due in its current fiscal year or, based on an adopted budget, in its next fiscal year," he wrote.
"In the absence of that proof," he continued, "it would be an unwarranted intrusion into the political and collective-bargaining processes for a bankruptcy court to become involved in the resolution of that city's economic problems."
James Spiotto, a municipal bankruptcy expert and partner in the Chicago law firm of Chapman & Cutler, said the opinion, broke no new ground but offered a well-reasoned reminder of the purpose of Chapter 9, which was enacted during the Depression to aid troubled municipalities.
"Chapter 9 is intended to be the remedy of last resort," Mr. Spiotto said. "It is the hope that everyone addresses the problems and resolves them before you ever get there. For any large municipality, the filing of Chapter 9 creates a real trauma."
Today's ruling, however, left unclear what happens next. Bridgeport remains under orders from the financial review board to balance its $319 million budget.
Mayor Moran, at a news conference, pledged to "not raise your taxes as a result of this court's decision." She added, "The city will continue to provide the essential services necessary for the recovery of our city."
 
'Final Opportunity'
 She said she would appeal to Governor Weicker again for assistance and resume discussions with the review board and the city's unions.
"As the court has recognized," she said, "the city, the state and the unions must now use this final opportunity to cooperatively resurrect Bridgeport.
City officials and their lawyers plan to meet to decide whether to appeal the ruling in Federal District Court.
In Hartford, Attorney General Blumenthal said he and the head of the review board, William J. Cibes, the Governor's budget director, would begin studying their next step. He said the city had many ways to balance its budget without raising taxes, by, for example, renegotiating tax abatements, collecting a higher percentage of its taxes or cutting more services.
Douglas Cutler, an under secretary at the Office of Policy and Management, which Mr. Cibes heads, said one effect of the bankruptcy ruling was to "lift a cloud" from high-level discussions that have been held among state commissioners, city officials and Bridgeport business executives on how to help the city's economy.

Moran after the decision. She had said she hoped to avoid a tax increase by using bankruptcy court to reorganize the city's bureaucracy and break "economically burdensome" union contracts.
