HEADLINE: U.S. Effort On B.C.C.I. Is Assailed

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
William von Raab, the former Commissioner of Customs, today accused the Bush Administration of dragging its feet on an investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and of barring him from sensitive information about the scandal-riddled bank when he pushed for stronger action.
The Treasury Department, under which Mr. von Rabb served as Customs Commissioner, immediately replied that the commissioner was, indeed, kept away from sensitive information for fear he would disclose it. 
 This exchange marked another chapter in a long-running feud between Mr. von Rabb and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Still, it also underscored the political tensions involved in the hearings on B.C.C.I. conducted today by the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on terrorism, narcotics and international operations.
 
Big Point of Contention
 The question of whether the Treasury Department, the Justice Department and the Federal Reserve Board ignored warnings that B.C.C.I. was engaged in criminal activities and was the secret owner of First American Bankshares Inc., a company with strong political connections, has emerged in recent days as a big point of contention between the Administration and critics in Congress and elsewhere.
Senator John F. Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat and subcommittee chairman, has been criticizing the Government and pressing for answers as to why the Government knew so much about B.C.C.I.'s potentially criminal tendencies, yet appeared to have ignored the evidence. Mr. von Rabb was one of several witnesses during a day of accusation and official denial that produced the following accounts:
*Officials of the Federal Reserve said the bank was never informed that the Central Intelligence Agency knew at least five years ago that B.C.C.I. illegally controlled First American Bankshares, Washington's largest banking company.
*The State Department said it learned in 1986 through the intelligence community that the organization of a leading terrorist, Abu Nidal, used a B.C.C.I. branch in Europe for commercial transactions. In his written testimony, A. Peter Burleigh, the department's coordinator for counterterrorism, said that information was used to disrupt Abu Nidal's commercial activities in an international effort. A number of countries, including East Germany and Poland under Communist governments, were approached as part of the effort with requests that they close down businesses in their countries that were working with Abu Nidal.
*Jack Blum, a former investigator for the subcommittee, testified that he had been told by a former bank official that B.C.C.I. worked with "about 3,000 high-net-worth criminal clients," and that the rest of the bank's apparently legitimate banking activity was set up to shroud its business with those clients.
*According to an affidavit introduced at the hearing, a former B.C.C.I. official who had been subpoened in 1988 to testify before the subcommittee told an undercover Customs agent that he had been advised by Clark M. Clifford, who represented B.C.C.I., to get transferred to Paris to slow down Senator Kerry's investigation. Robert S. Bennett, a lawyer for Mr. Clifford, the chairman of First American, did not return a call for comment last night.
 
Reports of Weapons Deals
 The hearing also brought out a number of allegations about the bank's involvement in illicit activities and weapons deals. These included statements that B.C.C.I. had been involved in financing a shipment of Scud missles to Syria and had assisted Pakistan in its efforts to obtain triggers for nuclear weapons.
In his statements, Mr. von Raab said that he had been "eased out" of responsibility for a 1988 Customs investigation of money-laundering at B.C.C.I. in Florida, and that sensitive documents had been kept from him by order of officials with the Treasury Department just as the inquiry was reaching its peak.
"I was told I was not to have information from the B.C.C.I. case," Mr. von Raab said, "They felt I was overzealous in my drug enforcement efforts, and they were uncomfortable with the way I worked with Congress and the press to push cases."
He asserted this as part of his contention that the Government had been "lackadaisical" in its prosecution of criminal cases against the bank, which was indicted in 1988 for money-laundering at a Tampa, Fla., branch office. The bank pleaded guilty in 1990 and forfeited $14 million.
 
Plea-Bargain Agreement
 More important, the plea-bargain arrangement included an agreement that the Justice Department could not prosecute B.C.C.I. for any illegal activities that the Government was aware of at the time. The deal formally entered in the Federal District Court in Tampa in 1990.
At the time, the Justice Department had possession of tape recordings, made by undercover Federal agents, in which B.C.C.I. officials openly claimed to control First American Bank and could rely on the influence of its chairman, Mr. Clifford, a prominent Washington lawyer and Democratic presidential adviser.
Mr. von Raab's criticism was a footnote to a long history of clashes with Mr. Brady and criticism of the Administration's drug enforcement efforts. Upon leaving his job in 1989, Mr. von Raab wrote an emotional letter to President Bush, warning him that that the Treasury Department, the State Department and the Justice Department did not have the zeal to fight a war on drugs.
But today, the Treasury Department replied with unusual bluntness. Desiree Tucker-Sorini, a spokeswoman for the department, confirmed that Mr. von Raab had been precluded from seeing classified information in the B.C.C.I. investigation after a Federal prosecutor in the case complained that there had been leaks of sensitive documents that could jeapordize the case.
 
Limited Distribution
 "The decision was made at that point to limit the classified information to the very pure definition of who needs to know," Ms. Tucker-Sorini said. "From then on, there was a limited distribution solely to the people investigating the case. No information was withheld from the people working on the cases."
In response to the former Customs Commissioner's criticism that Federal prosecutors had allowed B.C.C.I. to escape serious penalties, Doug Tillett, a Justice Department spokesman, said that Mr. von Raab never made his objections known, and that the deal had been supported by others who brought the case against the bank in Tampa.
 But Mr. von Raab said much of the support developed as a result of the team of Washington lawyers, lobbyists and public relations firms hired by B.C.C.I. during its legal troubles. He said that after the bank was indicted for money-laundering, it was able to plead guilty and forfeit only $14 million -- relatively modest for a global bank with $20 billion in assets -- partly because of the "influence team working up and down the Eastern seaboard" on behalf of the bank.
That team, he said, included Mr. Clifford and Patton, Boggs & Blow, a Washington law firm with close ties to the Democratic Party, as well as Hill & Knowlton, the public relations firm headed by Robert Gray and Frank Mankiewicz, both of whom had successful political careers before entering the public relations business.
Robert S. Mueller 3d, who has headed the department's criminal division since last September, said none of the bank's lawyers had ever approached senior officials with the Justice Department on behalf of B.C.C.I. or First American. Mr. Mueller's predecessor, Edward S. G. Dennis, said in an interview that he could recall no contact with the bank's representatives.
Mr. Mankiewicz, the vice chairman of Hill & Knowlton, also disputed Mr. von Raab's testimony, calling it "incredibly irresponsible and false." In a statement, Mr. Mankiewicz said no one at his firm, including Mr. Gray, had ever contacted anyone in the Administration or in Congress about B.C.C.I.

Peruvian Official Resigns
 LIMA, Peru, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- A Peruvian representative at the World Bank, a former official of Peru's central bank who also once worked for the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, resigned today.
"Mr. Brian Jensen, who worked in B.C.C.I., has been in the post of alternative assistant in the World Bank," Peru's Economy Minister, Carlos Bolona, said at a news conference at the Government palace. "Mr. Jensen is definitely no longer in this post."
Mr. Bolona said Jensen's relationship to B.C.C.I. "was the factor that determined his resignation." He did not say, however, that Mr. Jensen had been accused of any wrongdoing in connection with B.C.C.I.
"We are trying to determine responsibilities," Mr. Bolona said.
Mr. Jensen, who is also a former official of Peru's central bank, could not be reached for comment.
Peru's Attorney General has opened an investigation into possible wrongdoing by former central bank officials in connection with B.C.C.I., which was seized by regulators in several countries last month amid allegations of widespread fraud. Earlier this week, the Manhattan district attorney's office accused two former Peruvian central bank officials of accepting bribes from B.C.C.I. in return for deposits.
Peru's President, Alberto Fujimori, has said his Government would take strong action if it found crimes had been committed in connection with B.C.C.I.
Mr. Jensen was general manager of Peru's central bank in 1984 when the bank approved the opening of a B.C.C.I. branch in Lima. The branch never opened, however. Mr. Jensen was employed by B.C.C.I. when Peru placed the reserves in the bank in 1986, during the administration of former President Alan Garcia.
Juan Candela, who was central bank chief at the time the decision was made to deposit the reserves, said, "I do not know of any action that Mr. Jensen may have made on behalf of Peru."
Mr. Candela said he was not aware of any bribes or commissions in connection with the deposits. He said the decision to place the reserves with B.C.C.I. was made after the bank offered Peru a $60 million credit line on the condition that Peru place $200 million dollars in the bank.
"There were very few banks that were willing to lend money to Peru at that time," Mr. Candela said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Holding the Edge In Paper Business

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
THESE are not the best of times for paper companies. The recession has left them with sinking profits, sagging demand and eroding prices for a number of products.
For example, the price of market pulp, the material from which paper is manufactured, has plunged 35 percent in two years, while prices of coated paper -- the slick paper used in magazines and advertising supplements -- are down 10 percent in that period. Even bleached board, the profitable paper used for frozen-food containers and packaging for cosmetics, has languished. 
 But the International Paper Company has gone against the grain. In this difficult economic environment, the company, the world's largest paper producer, has outperformed its competition. While profits for the industry dropped 38 percent last year, International Paper earnings fell by only 16 percent.
Fortified by acquisitions of paper companies in Europe and specialty paper-related companies in the United States, International Paper has managed to post earnings that, while lower than those in year-earlier periods, have been the envy of the industry.
Now, though, some question if this will last. Recently, International Paper announced that second-quarter earnings dropped 44 percent from the period last year. While many analysts predict that the industry on average will see an earnings drop of about 50 percent -- some companies are expected to report losses -- the recent earnings suggest that the gap between International Paper and its competitors is narrowing.
Indeed, the features that analysts credit with keeping International Paper's financial performance above the competition are the same ones that are now the source of their concerns.
For one, International Paper expanded in Europe in the last few years with acquisitions of paper producers. The company has also acquired domestic paper-distibution companies, stable businesses that, while generating low margins, are not capital intensive. In addition, the company has acquired profitable makers of photographic plates and chemicals.
And while other domestic paper producers were spending huge sums adding capacity, International Paper concentrated on acquisitions and spent little on machinery.
But the recent strengthening of the dollar and the signs of weakness in Europe have caused some analysts to question how well International Paper will fare in the coming quarters compared with competitors.
"Over the last two years they have done all the right things to shield their earnings decline," said Sherman Chao, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. "But growth in Europe is now slowing and the likelihood that the domestic economic recovery will be gradual suggests that we will have little price recovery in the paper industry."
Officials at International Paper suggest that the second-quarter drop represents the bottom of the cycle and that the company will continue to outperform the competition, particularly those companies with a similarly broad-based mix of products like Boise Cascade, Georgia Pacific and Westvaco.
"Many analysts look at the economic situation in Europe and suggest that we will be adversely affected because of softness there," said Robert C. Butler, chief financial officer for International Paper. "But there are more factors than our geographic diversity that will enable us to outperform our competitors."
Mr. Butler said the company's specialty and distribution businesses, which account for about a third of sales and include nonwoven fabric products, imaging products and chemical operations, "don't have cyclicial swings in earnings."
Also, he added, "In most of the commodity grades, we are a low-cost producer if not the low-cost producer."
Mr. Chao predicts that International Paper's earnings will fall to $3.90 a share for all of this year, down sharply from $6.47 in 1990. But he forecasts that earnings will rebound, to $4.50 a share next year, as the economy improves.
Some analysts have been more optimistic. "The industry consensus is that their earnings will be about $4.30 for this year," said Robert E. Hanss, an analyst with Edward D. Jones & Company. "Even with their exposure in Europe and the economic problems in the industry, we still expect International Paper to be heads and tails above the others in the industry."
Investors apparently agree. the stock, which was at $53 at the beginning of the year, closed yesterday at $68.625, off 87.5 cents for the day.

HEADLINE: Public Works Aging Fast, Report Says

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City's antiquated sewers, water mains, roads and bridges are falling apart faster than the city is fixing them, according to a new engineering study that is the first to measure both the aging of the system and the current pace of repairs.
It paints a grim picture of New York circa 2030 in which pipes are bursting like cheap balloons and citizens are struggling without running water for days on end; in which roads and bridges are being closed for fear of collapse, and every corner of the city is immobilized in epic traffic jams. 
 The study also proposes a solution: money.
"The good news is that it is all manageable and fixable if we put a long-term plan into place now that spreads the cost over many years," said Samuel I. Schwartz, an engineering professor at the Cooper Union Infrastructure Institute and a former deputy transportation commissioner for the city.
He said his study is the first to assess the age of the city's water distribution, waste management and transportation systems and to provide a time frame for when these systems will reach the end of their life cycle.
 
A Worst-Case Scenario? <EH>
 City officials acknowledged yesterday that the system is deteriorating, but said it is not useful to predict conditions so many years in advance. Current repair plans will change, they said, according to need and economic conditions.
Ian Michaels, a spokesman for the city's Environmental Protection Department said that while the agency is reviewing the study, the findings appear to paint a worst-case scenario. "We realize full well that these aging water mains will have to be replaced and they will in fact be replaced," Mr. Michaels said. "The city would certainly not allow conditions to deteriorate to the point where an entire neighborhood would not have water for several days."
Joseph DePlasco, a spokesman for the Department of Transportation, said: "I think the report is a good first step and it's important that private groups are looking at the city's infrastructure and analyzing what it will cost us to return it to a state of good repair."
The Cooper Union study found that most of the city's water mains, sewers, bridges and streets were constructed starting in the 1890's and that these public works, which have an average life span of about 100 years, will reach maturity within the next 30 to 40 years. By the year 2020, more than one-quarter of all the city's mains will be 100 years old and by 2040 the percentage will rise to 40 percent.
By the year 2030, the study says New York City is expected to have more than 1,600 water main breaks annually, given the current rate of repair. That compares with 601 water main breaks in 1990.
"We cannot afford to wait for the day when all the mains start breaking and sewers collapsing," Mr. Schwartz said. "By then it will be too expensive and too late, and virtually nothing we can do about it." To reverse the trend, Mr. Schwartz said that a long-term plan must be formulated to spread the cost of repairing the city's infrastructure over time and to insure that financing for such a rebuilding program is not cut in hard economic times.
The Cooper Union report contrasts sharply with the upbeat assessment of the city's infrastructure that was provided by the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, in which Mr. Schwartz served as deputy transportation commissioner. In 1989, Koch administration officials said that there was "a misunderstanding about the state of the city's infrastructure" and that the city's public works were rebounding.
Mr. Schwartz said that such an assessment was "probably a lot rosier than it should have been" and was made in the wake of an election campaign.
The study found that the city's current replacement cycle for water mains is 150 years, and for sewers it is 255, while the useful life of both is estimated at 100 years. The researchers said that it is important to replace water mains and sewers before they reach the end of their life cycle because many of them were not designed to withstand the stresses caused by subways, heavy traffic, and construction and are particularly susceptible to breakage.
The study noted that the city's street repair policy has shifted to repaving and away from reconstruction, in which sewers and water mains are replaced. Streets like Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, which has water mains that are 120 years old, are likely to suffer major breaks, the report said.
Clark Wieman, chief researcher for the Cooper Union study, said that deferring maintenance and repairs on the city's infrastructure will be more costly for the city in the long term. For example, he said that if the city reconstructed sewers at the end of their useful lives instead of replacing collapsed sewers, it would save nearly $150 million on sewer reconstruction over the next 10 years. He estimated that the city could save $250 million a year by adopting a preventive maintenance program for all the city's bridges.
The study was based on data provided by city agencies, municipal employees, and studies performed by the United States Army Corps of Engineers.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Seeking Fairer Health Coverage

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
MOST business executives, Government officials and union spokesmen deplore the failure of the health-care system to serve the growing numbers of Americans who do not have medical insurance. For one thing, with at least 33 million people uninsured, their largely unpaid hospital and doctor bills are often passed along in higher costs to employers and others who pay for health care.
Companies that have good health plans pay for the care of 16 million employees' spouses, for example, who have jobs with other employers that do not provide coverage. And millions of Americans are covered only for big-ticket emergencies. 
 The inadequacies of health coverage are a growing national concern, as shown in recent opinion surveys. But the political problem is to make the system more equitable without upsetting the many influential participants -- doctors, hospitals, insurers and employers -- that have blocked previous proposals for change. And, of course, there is the thorny problem of how to pay for expanded care.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, disclosed cost estimates last week for a health-care bill that he is co-sponsoring with George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate Democratic leader. Economists who developed the plan said at a Senate Labor Committee hearing that it would add $18 billion, or about 2.4 percent, to the $756 billion in current health-care spending, as more people gain access to the system. The economists contended that such an increase would not undermine employment or hurt American competitiveness overseas.
The Kennedy-Mitchell bill would expand coverage for the poor, replacing the existing Federal-state Medicaid program. Physicians' fees would be raised to attract doctors who currently shun these patients. John Sheils, a vice president with Lewin/ ICF, a Washington-based consulting firm, said state and local government health-care spending could drop by at least $7 billion as Federal responsibility grows.
The Democratic proposal would probably add $28 billion to $30 billion to Federal spending, according to Mr. Sheils and Karen Davis, chairman of the department of health policy and management at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health. The Congressional Budget Office is preparing its own estimate.
Under the plan, all employers would either have to provide basic benefits or pay a 7 percent payroll tax to help finance a public program. To attract support from groups that fought previous health-care plans, the burden would be relatively light for small businesses with only a couple of low-paid employees: only $105 a month, for example, for an $18,000 annual payroll. And Mr. Sheils said that large employers might save $12 billion, as hospitals and doctors stopped shifting to them the costs for people who do not pay.
He added that small businesses already typically spend 7 percent of their payroll on health benefits, when they can afford them. Large employers spend 4 percent to 5 percent for basic coverage and perhaps 2 percentage points more for extras that, not incidentally, add to health-care inflation.
The Mitchell bill would supersede state laws that specify types of coverage like chiropractic and dental care. It would retain coverage of prenatal and well-baby care, pap smears, mammograms and mental health services. Companies with narrow profit margins could get tax credits to reduce their health costs.
Trying to rein in the runaway costs and utilization of care that are expected to add at least 12 percent to national health expenditures this year, the bill would create a Presidential commission to set spending targets. And to encourage local price competition, hospital fees would be published. Measures that restrict health maintenance organizations in some states would be outlawed.
If hospitals and doctors were unable to agree with the commission on the spending targets, as seems likely, the targets would be published anyway to guide Federal and private insurers. Ms. Davis notes that Medicare, the Federal program for the elderly, is already trying spending targets for physicians. And because the Medicare spending exceeded the target percentage increase last year by 1.5 percentage points, the Department of Health and Human Services has reduced its request to Congress for Medicare fee increases for 1992 by an equal amount.
Sharon Canner, an assistant vice president with the National Association of Manufacturers, called the Mitchell-Kennedy bill "a good first step" that is "forcing some of the discussion." But Ms. Canner noted that the Bush Administration had yet to address it. She said she did not expect a new health-care law to be enacted until after the 1992 Presidential election campaign.
Stephen H. Long, an economist in Washington with the Rand research group, said that "desperation" with the health-care system's shortcomings "seems to be deeper and wider than it's been for a lot of years." But he added that it was still "not very clear what is going to handle the cost-control problem."

HEADLINE: Jackson Organizing March From Bridgeport to Hartford

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson plans to lead a march through Connecticut from Aug. 11 to 17 to draw attention to the social impact of the budget crises in the state Capitol and in Bridgeport.
Mr. Jackson said he intended to walk at least 55 miles from Bridgeport, which yesterday lost its bid for bankruptcy protection, to Hartford, where the failure to pass a state budget caused a partial shutdown in state services in July. 
 "I'm urging people to mass mobilization," Mr. Jackson said yesterday, adding he would demand "attention for distressed municipalities and human needs."
Mr. Jackson wants the Connecticut General Assembly to "define what the human needs would cost" and "what it would cost not to address them." He listed unemployment, health care, education and housing as some of the issues cities face.
The National Rainbow Coalition is organizing the march.

HEADLINE: After the Summit;
Bush, in Ukraine, Walks Fine Line on Sovereignty

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, U.S.S.R., Aug. 1

 BODY:
Walking a fine line in the struggle for self-rule that is bedeviling Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Bush warned today of the excesses of "suicidal nationalism," but said the United States would not choose sides between the Government in Moscow and restless Soviet republics.
Still Mr. Bush spent much of his day here praising Mr. Gorbachev and his vision of the Soviet Union. 
 Descending from the summit diplomacy of Moscow to the grass-roots fervor of the Ukraine, the President said he would reject the "false choice" being pressed on him by some separatists -- either supporting Mr. Gorbachev or the independence leaders of the Soviet republics.
"We will not try to pick winners and losers in political competitions between republics, or between republics and the center," the President said, stopping here for a six-hour visit after finishing his two-day meeting in Moscow with Mr. Gorbachev.
"That is your business, and not the business of the United States of America," he said to the Ukrainian Parliament in a speech that included the caution that democratic unity is urgently needed if the Soviet Union is to resurrect its economic and political life.
 
Endorsement of Gorbachev
 "Americans will not support those who seek independence in order to replace a far-off tyranny with a local despotism," he said. "They will not aid those who promote a suicidal nationalism based upon ethnic hatred." [Excerpts, page A8.]
But for all his proclaimed neutrality in the nation's sovereignty struggle, Mr. Bush made a point of strongly endorsing the program of Mr. Gorbachev in liberalizing the country. The Soviet leader was the object of complaint and some derision among the street crowds, but Mr. Bush stood fast.
"In fairness, President Gorbachev has achieved astonishing things," he said in his Parliament speech. And later in the day, he even linked Mr. Gorbachev with Lincoln as a man who believed that history should be studied for its truth and not "to settle political scores."
"We will maintain the strongest possible relationship with the Soviet Government of President Gorbachev," Mr. Bush declared. "But we also appreciate the new realities of life in the U.S.S.R. and therefore as a federation ourselves we want good relations -- improved relations -- with the republics."
The President got a kaleidoscopic if brief look at Kiev during his visit, moving out quickly from the airport, where the welcoming committee included some Ukrainians in embroidered belted blouses that billowed in the stiff wind of a cloudy day. He was not the first American President to visit Kiev; Richard M. Nixon was here in May 1972.
 
Visit to Babi Yar
 Beyond addressing Parliament, the principal event for Mr. Bush was a visit to the Babi Yar memorial. This sculpture stands in mourning for the scores of thousands of people shot to death and their bodies thrown into a forest ravine by the Nazis in 1941-43.
In his comments at the monument, Mr. Bush declared: "For many years the tragedy of Babi Yar went unacknowledged, but no more. You soon will place a plaque on this site that acknowledges the genocide against the Jews, the slaughter of gypsies, the wanton murder of Communists, Christians, of anyone who dared oppose the Nazi madman's fantasies."
The killings at Babi Yar began with the machine-gun execution of more than 33,000 Ukrainian Jews over 36 hours beginning on Sept. 29, 1941. In the next 18 months, many tens of thousands more victims, both Jews and non-Jews, were killed as the mass executions continued.
"Babi Yar was the beginning of the fascist genocide of the Jews," said Aleksandr Burakovsky, co-chairman of the Sholom Aleichem Cultural and Education Society, who said the Soviet authorities still resist acknowledging that half or more of all the victims were Jewish. "The fact that they refused to say anything specific about the Jews is a sign that anti-Semitism has not really died here."
 
'Inspires Great Confidence'
 On the flight from Moscow, Mr. Bush spoke with high respect for Mr. Gorbachev.
"You're dealing with a man who is coping with enormous problems and handling them well," the President said aboard Air Force One.
"The man just inspires great confidence in you," he continued, chatting in the aisle, wearing a white windbreaker imprinted with a map of the world.
Crowds of Ukrainians proudly welcomed the American visitor as evidence that the republic, with 52 million people and deep agricultural and industrial resources, is potentially the independent equal of some Western European countries.
Fervent chants for independence broke out at some points. There was a sense in the streets of the Ukrainians enjoying both the moment and the momentum in their quest for sovereignty.
 
Evolution of Nationalism
 This push began a year ago with a surprising declaration endorsed by the Communist majority in the republic's Parliament. It continued with student protest strikes and has lately evolved into resisting Mr. Gorbachev's hopes for a new, more workable form of power-sharing with the republics.
"This is the first signal that the outside world is finally viewing us as a sovereign nation, not as part of Moscow's periphery," said Zenon Lotsunyak, a 50-year-old lawyer watching along the parade route.
Petro Sarafanyuk, a 14-year-old student in an embroidered Ukrainian shirt who was moving amid an independence demonstration of several thousand marchers, said, "I think Bush should pressure Gorbachev to stop squelching our movement toward independence." Another student said Mr. Bush should deal only with popularly elected leaders and withhold aid "until the Communist-fascist regime has no money in its pockets."
The crowd was particularly sensitive to the power the Ukraine currently holds: It is being courted by Mr. Gorbachev to approve a new union treaty, with its provisions for increased power-sharing with the republics.
The Ukrainian leadership, sensing the growing popular demand for self-rule, has been delaying the quick approval of the treaty sought by Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Bush endorsed the Gorbachev approach, telling Parliament that the new agreement "holds forth the hope that the republics will combine greater autonomy with greater voluntary interaction" and thereby avoid "the hopeless course of isolation."
What Mr. Bush sought to avoid as a "false choice" was more or less the issue being pressed on him by independence demonstrators who sometimes politely, sometimes stridently, lined the President's parade route. They waved yellow-and-blue independence flags and protested that he had not given a separate audience to the leaders of the Ukraine's leading independence movement, called Rukh.
The Rukh chairman, Ivan Drach, rebuffed in seeking a private meeting, complained that Mr. Bush had no sense of the true democratic struggles under way in the republics. He belittled the President as a "messenger" fresh from the summit gathering who had been "hypnotized by Gorbachev."
 
Communists With Survival Skills
 Nevertheless, Mr. Drach was included in a luncheon gathering with the President. It was given at the 250-year-old Mariinsky Palace by Leonid M. Kravchuk. He is the highly adaptive Communist leader who is chairman of the republic's Parliament and is widely regarded as the front-runner in the republic's presidential election, scheduled in December.
White House specialists had carefully researched the convoluted politics of the Ukraine, in which the Communists have retained their power, for now at least, by recasting themselves in relation to the drive for Ukrainian nationalism.
As "sovereignty Communists," they have maintained an ever-shifting, 2-to-1 edge in Parliament over an opposition minority that, with its own aggressive discord, still provides the cutting edge for insurgency in the republic.
Thus, the 50-guest luncheon list for President Bush was a blend of Mr. Kravchuk and the ranking Communists of the government, plus some opposition leaders. Chief among them were Mr. Drach; Levko Lukyanenko, chairman of the Ukrainian Republican Party; Yuri Shcherbak, chairman of the Green Party; Volodymyr Yavorisky, a member of Parliament, and Igor Yukhnovsky, leader of the National Council, the opposition legislative bloc.
The day of bristling politics, and a few quick motorcades across the rich green Ukraine before Mr. Bush returned to the White House tonight, offered him a portrait of a republic that is virtually a separate nation from the power centers of Moscow.
In contrast to Moscow, the President found a far more excited and politically involved public here. Many Ukrainians heatedly debate between outright independence or militant nationalism as the best alternatives for curtailing the power of the central Government.
 
'No Heartburn'
 President Bush said on Air Force One that he had asked Mr. Gorbachev in advance whether he had any concerns about his touching down here.
"No, there is no heartburn at all that I can detect about going there," he said. "And I think we'll handle it with proper balance."
He added that Mr. Gorbachev "feels he has assurances" that the Ukraine will eventually support the new union treaty.
Opposition politicians theorize that Mr. Kravchuk, as a transmogrified Communist, will hedge on the treaty until after the December presidential election and then, once elected, will support it.
Mr. Bush left Moscow with a freshly signed strategic arms agreement as a promise against future war. He left here with a remembrance of a past war's atrocities at Babi Yar.
"In the vast quiet here," the President said, "something larger than life assails us: the shadows of past evils, the light of past virtue."
The Babi Yar memorial where Mr. Bush spoke is not at the actual site of the Nazi massacre of civilians in the fall of 1941. This was done a mile away by firing squads' systematically shooting families of people so that their bodies tumbled into the natural grave of the ravine.
Two years later, when the German armies were in retreat, they sought to cover the evidence by having the bodies retrieved and burned near what is now the memorial site. The grisly pall from the burning bodies hung over Kiev for days and is well remembered by older residents.
The memorial, put up in 1976, depicts 11 victims as they die at the edge of the ravine, the central figure being a Communist resistance fighter.
Mr. Burakovsky, the co-chairman of the Sholom Aleichem Society, said that whereas a century ago there were six million Jews in the Ukraine, now there are 500,000. Most of them -- perhaps 350,000 -- have plans to emigrate, he said, because of the lack of economic opportunity for their families.

HEADLINE: As the Games Begin, Havana Is Glowing With Self-Satisfaction

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 1

 BODY:
After five years of wondering whether their hometown could meet the challenge, the people of this tough-minded city full of contradictions and rustic charm are prepared to welcome athletes from 39 hemispheric neighbors Friday evening for the beginning of the Pan American Games.
As recently as this spring there were serious questions about the ability of Cuba -- in the face of a severe economic crunch and growing diplomatic isolation -- to complete all the construction needed to accommodate 17,000 athletes, journalists and tourists for 16 days. 
 But now, a day before the opening ceremonies at Pan American Stadium, the facilities are ready and the visitors have been accommodated. And Havana, glowing with a sense of self satisfaction, is preparing to reward itself.
An atmosphere of want and need, created by chronic shortages of basic supplies, has given way -- for the time being -- to rapidly escalating good feeling.
And for the Cubans who will admit it, there is an overriding feeling of amazement that the work has been finished.
"To do this with so few resources, in such a short time during this special period and to do it with quality has been good," said Ulices Sanchez, a nurse here.
 
'We Cannot Complain'
 Sanchez and his wife, Rosa, strolled through the Miramar section of Havana with their 3-year-old daughter, Yanetsys, eating ice cream and enjoying a balmy summer evening. They agreed that Cuba's ability to complete the work was a monumental achievement.
"The Pan American village is beautiful," said Rosa, also a nurse. "I studied in Cojima, and that area used to be a desert. The multipurpose center is beautiful; those are works I myself thought would never be finished on time. Even in January it looked as if they were just beginning."
Her husband cut in: "Not January. In May people said it was not going to be finished. The velodrome is one of the things I thought would never be finished, and the bowling alleys. But you see, they are done. So we cannot complain."
"Just imagine," Rosa added. "After such a long time we've been struggling so that the games will be held here and they are here. I think it's a step forward in relationships with others."
Onidia Parrodi Diaz, an unemployed woman in her mid-20's, said the games represented a change of pace, an opportunity to meet new people and an excuse to party.
"For the next three weeks young people are going to be very happy," she said. "It means entertainment, amusing ourselves, going out for parties.
"I also feel excited because we are going to meet Americans, French, Russians, Spaniards, Venezuelans. And I think because everybody contributed to the games everybody is happy. It is a sense of satisfaction."
 
Something for Their Money
 But the games are also expensive, some estimates putting the cost at $156 million. This at a time when homes of the masses are crumbling, food is in short supply and the majority of Cubans are not allowed to possess United States currency.
Ivan Valladares, a waiter at a tea room near Luyano section of Havana, said that Cubans would receive a high return on their money. "After the games finish, everything used for the games will be used by the population," he said. "There are people who have needs, people who really live in a chaotic situation. That's life around the world. When the games finish, all those facilities built for the games will be used for the people."
Asked if he had any special feelings for visitors from the United States, Valladares said, "I regard all the visitors here as brothers, even the United States. As long as they come as brothers, I will treat them as brothers."
For Cubans like 71-year-old Arturo Sosa Martinez de Celis, the Pan American Games, for all their excitement, are a mere pebble in Cuba's long, winding history.
A former medical translator, he lives by himself in a weatherbeaten white cottage that faces a beach and sits at the end of a dead-end street in Santa Fe, a city about 11 miles outside of Havana.
His father built the house in 1936 as a second home for his Havana-based family. After the revolution, Celis moved from Havana to the five-room cottage and teaches English, sometimes in his home, "sometimes in my pupil's house."
His interest in the games is not high ("At my age?" he said) but theoretical. "Every country needs something of this importance," he said.
The presence of the games here, and the infusion of tourists and dollars, represents a new phase for Cuba and a respite from the decades of isolation it has suffered since Fidel Castro came to power three decades ago. "Will I go to the games?" said Celis. "Maybe. I don't know exactly. I don't leave here very much. I'm out of everything."
The old man sighed and stared in the distance at the Pan de Gujaibon mountains. "Everything is older now," he said. "The only thing beautiful now is the sea and the sunset."

HEADLINE: Senate Votes $5.8 Billion For Extended Jobless Pay

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Senate tonight passed a $5.8 billion program to extend unemployment benefits to people who have been out of work more than half a year.
After a week of delaying actions by Republicans in both houses, passage came swiftly tonight on a voice vote with no opposition heard. 
 The House is expected to adopt the measure Friday, but what President Bush will do when it goes to him is uncertain. All week long his senior aides have been saying they would advise him to veto the bill.
Since last week Democrats have seized on jobless benefits as an effective political issue, contending that Mr. Bush was ready to declare emergencies to help the Kurds or the Bangladeshis. They made that argument again tonight. "The Bush Administration has an economic program for every country in the world except this one," said Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan. "Tonight we're stepping up to help the American people."
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said that about three million people would be eligible for benefits before the temporary program expires next July.
 
Bush Declaration Needed
 The bill would declare a "dire emergency" under last year's budget act, a declaration necessary to allow adoption of measures that would increase the Federal deficit.
But as the Senate bill was drafted, the benefits would only flow if Mr. Bush not only signed the bill but also issued a declaration that an emergency existed.
Tonight Republicans sought to make it clear, as Senator Bob Dole said, that "no one disputes the pain and hardship of many of the unemployed." But he argued that it was unwise to add to the deficit and said it was untimely because the recession was ending. He proposed a smaller program, costing $3.2 billion, and proposed raising the money through various methods.
Another measure Mr. Dole obtained as political cover for his party was an agreement that there would be no roll-call votes, so Republicans would not be put in the position of either voting against the Administration or against the unemployed.
Senator Bentsen concentrated on the domestic argument, saying, "Today we have an opportunity to help families pay their rent; to help them buy gas for the car so they can get out and look for a job; to help them keep food on the table and kids in school."
 
Tapping a Trust Fund
 Mr. Bentsen said his bill was spending money that had already been raised by taxes for a trust fund intended to pay for extended benefits. He said the bill was necessary because the standards of existing law made it too hard to qualify for benefits, and $8 billion had piled up in the fund.
Under current law, benefits can be extended beyond the regular 26 weeks in a state when joblessness among those covered by unemployment insurance reaches 6 percent in that state, or when the insured jobless level exceeds by one fifth the average levels in that state over the past two years. In only Alaska, Maine and Rhode Island and in Puerto Rico are the long-term unemployed now eligible for extended benefits, which are now paid half from state and half from Federal funds.
The bill, whose entire cost would be paid by the Federal Government, would shift the standard from the insured unemployed rate to the total unemployed rate in a state, on the ground that if total unemployment is very high, then it is very hard to find a job, regardless of insured status.
In states with 8 percent unemployment, averaged over the last six months, an additional 20 weeks of benefits could be paid. In states where the level was at least 7 percent, 13 weeks could be paid. In states with 6 percent or more, 7 weeks of benefits could be paid. In all other states, four extra weeks of benefits could be paid.
Finally, military veterans, who now have to wait four weeks to collect any benefits and can then collect them for only 13 weeks, would be eligible like civilians for 26 weeks of regular benefits, after only a one-week wait.
 
A Temporary Measure
 The bill would be effective from Sept. 1 through next July 4. After that the old standards will apply.
A key to tonight's agreement, after Democrats in both bodies had denounced the Republicans for delay, was accepting the Senate version of the bill, rather than the similar House measure.
One reason was that the Senate bill is temporary, while the House bill was permanent.
But even more important was the fact the President could thwart the extended benefits under the Senate bill. Under the House bill, if the bill was passed over his veto, it would go into effect anyway, thus contradicting the principle of the budget act that both the legislative and executive branches had to agree before an emergency could be declared.
A final reason for the agreement, which contemplates that the House will pass the bill around midday Friday, was that fact that Congress has scheduled a five-week vacation period to begin this weekend. The Democratic leaders of both houses had insisted they would keep Congress in session this weekend to get the bill passed if the Republicans kept delaying.
Referring to the anxious desire ofmany of his colleagues to leave on vacation, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, observed, "those jet engines are beginning to whine."
 
Fewer Jobless Seeking Benefits
 WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- The number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits fell nearly 5 percent in mid-July, the Government said today, signaling possibly brighter job prospects.
New applications for unemployment insurance fell to a seasonally adjusted 404,000 in the week ended July 20, a drop of 21,000 from the previous week, the Labor Department said.
"This is indicating that the job situation is improving somewhat," said Jean Sundrla, an economist with Evans Economics Inc. in Washington, a private economic forecaster. "It's in line with other indicators that say the economy is continuing to improve very slowly."
Among those indicators was a new report from the National Association of Purchasing Management that showed its index of manufacturing activity in more than 300 companies at 51.8 percent on July 31, its highest since April April 30, 1989, when it reached 52.1 percent.
Also, the nation's gross national product, which measures the total output of goods and services, grew at a 0.4 percent annual rate between April and June. Although the gain was slight, it was the first sign of revival after two quarters of contraction.
The Labor Department will release its report on national unemployment in July on Friday.

HEADLINE: Gulf War, and Peace, Revisited

 BODY:
Before 100 hours passed, the ground war had turned into a "turkey shoot." With word from Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf that Saddam Hussein's Republican Guard was shattered and his nuclear capacity "neutralized," the President decided the fighting had gone on long enough. The invasion of Kuwait that horrified the world a year ago today had been undone.
Americans greeted the Feb. 28 cease-fire with relief and pride -- relief at miraculously few U.S. casualties and pride in the brilliant performance of the allied forces. 
 Yet a remorseless Saddam Hussein remains in power, cruelly repressing Kurds and Shiites, defiantly playing nuclear hide-and-seek and maliciously manipulating the Iraqi people's misery. Even liberals who thought Mr. Bush was too quick to pull the trigger in January now wonder if he should have finished off Saddam Hussein and his army when he had the chance.
But the doubters do not do justice to Mr. Bush's restraint. With the benefit of later information showing, for instance, that Iraq's losses had been overestimated, Americans can sensibly wish he had gone on somewhat longer. But even with hindsight, his decision deserves credit.
That can be seen by asking what if Mr. Bush had gone all the way, wrecked the rest of Iraq's war machine, marched to Baghdad and overthrown Saddam Hussein?
With no evident successor to restore Iraq's unity, defend its borders or even maintain rudimentary services, there probably would have been a plague of troubles: many more allied and civilian casualties . . . protracted civil war, with allied troops by the thousands caught in the middle . . . Americans hated throughout the Arab world as an occupying army.
For all the ugly ambiguities of the actual consequences, Mr. Bush has avoided the quagmire and preserved his two triumphs: the extraordinary cooperation among coalition members and the revived self-confidence of Americans.
This was very much George Bush's war. He defined the options and framed the debate, at home and abroad. He gambled his Presidency on a quick and decisive struggle, and won. In personalizing the conflict, he tended to identify regional security and stability with the end of Saddam Hussein's army and rule. These goals were critical to his contention that the international economic embargo on Iraq would not suffice, necessitating the use of armed force.
But even if Mr. Bush overpersonalized the war, he was careful to defer to his allies. He thereby assured their loyalty and also enhanced the prospects for enduring cooperation in Iraq and for new coalitions in the future. That may disappoint unilateralists in the U.S. who hoped the war would give rise to a Pax Americana. But it's the most promising way to bring a measure of stability and security to this troubled region.
It is obviously impossible to render a final judgment now on Mr. Bush's war policy. We and others argued last fall that it would have been wiser to give the international economic embargo against Iraq more time to deny Iraq its billions in oil revenue. We thought he was in too much of a hurry to start shooting. That said, the President was right to stop it when he did.
By thundering on to Baghdad, Desert Storm might have brought some immediate satisfaction to Americans who have grown increasingly frustrated and furious about Saddam Hussein. But had that happened, just imagine where Americans would be today, a year after the invasion: still in Baghdad, in more danger and more frustration, and with no end in sight.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: One Year After the Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait: What Did Winning Mean? And What's Next?;
Blood, Sweat And Paradox

BYLINE: By Roger Morris; Roger Morris, author of "Richard Milhous Nixon: The Rise of an American Politician," was on the staff of the National Security Council under Presidents Johnson and Nixon.

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M.

 BODY:
At the moment of the German surrender in May 1945, the Supreme Allied Commander, Dwight D. Eisenhower, called for a toast. The Champagne turned out to be flat. It was an omen, some thought later, of the spoiled, cold-war peace that lay ahead.
A year after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and five months after the apparent triumph of Operation Desert Storm, the taste of victory in the Persian Gulf remains similarly stale, if not yet bitter, for the Commander in Chief, George Bush. 
 For all its anguish, the results of this eventful year have been paradoxical at best. Kuwait is free of Iraqi conquest yet unfree of its own feudal oppression. U.S. arms triumphed in the gulf, yet Europe and Japan remain dependent on Arabian oil and the U.S. is hostage to its own refusal to pursue energy alternatives. War curbed the real or imagined threats of Saddam Hussein, yet his thuggish regime survives. The awful human toll mounts, still uncounted, no end in sight.
Mr. Bush assembled the most impressive coalition since World War II. He balanced disparate interests, partially destroyed Iraq to hold Iran and other would-be territorial predators at bay, and even kept lines open to the Jordanians and Palestinians despite their pro-Iraqi sympathies.
Yet the Arab allies were soon riven by old factionalism, which divided them on further actions toward Iraq, thwarting gulf security arrangements, threatening to draw the U.S. by default into an uneasy military protectorate over the region.
War did not reduce the vast gap between Middle East rich and poor, and volatile resentment at Western domination. Despite his tyranny, Saddam Hussein symbolized these grievances to millions by defying the status quo. Anti-American fundamentalists and radicals remain sullenly undefeated from Teheran to Algiers.
Diplomatically, President Bush's war policy, whether as expedient or principle, lent an authority to the U.N. not seen since the Korean War. Washington's invocation of international edict and collective action, however, now compels it to observe resolutions on Palestine and ultimately to confront Israel, our client.
Israel, the silent partner in the Desert Storm coalition, was defended during the war as never before by American patronage and for the moment is rid of a menacing enemy. But even the erratic Scud missile attacks exposed the irrelevance of the occupied territories as strategic buffers.
However sternly Mr. Bush denied "linkage," the war brought unprecedented U.S. pressure on the Israelis to settle the Palestinian issue. The result in August 1991 is an Israel more militarily secure than ever, more politically challenged than a year ago.
Not least are the American paradoxes of this year of yellow ribbons. In punishing Iraq, Desert Storm was also a showcase war, a deterrent demonstration of might to subdue spreading doubts about American power. At home, it was a war to end the shame of the last, a staging of pride and prowess against deep feelings of unrequited sacrifice.
Yet a tortuous postwar period has raised new questions about the limits of U.S. power, the impotence of Mr. Bush's policies beyond the battlefield. The great expedition also left untouched the root economic and social condition of the U.S. No satellite reconnaissance is needed to see an America even more troubled this summer than last.
With so much of its prestige invested, and a secure peace yet so unfinished, the U.S. has more at stake in the Middle East today than when Iraqi tanks churned into Kuwait last August. The efficacy of Washington's showcase war has come to depend on an equally exemplary peace.
The symbol and substance of that peace is an Israeli-Palestinian settlement, a task requiring U.S. leadership no less than in Desert Storm, with long-term American interests uniquely in the balance.
It is not only that Mr. Bush pledged to his Arab allies that he would turn after the fight to heal this old wound, or that a settlement would effectively disarm anti-American Arabs -- though both factors are crucial to stability in the Middle East. Just as the war displayed military power, an Israeli-Palestinian peace through American mediation will show political-diplomatic strength of incalculable value in dealing with both resurgent allies and reborn adversaries in the complex new world of the 1990's.
To succumb to the old drift is only to fortify Middle East enmities. To abdicate initiative to the Europeans is to squander the influence and leadership won in the war. To cede a settlement to a U.N. resolution is to reduce the U.S. to veto or acquiescence. To suffer diplomatic defeat in the wake of military victory is to breed distrust and disillusion at home, where the political reaction would be unpredictable.
Far more imposing to Mr. Bush than Saddam Hussein and his peasant army is an obdurate Israeli regime, being led to the peace table by Secretary of State James Baker. Mr. Baker's shuttle diplomacy has produced initial Arab concessions but scant progress from Israel. The U.S. effort is also haunted by the pro-Israel lobby, perhaps the most impregnable bloc supporting the interests of a foreign government ever assembled in American politics.
Like Desert Storm, the peace campaign will demand Mr. Bush's all-out commitment of Presidential power. But as in the war, he does not lack means.
Internationally, an Israeli-Palestinian peace is the one cause that still unites the gulf crisis coalition. Moreover, just as Soviet temperance was crucial in the gulf war, Moscow, as it has indicated in this week's summit, will be a ready ally in negotiations -- both as a great power presence in future regional guarantees and as a potential arbiter.
In moving the Israelis, the White House has not only $5.6 billion in annual U.S. aid vital to Israel's economy, but also the $10 billion requested by Israel for housing loan guarantees over the next five years, money necessary to cope with the flood of Soviet immigrants who are demographic insurance for Israel's long-term hold in the Middle East.
Against pro-Israeli support, much of it Democratic, the President can marshal most of his own party, new allies in the American Jewish community and, ultimately, the vast, grass-roots constituency of Desert Storm.
Before his eventual preoccupation with re-election in 1992, President Bush has a fleeting chance to show that we can construct as well as coerce, sustain as well as savage, that Desert Storm was not the spasm of an ebbing power but part of the statesmanship and world leadership he always claimed.
Beyond a Middle East peace lies a renewed opportunity to engage worldwide challenges of poverty and famine, education and disarmament, and in new-found security to turn to America's needy homeland. It is altogether the test of his Presidency.
A year after the violation of Kuwait's frontier, months after Desert Storm's guns fell silent, our real Middle East crisis is only beginning.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: When Politics Topples Precedent, That's Chaos

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Court Reversals" by John W. Farrell (letter, July 23) deals with an important subject in constitutional law and sorely needs correction. Overruling precedents recently made is quite different from overruling decisions that were themselves in conflict with earlier decisions, and from overruling old decisions after substantial changes in social and economic conditions have occurred. 
 Mr. Farrell cites cases in three areas: segregation, the right to counsel and the role of the judiciary in reapportionment. On segregation, a half-century had elapsed between Plessy v. Ferguson and Brown v. Board of Education, and a growing part of the population had come to see racism as an evil. It had also become clear that "separate but equal" was a fatuous notion, enforced separation being itself a form of inequality.
As for the right to counsel, the decision in Betts v. Brady (1942), overruled by Gideon v. Wainwright (1963), was itself contrary to decisions of the Court rendered in 1932, 1936 and 1938. As to Baker v. Carr (1962), the legislative-district case, there was no precedent to overrule, no holding directly in point.
Our law, essentially the Anglo-American common law, involves the judiciary in both attachment to prededent and adaptation to changing conditions and ideas. The law must be reasonably stable so that we know where we stand. But the world is not immobile. Adherence to precedent is a gravitational pull rather than an unyielding hobble.
The present Supreme Court, in contrast to its predecessors, overturns decisions recently made despite the absence of social or economic developments that might require a different judicial response. As Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist puts it, a precedent may be overruled because it was "badly reasoned." That is, he may ignore the precedent because he prefers his reasoning to that of those who set the precedent. Or, as Associate Justice David Souter says, a precedent may be overruled because it was "wrongly decided." That is, he would have decided it differently.
Such thought destroys our legal system. We are given a prescription for chaos.
 
CHARLES REMBAR
New York, July 24, 1991

HEADLINE: MONY, Sorely Tested, Reassures Customers

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York boasts about its 148 years in the business, its 145 years of uninterrupted dividends and its financial strength as the nation's 13th-largest insurance company. Even the company's more familiar name -- MONY -- seems to instill confidence.
But now MONY's reputation is being sorely tested. Two weeks ago, Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating of the company's financial strength to Baa-1, which effectively means "adequate," from A-2. The change makes MONY the only one of the nation's 20 biggest insurers not to receive an A-or-higher rating, which implies "exceptional," "excellent" or "good." 
 Moody's, which commands enormous attention in the financial community, cited the size of MONY's capital cushion and concerns about its portfolio of mortgages and real estate investments.
The lower rating comes despite the fact that MONY's management has moved for more than a year to increase its capital cushion, raise cash and jettison money-losing operations. The company has been talking with American International Group Inc., another insurer based in New York, and other companies about joint ventures or transactions to increase its capital -- only the latest indication that its management is eager to bolster its financial condition.
But all its efforts may be futile if fears about the company's strength and solvency scare policyholders and pension investors into a run that could turn a manageable situation into a devastating crisis. Hoping to prevent the kind of withdrawals that have badly hurt some other insurers in recent months, MONY has been taking out newspaper ads to reassure policyholders and has even set up an 800 number, open 11 hours a day, to answer questions. It has also been meeting with some of its pension fund clients.
Analysts say that MONY and insurers like it can probably survive and thrive if given the opportunity and time to improve their balance sheets.
"My impression is that they have been moving quickly to get out of losing lines, cut losses short and take some action to boost surplus," said Fred Townsend of Townsend & Schupp, a firm that advises, among others, corporate treasurers who buy guaranteed investment contracts from MONY. "In my view they were taking steps to improve what had been a below-average performance in the past few years."
 
Claims of Financial Strength
 The company's top management defends its financial strength by insisting that MONY's surplus capital is more than enough and that its talks with potential investors are simply business as usual.
"We do not feel our levels of capital are inadequate," said Michael I. Roth, president of MONY. "If someone was to come to us with capital we would look to deploy that capital to grow our business."
James B. Farley, MONY's chairman and chief executive, emphasized that the talks the company has had about raising capital have nothing to do with its liabilities.
MONY has had troubles on several fronts. Real estate investments and mortgages represent percentages of the insurer's invested assets that are substantially above the industry averages. The total mortgage portfolio is $5.5 billion, including $300 million for farm loans. At the end of this year's first quarter, mortgages represented about 40 percent of the insurer's $14 billion or so in assets, which is substantially above the 24.5 percent average for the industry.
 
Rise in Nonperforming Mortgages
 The nonperforming mortgages for the insurance industry went from an average of 2.4 percent in 1989 to 3.1 percent in 1990, while MONY's nonperforming mortgages went from 1.8 percent to 3.5 percent.
Direct investments in real estate totaled about $740 million at the end of the first quarter. Those investments are carried at book value, not market value. Given the troubles of the real estate markets and how difficult it is to judge value, the market value of some of these investments may fall substantially below their book value.
In the first quarter, MONY foreclosed on about $23 million of real estate, which regulators say represents a slight increase over the amount on which it foreclosed in the year-earlier quarter. The total foreclosed property on the company's books rose $109 million last year and totaled about $274 million at the end of the first quarter this year.
 
Extent of Troubled Real Estate
 At year-end, delinquent mortgages totaled about $169 million, leaving the company with at least $443 million in troubled real estate on its books. Because mortgages and real estate investments are carried at book value rather than market value there is the potential that the company has substantially bigger real estate problems. Mr. Roth said a special $73 million fund would be established by year-end to guard against such a surprise.
Junk bonds are another area that troubles MONY. About 9.5 percent of MONY's $5.9 billion of bonds are rated below investment grade, with about a third of that rated B or lower by the ratings agencies and the other two-thirds rated BB. According to Weiss Research, a Palm Beach, Fla., firm that rates insurance companies, the junk bond holdings represented 186 percent of the company's capital at the end of last year.
The company's executives argue that more than half of its junk bonds fall in that vast middle area of medium-quality, below-investment-grade securities, but analysts find little comfort in that argument. Mr. Roth emphasized that MONY has had a strong record managing its portfolio of junk bonds.
 
A Borderline D-Plus Rating
 The junk bonds and the heavy mortgage exposure are the greatest concerns Weiss researchers have about MONY, to which they give a borderline D-plus rating. (Weiss, with its consumer orientation, uses a grading system that descends from A to F.) Weiss estimates that on a risk-adjusted basis, MONY has less than 68 percent of the capital it needs to remain solvent during an average recession and 41 percent of the capital it needs during a severe recession with a large number of defaults.
"They are undercapitalized and their investments are weak, so any activity they could implement to raise capital would help them," said Anthony McCoy, Weiss's director of research.
MONY has about $806 million in surplus capital and in a mandatory contingency fund for losses on bonds, preferred stock and common stock. The company has not set up reserves for its mortgage portfolio and is not required to, so losses in that area are charged against capital surplus.
In addition to the real estate and junk bond exposure, MONY has suffered over the last few years with money-losing group health and disability insurance businesses. The company's group health business has lost about $181 million over the last five years. There have also been losses in other subsidiaries.
MONY claims $4 billion in liquid assets. Of those assets, 41.5 percent are bonds and 69 percent of those bonds are private placements. The resale market for the private placement bonds might be quite thin if the company had to raise cash quickly. MONY has $14 billion in liabilities, of which about $9.8 billion can be withdrawn on demand. The pension liabilities are about $6.8 billion, with $2.2 billion in guaranteed investment contracts, $2.3 billion in group annuity contracts, $970 million in (401)k plans, plus other liabilities.
"If you assumed there was little liquidity in their private placement bonds, we would estimate their liquid assets at $2.5 billion and their demand liabilities at $9.8 billion," Mr. Townsend said, meaning that if MONY had to raise large amounts of cash on short notice it might not be able to raise enough to cover all its liabilities, because not all the privately placed bonds would be quickly sellable.
Mr. Roth has defended the liquidity of MONY's private placement securities by noting that a major investment bank has promised the company that if necessary $1 billion could be raised in three weeks on the portfolio of $3.6 billion in private placement junk bonds.

A table in Business Day yesterday with an article about the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York misstated the relationship of mortgage investment to statutory equity in one listing of figures for several insurance companies. The figures, which were correct, were for mortgages as a multiple of equity, not as a percentage of equity.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bush's Ukraine Speech: Working 'For the Good of Both of Us'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: KIEV, U.S.S.R., Aug. 1

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech today to the Ukrainian Parliament:
 This beautiful city brings to mind the words of the poet Aleksandr Dovzhenko: "The city of Kiev is an orchard. Kiev is a poet. Kiev is an epic. Kiev is history. Kiev is art."
 Centuries ago, your forbearers named this country Ukraine or frontier because your steppes link Europe and Asia. But Ukrainians have become frontiersmen of another sort. Today you explore the frontiers and contours of liberty.
 Though my stay here, as I said, is far too short, I've come here to talk with you and to learn. And for those who love freedom, every experiment in building an open society offers new lessons and insights.
 You face an especially daunting task. For years people in this nation felt powerless, overshadowed by a vast government apparatus, cramped by forces that attempted to control every aspect of their lives. And today your people probe the promise of freedom. In cities and republics, on farms, in businesses, around university campuses, you debate the fundamental question of liberty, self-rule and free enterprise.
 Americans, you see, have a deep commitment in these values. We follow your progress with a sense of fascination, excitement and hope. And this alone is historic. In the past, our nations engaged in duels of eloquent bluff and bravado, and now the fireworks of superpower confrontation are giving way to the quieter and far more hopeful arts of cooperation.
I come here to tell you we support the struggle in this great country for democracy and economic reform. And I would like to talk to you today about how the United States views this complex and exciting period in your history, how we intend to relate to the Soviet central Government and the republican governments.
 
 
 
U.S. Support Outlined
 In Moscow I outlined our approach. We will support those in the center and the republics who pursue freedom, democracy and economic liberty. We will determine our support not on the basis of personalities but on the basis of principles. And we cannot tell you how to reform your society. We will not try to pick winners and losers in political competition between republics or between republics and the center. That is your business. That's not the business of the United States of America.
 Do not doubt our real commitment, however, to reform. Do not think we can presume to solve your problems for you. Theodore Roosevelt, one of our great Presidents, once wrote: "To be patronized is as offensive as to be insulted. No one of us cares permanently to have someone else conscientiously striving to do him good. What -- we want to work with that someone else for the good of both of us." That's what our former President said.
 We will work for the good of both of us, which means that we will not meddle in your internal affairs.
 Some people have urged the United States to choose between supporting President Gorbachev and supporting independence-minded leaders throughout the U.S.S.R. I consider this a false choice.
 In fairness, President Gorbachev has achieved astonishing things and his policies of glasnost and perestroika and democratization point towards the goals of freedom, democracy and economic liberty.
 We will maintain the strongest possible relationship with the Soviet Government of President Gorbachev, but we also appreciate the new realities of life in the U.S.S.R. and therefore, as a federation ourselves, we want good relations, improved relations with the republics.
 Lord Acton once observed,"The most certain test by which we judge whether a country is really free is the amount of security enjoyed by minorities." Freedom requires tolerance, a concept imbedded in openness, in glasnost, and in our First Admendment protections for the freedoms of speech, association and religion, all religions.
 
 
 
Freedom and Hope
 Tolerance nourishes hope. A priest wrote of glasnost: "Today more than ever, the words of Paul the Apostle spoken 2,000 years ago ring out. 'They counted us among the dead but look, we are alive.'
 In Ukraine, in Russia, in Armenia and the Baltics, the spirit of liberty thrives. But freedom cannot survive if we let despots flourish or permit seemingly minor restrictions multiply until they form chains, until they form shackles...
 And yet freedom is not the same as independence. Americans will not support those who seek freedin in order to replace a far-off tyranny with a local despotism. They will not aid those who promote a suicidal nationalism based upon ethnic hatred.
 We will support those who want to build democracy. And by democracy we mean a system of government in which people may vie openly for the hearts and yes, the votes of the public. We mean a system of government that derives its just power from the consent of the governed, that retains its legitimacy by controlling its appetite for power...
 Democracy is not a technical process driven by dry statistics. It is the very human enterprise of perserving freedom so that we can do the important things, the really important things -- raise families, explore our own creativity, build good and fruitful lives.
 In modern societies, freedom and democracy rely on economic liberty. A free economy is nothing more than a system of communication. It simply cannot function without individual rights or a profit motive, which give people an incentive to go to work, an incentive to produce. And it certainly cannot function without the rule of law, without fair and enforceable contracts, without laws that protect property rights and punish fraud.
 
 
 
Free Economies
 Free economies depend upon the freedom of expression, the ability of people to exchange ideas and test out new theories. The Soviet Union weakened itself for years by restricting the flow of information, by outlawing devices crucial to modern communication, such as computers and copying machines. And when you restricted free movement, even tourist travel, you prevented your own people from making the most of their talent. You cannot innovate if you cannot communicate.
 And finally, a free economy demands engagement in the economic mainstream. Adam Smith noted two centuries ago: "Trade enriches all who engage in it. Isolation and protectionsim doom its practitioners to degradation and want."
 I note this today because some Soviet cities, regions and even republics have engaged in ruinous trade wars....The vast majority of trade conducted by Soviet companies, imports and exports, involves, as you know better than I, trade between republics. The Nine Plus One Agreement holds forth the hope that republics will combine greater autonomy with greater voluntary interaction -- political, social, cultural, economic -- rather than pursuing the hopeless course of isolation.
 And so American investors and businessmen look forward to doing business in the Soviet Union, including the Ukraine. We've signed agreements this week that will encourage further interaction between the U.S. and all levels of the Soviet Union. But ultimately, our trade relations will depend upon our ability to develop a common language, a common language of commerce-currencies that communicate with one another, laws that protect innovators and entrepreneurs, bonds of understanding and trust.
 It should be obvious that the ties between our nations grow stronger every single day. I set forth a Presidetial initiative that is providing badly needed medical aid to the Soviet Union, and this aid expresses American solidarity with the Soviet peoples during a tie of hardship and suffering. And it has facilities in Kiev that are treating victims of Chernobyl.
 You should know that America's heart, the hearts of all, went out to the people here at the time of Chernobyl.
 An old Ukrainian proverb says, "When you enter a great enterprise, free your soul from weakness." The peoples of the U.S.S.R. have entered a great enterprise, full of courage and vigor, and I've come here today to say we support those who explore the frontiers of freedom. We will join these reformers on the path to what we call, appropriately call a new world order...
 This has been a great experience for Barbara and me to be here. We salute you. We salute the changes that we see. I remember the French expression, "Vive la difference," and I see different churnings around this chamber and that's exactly the way it ought to be. One guy wants this and another one that. That's the way the process works when you're open and free, competing with ideas to see who's going to emerge correct and who can do the most for the people in Ukraine.
 And so for us, this has been a wonderful trip, albeit far too short. And may I simply say may God bless the people of Ukraine. Thank you very, very much.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush speaking in front of the Babi Yar Monument in Kiev, which commemorates scores of thousands of people gunned down in a forest ravine by Nazis. (Associated Press)
