HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Leaves Square D As Schneider Moves In

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
No one was surprised when Jerre L. Stead stepped down yesterday from his job as chairman, president and chief executive of the Square D Company, the $1.65 billion electrical distribution equipment giant. Once Square D was acquired by Groupe Schneider S.A., the French electrical equipment maker, in May, analysts said it would be only a matter of time until Mr. Stead moved on.
"He was not entirely in favor of the takeover, so I'm not surprised he is leaving," said Russell Leavitt, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. 
 Employees in the company's Palatine, Ill., headquarters will be told today that Didier Pineau-Valencienne, Groupe Schneider's chairman and chief executive, will take on those titles at Square D and that Charles W. Denny 3d, who has been with Square D for 31 years, will become chief operating officer. Mr. Denny, 55, will oversee day-to-day operations of Square D and report to Mr. Pineau-Valencienne. Both appointments are on an interim basis but are expected to become permanent in October, Mr. Stead said.
Square D was acquired for $2.23 billion in a hostile takeover by Schneider after a 10-week fight. The deal made Schneider the world's largest maker of electrical distribution equipment including circuit breakers, switches and infrared measurement devices.
Mr. Stead, 48, said he planned to announce his new job on Tuesday. He refused to give any details. He has been with Square D for four and a half years, joining the company in 1987 as president and chief operating officer and becoming chairman in 1989. Before joining Square D, he was an executive at Honeywell Inc.
Mr. Stead said the merger would be completed within 30 days and it was time to "move on to other challenges." He acknowledged that there was concern on the part of employees about his plans, but he insisted that employees had remained neutral throughout the merger process.
Despite his initial rejection of the takeover attempt, Mr. Stead says he has had an excellent relationship throughout with Mr. Pineau-Valencienne and is pleased with the transition. He said Mr. Pineau-Valencienne had asked him to stay on for five years when the merger first happened, but that he said at the time he would only remain through the transition period.
Mr. Stead said he announced his departure about a month early to settle the question for employees as to whether he would stay or leave. "The global business market is far too demanding for the energy to be wasted on me staying or leaving," he said.
Mr. Stead said he had actively pushed for Mr. Denny to be named chief operating officer. Mr. Denny has been executive vice president in charge of Square D's $1.2 billion worldwide electrical distribution business since 1989.
A native of Middletown, Ohio, Mr. Denny holds a bachelor's degree in economics from Wesleyan University and an M.B.A. from Northwestern University. He joined the Barkelew Electric Manufacturing Company in 1960 and stayed on after Barkelew was acquired by Square D in 1967.

HEADLINE: One Year After the Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait: What Did Winning Mean? And What's Next?;
Oil Business, Not Oil Politics

BYLINE: By Daniel Yergin; Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, is author of "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Iraq's bid to dominate world petroleum supplies lies smoldering in the still burning oil fields of Kuwait. The aftermath of Baghdad's defeat could turn into a period of calm for oil producers and consumers. For, while the Persian Gulf crisis turned out to be about oil and geopolitics, its outcome suggests that the "business of oil" could take precedence over the "politics of oil" in the years immediately ahead.
The U.S., along with some coalition partners, has assumed an explicit role in assuring the secure flow of oil, and that certainly affects the orientation of the oil exporters. 
 OPEC, as always, reflects the balance of interests and power among its members. Today, Saudi Arabia is more dominant among the exporters than ever. Committed to moderate prices and stable supplies, it has no doubt that its fortunes depend on the Western economies; and, with a quarter of proved world oil reserves, it wants to be assured of a long-term market. At the same time, the crisis demonstrated that Saudi security is entwined with the West.
But the Saudis' strategy is not much different from that of most other exporters, who have much greater respect for the power of the marketplace today than in the era of oil nationalism. They have learned that customers count, and they want to demonstrate that they are reliable suppliers. Even Iran is showing some stirrings in that direction.
The economic imperatives of the 1990's also are pushing the exporters toward a new flexibility. With the question of sovereignty over oil resources resolved in their favor, they are now preoccupied with more pragmatic and acute needs -- chiefly, for capital and technology. They need more income from oil just to keep up with their rapidly growing populations. And since they are unlikely to gain more revenue from much higher prices (because they will lose customers), they need to pump more oil. And that requires new investment in exploration and production capacity.
But how to pay for it? There is a general expectation of a capital shortage in the 1990's. So the one place oil exporters will look for investment funds is in the once-banished foreign oil companies. As a result, doors that slammed shut with nationalization in the 1970's will swing open again in the 1990's, and companies will find themselves exploring and producing in territories they never expected to see again.
In the aftermath of the gulf crisis, attention has actually shifted away from the Middle East, toward the Soviet Union, which will become a more important, if uncertain, factor in international oil. If a secure contractual basis can be established with Western oil companies, the Soviet Union may, in some degree, balance the world's dependence on the Persian Gulf.
The biggest battle over oil in the 1990's may not even concern producing countries directly, but will be the struggle within the industrial countries over energy needs and environmental values. It could turn out that America's "energy strategy" is actually embodied in initiatives like the 1990 Clean Air Act. Right now, there is an unprecedented state and Federal effort to regulate into existence a market demand for alternatives to gasoline, challenging the basic role of oil.
The petroleum industry is anticipating a huge bill for new environmental investments. Perhaps oil demand, not oil supplies, will be the question of this decade.
Or will it? Oil remains a strategic commodity, and recent history shows that just when calm is taken for granted, some new surprise, mixing politics and economics, comes along and shakes all assumptions. Even now, one can see the possible elements of a surprise during the next two or three years.
The world is producing oil near the limits of capacity, meaning there is little room for error. But "error" could arise from a combination of political change and capacity limits in the Middle East, declining U.S. production, falling Soviet oil exports and rising demand resulting from economic recovery. Then what?

GRAPHIC: Drawing

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Miroslav A. Kriz, Economist, 83

 BODY:
Miroslav A. Kriz, an international economist and retired vice president of Citibank, died yesterday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 83 years old.
He died of complications of a stroke, his son said. 
 Mr. Kriz, who was educated in Prague and Paris, began his career as an economist with the League of Nations in Geneva in 1936. In 1941, he and a handful of League officials were invited to the United States to continue their work. From 1945 to 1958, Mr. Kriz was with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and served on economic development missions to Iraq, Egypt and Latin America. He was with Citibank from 1958 until his retirement in 1973.
He is survived by his wife, Suzanne; a son, John, of Palisades, N.Y.; two daughters, Mireille Bessin of Madison, N.J., and Nina Leneman of Geneva; a sister, Zdenka Zemanova of Ceske Budejovice, Czechoslovakia; and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Plunges on Report Of Continued U.S. Layoffs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday in heavy trading after the release of a report that indicated United States companies continued to lay off workers in July.
The Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate slipped to 6.8 percent in July from a five-year high of 7 percent in June, but the improvement was attributed to job seekers giving up the search. Separately, the Government said non-farm payrolls declined last month by 51,000. 
 "The data were far weaker than expected in terms of payrolls," said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer at Barclays Bank, noting that some economists had recently revised their estimates upward and were actually looking for payrolls to increase by as much as 75,000.
"The market was badly, badly surprised, and the dollar just plummeted" after what appeared to be a buoyant opening, he said.
Traders were concerned that after several rounds of favorable data, the economy may be slipping back into another decline in what economists call a double-dip recession.
That raises the possibility that the Federal Reserve will be inclined to cut interest rates to spur growth. Lower interest rates are negative for the dollar because they make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors.
Mr. Hatcher said dollar-selling was heavy throughout the session, particularly since traders had been expecting the data to be different.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 137.53 Japanese yen, up from 137.20 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 136.75 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 137.20 yen, down from 137.55 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.6945, from $1.6725 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.6890 to buy 1, up from Thursday's $1.6745.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.7415 marks, from 1.7570.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5147 Swiss francs, down from 1.5335; 5.9210 French francs, down from 5.9700; 1,301.50 Italian lire, down from 1,312.00, and 1.1505 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1498.

HEADLINE: Atom Arms Labs Defend Role In the Post-Cold-War Future

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Budgets for nuclear weapons will shrink with the ending of the cold war and the conclusion of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, but "nuclear competence," a very expensive commodity, remains essential to the nation's defense, say directors of the laboratories that design America's nuclear weapons.
Conserving that competence, which consists of specialized laboratories and equipment as well as a cadre of scientific specialists in nuclear weapons technology, now costs some $3 billion a year, not counting the cost of manufacturing the weapons themselves. 
 With the United States nuclear arsenal of about 20,000 warheads slated for eventual reduction to 12,000, critics in Congress and elsewhere assert that continued multibillion-dollar spending on nuclear weapons plants far exceeds the reduced needs of national defense.
 
Administration Defends Labs
 But the Administration strongly opposes major reductions in the strength of the nuclear weapons laboratories.
In his testimony before the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, Secretary of Energy James D. Watkins said on Tuesday that the United States must continue research in nuclear weapons to maintain nuclear deterrence in "an international scene that is multipolar rather than bipolar."
Mr. Watkins, whose department pays for the nation's nuclear weapons laboratories, said that scientists from these institutions had played vital supporting roles as advisers in the negotiations for the new treaty, and that the security of the world would depend partly on the laboratories' continued technical strength.
"Put bluntly," Mr. Watkins said, "even if we reduce our stockpile to just one weapon, I believe that this nation must still have a strong cadre of the world's best nuclear weapons designers and engineers, if we want to anticipate how other nations might try to build a clandestine bomb, to track the telltale signs of such activity."
Critics say that the Department of Energy laboratories now design two new warheads a year, considerably fewer than during the height of the arms race, but that the laboratories' budgets and staff are only slightly smaller.
Speaking for the Washington-based organization Physicians for Social Responsibility, Daryl Kimball said that the functions of two of the nuclear weapons laboratories, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and Los Alamos National Laboratory, could be merged, and that the money saved should be used for cleaning up nuclear waste and other contaminants from the half-century-old bomb program.
"We're not sure which laboratory should be saved, but only one is necessary," he said.
The laboratory directors concede that some budget cuts may be likely, but counter that the need for weapons-related research remains as great as ever, even if the strategic arms treaty signed this week is approved by the Senate.
"The build-down of the nation's warhead stockpile," said Dr. Siegfried S. Hecker, director of Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, "means that the warheads we retain must be all the more reliable and effective, if we are to maintain a credible nuclear deterrence."
 
Future Needs Unpredictable
 Moreover, he and the directors of the country's two other nuclear weapons laboratories said in interviews, the world is far short of achieving general nuclear disarmament, and it is impossible to predict future American needs requiring nuclear expertise in defense, deterrence, intelligence and disarmament verification.
Even if the weapons laboratories' only purpose were to to detect the clandestine nuclear weapons programs of other nations, they said, this ability would be well worth the cost.
Dr. Albert Narath, president of Sandia National Laboratories, said that budget cuts at all three laboratories were inevitable but that if cuts were too severe, national security would be at risk.
"We all know that we'll have to take our knocks," he said, "but if the cuts are so deep that we lose our pools of experts, the nation will lose nuclear competence -- an indispensable asset in a world where nuclear proliferation has yet to be halted."
 
Safety Issue Cited
 Dr. Hecker of Los Alamos said that nuclear weapons continue to become obsolete, and that the most important object in the design of new weapons was safety. Weapons need to be made even more resistance to accidental detonation, either of a nuclear charge or of the chemical explosives used to initiate the nuclear blast. A major challenge for designers has been the development of "insensitive" chemical explosives that are not easily detonated.
"A Congressional advisory panel headed by Dr. Sidney Drell of Stanford University recently concluded that safety must be incorporated in future nuclear weapons themselves, not merely in the procedures used in handling them. The committee ordered top-priority competition between the nuclear weapons laboratories to develop such safety features, and that's the major thrust of our present work," Dr. Hecker said. Keeping track of the proliferation of nuclear weapons in many developing countries has become a major problem that American weapons laboratories are particularly qualified to address, according to Dr. John H. Nuckols, director of Lawrence Livermore Laboratory.
"The world has had some unpleasant surprises in Iraq," he said. "Iraq's use of the calutron electromagnetic method for separating weapons-grade uranium came as quite a surprise. Our proliferation group at Livermore is rethinking these problems, with the object of reducing future surprises."
 
New Cleanup Methods Sought
 Finding effective and economical methods for cleaning up the radioactive messes created by nearly a half century of nuclear-weapon production at such plants as Savannah River, S.C., and Rocky Flats, Colo., also figures prominently in the post-cold-war plans of Los Alamos and its two sister research laboratories, Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California, and Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., and Livermore, Calif.
Reflecting the change in research goals, the Department of Energy has ordered the spending of $4 billion this year on cleaning up buildings, land and waterways near nuclear weapons plants that have been contaminated by various dangerous byproducts. This is more than one-third of the $10.5 billion budgeted by the department this year for nuclear weapons research, testing and production.
All three nuclear weapons laboratories owe their existence to war or the threat of war.
Los Alamos was founded in 1943 as part of the Manhattan Project that developed the first atomic bombs for use against the Axis. Livermore was created in 1952 during the Korean War, partly to develop a hydrogen bomb and partly to compete with Los Alamos, thereby spurring rival teams of scientists to extra effort.
The founding director of Los Alamos, Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, and one of Livermore's founders, Dr. Edward Teller, were political as well as scientific adversaries, and the bitterness of their famous McCarthy-era dispute helped to create the competitive tradition between the laboratories that persists to this day.
 
Under One University
 Both laboratories were placed under the administration of the University of California, which the Energy Department redesignated on Wednesday for another term as administrator.
In 1949, the Government also created Sandia, a third nuclear-weapons laboratory, under the administration of what is today A.T. & T. Bell Laboratories. Unlike Los Alamos and Livermore, Sandia does not deal directly with nuclear explosives but designs and tests other parts of nuclear weapons, including the complex electronic devices intended to allow only authorized officials to arm warheads. Much of Sandia's work is devoted to developing systems that guard against accidents or the use of weapons for nuclear blackmail or terrorism.
The three laboratories are roughly equal in size. Livermore employs about 8,000, including 3,000 nuclear weapons experts, and its current budget is $1.175 billion. Los Alamos has about 7,540 employees and a budget of $928 million. Sandia has 8,500 with a budget of about $1.2 billion.
Roughly one-third of the money spent by Los Alamos and Livermore is for the "core" mission -- research, development and testing of nuclear weapons. If such related fields of research as arms-reduction verification, nuclear intelligence, safeguards, security and improved nuclear processing methods are included, nuclear weapons account for somewhat more than half of the laboratory budgets.
 
Competition Called Wasteful
 Los Alamos and Livermore remain in direct competition for funds, projects and scientific talent -- a fact that critics regard as wasteful. But the laboratory directors believe the competition is essential.
Dr. Narath of Sandia said that although his laboratory was not itself in competition, rivalry between Los Alamos and Livermore "creates a kind of peer-review system, in which the two laboratories check each other and point out research errors and alternatives."
All three laboratory directors said that their research goals began a transition from nuclear weapons as long ago as the early 1970's, and that programs unrelated to nuclear weapons benefit many branches of science. Research involving antimissile defense programs, which will continue at Livermore and Los Alamos, has produced laser systems that laboratory officials expect to benefit astronomy and other sciences. The gigantic power of computers used by the weapons laboratories to simulate the dynamics of nuclear explosions has been put to use on many other programs.
Los Alamos, for instance, is a major participant in the Human Genome Project, a detailed analysis of the complete genetic code by which a human being is assembled from proteins and other substances. Besides conducting some of the analysis itself, Los Alamos is the repository of the GenBank, the national computer data base of all genetic sequence information.
 
Work on Fusion Energy
 All three weapons laboratories have been deeply involved for more than a decade in efforts to exploit fusion energy -- the same source of energy that powers hydrogen bombs and stars -- as a cheap and nonpolluting alternative to the fossil fuels polluting the atmosphere.
"If we are to take timely action to head off the effects of greenhouse warming," Dr. Nuckolls said, "it's essential that we move as fast as possible toward developing fusion power. The national laboratories are uniquely equipped to do this." But although directors of the laboratories feel that extracurricular projects contribute greatly to the value of their institutions, the main role of the Los Alamos, Livermore and Sandia will always be the maintenance of America's ability to wield and counter nuclear weapons.
"That is our core mission," Dr. Hecker said, "and as long as the world faces threats of war, we must try to meet our responsibilities."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Off Sharply; Platinum Leads the Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal futures prices fell sharply yesterday. Platinum led the decline in reaction to heavy Japanese selling, fears of Soviet selling and perceptions that industrial demand is fading.
Platinum futures settled $9 to $9.20 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the contract for delivery in October at $355.10 an ounce, the lowest price since early 1986. 
 On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $7.60 to $9.80 lower, with October at $358.90 an ounce and August at $355.60. Silver was 11.8 cents to 14.2 cents lower, with September at $3.935 an ounce.
Platinum plunged at the opening bell after an overnight selloff of platinum futures on the Tokyo Commodity Exchange, said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc.
There was little other news, but platinum remained lower and gold and silver steadily eroded against a backdrop of bearish developments. Among them were the slow economic recovery, slack investor demand for precious metals and fears the Soviet Union would be forced to sell huge amounts of platinum to raise hard currency.
Soybean futures prices rallied to a 13-month high on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders overwhelmingly bet against weekend showers halting the spread of the Midwestern drought. Grain futures finished mostly higher.
"If we don't receive the kind of rain forecast by meteorologists over the weekend, it's going to be off to the races again next week," said Richard Feltes, research director with Refco Inc. in Chicago.
Wheat futures settled unchanged to 3 1/2 cents higher, with September at $2.98 a bushel. Corn futures were 1/4 cent lower to 1 1/4 cents higher, with September at $2.62 1/4 a bushel. Oats were 1/2 cent lower to 1 1/2 cents higher, with September at $1.35 a bushel. Soybeans were 9 1/2 cents to 23 cents higher, with August at $6.37 a bushel, the highest settlement of a near-term soybean contract since July 3, 1990.
Gasoline Pushed Higher
Oil prices held firm and gasoline shot up in quiet trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange on the anniversary of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
There was no news motivating the market, but gasoline prices were pushed higher by strong demand in cash markets, analysts said.
Crude oil futures finished 2 cents lower to 10 cents higher, with September at $21.32 a barrel. Heating oil was 0.26 cent to 0.35 cent higher, with September at 59.80 cents a pound. Unleaded gasoline was 0.55 cent to 1.22 cents higher, with September at 66.40 cents a pound. Natural gas was 2 cents lower to 3.5 cents higher, with September at $1.26 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Hog futures fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid expectations for increased hog slaughtering next week. Cattle futures ended mostly lower.

HEADLINE: Tale of Political Ties and Bad Debt

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH with STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
A prominent Republican family in New Hampshire with close ties to the White House is hoping to stave off the imminent collapse of its real estate empire, and it says it is close to reaching an agreement on a four-and-a-half-year moratorium on repaying more than $100 million it borrowed from New England lenders.
There is no evidence of any improper interference in the renegotiation of the debts of the Tamposi family of Nashua, N.H. But regulators and borrowers say such a lengthy moratorium is exceptional, and some New Hampshire businessmen with large debts who have been unable to get the same terms are upset. 
 The story of the rise of the Tamposis and their current plight is a personification of the nation's banking crisis.
The family has been one of the largest borrowers in a region with the nation's weakest banking system. The negotiations over the Tamposis' loans, as well as the Federal bailout of insolvent New Hampshire banks, also illustrates the wide discretion allowed banks and Federal regulators in resolving troubled debts and rescuing banks. This power is often exercised out of public view.
Charles Dougherty, a lawyer in Boston for the six Tamposi children, said the renegotiation of the family's debts was not a result of any special treatment but the most efficient and economical way to handle the bad loans.
"When the banks have a lot of money at issue, they're going to find ways to improve the situation," he said. "The Tamposis have been central to the development of real estate in southern New Hampshire. That has necessitated a lot of borrowings. They have a wonderful reputation. Banks thought they were good loans; the Tamposis thought the same. Now it turns out it's not the case for some."
The troubles of the Tamposis and the troubles of the New Hampshire banks have the same root: countless real estate deals of the last decade that have now gone sour. The family's real estate holdings stretch from New Hampshire to Florida. Much of it was purchased through bank loans during the last decade at the height of the market, before prices plummeted in the worst recession to hit the New England region in decades.
The family, Mr. Dougherty said, has "by and large" stopped making payments on their loans and sought time to try to sell their holdings at better prices in order to make good on loans to some 50 lenders.
A. Roland Roberge, the state's Banking Commissioner, said, "There isn't a bank in the state that hasn't done business with them." He added: "Four-to-five-year moratoriums are very, very exceptional. That is not normal."
The Banking Commissioner declined to discuss any specific transaction but said each loan renegotiation depends on its own set of circumstances.
 
The Family
Vacuum Cleaners To Real Estate

Samuel A. Tamposi Sr., the family patriarch, rose from modest beginnings as a farmer and vacuum cleaner salesman to become New Hampshire's largest commercial real estate developer.
He bought a minority interest in the Boston Red Sox and enlisted the help of the former baseball star Ted Williams in a large development in Florida called Citrus Hills. Mr. Williams, who has a home in Citrus Hills, has helped attract New Englanders to the development, which is about 75 miles north of Tampa and has a golf course designed by Arnold Palmer.
Mr. Tamposi's six children also became involved in real estate, including the Citrus Hills project.
Mr. Tamposi has resigned from the boards of two banks and said in a recent interview that he was trying to help his children. The family has also been significant stockholders in some of New Hampshire's banks. While the substantial holdings of Mr. Tamposi do not appear to be in jeopardy and are not part of the loan negotiations, not all his real estate investments have proved to be winners.
One deal he struck in partnership with the Amoskeag Bank of Manchester, N.H., involved the joint ownership and development of a 14-story office building in West Palm Beach, Fla., and was financed by $16 million from the bank.
The building has lost money and is now owned by the bank. Amoskeag recently agreed to take it back from Mr. Tamposi and another partner in exchange for assuming all the debt, said Cathleen Maloney, a spokeswoman for the bank. The building is half empty and is valued at $13.5 million, but the resolution was fair to all parties, she said.
 
Politics
Longtime Ties With the G.O.P.

Like many real estate developers, Mr. Tamposi was politically active, raising money for Republican candidates and bringing Ted Williams to some party functions.
The list of those Republicans Mr. Tamposi has backed or raised money for includes President Bush, Senator Warren Rudman of New Hampshire and John H. Sununu, who served as New Hampshire's Governor for six years before joining the Bush Administration as White House chief of staff.
And Mr. Tamposi's daughter Elizabeth served in the New Hampshire legislature during some of Mr. Sununu's tenure as Governor. Now 36 years old, she was named assistant Secretary of State for consular affairs in 1989, after running unsuccessfully for Congress in 1988. Mr. Sununu endorsed her in that campaign.
From 1984 to 1989, Ms. Tamposi was also a director and borrowed heavily from what has since become First New Hampshire Bank, records show.
To help finance her campaign Ms. Tamposi borrowed $233,000 from a Nashua bank, Nashua Trust, where her father and brother served as directors.
Another $10,000 was borrowed from Nashua Trust on Dec. 13, 1988, three months after Ms. Tamposi lost the primary election. The day the money was borrowed, Ms. Tamposi's committee paid $10,165 to Mr. Sununu's gubernatorial campaign committee, mostly to repay a three-month-old debt for advertising services her committee had obtained from Mr. Sununu's committee, and also to buy an inventory of postage, said Edwin D. Duvall, treasurer of Mr. Sununu's committee, and Mr. Dougherty, the Tamposi family's lawyer.
Since deciding in June 1988 not to run for another term as Governor, Mr. Sununu has used his campaign fund to pay for his family's travel expenses, which is permissible under New Hampshire law.
Most of the Tamposi campaign loans have since been repaid, records show, but they were not properly disclosed until six months after the election ended. Mr. Dougherty said the reporting delay stemmed from a "misunderstanding of Federal Election Commission regulations."
About one month after the Presidential election in 1988, Ms. Tamposi sought a job in the Bush Administration, with the help of Senator Rudman and Mr. Sununu, she told the Senate in 1989 during her confirmation hearings for her current State Department post.
Mr. Rudman, who recently talked with the family about their financial situation, said their political connections carried no weight in debt negotiations.
"There is no way anybody is going to say, 'They're friends of powerful people, so be nice,' " he said, having called a reporter at the urging of the Tamposis.
 
The Lenders
Banks Are Moving To Collect

While the recession in New Hampshire real estate has been going on for some time, it was not until several months ago that the Tamposi children stopped making payments to their lenders.
According to court records in New Hampshire, lenders have provided more than $140 million to finance the business ventures of the Tamposi children.
Some family's holdings, like raw land near the Manchester airport, produce no income, while other ventures, like a 484-unit condominium project in Nashau, are not generating enough income to meet the interest payments on the loans the family took to finance the projects.
In addition, many banks, having provided the family millions of dollars in unsecured lines of credit, have moved in court to try to seize Tamposi real estate as collateral. If the family should seek protection under Federal bankruptcy law, a distinct possibility if the negotiations fail, the unsecured creditors would be last in line to recover their loans.
The banks are themselves under considerable pressure. A number of the state's largest banks no longer have any capital.
But the Tamposis have tried to keep the banks from moving too fast, arguing that a forced sale of their assets would leave a deficit of more than $15 million, according to court records.
A $5 million loan for one of the family's larger projects has already figured in the $2.5 billion collapse earlier this year of the Boston-based Bank of New England, making the Federal Government one of the family's creditors.
The loan for the Nashua condominium project became part of the bad loans taken over by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, according to public records and Mr. Dougherty. Earlier the agency rescued the bank and sold its good assets to the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc.
 
The Bank Rescue
The Federal Plan In New Hampshire

Fleet has a prospective role in the plan by the F.D.I.C. to rescue and reorganize New Hampshire's banking system.
Regulators say that under the plan, the F.D.I.C. would merge five of the state's largest banking organizations into two groups and inject capital, along with private investors.
Many of these banks, like Amoskeag, have been insolvent since last year but have remained open with the assistance of the Federal Government. "The F.D.I.C. position is that if the current management of the bank is acceptable and doing everything the F.D.I.C. would do if they were in the bank, and if the process is leading to an eventual resolution and is proceeding in an orderly way, why rush in," said Mr. Roberge, the state Banking Commissioner.
Amoskeag and its sister bank Nashua Trust have received waivers from the F.D.I.C. to use brokered deposits, which are large deposits brought in by outside brokers who are paid a fee by the bank. Under the 1989 legislation that rescued the savings and loan industry, troubled institutions were prohibited from using brokered deposits, which can increase an institution's costs, unless the agency grants them a waiver.
Amoskeag has also borrowed more than $125 million from the Federal Home Loan Bank of Boston, secured by home mortgages, and delivered $132 million in other collateral, including commercial loans, to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, in anticipation of further borrowing needs, according to bank filings.
The F.D.I.C.'s consolidation deal is expected to be completed in September. Another large banking company, the Bankeast Corporation, that is part of the F.D.I.C. deal, filed for protection under bankruptcy laws in October.
The other banks that are part of the consolidation plan are Dartmouth, Numerica Savings and New Hampshire Savings.
 
Negotiation
The Family Tries To Make a Deal

While the Tamposi family has been quietly working with lenders for months in an effort to reach some sort of agreement, it was not until some banks went to court to try to attach the family's assets that the negotiations became public.
Some of the court proceedings have been reported by New Hampshire newspapers, but the length of the moratorium the family is seeking has not been mentioned in the news reports.
In one court filing, the Bank of New Hampshire said in June that a month earlier "the Tamposis requested forebearance and interest concessions from the bank and further represented that no payments would be made to the bank until Dec. 31, 1995."
Referring to the deal that is being worked out, the bank said: "The plan seeks to transfer the Tamposi's interests in over 75 entities and 250 assets into a plan administered by the Tamposis on behalf of their creditors."
Mr. Dougherty said that despite the motions by some New Hampshire banks, "all signs point to having an agreement in the next several weeks."
Other New Hampshire businessmen say they are not being offered such a moratorium by the state's banks.
"There is a general atmosphere among members of the business community; it is generally recognized that the Amoskeag Bank has been extremely difficult to arrive at a forebearance, a workout, or negotiations," said Frank Yanco, an auto dealer in Manchester who is involved in a lawsuit with the bank.
The bank's spokeswoman, Ms. Maloney, said, "We try to work out each situation separately; they are looked at on a case-by-case basis."
That is not much consolation for John E. Pearson, a large New Hampshire developer and former partner of the Tamposis who is now in litigation with them and some banks.
Last week Mr. Pearson sent a letter about the concessions being sought by the Tamposis to a bank managing bad loans made to both the Tamposis and one of Mr. Pearson's ventures.
"I do not have any political connections that could intercede on my behalf," he wrote. "However, I feel in all fairness that we are due equal treatment."
Mr. Dougherty, the Tamposi lawyer, said the family was not seeking any special favors.
He described their plan this way: "The plan anticipates an orderly sale of the present assets of the Tamposi family group over a period of four and a half years up to and including Dec. 31, 1995" and is "designed to maximize returns to creditors" though there is "no requirement of payment on a particular date other than Dec. 31, 1995."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Cut as Labor Dropouts Rise

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate dropped slightly last month, not because more people had jobs but because people dropped out of the labor market.
As a result, the Labor Department's monthly employment report, released today, the first comprehensive data about the state of the economy in July, was inconclusive. It showed mainly what economists already knew: that the economy was not growing at a robust pace. 
 Janet L. Norwood, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, observed that the unemployment rate last month, 6.8 percent, and the number of people employed, 116.7 million, were the same as in March, and she cautioned against drawing firm conclusions from the month-to-month fluctuations.
 
'Little Clear Direction'
 "Changes in the labor market continued to show little clear direction in July," she told the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.
The unemployment rate was two-tenths of a percentage point less than the 7 percent rate in June, the highest in five years. Seasonally adjusted, 8.5 million people were officially out of work last month, 1.6 million more than in July 1990, the month the recession is said to have begun.
Economists tend to look first at the number of people employed, rather than the number unemployed, because the former is a better measure of economic growth. An erratic pattern of job growth, up one month and down the next, is typical for the early stages of a recovery.
 
Payroll Decline of 51,000
 The number of people with jobs grew in May and June, but as measured by the Bureau of Labor Statistics survey of households, 172,000 fewer people had jobs in July than in June. By another measure, a survey of businesses, the number of people on payrolls fell by 51,000 last month.
Some economists predicted that the weak employment figures and a slight decrease in hourly earnings last month, an indication that inflation is under control, would convince the Federal Reserve that it should reduce interest rates for the first time since April. On Wall Street, bond prices rose rapidly today in anticipation of lower rates.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has described the central bank's posture as one of "watchful waiting" to see how fast the economy pulled out of the recession and whether inflation was tamed.
Predictably, the Bush Administration viewed the inconclusive figures as a glass half full. "I don't read the unemployment news as anything but very good news for the American people," President Bush said at a news conference.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said he was pleased because a decline in the unemployment rate was "a major Administration priority." He added that the Fed should certainly lower rates if the nation's money supply did not soon begin to grow faster.
Democrats naturally took the half-empty glass approach. "A falling unemployment rate caused by a sharp rise in labor force dropouts, in my opinion, is no evidence of a healthy economy," said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee.
Private economists were mildly disappointed by the decline in employment.
Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said the firmest conclusion he could draw was that the economy was "slow to recover from the recession," but he added that the new figures did not mean the recovery had stalled.
John M. Albertine, the head of an economic forecasting and consulting company in Washington, said the new data showed that the economy was "sputtering along at a very slow speed."
The drop in unemployment came primarily among blacks and women, but the black rate, 11.8 percent, remained almost twice as high as the white rate, 6.2 percent. Dr. Norwood, the Labor Statistics Commissioner, observed that the fall in the rate for women resulted almost entirely from women who stopped looking for jobs and thus were not counted as unemployed.
The number of construction jobs fell by 22,000, an indication that the recession in real estate has not abated.

HEADLINE: Pan Am Plans to Dismiss 5,000 Employees

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
More than a fifth of the employees of Pan American World Airways will lose their jobs in the next few weeks, the troubled carrier said yesterday.
Pan Am, which is operating under Federal Bankruptcy Court protection and is in the process of selling most of its assets, said it would dismiss 5,000 of its 22,300 employees worldwide "in all work categories." About 10,500 of Pan Am's entire work force, nearly half, works in New York, and it could not be learned yesterday how many of those jobs would be spared. 
 A spokesman for the airline, Jeffrey Kriendler, acknowledged that the cuts go deeper than the usual yearly reduction after the peak summer season. "We are going to be cutting schedules unrelated to any future asset sales to reflect what we feel will be continued soft demand in the fall," he said.
Yesterday, the carrier's parent company, the Pan Am Corporation, released its second-quarter results, which showed that the company lost $125.3 million on an operating basis in a period when traffic and profits usually pick up and that it netted $99.9 million, counting a $260 million one-time gain from its sale of London routes and other assets to United Airlines. The airline had an operating loss of $8.5 million and a net loss of $49 million for the quarter last year. Revenues for the recent quarter were $721.2 million, down 29.3 percent from the $1.02 billion posted last year.
Affected employees will be notified starting Monday, Mr. Kriendler said. Asked where the cutbacks would be concentrated, he said they would hit management the hardest.
But George Miranda, a vice president of Local 732 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents 5,400 reservation agents and other Pan Am workers, said he would be surprised if management bore the brunt.
"I'd like to see that," he said. "I haven't seen that in any previous layoffs. Maybe it's about time."
Though job losses had been expected for some time because of the airline's dire straits, union officials took the news hard.
"Five thousand is a big number," Mr. Miranda said. "We don't lay off 5,000 every year. Under normal circusmtances, you may get some adjustments, 100 here or 200 there, as you adjust your schedule, but 5,000 -- this is a major layoff."
The announcement also comes at a time when New York's economy is already losing thousands of other jobs to bank mergers and when its once-thriving financial-services sector is shrinking.
Certainly, the prospect of a deep thinning of the ranks at Pan Am is only likely to turn up the heat on Pan Am's management to look hard at how many of its remaining 17,300 jobs would be preserved under various competing offers it has received for its route system.
 
Outlook Under Delta's Offer
 The offer it has tentatively accepted from Delta Air Lines would save 6,500 jobs and possibly another 6,500 or so if Delta and Pan Am come to terms on a plan, partly financed by Delta, that would allow Pan Am to reorganize as a smaller airline flying mostly to Latin America.
United, by contrast, has offered to hire 2,500 of Pan Am's employees as part of its deal and to give priority to another 2,000 if industry conditions permit it to expand its work force in the future.
American Airlines so far has refused to bid on Pan Am alone, because it has a well-known aversion to any deal in which it would have to hire and assimilate large numbers of unionized employees from a competing carrier.
For that reason, American has teamed up with Trans World Airlines, which so far is talking about saving at least 14,500 jobs. T.W.A.'s proposal, however, would also appear to have the harshest impact on the New York region, since Pan Am's and T.W.A.'s operations at Kennedy International Airport duplicate each other and would be ripe for paring.
"We would hope whoever wins out has a plan of reorganization around the Latin American division," said Mr. Miranda, who represents his union on Pan Am's creditors committee. Such a plan would presumably save the most jobs.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bonds Rise Sharply On Jobs Data

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose sharply yesterday after a weaker-than-expected employment report for July gave rise to hopes for lower interest rates, with or without a push by the Federal Reserve.
The buoyancy of the Treasury market quickly spread to the corporate sector, inspiring a flurry of new offerings by corporate treasurers eager to take advantage of good investor demand. By the end of the day, new corporate issues totaling $1.05 billion were offered by Tenneco, the Shell Oil Company, the Norwest Financial Corporation, the Sonoco Products Company and Dillard Department Stores. 
 In the continuing debate about the strength of the economic recovery, analysts said yesterday's report of a decline of 51,000 in non-farm payrolls during July was evidence of a weak economy. But they added that the signs were not dramatic enough to prove that the recovery was stalled or to show a clear need for a quick move by the Federal Reserve to push down short-term rates.
 
Long-Term Rates Down
 "The problem for the economy is not with short-term rates, the area where lower rates would be a big help is in the long-term market," said Donald Fine, an economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank. He said the Fed would want more evidence of a faltering economy before pushing short-term rates lower, and that meanwhile, long-term interest rates had declined without any Fed move.
The yield on long-term Treasury bonds, which serves as a benchmark for fixed-rate mortgages and corporate bonds, fell yesterday to 8.24 percent, the lowest level since late May and down from 8.38 percent a week ago. By late in the day the closely watched 8 1/8 percent Treasury bond due in 2021 was offered at 98 22/32, up 1 6/32, or $11.87 for a $1,000 bond, and its yield had fallen from 8.35 percent a day earlier. In advance of next Tuesday's auction of three-year Treasury notes, securities dealers offered the issue to large institutions with a yield of 7.01 percent, down from 7.15 percent. The 10-year Treasury notes to be sold on Wednesday were at 8.03 percent, down from 8.15 percent.
"The employment data raise some questions about the sustainability of the economy's expansion, and increase the possibility of another easing in monetary policy," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh. But he added that declines in payrolls in the early stages of a recovery were not unusual and that upward adjustments to payrolls reported yesterday for June and May "show that the employment picture recently is really more flat than down."
A weaker economy, which is associated with slack credit demand and low inflation, results in lower bond yields, as investors and traders buy bonds in expectation of lower interest rates and higher bond prices.
There were no signs yesterday of a change in Fed policy, as the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market continued to hover around its recent average of 5 3/4 percent. The overnight rate is closely controlled by the Fed and is a benchmark for other short-term interest rates. But the absence of any signals of a change in Fed policy did not prevent securities dealers and other speculators from pushing up prices of Treasury bills enough to lower the rate for the three-month issue to 5.47 percent from 5.54 percent.
Among new corporate offerings, Tenneco's notes due in 1998 were so avidly sought at a yield of 10 percent that the size of the issue was increased to $500 million from $300 million. The notes were rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and offered through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company with a yield 2.1 percentage points higher than comparable Treasury notes.
A $250 million issue of the Shell Oil Company's 7 1/8 percent notes due in 1994 was offered at 99.746, to yield 7.22 percent, by a Lehman Brothers group. The notes, which are expected to be rated triple-A, did not sell as briskly yesterday as other new issues because they offered only 22-hundredths of a percentage point more in yield than three-year Treasury notes.
Smaller offerings included a $100 million issue of Dillard Department Stores A-2/A+ rated 9 1/8 percent debentures due in 2011, offered through Morgan Stanley with a yield of 9.195 percent, and $100 million of the Norwest Financial Corporation's Aa-3/A+ rated 8 1/2 percent notes due in 1998, offered with a yield of 8.625 percent through Merrill Lynch. The Sonoco Products Company's $100 million issue of 9.2 percent bonds due in 2021, rated A-2/A+, was offered with a yield of 9.208 percent through J. P. Morgan Securities.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
The Senate Banking Committee narrowly approved a measure to overhaul the nation's banking laws in a way significantly different from either the measure proposed by the Bush Administration or the one passed by the House Banking Committee. [Page 33.] 
 The U.S. unemployment rate dropped slightly last month, to 6.8 percent, not be cause more people had jobs but because peo ple dropped out of the labor market. As a re sult, the Labor Department's monthly report was inconclusive. It showed mainly what economists already knew: that the economy was not growing at a robust pace. [7.]
 Congress sent President Bush a $5.8 bil lion measure to aid people who remain unemployed for more than half a year, a total of about three million Americans. [1.]
 A prominent Republican family in New Hampshire with close ties to the White House is hoping to stave off the imminent collapse of its real estate empire, and it says it is close to reaching an agreement on a four-and-a-half-year moratorium on repaying more than $100 million it borrowed from New England lenders. [33.]
 Defying the national trend, Santa Fe's hotel business has been roaring, chalking up impressive occupancy rates while vacancy signs are going up in most of the rest of the country. [33.]
 A 90-year-old woman had no doubts about Keating's guilt as his trial began. Screaming "You took all my money," she shook him by the lapels in the courtroom before being hustled away. [35.]
 
Companies
More than a fifth of Pan Am's employees will lose their jobs in the next few weeks. Pan Am said it would dismiss 5,000 of its 22,300 employees worldwide "in all work categories." [33.]
 Metropolitan Life and Prudential said they would probably assume some of Mutual Benefit's liabilities related to life insurance, annuities and other obligations. [33.]
 McDonnell Douglas lost an order for up to 20 jets said to be worth $2 billion from Singapore Airlines, which chose Airbus. [35.]
 
International
Several reports about B.C.C.I.'s illegal activities were disseminated by the C.I.A. to other Federal agencies in the early 80's even as the agency was using the bank to finance operations abroad, a senior C.I.A. official and other U.S. Government officials said. [34.]
 Peruvian Government officials detailed how B.C.C.I. assisted in a secret effort to hide Peru's money from creditors in 1986. [34.]
 
Markets
Treasury bond prices rose sharply after a weak employment report gave rise to hopes for lower interest rates, with or without a push by the Federal Reserve. [33.]
 Blue-chip stocks fell slightly for the second day after a three-day advance, with the Dow ending at 3,006.26, off 11.41 for the day but up 33.76 for the week. [40.]
 The dollar fell sharply in heavy trading after the release of a report that indicated that U.S. companies continued to lay off workers in July. [42.]
 Precious metal futures prices fell sharply, with platinum leading the decline in reaction to heavy Japanese selling, fears of Soviet selling and perceptions that industrial demand is fading. [42.]

 People should examine their disability coverage to see if it is sufficient and see what else may be available to them, financial advisers say. Your Money. [34.]
 A line of jackets and skirts that can each be flipped four ways, which together form 16 possible mix-and-match combinations, has been invented by a husband-and-wife team. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: BAKER MAKES CASE TO 3 PALESTINIANS FOR OCTOBER TALKS

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Armed with Israel's conditional agreement to a Middle East peace conference, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today sought to convince the Palestinians, the last party yet to agree, that even if they accepted Israel's terms they still stood to gain the most from the process.
Mr. Baker first met for four hours with three prominent Palestinians in Jerusalem, then flew to the Jordanian capital, Amman, for talks with King Hussein. Under the American plan, the Palestinians would take part in the first stage of the peace conference in a delegation with Jordan. 
 A quick agreement between the Palestinians and Mr. Baker had not been expected since, as the Palestinian group made plain, they did not have the authority to accept or reject the restrictions on Palestinian participation raised by the Israelis.
That decision, both the Palestinians and Arab leaders agreed, must come from the Palestine Liberation Organization, which despite disarray remains the principal umbrella organization for most Palestinians in and out of Israel.
"It's a question of principle and who has the right to form the Palestinian delegation," said Prof. Hanan Ashrawi, a participant in the talks with Mr. Baker. "This is only the P.L.O. and the Palestinian people. Who has the right to interfere, to dictate, to veto? No one."
The Secretary said he tried to impress on the Palestinians that "in our view, the Palestinians have more to gain from a viable and active peace process than do almost anyone else."
 
'The Most to Lose'
 "Further to that," he added, "in our view at least, Palestinians have the most to lose if there is no process.
"So the United States at least, we are very hopeful that Palestinians will determine that they want to be part of this process and that they will determine that they want to take advantage of His Majesty's offer here of an umbrella in the form of a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation."
Speaking at a news conference alongside King Hussein at the King's summer palace outside Amman, Mr. Baker indicated that a resolution of the problem was not imminent and that work on it would continue "over the course of the next few weeks."
So far, the P.L.O. has not budged, but the Palestinians, Mr. Baker and King Hussein all insisted that the peace process had not derailed.
"I can say that we are working on everything to move the obstacle put in front of us," said Faisal al-Husseini, who spoke with Mr. Baker. The third Palestinian in the talks, Zakaria al-Agha, did not speak to reporters.
Mr. Baker described the meeting as a "very serious engagement" and said he was "pleased" with it.
The question of how the Palestinians should be represented has emerged as the last and stickiest in the Bush Administration's campaign to bring Israel face to face with its Arab adversaries, because it touches on fundamental principles in the bitter dispute between Israel and the Palestinians.
 
October Goal
 At their summit meeting in Moscow earlier this week, Presidents Bush and Gorbachev announced that they would try to convene an inaugural international conference by October.
On Thursday, Israel agreed to attend on the condition that the Palestinian representatives not include members of the P.L.O., stateless Palestinians or Palestinians from East Jerusalem.
For Israel's conservative Government, Palestinians from Jerusalem or elsewhere would implicitly raise property claims and question Israel's control over East Jerusalem, which the Israelis deem non-negotiable.
For the Palestinians, restricted representation would imply accepting a dependent status and suspending claims to former homes and to East Jerusalem. In Mr. Baker's view, the Palestinians' stand on principle has worsened their plight through all previous efforts at negotiating a settlement, dating to the creation of Israel.
Reporters traveling with the Secretary were reminded of the remark by the Israeli statesman Abba Eban that "the Palestinians never pass up an opportunity to pass up an opportunity," and Mr. Baker believes that the Palestinians have a chance to prove this wrong. Mr. Baker's argument was that with every passing crisis, the Palestinians have found themselves less united, more scattered and ever less welcome in other Arab countries.
While Egypt regained the Sinai through willingness to establish relations with Israel, Palestinian forces were chased from Jordan and Lebanon, tens of thousands remained in refugee districts and Israel became ever more rooted in occupied territory.
By accepting at least partly the hard realities of the region and joining in the peace process, the Palestinians stood to gain at least a measure of sovereignty and security.
 
Jordan's Palestinians
 Mr. Baker has refused to divulge any possible compromises discussed with the Palestinians. But Arab and Israeli newspapers have suggested that the Palestinians could be represented by Palestinians with Jordanian or other citizenship. Jordan, in particular, has many Palestinians in high positions, including Prime Minister Taher Masri.
According to the American blueprint for the Middle East conference, an opening session of one or two days would be co-chaired by the United States and the Soviet Union and attended by observers from the United Nations and the European Community.
That would create an international framework in which Israel and its neighbors -- Syria, Lebanon and a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation -- would sit down to separate talks.
On the Palestinian issue, the first stage of the talks would deal with Palestinian self-rule in the occupied territories. Part of the problem is that any Palestinian who agrees to join the conference without P.L.O. sanction would do so at risk to his or her life.
Reporters with Mr. Baker were told that he appreciated "the large element of personal courage" required of the Palestinians in this process.
In the latest effort, the Palestinians have found themselves alone. All other Arab states involved have agreed to attend, and Saudi Arabia has given its endorsement to the process.
 
'Comprehensive Settlement'
 King Hussein has been particularly eager for the Palestinians to join, since his participation in the process has brought him under criticism from hard-liners in his Parliament for abandoning the Palestinian cause.
At the news conference today, the King said, "The time has come, hopefully, for Palestinians to decide in view of all the circumstances and opportunities the moment presents on their participation in efforts for a comprehensive settlement." The King has pinned hopes on the peace process to lift the political and economic penalties imposed by the United States over his pro-Iraqi stance in the Persian Gulf crisis.
Mr. Baker's visit coincided with the anniversary of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the publication of a "white paper" by the Jordanian Government in which it sought to explain and justify its position. The document tried to show that Jordan opposed the acquisition of territory by force, and that King Hussein wrote President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warning that aggression could prompt Israeli retaliation.
 
'You Will Understand'
 "I still believe maybe one day you will understand what our position was," King Hussein told the news conference today, citing some of the arguments in the "white paper."
Jordan's support for the peace process has brought moves by the Administration to restore some of the military and economic aid frozen last year.
"I told his majesty that the President had executed the determination required under our legislation to make it possible to reinstitute some of the programs which we had ongoing which were suspended by legislation, and we discussed that subject in some detail," Mr. Baker said. Alluding to the King's domestic problems with the peace process, Mr. Baker praised him for showing "the courage you have demonstrated in the past."
On Saturday, Mr. Baker will meet with Prime Minister Masri and then fly to Morocco to start a two-day visit to Morocco, Tunisia and Algeria.

HEADLINE: Saudi Financier Quits Beirut Rebuilding Plan

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 2

 BODY:
A Saudi financier who had expressed willingness to invest millions of dollars in the reconstruction of Beirut has backed out, citing Government corruption, officials here say.
The businessman, Rafik Hariri, who is of Lebanese origin, had proposed to set up a joint venture company of landowners and investors to rebuild downtown Beirut. According to his plan, a modern complex of towers and tunnels was to be put up on the Green Line, the battered area in the central city that served as a dividing line between the city's mainly Muslim and Christian halves for the last 15 years. 
 But Mr. Hariri backed out on his offer recently, asserting that some Government ministers and deputies were blackmailing him for commissions and briberies in exchange for their support. He was not specific about his charges.
American diplomatic officials said they thought Mr. Hariri backed off because of Saudi Arabia's desire to keep its money from pouring into Lebanon before the country fully recovers from the civil war. They fear the money would be wasted like it was after the 1982 invasion of the country.
Lebanon has turned to the task of rebuilding after the Government of President Elias Hrawi, with the support of about 40,000 Syrian soldiers, started to reassert control over the nation under a reconciliation pact reached in late 1989 under Arab mediation in the Saudi resort of Taif.
Economists said Mr. Hariri's decision was a severe blow to any chance for reviving Lebanon's collapsing economy and caused panic in Beirut's money market.
 
Lebanese Pound Drops
 After the news was reported here, the value of the Lebanese pound fell against the United States dollar, from 850 to 900, the central bank said.
Mr. Hariri, who is 56 years old, is from a fisherman's family in the southern city of Sidon. A former school teacher, he traveled to Saudi Arabia to work there and became close to the ruling family and was entrusted with some of their businesses. He then started his own construction company there and his business flourished. He he is now considered the richest man in the Middle East, according to An Nahar, a Beirut newspaper.
Mr. Hariri has done previous reconstruction work in Beirut, and has contributed large amounts of money to the Government. President Elias Hrawi lives in Mr. Hariri's appartment in West Beirut, and Mr. Hariri pays for Mr. Hrawi's bodyguards. He has also been paying the residency costs of the Syrian officers who are entrusted to keep order in Beirut since 1987.
Former Prime Minister Salim al-Hoss, an economist, said Mr. Hariri's withdrawal was an economic and moral blow to efforts to restore peace to the country.
Economists estimated that Mr. Hariri's departure represented a loss in opportunity of some $7 billion.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT IS SENT MEASURE TO WIDEN JOBLESS BENEFITS

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Congress today sent President Bush a $5.8 billion measure to aid people who remain unemployed for more than half a year, a total of about three million Americans.
But Mr. Bush is expected to keep the extended benefits from flowing, according to White House aides and Republican lawmakers. Mr. Bush would not commit himself at a news conference, but he warned against increasing the Federal budget deficit. 
 Before the House passed it on a 375 to 45 vote this afternoon, Democrats appealed to Mr. Bush to sign it and also to make the accompanying declaration of emergency that is required under last year's budget act for the bill to go into effect because of its impact on the deficit. The legislation cleared the Senate by voice vote Thursday night.
 
'Sign the Bill'
 "Sign the bill, declare the emergency, use your enormous power to help the people who elected you," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
The bill cleared Congress a few hours after the Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate dropped slightly last month, to 6.8 percent from 7 percent. But the report showed that the reason for the improvement was that more people had dropped out of the labor market, not that more workers had jobs. [Page 7.]
As they had ever since they seized on the extended-benefits issue last week, Democrats berated Mr. Bush, asserting that he was more interested in disaster victims abroad than at home. Citing the emergencies that the President has urged Congress to accept, involving the Kurds, Bangladesh and Egypt, Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the incoming Democratic whip, told the House it was now time to help "American middle-income families who are suffering."
 
Little Response From G.O.P.
 In contrast, Republicans had little to say and did not use all their allotted debate time before the vote. Representative Jerry Lewis, of California and chairman of the Republican Conference, said, "Democrats had plenty of time to change the law" when the recession was more severe and should have acted sooner if they were serious.
Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, said, "Their real emergency with long-term unemployment is the long-term unemployment of their Presidential candidates."
At his news conference, which began soon before the House acted, Mr. Bush said, "The last thing we want to do is break the budget agreement and spend outside to increase the deficit." The President couched his answer with optimism about the economy and said the lower unemployment level for July was "very good news."
A White House spokesman said the current plan was for Mr. Bush to sign the bill but not issue the emergency declaration. Such a strategy would allow the President to avoid a veto and with it the continuing public attention that would accompany the Congressional votes to override.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the senior Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, said it was "unlikely" that Mr. Bush would issue the emergency declaration.
 
Paying for the Benefits
 The bill would cover the period from Sept. 1 through July 4. It would provide benefits beyond the basic 26 weeks' unemployment compensation much more widely than under current law. To pay for the new benefits, the Government would draw from an $8 billion Federal trust fund.
Under current law, benefits can be extended for 13 weeks in a state when joblessness among its workers who are covered by unemployment insurance reaches 6 percent. The benefits can also be extended when the rate reaches 5 percent if the level of the insured jobless exceeds by one-fifth the average level in that state over the last two years.
The unemployment rate among those covered by insurance, about half of the workforce, is much lower than the total unemployment rate. As a result, only in Alaska, Maine, Rhode Island and Puerto Rico are extended benefits now being paid.
Under the bill, the measuring standard used would be total unemployment, not insured unemployment. In states with 8 percent unemployment, averaged over the last six months, an additional 20 weeks of benefits could be paid. If the law were in effect today, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi and West Virginia would be added to the list of states that now qualify.
In states with 7 percent unemployment, an extra 13 weeks of benefits could be paid. The nation's two most populous states, New York and California, are among 13 that would qualify.
In states with 6 percent unemployment, an additional 7 weeks of benefits could be paid;, and in all other states an additional 4 weeks could be paid.
The other major change provided by the bill would be permanent rather than expire next July. It would make people who leave the armed services eligible for 26 weeks of benefits, instead of the current 13 weeks. They would also be able to start collecting after one week instead of the current four. Under both changes, they would be treated like civilians.
Democrats in the House disputed Mr. Bush's conclusion that the recession was ending, noting that the main reason for the decline in the unemployment rate was that many workers had given up trying to find jobs.
But the Democrats also argued that unemployment would remain high for some time even if the economy turned up and that as many as 300,000 workers would exhaust their regular 26 weeks of benefits each month. And they assailed Richard G. Darman, the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, for saying earlier this week that too generous an unemployment system encouraged people to stay out of work.
"It's Republican macho that the unemployed enjoy unemployment," said Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, the bill's principal House sponsor.
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said Mr. Darman's remark was "in the worst tradition of stand-aside attitudes on the part of people in government."
Mr. Foley told a news conference that if the President did not implement the extended benefits, "we are going to be right back here in September with another bill." And Mr. Gephardt said that the House might pass a bill then that did not allow the President to sign it and then nullify it by refusing to issue an emergency declaration.
The bill that passed today is expected to be delivered to the White House formally on Monday. That would give Mr. Bush until Aug. 15 to act, or it would become law without his signature. But it would have no effect unless he issued the emergency declaration.

HEADLINE: Bush Says Only Bad Health Would Bar Candidacy in '92

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
President Bush all but announced his intention to seek re-election at a Rose Garden news conference today, saying that only a change in his health would deter him from seeking a second term.
Mr. Bush then tested a potential campaign theme by accusing a "frustratingly negative" Congress of blocking his domestic legislative agenda. 
 As if determined to allay any lingering concerns about his health, Mr. Bush declared, "I feel like a million dollars," and said he was extraordinarily "blessed" for a man of 67.
The remarks, his first since his return last night from the Soviet Union, were aimed at Democrats who this week accused him of abandoning social and financial problems at home for the glitter of global summitry.
 
Initially Coy About Plans
 When asked about his re-election plans, Mr. Bush was initially coy, saying he had not decided whether to try for a second term and might not do so until next year. But moments later, he added that he knew of nothing that would stop him from making such a bid.
"I'll be honest, the only thing would be a health problem, and I don't have one right now," Mr. Bush said. "But, I mean it wouldn't be fair to the American people to ask to be re-elected knowing that you, in your heart of hearts, might feel you couldn't finish the job. But I don't feel that way."
With that comment, Mr. Bush edged close to making the formal announcement that he said he would make early next year. Although incumbent Presidents are usually reticent about announcing for a second term, Mr. Bush's strong hint may have been intended to scotch rumors among some Bush family friends that his wife, Barbara, might oppose a second term for health reasons.
The President stressed his feeling several times that he had fully recovered from the heart arrhythmia and thyroid problems he experienced in the spring. The White House later said that Mr. Bush had been examined by his doctor, Burton Lee, and pronounced in "excellent health."
The President said he would discuss his prospects for a second term with his Washington political advisers this weekend at the Presidential retreat in Camp David, Md.
The White House press office declined to disclose who would attend that meeting, saying Mr. Bush did not wish to publicly embarrass anyone left out.
Associates of Mr. Bush said that the meeting was to be an informal gathering meant to convey the message that the President was serious about preparing for a second term and that no one should be lulled into overconfidence by his current political popularity.
Those associates later said that a mix of Mr. Bush's current advisers and veterans of his 1980 and 1988 races for the White House would go to Camp David. They included Robert Teeter, Mr. Bush's pollster; Frederic V. Malek, an airline executive and longtime political friend; Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher; Vice President Dan Quayle; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Ronald Kaufman, a White House staff member and political adviser; Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter; Jeannie Austin, co-chairwoman of the Republican National Committee; Craig L. Fuller, who headed Mr. Bush's staff when he was Vice President, and Mr. Bush's current chief of staff, John H. Sununu.
 
Attacks on Congress
 Mr. Bush appeared to revel in the back-and-forth about his political plans. Asked when he would announce his re-election plans, the President answered, "Well, I want to get some opinion from all these gurus with whom I'll be surrounded here." Then he added: "Maybe January, I don't know. It's just -- please don't write 'maybe January' down. It may be February. It may be March. I don't know."
But he reserved most of his energy for attacking Congressional Democrats, who have begun criticizing what they say is his apparent lack of sustained interest in domestic problems like welfare reform and economic policy and who have begun to make political issues of his record on matters like civil rights, abortion and drug control.
Recent public opinion polls have suggested that while the public believes Mr. Bush can handle national security matters more effectively than his Democratic critics, the Democrats are seen as better able to deal with domestic issues like the environment and education.
At one point, Mr. Bush turned from the crowd of reporters in front of him to the television cameras recording his news conference, making his point directly to viewers.
"So please, American people -- let me look over this way -- please, do not listen to the charges by frantic Democrats who are trying to say we don't have a domestic policy, when we have a very good one," he said.
As prime examples of his Administration's interest in domestic matters, Mr. Bush cited his initiatives on civil rights, education and housing, although the Senator who has been trying to work out a compromise with the White House on civil rights legislation, John C. Danforth of Missouri, has failed in his effort.
Later, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Ronald H. Brown, attacked Mr. Bush for opposing the civil rights legislation and a Democratic proposal to extend unemployment benefits for about three million jobless people.
"While the Soviets, the Syrians and the Chinese get an animated George Bush ready to cut deals and get things done, back home on the domestic front, he's just the veto man," Mr. Brown said in a written statement.
Mr. Bush called the charges part of "a concerted liberal Democratic attack on the President" and suggested that he would mount a stiff counterattack after returning from his vacation at his home in Kennebunkport, Me., the day after Labor Day. He indicated that he would use his attack on the Democrats in campaign trips this fall for Republican candidates for Congress.
"Wait till you see me come back after August, after I'm rested up a little, to take on these fellows," Mr. Bush said.
