HEADLINE: Philadelphia Journal;
Egan for Mayor. Ah, but Which One?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL DeCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The Republican City Committee met one night this week in Palumbo's Nostalgia Room in South Philadelphia to nominate a candidate to replace Frank L. Rizzo, who died of a heart attack last month in the middle of his fifth mayoral campaign. But everybody already knew that the new candidate had been selected, though there has been much confusion involving his name and exactly who he is.
Earlier this week, William A. Meehan, the last big-city Republican Party boss in America, gave his endorsement and, for all practical purposes, that was that. The rest was cigar smoke. "I've never lost a roll-call vote, but there is always a first time," Mr. Meehan, a 66-year-old lawyer, predicted Thursday afternoon, just before the ward leaders voted unanimously to accept his choice. (Never mind that the Republicans have not had a mayoral victory since 1947 and have won only a few citywide races in those years.) 
 Mr. Meehan endorsed, and the Republican ward leaders nominated, Joseph J. Egan, a commercial real estate broker, as the choice to lead the party's ticket Nov. 5 against the Democratic mayoral candidate, Edward G. Rendell, a former Philadelphia District Attorney.
But it would not be Pennsylvania politics this year without a lawsuit to scramble things.
On Thursday, a civic leader filed a suit in Federal District Court saying the city Republican Party's nominating process was undemocratic and unconstitutional. The suit comes at a time when the Federal Courts are considering challenges to the state's elections laws dealing with Congressional races.
There is also confusion about the Republican candidate. Mr. Egan, like many recent Republican mayoral candidates, is a former Democrat, and this year he was running for a seat on the City Council in his first attempt at an elected office.
Many people erroneously think Mr. Egan is another Egan, the Egan who twice before, in 1983 and 1987, ran unsuccessful Republican mayoral campaigns. The confusion increased when the lesser-known Mr. Egan introduced the well-known John J. Egan, the two-time loser, as his campaign adviser this week.
"I know Egan, he ran for mayor before," a police detective said this week, confusing, as many do, the well-known Egan with the lesser-known Egan. "I wish him luck, whoever he is," he added. The detective, who was taking a walk downtown during his lunch break, said he did not want to give his name. But he said it was not Egan.
A spark of controversy helped clear the air a bit when the well-known Egan announced Wednesday that he would not become the lesser-known Egan's campaign manager after all, because of a perceived conflict of interest. It seems that the well-known Egan is a member of the new nonpartisan financial oversight board, which the State Legislature created to help Philadelphia out of its fiscal crisis. Democrats, including state legislators, said that because board members would be passing judgment on the next mayor's budgets, board members should not be running a mayoral candidate's campaign.
Will the name confusion help or hinder Mr. Egan's campaign? "There is a benefit there, but it's negligible," the candidate said in an interview on Thursday. Mr. Egan said he was putting together a campaign staff and was trying to raise $1.5 million for the 14-week campaign.
By comparison, Mr. Rendell spent $1.8 million in the primary and is preparing to spend $2.2 million to $2.5 million in the general election, said David L. Cohen, Mr. Rendell's campaign manager. "Egans, Egans, everywhere, but we're treating any candidate the Republicans nominate as a serious threat," said Mr. Cohen, adding that Mr. Rendell was vacationing in Bermuda.
Political analysts say the Republicans are giving the election away. "Joe Egan has no name recognition, no previous citywide campaign experience, no money and no campaign organization," said David Buffington, editor of the Pennsylvania Report, a political newsletter. "No way can he enter the race at this late date and be, even remotely, a credible candidate."
Candidate Egan is a native Philadelphian, a high school graduate who worked his way up to partner in a major real estate brokerage. He has also served as president of the Philadelphia Industrial Development Corporation, a quasi-public economic development agency. He is married, has three adult children and describes himself as "a results guy, a coalition builder."
The theme of his campaign, he continued, would be "change." He also said he planned to pick up where Mr. Rizzo left off with his law-and-order theme.
The rest of his campaign platform, as he described it, is identical, even in its vagueness, to Mr. Rizzo's. If elected, Mr. Egan said he would hire more police officers, reduce spending on social services and bring better management to government without turning over city services to private companies, a major campaign issue this year.
To help the electorate sort out the Egans, Candidate Egan, who is 57 years old, gave this tip: "I'm younger and better looking than John Egan."
To which John Egan, who is 48, responded: "Joe must have been kidding."

HEADLINE: Sweeping Health Care Bill Drafted, Charting Path for Congress Next Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today introduced a bill that would essentially set price controls for health care services, lower the age of eligibility for Medicare to 60 and impose new taxes to finance health insurance for millions of Americans who lack such protection.
Neither Mr. Rostenkowski's bill nor a similar measure offered by Senate Democratic leaders is likely to be enacted this year. But they provide a road map for Congressional action in 1992 or 1993, and they stake out a political position from which Democrats plan to chide President Bush and other Republicans in the 1992 campaign. 
 The Administration has been studying the issue since February 1990, but appears to be internally divided on how best to help the 34 million people who have no health insurance.
Mr. Rostenkowski, a Democrat from Illinois, would gradually reduce the eligibility age for Medicare to 60 from 65, to cover the many workers who retire early. Aides to the Congressman estimated that this change, when fully effective, would cost $25 billion a year. The Census Bureau says there are more than 10.5 million people from 60 to 64 years old.
 
A Price-Control Approach
 Mr. Rostenkowski's bill rejects proposals for national health insurance monopolized by the Government, calling instead for the Government to establish price ceilings so that health spending would grow at roughly the same rate as the gross national product, the total output of goods and services, starting in 2001. In recent years, health spending has grown much faster than the economy as a whole, partly because of the growing number of elderly people and partly because of life-saving improvements in medical technology.
The Ways and Means panel originates tax legislation and is responsible for Medicare, so Mr. Rostenkowski is in a strong position to influence any change in the nation's health-care system. He said he would hold hearings on his bill in October, and he emphasized that he was open to suggestions for improving it.
"There is no more important problem confronting our country today than health care," Mr. Rostenkowski said in introducing his proposal. "It is time to abandon the catchy slogans and gear up for the legislative long march."
But he said, "Absent Presidential leadership, we will not be able to achieve a major reform of the health-care system." He said he was willing to see health care as "the cornerstone issue of the next Presidential election," and he asserted, "George Bush is wrong to duck this issue."
Mr. Rostenkowski's bill, like the one introduced by the Senate's Democratic majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, says that all employers must provide basic health insurance for employees or pay a tax to help finance care under a Government program like Medicare. This requirement would be phased in gradually from 1993 to 1996, starting with employers who have more than 100 workers.
Mr. Rostenkowski proposes a surtax that would increase the income tax obligations of individuals and corporations by 6 percent in 1993 and 1994, by 7 percent in 1995 and by 9 percent in 1996. The surtax would help pay for the care of people who did not receive health insurance from employers or other sources.
 
Panel to Hold Down Costs
 The Rostenkowski bill would set limits on the permissible growth in national health spending and would create a panel of 11 experts known as the Health Care Cost Containment Commission. The panel would would negotiate with health-care providers to decide how much of national health outlays should go to doctors, hospitals, laboratories and other entities. Prescription drugs are not subject to cost control in the bill.
The Secretary of Health and Human Services would translate the commission's decisions into reality by setting annual payment rates for health care services. The rates would establish the maximum amounts to be paid for specific services by Government, employers and private insurers.
To cover the additional costs of having more than 10 million more Medicare beneficiaries, Mr. Rostenkowski would increase the amount of wages subject to the Medicare payroll tax, and the tax rate. Under current law, employer and employee each pay a Medicare tax equal to 1.45 percent of the first $125,000 of earnings. The amount of earnings subject to the tax was increased from $51,300 last year and would be raised again, to $200,000 in 1993, under Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal. He would increase the rate to 1.55 percent in 1993 and to 1.65 percent in 1996.
Mr. Rostenkowski did not have an estimate of how his bill would affect families. But it is clear that the tax increases could be substantial, especially for those with high income.
 
National Health System Seen
 As lawmakers left town for the summer recess, few were available to comment on the new proposal.
Stuart M. Butler, director of domestic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation, said: "These bills purport to be a kind of midway position between what we now have and universal national health insurance, like what exists in Canada, Britain or Sweden. But in practice these proposals are unstable. They will degenerate or evolve into some type of national health system."
But John C. Rother, legislative director of the American Association of Retired Persons, said he supported the idea of lowering the age of eligibility for Medicare, and he praised the Congressman for candor in specifying how to pay for his proposals, something the Senate plan does not do.
The basic benefits required under Mr. Rostenkowski's bill would generally be the same as those available through Medicare. But preventive and pediatric health services would be added to the Medicare package.
The bill would also set Federal standards for health insurance sold to groups of employees, and it would allow self-employed people to take larger tax deductions for such insurance, provided the coverage met Federal criteria.

HEADLINE: Letter: On Science;
Weigh Basic vs. 'Big' Research

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"NASA's Untouchable Folly" (editorial, July 14) was right on target.
As chairman of the House Budget Committee task force on defense, foreign policy and space, I held a hearing last week on the budgetary consequences of "big science" projects like the space station and the superconducting supercollider. The hearing made it clear that financing these projects may very well come at the expense of other compelling science needs that provide a far stronger contribution to the maintenance of America's scientific base and our international economic competitiveness.
Under President Bush's budget proposal, spending on large research and development projects increased by 29 percent over fiscal year 1991 levels, and would consume an increasing share of the domestic discretionary spending during the first half of the 1990's.
The President's proposed increases for the space station and supercollider represent 50 percent of all his proposed increases for domestic discretionary spending in fiscal year 1994. If we include NASA's earth-observing system, these three largest projects represent 90 percent of the President's request for domestic discretionary spending growth in fiscal year 1994. These increases stand in sharp contrast to the $3.6 billion in Federal spending reductions in fiscal year 1994 that were imposed by last year's budget agreement.
My task force will hold another hearing to examine our investment in "small science" projects and the contributions which basic and applied research make to United States competitiveness and the maintenance of America's scientific base. In these times of severe budgetary constraints, Congress must invest scarce Federal research and development dollars wisely and in a way that will insure that the United States gets the greatest possible return for these dollars.
 
RICHARD J. DURBIN
Member of Congress, 20th Dist., Ill.
Washington, July 16, 1991

HEADLINE: Congress Gets in Way Of Microenterprises

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We are pleased that Lorna Hahn (Op-Ed, July 22) recognized the long-term support by the United States Agency for International Development given to South African black private enterprise, and A.I.D.'s microenterprise assistance program, which operates in more than 50 developing countries.
Several points require clarification, however. A.I.D.'s commitment to its microenterprise program does not depend on Congress passing the microenterprise development portion of the foreign aid bill. Funds increased from $57.5 million worldwide in 1988 to $85 million in 1990 and are projected to grow to more than $137 million in 1992. The legislation Ms. Hahn refers to calls for a program level of only $85 million next year.
As is often the case, apart from setting a target level for spending on microenterprise, the legislation Ms. Hahn supports contains restrictive provisions that would decrease the agency's flexibility to fashion microenterprise programs to the situation of each recipient country.
Rather than helping microentrepreneurs in South Africa and elsewhere, such restrictions can actually thwart the legislation's purported objectives.
 
MICHAEL FARBMAN
Director, Office of Small, Micro
and Informal Enterprise
Agency for Intl. Development
Washington, July 24, 1991

HEADLINE: Dow Declines 11.41 Points, to 3,006.26

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
The prices of blue chip stocks fell slightly yesterday, with analysts citing disappointingly weak employment numbers released in the morning. They said the decline reflected investor concern that the current economic recovery may be anemic, at best.
 Falling for a second day after a three-day advance, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 11.41 points, to close at 3,006.26. Still, the Dow remained above the 3,000 mark and ended 33.76 points higher than when the week began. The day's volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 162.3 million shares, down from 170.6 million on Thursday. 
Smaller stocks fared better. Prices were higher on the American Stock Exchange, where the value index rose by 0.16 point, to close at 368.40. In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index rose by 1.52 points, to 505.67.
 
'A Very Disappointing Day'
 "It was a very disappointing day," said Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "Any day that employment numbers come out is an important day. But based on the numbers that the market saw, it was disappointed."
 In what is considered the first significant economic indicator of the third quarter, the Labor Department reported yesterday morning that nonfarm employment fell by an unexpected 51,000 jobs. Many analysts had expected employment to rise. In response to this weak showing, the bond market rallied, reflecting a belief that the Federal Reserve would act soon to lower interest rates.
 In theory, falling interest rates should be good news for stocks. But the market saw it differently. Because of poor earnings at many corporations, investors saw the weak employment numbers as a sign the recovery might be particularly weak.
 "The belief is that corporate earnings will not be strong enough to validate stocks at their current levels," Mr. Johnson said.
 
A Rise at the Opening
 The market opened higher, even though the opening bell on the Big Board came more than an hour after the Labor Department issued the employment statistics. And stock prices continued to rise for about an hour, going as high as 3,042. But as the employment numbers were analyzed by economists and the view was decidedly gloomy, the market quickly tumbled and stayed down the rest of the day.
 "The bears were in the economic firms," said William M. LeFevre, a market strategist with Tucker Anthony Inc. "And they were talking about a weak recovery and job losses."
 One positive sign was that more Big Board stocks closed up than down, by 894 to 683. "We're at the point where the stock market needs improving earnings more than lower interest rates," Mr. LeFevre said.
 
Gains for Some Stocks
 Individual stocks and groups of stocks performed in line with yesterday's economic news. Companies that tend to do well in good times and bad did well. The most important of these were pharmaceutical stocks, which as a group closed higher. The leader was Eli Lilly, which closed at 79, up 2 3/4. Consumer and household stocks, which also do well in weak times, did well yesterday. Coca-Cola closed at 61 7/8, up 1, and Gillette closed at 40 3/4, up 1/2.
 While most oil stocks ended the day slightly off, one big gainer was USX-Marathon, which rose 1 3/4, to 27 5/8. The stock gained on reports that a newly discovered Tunisian oilfield may be bigger than typical oilfields in that region.
 Some stocks were hurt by bad news yesterday. McDonnell-Douglas fell to 54 1/4, down 2 1/8, after Singapore Airlines canceled orders for some 20 MD-11 midrange airplanes, chosing Airbus Industrie instead. Analysts took this as a bad sign for future orders to American companies from other Asian carriers.

HEADLINE: Corporate Lessons In Campus Quality

BYLINE: By Claudia H. Deutsch

 BODY:
JUDGING by the more than 75,000 students who pursue M.B.A.'s each year -- and the businesses that recruit them -- American executives have swallowed whole the idea that exposure to professorial research and classroom wit is essential to success.
Now, the tables are turning. Universities, facing a demographically induced shrinkage in the pool of students and a recession-induced shrinkage in financial support, are discovering that neither their staff theoreticians nor their professors-cum-consultants have a magic pill that attracts and retains customers. 
 So now, universities are going to industry to learn, not lecture. Their plea: Teach us about quality, customer service, teamwork, all the things we've supposedly been teaching you for lo these many years.
"We've finally recognized that there's an awful lot a university can learn from a corporation," said William E. Kirwan, president of the University of Maryland.
 
Turning to Industry
 Specifically, university administrators have asked companies to help them set up Total Quality Management programs. Called T.Q.M. throughout industry, these popular programs are as much mindset as method. They require every corporate department to define its customers, beef up activities that are directly linked to serving those customers and eliminate most everything else.
"T.Q.M. is a leadership philosophy, an ability to look at every product and service you provide from everyone's point of view," said Aris Melissaratos, a vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation who often helps universities with T.Q.M.
Last year more than 500 academics came to hear industry speakers at the first Total Quality Management in Academia symposium, hosted by the University of West Virginia. Maryland held its own daylong T.Q.M. conference in March, at which executives and university administrators took turns discussing their experiences. Nearly 900 people showed up.
Corning, Westinghouse, Xerox, Hewlett-Packard and other large companies regularly send executives, gratis, to speak to university administrators about T.Q.M. The Ford Motor Company brings in delegations from universities to observe its T.Q.M. program.
The University of Pennsylvania is paying Frank Topper, a consultant, to teach quality processes to its administrative staff. "They're learning how not to waste other people's time or dollars," Mr. Topper said.
These are not easy lessons to absorb for the political minefield that is academia. T.Q.M., by its nature, is apolitical. It defines "customer" as anyone who uses a department's services -- even people normally considered the "enemy." Under T.Q.M., people in purchasing, for example, must put top priority on easing the process for ordering supplies -- and that means catering to the very people whom purchasing has traditionally held responsible for bidding and ordering problems.
"T.Q.M. is a team approach, and universities notoriously don't work well as teams," said L. Edwin Coate, vice president for finance and administration at Oregon State University.
Nor do universities easily embrace the idea that they have customers, rather than supplicants and apprentices. "While companies are figuring how to better focus on their customers, schools are still defining who those customers are," said Charles P. Kendig, a Xerox quality specialist on loan to the University of Maryland.
Universities do, in fact, deal with multiple customer groups: the students who pay tuition, the companies that hire those students, the people who approve research grants and the people who use the research.
And university bureaucracy can be a killer. Take the "simple" process of collecting money for grant programs. Faculty members file grant proposals with department chiefs, who file them with the head of the school, who files them with the office of research negotiation, who negotiates terms with the sponsor. By the time they get to accounting, there have been hundreds of chances for mistakes -- and no way to place blame.
 
Order From Chaos
 T.Q.M. breaks such chaotic problems into manageable tasks. The University of Pennsylvania carved a team out of every group involved in the grant process, and charged it with reducing errors and lowering deficits. As of June the team had redesigned invoices, mapped out negotiation guidelines and simplified communications and accounting. "They went on a diagnostic journey, not to fix blame but to fix systems," Mr. Topper said.
More universities are trying this approach. Their T.Q.M. teams are interviewing students, faculty members, campus recruiters, all sorts of "customers," to see what they want done differently, and devising ways to do it.
At the University of Maryland, Mr. Kirwan and his vice presidents went through a one-day brush-up program on the rudiments of programs that address quality issues. Now they are talking about pushing T.Q.M. principles at the faculty.
"They should provide a clear syllabus on day one, accessible office hours, advance notice of when the final exam will be," Mr. Kirwan said. "They must think what students want from the classroom experience, and give it to them."
Oregon State is also broadening its T.Q.M. scope. This year its benefits office changed its call routing methods, and increased by 40 percent the number of calls answered by a person rather than an answering machine. Its purchasing department rethought a few forms and reduced the number of vouchers returned to other departments for more information by a staggering 94 percent. Now, to please "customers" in industry who complained about new hires who can't write well, Oregon State is teaching students to write better.
Similarly, after focus groups with students, the University of Tennessee's College of Business Administration scuttled an arbitrary system of scheduling 15-minute sessions with counselors in favor of one that allots time in terms of problem complexity. At the request of participants in the advanced management program, it has instituted follow-up visits by faculty members to company premises months after the courses end. To please other departments, financial affairs provides simplified accounting statements for department heads and more detailed ones for donors who want to see where their money goes.
Now C. Warren Neel, the business school's dean, is thinking the unthinkable. He is asking faculty teams to examine whether by rescheduling some classes they can ease parking congestion and uneven classroom utilization. "Tampering with scheduling strikes at the heart of faculty autonomy," Dr. Neel said. "But if it is important to students or other customers, we have to address it."

PUB-DATE: August 4, 1991

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 19; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 1068 words

HEADLINE: SPECIAL REPORT;
Catering to a New Crowd

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
EIGHT YEARS AGO, Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond allocated about $147,000 for child-care services, which provide developmental programs and meals for children of students throughout the workday. That budget has since grown 61 percent, to more than $200,000, for the school year ending this spring.
The increase largely reflects the higher number of older students with children who are returning to the university to complete degrees or entering the university later in life to pursue a deferred ambition of higher education, university administrators say. 
 "The average age of our students is 26," said Eugene P. Tranni, president of Virginia Commonwealth, which has a student body of 21,700. "For the first time this past year, we had more first-time transfer students than we have first-time freshman students. When you have numbers like that, you are catering to older students and you have to do things differently and develop programs with these older students in mind."
The increase in child-care spending is only one of many ways in which the sprawling campus in Richmond has joined universities nationwide in responding to the growing number of college students over age 25.
"With 18-to-20-year-old students, you have more services dedicated to nonacademic programming: intramural activities, concerts and the typical things you find on a college campus," Dr. Tranni said. "But when the average age is 26, you have students who are more concerned with placement services, part-time jobs and university services that are open at times when working students can take advantage of them."
The distinctive schedules, budgets and life styles of these young adults has prompted changes in the structure and economics of many universities.
Colorado State University, for example, is providing credit courses in 21 disciplines through videotapes to about 100 sites -- mostly for corporation employees. Students send completed assignments and tests to the university in Fort Collins for grading. Faculty members can be consulted during arranged hours.
The University of Maryland's University College leads a consortium of eight other universities in providing degrees through cable television. "There are a number of working adults whose schedules and geographic locations make it impossible for them to attend a traditional class in a traditional setting," said Lissa Brown, a University College spokeswoman. She said the program is designed to make a college education attainable to "everyone from firefighters and homemakers to workers whose workshifts change repeatedly."
Even the scheduling of courses in more traditional settings has begun to reflect the needs of a growing number of students who hold full- or part-time jobs. University officials say they now offer a larger number of classes beginning before 8 A.M. and after 5 P.M. More classes are being scheduled on weekends.
"Surveys of students' class schedules have shown that 47 percent of all the adult students who are studying for credit take classes after 5 P.M.," said J. Noah Brown, director of governmental relations with the National University Continuing Education Association, a Washington-based organization promoting programs for older students. That has meant keeping buildings open longer, which has driven up maintenance costs.
Mr. Brown also said that, while the increased number of older students has not dramatically affected most college curriculums, it has fueled an expansion in certificate programs, nondegree courses that carry specific academic requirements and are a recognized credential in fields like real estate and conflict resolution. "There has been a big explosion in these programs, largely because states are mandating more of them within many professions," he said.
 
Not All Schools Are Affected
 Not all schools have been affected by the rising number of older students. Some officials of smaller, private institutions in smaller communities contend that adults in their 20's and 30's often find their curriculum too rigorous and their tuition too high.
Nonetheless, to compensate for the declining population of 18-to-20-year-olds, many smaller, private colleges are spending large sums to recruit older students, through brochures and by sending administrators to address business and professional groups.
University administrators say older students are less inclined to pursue liberal arts majors than business, engineering and computer science courses.
"Most are not coming back with the idea of self-improvement in mind, but to pursue what they consider practical means of career advancement or professional development," said Beverly R. Greenfieg, a coordinator of the Returning Students Program at the University of Maryland in College Park, a separate program from the one at Maryland's University College.
 
 
'Services We Haven't Thought About'
 Like other universities, the University of Maryland has created programs aimed at easing the transition for these new kids on campus. "We are discovering that a larger number of older students are taking care of parents who need care," said Barbara J. Goldberg, another coordinator of the Returning Students Program. "That means that we have to begin to think about services we haven't thought about before," like adult day care, which the university is exploring.
The university also provides networking meetings, where older students can meet one another and discuss assertiveness, financial assistance, study skills and other concerns. The interaction, Ms. Goldberg said, enables students "to develop confidence in themselves and not be intimidated about coming back to school."

 	 	 		. . .	 	Information on financial assistance for older students has not exactly flooded the market, but the University of Maryland publishes a brochure called "Dollars and Sense: A Resource Guide to Financial Aid for Returning Students." The publication, which is free, can be obtained by writing the Returning Students Program of the Counseling Center, University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland 20742. Books on the subject include "Paying for Your Education: A Guide for Adult Learners," published by College Board Publications, 45 Columbus Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10023-6992, and "Happier By Degrees," by Pam Mendelsohn, by E. P. Dutton Press, 2 Park Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016.

PUB-DATE: August 4, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 21; Column 6; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4323 words

HEADLINE: The Great Alaska Debate

BYLINE: By Timothy Egan; Timothy Egan is Seattle bureau chief of The Times.

 BODY:
THE BEST-KEPT SECRET in the oil industry lies under a steel pipe, six inches in diameter, that pokes out of the tundra inside one of the world's last truly wild places. Eight months of the year, the pipe is surrounded by the frozen chop of snow and blue ice that covers the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northeast Alaska. A desert, with less than 10 inches of annual precipitation, the flat land bordering the Beaufort Sea holds the imprint of a savage wind for most of the year: snowdrifts contorted and hardened, a landscape like paste from a blender.
In the summer, when the sun circles the horizon but never sets, the snow melts, wildflowers rise in the plain and great masses of caribou arrive to give birth to their young, seeking the coastal wind as refuge from swarms of mosquitoes. Driven by biological imperative, the animal herds gorge themselves on grass and flowers, storing fuel for the long migration through the Brooks Range in mid-summer. 
 In September, the tundra freezes again, the sea hardens, grizzly bears hibernate in pockets of warmer air near the mountains, daylight is squeezed from the sky. Through the seasons, the pipe remains -- a totem of the great mystery whose resolution may determine the future of American energy policy. The five-foot shank of steel marks an exploratory oil well, called KIC-1, that was drilled by a partnership led by Chevron U.S.A. in 1985 and 1986 at a cost of more than $40 million. The oil companies drilled to a depth of 15,200 feet on land owned by an Eskimo regional corporation in order to peek beneath the permafrost. They may have discovered the largest recoverable oil field in North America, or they may have struck out, reaching only natural gas or water in a reservoir mapped out by geologists.
Fewer than 10 people know what was found beneath the pipe, says Tom Cook, a geologist who is Chevron's exploration representative in Alaska. The oil company considers the information obtained from its exploratory well proprietary and will not share its findings. Test drilling for oil, like trying to forecast the weather, is risky, an inexact science. Nobody, not even the Chevron geologists, knows for sure how much oil there may be under the refuge, or how much of it is recoverable. But the test results must have been tantalizing enough, prompting the intense lobbying now underway in Congress by the major oil companies.
"What you get from that kind of well is a better understanding of the geology," Cook says, poker-faced. He lights a cigar inside one of the drab huts latched to the tundra in the oil town of Deadhorse, at Prudhoe Bay, 65 miles west of the refuge. "Hopefully that puts us at a competitive advantage when -- if -- we start production," he says.
The question of whether the nation's second-largest wildlife refuge (the biggest is the Yukon Delta Refuge in western Alaska) will be opened to roads, drilling pads and the clank of industry pursuing another jackpot is up to Congress. In May, the Senate Energy Committee passed legislation that would allow drilling in the refuge, and the full Senate is expected to take up the matter in the fall. For the time being, by law, the 19-million-acre refuge is for the predominant use of wildlife so abundant inside the Arctic Circle that the area is often called the American Serengeti. (Map on page 26.) In a symmetry so perfect it suggests a modern parable, the refuge also happens to contain what many geologists consider the last great untapped oil field on the continent -- with a potential for yielding up to nine billion barrels, nearly matching that of Prudhoe Bay, America's biggest. More than 180,000 caribou, a herd that is to the native Gwich'in people what the Great Plains bison were to the Lakota Sioux, migrate annually to calving grounds in the same general area where the oil is supposed to be. Chief among the questions now before Congress is whether oil production and caribou can share the same patch of cold ground.
Beyond that, the fight over the Arctic refuge has once again raised the question of just how far Americans are willing to go for more domestic oil -- how many more wilderness areas, pristine beaches and wildlife refuges will be violated as the oil runs out. Eighteen years have passed since the oil crisis of 1973, but American energy policy has barely changed. More than 100 years ago, when oil production began in earnest in this country, the wells were located on industrial land, close to cities. Now drillers are knocking at the door of an Arctic wilderness in the most remote corner of the continent. For conservationists who would draw the line around this vast home for caribou and musk oxen, all other environmental battles are dwarfed by this epic struggle over the Arctic refuge. It may be the last big land fight of its kind.
 PRESIDENT BUSH has made drilling in the refuge the centerpiece of his national energy policy; Democrats, joined by many Republicans, are pushing fuel efficiency as an alternative. Increasing the average fuel-economy standard for new cars from 27.5 to 34 miles a gallon by the year 2001, the argument for conservation goes, would save more oil than could ever be pumped from the refuge. But the President will veto any energy bill, according to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, that does not include lifting the restrictions on Arctic oil development.
For those who want cheap Alaskan crude to keep flowing into the next century, the argument is simple. As Tom Cook says, "Do you want your energy policy always to be, 'Shoot the guy who's got the oil,' or should we develop our own resources?"
Sixty-five percent of the world's known oil reserves are in the Middle East; the United States has only about 4 percent. Conservationists point out that even if the Arctic refuge proved to be a bonanza as big as Prudhoe Bay, which produces about 1.5 million barrels a day but is declining at a rate of roughly 10 percent a year, the United States will continue to have to import up to half its oil. "We simply cannot drill ourselves to energy independence," says George T. Frampton Jr., president of the Wilderness Society.
The Arctic refuge -- with its prehistoric-looking musk oxen, millions of migratory birds, Dall sheep, wolf packs, moose, majestic caribou herds and fearsome polar bears -- has taken on an importance well beyond its potential ability to keep gas prices down and soldiers out of foreign lands. The ancient human cultures of Inupiat Eskimos on the one side and Gwich'in Indians on the other are also part of the refuge's ecology. As metaphor, the refuge is a sort of frozen Eden, the last paradise at the far northern edge of the Final Frontier. Larger than 10 of the states, it is without the industrial footprints that cover the rest of the globe -- the "geography of hope," as the writer Wallace Stegner defined wilderness.
Even the most poetic of nature writers find themselves straining to describe the coastal plain -- 8 percent of the total refuge -- which is where oil drilling would take place if Congress gives its approval. Few would call it majestic. "Grave, austere and beautiful" is how Peter Matthiessen described it recently. Unlike the rest of the refuge, which enjoys the more moderate climate of the south and abounds with spruce trees, flowering heathers and alpine crags, the 1.5 million acres of the coastal plain are flat and harsh. For most of the year, the area lacks color and the untidy edges of life. "A barren desert," in the words of Alaska Senator Ted Stevens, perhaps the most vocal proponent in the Senate of opening the refuge to drilling. But its emptiness is what some people find so redeeming. They see value in what the plain does not have -- the heavy metal and caterwauling tools of the oil industry. Of the 1,100 miles of northern Alaska coast along the Arctic Ocean, only the 125-mile stretch inside the refuge is off limits to development.
"Oil and gas development would destroy this area, with all its wild and spectacular diversity, forever," Sydney J. Butler, a vice president of the Wilderness Society, wrote in a letter to United States Senators in May. At the same time, three major environmental groups -- the National Wildlife Federation, the Natural Resources Defense Council and Trustees for Alaska -- released a report in which they pleaded with Congress to keep the refuge inviolate. At stake, the report said, is "the biological integrity of America's only Arctic sanctuary and the future of the wildlife it protects."
 FLYING LOW OVER the snow on a day when the surface is crackling under 24-hour sun, we leave the intersecting roads around Prudhoe Bay and enter a white wilderness. The landscape seems to be in a hurry to make the elemental transformation from ice to water -- alive with "breakup," a word used by Alaskans to describe late spring. The snow pack is surprisingly low, less than a foot on average. Bits of grass show here and there. The Beaufort Sea is just starting to reveal itself through broken ice; offshore, Eskimos have begun their annual hunt for seals. Inland, about 25 miles from the coast, grizzly bears are rousing themselves from a winter slumber in the foothills of the Brooks Range. And all through the low draws and passes of the range, caribou, led by pregnant cows, are heading north.
A large, picked-over piece of whalebone, a remnant of a spine bigger than most living rooms, is perched on the beach outside the town of Kaktovik, the only human community inside the refuge. Entering the village of 200 people, you can see the two worlds, past and future, of the Inupiat, a name that means "the Real People." They still hunt bowhead whales, their centuries-old source of subsistence. But the town has satellite dishes, off-road vehicles, new housing -- all spoils of oil money. Chevron's exploratory well was drilled just a few miles from this village, on lands for which the mineral rights are owned by the Arctic Slope Regional Corporation, whose shareholders are Eskimos. Any further drilling would require Congressional approval.
"We don't want to return to the past," says Archie Brower, a Kaktovik resident, toothless and chain-smoking. "Oil is the future."
In 1980, 20 years after the refuge was set aside, Congress designated the northernmost 1.5 million acres as a "special study area" for its oil and gas potential. In 1987, the Interior Department estimated there was about a 20 percent chance of recovering large quantities of oil in the Arctic refuge. This year, citing more accurate geologic studies and recent wells drilled on the periphery of the refuge, the department upped the odds to 46 percent -- a move environmentalists label political, timed to influence the legislation now making its way through Congress.
The Government places the amount of recoverable oil in the refuge at between 600 million and 9.2 billion barrels. The mean, estimated at 3.57 billion barrels, would be enough to meet the United States' total oil demand for 200 days. But if that oil were pumped at a rate of only 1 million barrels a day, it would keep the Trans-Alaska Pipeline -- the vital artery on which Alaskans depend for everything from an annual check to performing-arts subsidies -- busy for another decade or two. For the companies that run the pipeline, timing is crucial; the vast oil complex inside the Arctic Circle must be fed a steady diet of North Slope crude. If the refuge were opened to drilling today, it would take 8 to 12 years in exploration and construction time before oil could flow from the coastal plane to the pipeline.
In one report, the Interior Department drew a picture of what oil development in the refuge would be like. The handful of oil companies expected to be involved would need about 100 miles of pipeline, 120 miles of main roads and 160 miles of less-developed spur roads, two airfields, some 60 drilling pads and up to 50 million cubic yards of gravel, used to make hard surfaces over the tundra. The coastal plain is underlaid by up to 1,500 feet of permanently frozen water, rock, sand and loose soil -- called permafrost. The thin layer atop this, which thaws to a depth of several feet, is considered extremely vulnerable to environmental damage. To minimize the industrial footprint, the oil companies have said they would try to do much of the construction work in winter, using ice roads instead of those made of gravel. They say new technological advances make it possible to put all the drill pads and service centers closer together and to use about half the space required for the construction at Prudhoe Bay in the early 70's.
The oil would be sent to the lower 48 states through the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, which dissects the state and runs 800 miles from its origin in Prudhoe to the ice-free port of Valdez. What happens after the oil leaves the frozen north, of course, has as much to do with the politics of opening the refuge as what may happen near the drill sites. Legislation to allow drilling cleared the Senate Energy Committee once before, in 1989 -- eight days before the Exxon Valdez struck a reef and ruptured, spilling nearly 11 million gallons into Prince William Sound. The nation's worst oil spill, killing more than 260,000 birds, at least 3,500 sea otters, 200 harbor seals and staining a marine wilderness with blankets of crude, caused many in Congress -- and in Alaska -- to think twice about the pursuit of black gold inside the Arctic Circle. The measure to open the refuge died in the 1989 Congressional session.
"After the spill, when I went to give talks about oil development in the refuge, I had some people spit on me, call me every name in the book," Cook, the Chevron geologist, says. "It was rough."
One who did not change his mind about Alaska's relationship with oil was Walter J. Hickel, the state's new Governor. He dismisses the Exxon spill as a "mechanical thing" that would never have happened if there had been tugs escorting oil tankers all the way through the sound. Running on the platform of Alaska's Independence Party -- which advocated secession from the Union, an idea he later disavowed -- the 71-year-old Hickel was returned to the Governor's mansion last fall, more than 20 years after an earlier term in the Statehouse. Elected with less than 40 percent of the vote in a three-way election, Hickel's vision for Alaska includes opening up the refuge, laying railroad tracks to the far north and constructing a pipeline to deliver fresh water from his state to the parched metropolises of Southern California.
The state controls less than one-third of Alaska's 370 million acres. The rest is tied up in national parks, wilderness preserves, wildlife refuges, military fields and land owned by native corporations, the 13 regional groups that represent 70,000 Aleuts, Eskimos and Athabascan Indians. In his inaugural address this year, Governor Hickel described Alaska as "a state on the brink of colony status once again -- because we have let our rights be taken away by the Federal Government."
The Governor's plan for Alaska has been dubbed "Wally World" by the Anchorage press. He has just limped through a legislative session in which few of his initiatives were passed into law, and his deal to settle all legal claims against Exxon in return for a payment of $1.1 billion fell apart under a shower of criticism. Nonetheless, in his disdain for official wilderness areas, he speaks for a large segment of Alaskans. Wild areas, off limits to motorized vehicles and resource extraction, are, he says, "places where people have to break laws in order to see them."
 CERTAINLY, FEW people have ever tried to see the Arctic refuge. Last year, only about 15,000 visitors were recorded, an amount equal to, say, the number of people who might cross the street in Times Square on a given morning. Hiking the coastal plain, in summer, has been compared to walking on a water bed. Those who do visit come to raft under the midnight sun, to camp in the foothills of the Brooks Range, to take pictures of the big animals or to exalt in the feeling of being an inconsequential part of nature.
Even if a million visitors a year came to the Arctic refuge, it would not change the core argument against oil development. For ANWR (pronounced an-whar), as it is called, is not primarly for people, but for animals.
In arguing that industry and wild animals can share the same land, the oil companies that want to drill in the refuge -- Chevron, ARCO, British Petroleum, among the major ones -- cite the experience of the Central Arctic caribou herd, just to the west of the refuge. The fear expressed during the last great Alaska lands debate, over the pipeline, was that North Slope production would harm this herd. But in the last 18 years, following large-scale development at Prudhoe Bay, the herd has grown from 3,000 to nearly 20,000. Pictures of caribou crossing under elevated pipelines and over gravel roads are regularly trotted out to show that oil drilling has had no discernable effect on the animals. During the 1988 Presidential campaign, George Bush proclaimed that caribou like to "snuggle up next to the pipeline."
The animals are a common sight at Prudhoe during the summer. "They cross pipelines and roads with very few problems," says G. Scott Ronzio, manager of environmental sciences for ARCO Alaska. While conceding that there is "a lot of mystery to these animals," Ronzio says, "I'm fairly confident that oil development can continue on the North Slope with no harm to caribou."
The expansion of the Central Arctic herd has been attributed by biologists to a retreat of predators, mainly wolves and grizzly bears, which keep their distance from humans, to a series of mild winters and to normal ups and downs of animal population cycles. Caribou have increased throughout Alaska. Most biologists, Ronzio among them, think the Central Arctic herd will eventually decline, and there is evidence that their growth rate is already shrinking.
The animals that migrate to the refuge, known as the Porcupine caribou herd (named for the Porcupine River, which flows through the southern edge of the refuge), are a different story. For one thing, the Porcupine herd is nearly 10 times larger than the Central Arctic herd. For another, the bigger herd does its calving in an area where oil development would take place; about half of the Central Arctic calving takes place away from oil facilities. Few biologists know exactly what would happen if pregnant caribou cows, given their limited time to give birth, tried to calve within sight and sound of an industrial complex.
"Among the Central herd, females have never adjusted to oil development," says Dr. David R. Klein, a biologist considered one of the nation's foremost experts on caribou. A frequent witness before Congressional hearings, Klein has been studying Arctic caribou for nearly 30 years. "What oil could mean to the Porcupine herd is that the females and their young would be deprived of their best feeding grounds," he says.
Caribou eat grasses and flower buds, at a rather intense rate, during the short Arctic summer. The swarms of mosquitoes that rise from the spongelike tundra have driven them to the coast for the relief of ocean breezes. If the animals were forced to scatter inland, says Klein, insects would likely harass them to a point where they would be unable to eat enough food for their return migration, a march of nearly 1,000 miles.
Of equal concern to Klein are the musk oxen, which look like creatures out of the "Star Wars" movies. The musk oxen are native to Alaska, but were hunted to extinction. Since their reintroduction 20 years ago, they have thrived in the refuge, where they live year round, eating shrubs and willows in the valleys of the Brooks Range. Now numbering about 500, the musk oxen in the refuge make up one of the largest populations in North America. Klein worries that gouging streams in the refuge to build new roads would displace the shaggy, lumbering oxen from their prime habitat, a concern that the oil companies say is ill-founded. According to Ronald W. Chappell, a spokesman for ARCO Alaska, gravel would most likely be taken from one or two central pits.
Klein speaks in the cautious language of science. Both sides of the refuge debate have tried to use his conclusions to bolster their arguments. When asked for his opinion on whether the Porcupine herd could survive oil drilling in the refuge, he says: "These animals are extremely complex, but I believe it would be very difficult for oil development to take place in the coastal plain without having a detrimental effect on them. How great that would be, no one knows."
For the Gwich'in Indians, who live in 15 tiny communities just south of Alaska's Brooks Range and the Canadian Yukon, the caribou are a matter of survival. Most Gwich'ins, who number about 7,000, live a subsistence life, depending on the Porcupine caribou herd as their primary food source, much the way some coastal Alaskan communities still survive on seasonal salmon runs. The Gwich'ins are the northernmost Indian tribe in North America, perhaps the last big aboriginal group to resist assimilation and modern ways.
"For too long this has been an issue about environment versus energy, and no one wanted to hear about the Gwich'in," says Sarah James, a native leader who lives in Arctic Village, just south of the refuge. In a statement before the Senate Energy Committee in April, James compared the Gwich'in to the buffalo-hunting Sioux of the Great Plains: "The Gwich'in are caribou people. For thousands of years we have lived with caribou right where we are today. We're talking about an Indian nation that still lives on the land and depends on this herd. In my village, about 75 percent of our protein comes from caribou."
In Arctic Village, heat from the summer sun is used to dry caribou meat. Unlike other native people, the Gwich'ins do not own any mineral rights in the refuge and have not organized into a regional corporation. Caribou is the center of their lives. The Gwich'ins consider themselves part of the natural ecology of the Arctic refuge. "We think of it as a biocultural reserve, not just a wildlife refuge," James says.
The Gwich'ins, who have barely been heard from during the decade-long debate, came together for a meeting in the summer of 1988, the first time all the tribal communties had gathered in one place in more than 100 years. They signed a proclamation, agreeing to "speak as a single voice" against oil development in the refuge.
The other native people near the refuge, Eskimos on the northern border, take the opposite stand. Whale hunters represented by a powerful regional corporation, the Inupiat say oil has changed their lives for the better. They receive millions of dollars in royalties from drilling on the North Slope, and stand to gain additional millions if the refuge is opened. About 6,000 Inupiat live in eight villages inside the Arctic Circle, most of them in the town of Barrow.
"We used to be afraid of what the oil industry would do, but we saw that it has not harmed fish or wildlife," says Warren Matumeak, an Inupiat elder who lives in Barrow. "Things have changed for the better. We have schools, roads, firefigthing equipment. Our houses have kitchens and flush toilets and TV's. It's sad that some people think we should have to go back to the old ways."
Matumeak was with his grandson, fishing for char, a type of Arctic trout, four summers ago, when he suffered a heart attack. "I said, 'Grandson, I'm going to where Jesus is.' " His cholesterol built up, he said, because he was spending too much time in front of the television, dipping caribou fat in whale blubber -- a tasty snack. He survived the heart attack, thanks to a helicopter from Barrow that airlifted him to a hospital -- a search-and-rescue made possible by oil money. Matumeak still remembers when some Eskimos lived in igloos; now his grandchildren wear Los Angeles Raiders caps and the family takes occasional vacations to Disney World.
Some Inupiat are angry that they cannot lease their own land, inside the refuge, to oil companies. "We've lived here thousands of years," says Matumeak. "We should be able to do what we want with our own land. And what we want is to allow drilling. Oil is the best thing that ever happened to us."
Despite such statements, the Eskimos take a somewhat contradictory approach to oil drilling in the far north. While they advocate opening the refuge, which would benefit them economically, they are among the strongest opponents of an Interior Department plan to allow offshore drilling in the Arctic Ocean, which poses a potential threat to their whale hunting.
For most Americans, it would be easier if all the remaining oil fields were in West Texas or Oklahoma. But the search for petroleum has now gone to the far edges, near pleasure beaches in Florida and California, off the wilderness coast of the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State and inside an Arctic preserve that was supposed to belong to wild animals. These potential drill sites, on or near national treasures, force the question of just how far the nation will go to satisfy its oil habit.
Those who want to open the Arctic to development see a peculiar form of American naivete in the arguments for preservation. The idea of all that oil just sitting there, untapped, while the United States ups its trade imbalance with Middle Eastern countries is ludicrous, they say. But by keeping the refuge inviolate, the counter argument goes, Americans can take the first steps toward independence from a substance that, once pulled from the ground, inevitably spawns trouble -- wars, foul air and dirty water. The debate, in itself, is familiar. What has changed is that we are running out of places over which to have the argument.

HEADLINE: Spending Your Dollars in Europe: Greece;
In Europe's Best Bargain, the Prices Are Still Antique

BYLINE: By TULA BOGDANOS

 BODY:
Greek tour operators may be shaking their heads and muttering "terrible," but the tourism slump after the Persian Gulf war and the dollar's recent rise against the drachma means 1991 is a very good time to visit one of Western Europe's most inexpensive countries. Hotel and agency owners never quite recovered from the beating they took late last winter when scores of summer clients canceled, and some are offering discounts of up to 50 percent; especially outside of Athens, travelers can often negotiate room prices.
Travel costs have increased 10 to 15 percent because of Greece's rampant inflation. Museum fees, however, doubled: entrance to the Acropolis jumped from 800 to 1,500 drachmas (about $7.50). But because the dollar now equals 190 drachmas rather than the 150 it did in 1990, American travelers may find themselves paying much the same, if not less than last year. Some examples of average prices: package of four day-trips (Athens, Sounion, Delphi, island cruise), $107 ($109 in 1990); taverna meal, $8.90 ($8); Athens Festival ticket, $5.10 to $87.10 ($3.30 to $66.65); tourist-class ferry, Athens to Mykonos, $11 ($10.30); taxi from the center to most hotels mentioned here, $1.55 ($1.45). 
 Even in Athens, summer specials abound. For example, the deluxe Athenaeum Inter-Continental at 89-93 Syngrou offers a $135 rate until Sept. 1 for doubles with breakfast that usually cost $235 to $285; reservations must be made outside Greece. In the United States phone (800) 327-0200. The lovely Hotel Divani Palace Acropolis at 19-25 Parthenonons, below the Odeon Herod Atticus, may post an official $171 rate, but doubles with American breakfast this summer go for $94.80. Telephone 922-2945.
The Hilton is an oasis in hectic Athens with its Olympic-size pool, excellent staff and most sights a five-minute cab ride away. Standard rates for a double are $205 to $230 but, depending on the number of rooms available, can drop to $143; packages with doubles as low as $60 have been offered. The Athens Hilton is at 46 Vassilias Sofias; telephone 722-0201. In the United States, phone Hilton International, (800) 445-8667, for specials.
Tucked away in the Plaka district, Electra Palace Hotel (18 Nikodemou; 324-4201, $83 for double with buffet breakfast) has a roof garden, pool and comfortable rooms. Best of all, Plaka's winding streets and cafes, the Cine Paris outdoor cinema and a major Athens Festival site are all nearby. The city now has so many summer festivals with performers from Iggy Pop to Pavarotti that Greeks have coined the verb "to festivalize."
Travelers who want to avoid the touristy bluster of restaurants in Plaka's main square should dine at Platonos (4 Diogenous; 322-0666), a few streets over from Electra Palace. Run by the Karianos family since 1932, the taverna serves impeccable Greek food at Greek prices -- about $7.60 a person with wine: garlic-yogurt dip, octopus, juicy potatoes from the oven and grilled meats.
Even the least intrepid traveler will find reasonably priced vacation spots throughout Greece, such as uncrowded islands like Chiros, Antiparos and Anafi. A less explored region northwest of Athens, Epirus, offers majestic scenery, friendly people and a strong regional identity.
At Ioannina, the capital of Epirus, sites include the town's citadel with crumbling mosques and minarets; nearby Perama, with Greece's largest caves, and Dodoni's elegant ancient theater and the ruins of the Oracle of Zeus, important long before Delphi.
From Ioannina, visitors usually head to Zagoria -- wild mountains, rushing streams, 46 villages of stone mansions and cobbled streets -- and eventually the Vikos gorge, the mainland's rival to Samaria Gorge in Crete. Accommodations in Epirus range from $15.80 to $71.70; call the Athens tourist office at 325-2267 or, in Epirus, the Ioannina travel police at 25763.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Spending Your Dollars in Europe: Germany;
East and West Are Often Equal in Prices, but Not in Amenities

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

 BODY:
For travelers, Germany has been expensive for decades, but since unification it has become even more so. Still, cities like Berlin remain less costly than London or Paris. To be sure, inflation in June, while still a respectable 4 percent, was running higher than in France for the first time since 1973, largely because of recently raised taxes on everything from clothes to gasoline to pay for the rebuilding of eastern Germany. Nevertheless, the strength of the American dollar actually makes things a bit cheaper, in dollar terms, than last year.
Take hotels. A comfortable double room at the Savoy, one of the better hotels in Berlin, costs 410 marks this season, compared with 360 last year and only 260 five years ago. But with the dollar worth 1.8 marks, compared with 1.5 last summer, the price for Americans has actually dropped, to $228 from $240. The increase in the price in marks, hoteliers say, is purely a result of demand. Moreover, the summer discounts offered this year are less of a bargain. Last year a double room that normally costs $250 was discounted to about $130, but this year the $250 room drops only to about $210. Even so, it's worth asking if summer discounts are available. 
 A nice spot when visiting Berlin is just off the Kurfurstendamm, where the city's showiest boulevard spills out of the downtown at the Hotel Kronprinz (1 Kronprinzendamm; telephone 896030). Occupying a lovely beaux-arts townhouse, the Kronprinz has 53 rooms, and a double with bath and shower costs $125, up slightly from $120 last year. That includes a hearty German breakfast of coffee or tea, rolls and rich breads and an assortment of cheese and cold meats, jams and jellies. For lunch or a light supper, loll at the open-air cafe under the spreading chestnut trees in front, where you can enjoy a simple soup or platter of open sandwiches with cheese or cold lunch meats. A beer and sandwiches cost about $6.
Out of Berlin, note that tourist services in eastern Germany are still pretty abysmal. Hotels and restaurants are in short supply, so it's a seller's market with no one caring much to assure that customers come back again. Moreover, since last July's currency union, prices have shot up to western levels without standards of comfort following suit. East Germany used to be cheap; now it's just poor value. The best bet is often to stay with a family in rooms that are usually clean, if simple, and can cost as litle as $14 a night. Most hotels will supply the phone number or address of a local bed-and-breakfast exchange.
If you're leaving Berlin for a day or two, head for the Spreewald, an hour's drive southeast of the city. Its haunted marsh landscape has been inhabited for centuries by Slavic peasants -- the Sorbs -- who constructed their homes and tended garden patches among endless canals and waterways that crisscross the region. Like most eastern German sites that western Germans are rediscovering, the Spreewald becomes bedlam on summer weekends. So pick a weekday and, if you drive, take the Dresden autobahn for Lubbenau. Or take one of the buses that leave Berlin Fridays and Sundays from May to September at 8:30 A.M. from a site along the Kurfurstendamm near Fasanenstrasse. A day trip that includes a gentle round in a typical Sorb punt costs $27; reserve a place by phoning 8831015. From Lubbenau, take the footpath to Lehde, a quaint Sorb village with an outdoor museum that has assembled a wondrous collection of simple thatched Sorb peasant dwellings.
At prices such as these, and using the bargains available in Berlin, travelers to Germany not intending to splurge should budget about $1,220 to $1,390 a week for two persons.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An excursion in the marshy Spreewald in eastern Germany. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Spending Your Dollars in Europe: Austria;
Vienna is Losing Its High-Priced Name, but Not Its Luster

BYLINE: By BRENDA FOWLER

 BODY:
Vienna's reputation as one of Europe's most expensive cities is slowly fading. Granted, a good dinner can rarely be found for less than $15 and double rooms in the center for less than $100 are only slightly more available. But compared with cities in Italy and Germany, Vienna -- and Austria in general -- is a reasonably priced vacation spot.
One reason Austria appears affordable is that its inflation is so low -- only about 3.5 percent last year. Whereas in such Italian cities as Venice the price of a simple tomato and cheese pizza has more than doubled, and in some areas tripled, in the last six years, the price of a Viennese melange (coffee with milk) in Vienna has stuck at just about $2, and you can buy one coffee and sit until closing time. A glass of draft beer at a sidewalk cafe is about $1.90. For Americans, the low inflation in Austria helps make up a little bit for the steep fall in the dollar in the last six years. In 1985 the dollar stood at 21 schillings while it now stands at about 12 schillings, a slight improvement over the rate at the same time last year, when it was down to nearly 10 schillings. Egon Smeral, an economist at Vienna's Institute for Comparative Economic Studies, says that German unification has slightly lowered prices in Austria because of more competition, and Austrians are hoping that their entry into the European Community, which is not expected before 1993, will guarantee stable prices in the future. 
 A tourist on a week's visit to Austria who pays for half the cost of a double room with shower and breakfast and eats in restaurants for lunch and dinner should expect to pay about $504.
In Vienna, a restaurant with good value is Restaurant Beograd (7 Schikanedergasse; telephone 587-7444), just outside the Ringstrasse in Vienna's fourth district, which has customers ranging from gypsy wedding parties to local artists and an occasional off-the-beaten-path tourist. The walls of this comfortable restaurant are crammed with old photographs and paintings, many from the Balkans, whose cuisine is featured. Meat grilled over a wood fire is one of the specialties here. Cevapcici with onions, a spicy Yugoslav meat patty, costs $4.50. A shish kebab with three types of meat costs $7.50 and a large cucumber and tomato salad topped with grated goat cheese (sopska salat) costs $2. A hotel offering good value is Hotel Graf Stadion (5 Buchfeldgasse; 425284, doubles with shower and breakfast $79 to $86), old-fashioned, on a quiet street in Vienna's Josefstadt, an artists' district with many good restaurants and theaters nearby. The spotless rooms are renovated and have some old furniture and new carpet.
Most American travelers to Austria usually stick to Vienna and Salzburg, a popular axis that is slightly more expensive than the rest of the country. One undeservedly neglected area -- and compared with Vienna and Salzburg less expensive -- is Styria, a largely rural and mountainous province south of Vienna that stretches to the Yugoslav border. Graz, its capital, is a well-kept river city whose narrow streets are filled with Renaissance and Baroque houses that are as picturesque as any in Salzburg. South of Graz the landscape settles into rolling hills that are lush in the summer and perfect for campers. Styria, called Steiermark in German, is well-known for its wines and pumpkin seed oil, which the Styrians use in potato, bean and leafy salads.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Spending Your Dollars in Europe: Italy;
Make a Wish, and Try 5 or 10 Coins in the Fountain

BYLINE: By MAUREEN B. FANT

 BODY:
With the unveiling of the restored Trevi fountain, Rome this month is recalling la dolce vita, the postwar era of pleasure and prosperity and, for Americans, a muscular dollar. The not-so-sweet reality today is that Americans and Italians alike consider Italy one of the most expensive countries in Europe.
But with an exchange rate of about 1,350 lire to the dollar, against 1,200 in 1990, the dollar has risen faster than inflation (6.5 percent in June 1991). Prices in dollars are more than double 1985 levels, when the dollar broke 2,000, but are slightly better than last year. In 1985 a double room at a top hotel in Rome cost less than $200. In 1990 that room cost $466, today $414. A typical double in a small hotel in Rome cost $39 in 1985, $90 last year and $85 today. 
 Americans should budget about $1,200 for a weeklong stay, at a three-star (out of a possible five in the government rating system) hotel with meals in trattorias, for two people traveling together.
Though prices are high across the board, northern cities cost more than southern; the seaside more than the mountains; the Tyrrhenian (western) coast more than the Adriatic, and any place is cheaper out of the high season, July and August.
All of northern Europe knows about the Rimini area for bargain beach holidays. The Dolomite mountains offer fresh air and spectacular scenery for very reasonable prices. Venice is notoriously expensive, and Milan and Florence are too, but you can save by staying in a smaller city outside the metropolis (such as Padua or Jesolo for Venice; Pistoia for Florence) and commuting by train.
For logistical reasons, this option is less effective for Rome, but does work in Naples.
For normal tourist needs, a three-star hotel is sufficiently luxurious and a two-star just fine. In Rome, for a double with bath, the centrally situated three-star Hotel Portoghesi (1 Via dei Portoghesi; telephone 6864231) charges $88, including breakfast; the two-star Kolbe, across from the Forum and Palatine (44 Via St. Teodoro; 632955), charges $51, without breakfast.
Many hotels and restaurants are currently upgrading facilities and prices; be sure you have recent prices and ratings.
It's not hard to spend $75 to $100 or more for dinner for two. But you can eat well for less. At Il Dito e la Luna (51 Via dei Sabelli; 4940726) you can try traditional and "creative" dishes for around $30 a person, and that's as high as you need go. Lots of small trattorias will give you a simple meal for under $22 a person. The cheapest evening meal is pizza, not more than $11 for a pizzeria supper with beer or wine.
Inflation has not touched at least one major attraction -- a single coin in the Trevi fountain will still guarantee a return visit.

HEADLINE: Postings: Restoring Astor Row;
A Bucolic Harlem Haven

 BODY:
In the 1880's, William Astor owned much of the land between Fifth Avenue and Lenox Avenue in Harlem, and when 28 brick rowhouses with wooden porches and small front yards was built along the south side 130th Street, the street became known as Astor Row.
The houses were designated landmarks in 1981, and now an ambitious program of loans and grants, including a grant of half a million dollars from the Vincent Astor Foundation, has been created to help restore those brick facades and bucolic porches. 
 The project is being managed by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission and the New York Landmarks Conservancy, a private group, along with Astor Row homeowners who belong to the West 130th Street Block Association.
The ornately spindled and bracketed wooden porches, "together with the houses' front yards, provide a rural feeling unusual in New York City," said the Landmarks Conservancy in a statement.
Besides the Vincent Astor money, grants of up to $15,000 a house will be made available for facade work under the Facade Improvement Program of the Preservation Commission, and subsidized interior improvement loans at a 3 percent rate of interest will come from the New York City Historic Properties Fund.
Work on the street-long restoration is expected to begin in the fall.
