HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Hamden

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
HAMDEN is affectionately called the Land of the Sleeping Giant because of the huge reclining figure formed by a mountain in Sleeping Giant State Park, visible from most parts of town. Until recently the term seemed appropriate to the quiet, contented community.
But in the last five years its population has been shifting from third- and fourth-generation working people to a suburban mix that includes more transients. 
 "We get 30 to 40 percent relocated professionals," said Florence Michaud of the local Beazley Realty office. And now development is taking place in the once unspoiled western and northern hills.
Situated midway between Greenwich and Hartford and seven miles north of New Haven, Hamden is frequently the choice of two-income families when husbands and wives travel to work in opposite directions.
Typical buyers are Daniel Stanick, a sales representative for a heating and air-conditioning firm in Milford, and his fiancee, Deanne Dietrich, a legal secretary for a Hartford firm.
"We were looking for new construction," said Mr. Stanick, "so that limited our choice."
After looking at seven homes in Wallingford, North Haven and Hamden, they bought a 2,300-square-foot, 3-bedroom colonial on a half-acre on Kirk Road for $190,000.
"With current prices depressed by more than 20 percent, there are excellent opportunities between $175,000 and $225,000," said John Cuozzo, owner of a local realty firm. "Building lots are $65,000 to $200,000. Condominiums have dropped 25 percent."
Homes of 3,000 to 7,000 square feet on one to five acres are available in town from $400,000 to $900,000. On Birch Wood Drive, a handsome 3,500-square-foot house on one acre costs $250,000.
"Dozens of big houses were built three and four years ago, when land was expensive and the economy was strong," said Richard de Podesta of De Podesta Real Estate Company. "Since then, many have gone into foreclosure and are being sold at a loss."
Possibly the largest residential project in the state, the $150 million Hamden Hills, broke ground last month as a joint venture of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Connecticut and Trammell Crow Company of Dallas. In the next six years, more than 1,400 units will be built on 136 acres off Evergreen and Dixwell Avenues.
The first 430 apartments are scheduled to be completed by the end of the year. The 650- to 1,300-square-foot units will rent for $700 to $1,000 a month. Yet to be built are 1,500- to 2,400-square-foot single-family homes, 900- to 1,400-square-foot condominiums and 800- to 1,600-square-foot condominium units for the elderly. Homes will sell for $80,000 to $265,000. Common amenities include pools, tennis courts, fitness centers, clubhouses, jogging trails, children's centers and a health-care facility.
"It should bring in more than $2 million in taxes," said Mayor John Carusone, "and since we have recently enlarged the capacity of our schools and our fire and police departments, it should have no appreciable effect on town services."
Hamden operates eight lighted tennis courts, where fees are $2 an hour, a free swimming pool at the high school, 25 ball fields, 7 miles of walking trails, cross-country skiing and a petting zoo at the 195-acre Brooksvale Park, and an 18-hole golf course called Laurel View Country Club, where a season pass costs $350.
THE Miller Library complex is the cultural center of the community. Concerts, lectures, arts festivals and children's programs are offered year round in its Thornton Wilder Hall, named for the playwright, who lived in Hamden until his death in 1975.
Near the New Haven border, at Whitney Avenue and Armory Street, is the Eli Whitney arms factory, established in 1798, where Whitney originated weaponry with interchangeable parts. It was restored in the 1970's as a museum, technical school and performing arts center.
Hamden was a northern enclave of the New Haven Colony in 1638. Named for an English statesman, John Hampden, it was incorporated in 1786, and in the 18th and 19th centuries it was a mecca for Italian, Irish and German immigrants seeking jobs in its sawmills and stone quarries.
In the 20th century, prospering immigrants' descendants, bankers, businessmen, lawyers, engineers and Yale faculty members built large Tudor, Victorian and colonial homes on tree-shaded streets off Whitney Avenue. Some are still occasionally available at $450,000 and up.
The diversity of Hamden's inhabitants is reflected in its restaurants, which are informal and multi-ethnic. At one of the most popular, Friends & Co. at 4137 Whitney Avenue, international dishes are translated into an eclectic American cuisine and dinner for two is about $40.
At Hamden High School a Human Relations Club was formed to promote better understanding of the newest residents, among them Asians, Hispanics and blacks, and classes in English for foreign students are available at all levels. Out of a total enrollment of 5,379, 20 percent are from minority backgrounds.
OUTMODED school plants are being upgraded or replaced in preparation for a projected pupil increase of 10 percent in the 90's. Church Street Elementary School was replaced by a new building last year, Helen Elementary's new building is to open this fall and Alice Peck, the town's ninth elementary school, will reopen in September. A middle school for grades seven and eight remains untouched.
Hamden High, built in 1935, is one of five Connecticut high schools to participate in the International Baccalaureate Program administered in Geneva and New York City. Around 50 students a year take special classes and examinations in English, a foreign language, science, math, social science and an elective, resulting in advanced college placement.
The drama department won 12 out of the past 15 Connecticut High School Drama Festivals, but Scholastic Aptitude Test scores in math remain below state levels. They have improved, but an intensified math program in the elementary grades begins next year.
Hamden Hall Country Day School, a private, 80-year-old college preparatory institution, places 15 foreign students a year in area homes. The remaining 535 pupils come from 25 towns and 30 ethnic backgrounds. Annual tuition ranges from $8,300 to $9,650.
If a State Supreme Court decision expected this fall favors the planning and zoning commission over protesting neighborhood groups, Hamden could acquire its first mall. Upscale shoppers currently drive to the Danbury Mall, the Meriden Mall and even the Waterford Mall, 50 miles away.
A 600,000-square-foot enclosed mall has been proposed by Homart of Chicago and the Fusco Corporation of New Haven, to be built on 36 acres along Dixwell Avenue. Sears, which owns the land and has a store on the site, and G. Fox, a Hartford-based department store, would be the anchors for 100 shops and a food court.

The festivals, covering the last two weeks of April and the first week in May when the plants are ablaze, include free concerts, folk dancing, forums on local issues, baseball and soccer tournaments and a Golden Bells Ball, at which civic groups are honored for public service. "We chose 'golden bells' for a name," said Chris Rendeiro, chairman of the event since its inception, "because the children couldn't pronounce forsythia."

HEADLINE: Opinion Split On Proposals For Chemical Cleanups

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
WHEN the State Department of Environmental Protection recently proposed regulations that would make the state the first in the nation to establish comprehensive standards for cleaning up chemically contaminated sites, the department asked for reactions from people and businesses concerned with environmental law.
The department sent out 900 queries and received 105 replies, many of them praising the request for their opinions, but some criticizing the proposal. 
 Some environmentalists surveyed said that while the regulations might protect people from being exposed to hazardous chemicals, they would not go far enough in protecting the environment from man-made pollution.
Some specialists in hazardous-waste removal said the draft regulations perpetuated the practice of establishing cleanup standards that were unnecessarily strict and enormously costly to comply with. And some business executives and lawyers said the regulations would encourage industry to shun the state's larger cities and relocate, taking industry to otherwise pristine lands.
The draft proposal establishes numerical standards for the cleanup of contaminated areas. Most states, including New Jersey, either address cleanup case by case or handle it under legislation on specific environmental threats, like underground storage tanks or ground-water pollution.
The draft is expected to be revised and published as an official regulatory proposal later this year. The regulation is then subject to the final approval of the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, Scott A. Weiner.
"What the department is trying to do here is answer the long-debated question, how clean is clean?" said Lance R. Miller, an assistant commissioner of the department. "And that is a very difficult question to answer."
 
'Pressure' for Unified Standards
 Dr. Richard Greenberg, president of Environmental Waste Management Associates, an environmental cleanup concern based in Wayne, and one of the experts the department asked for comment, said, "The department has been under pressure for a while to come up with unified cleanup standards."
Under current law, he said, property owners sometimes face vague or even conflicting rules on removing chemical contamination. For example, he said, a property owner might remove an underground tank under one set of regulations, then a year later, in trying to sell his land, find himself subject to another set. "So you were subject to a double jeopardy," Dr. Greenberg said.
The proposal, he said, would establish acceptable levels for chemical contaminants in soil, ground water and building interiors. In addition, Dr. Greenberg said, the proposal treats contamination in certain areas differently from contamination in other areas. For example, he said, industrial areas might not have to be as clean as areas that might be used for housing.
And different standards would apply to contaminated soil that is within two feet of the surface. That soil is presumed to be exposed to people and would be held to a stricter standard than soil farther below the ground. Stricter standards would also apply to soil over potable aquifers.
"If human contact and human drinking uses are a concern, they use a more stringent standard," Dr. Greenberg said.
In general, he said, the proposed standards are not as stringent as some current state standards. If a property owner could prove that contamination was not likely to migrate into ground water or come in contact with people, it might be allowed to remain at higher levels.
But that concession does not come without a price, Dr. Greenberg said.
"They've made accommodations, but then they take all those accommodations right back with one little item that they threw in," he said. "Essentially, they came forward with their draft regulations and said: 'We're going to allow you to keep this contamination in place, but we want one little thing in return. We want you to put a notice on your deed saying that this property contains hazardous waste.' "
The notice, called a deed restriction, would alert potential buyers to the contamination and could restrict future uses of the property. The proposed regulations would also require property owners to give the department a perpetual easement to enter the property for cleanup or testing.
 
'No One Will Buy It'
 Dr. Greenberg said he opposed those two rules. "The deed restriction and the perpetual easement are absurd," he said. "You can't get financing on such a property, and you can't sell it because no one will buy it."
Because most contaminated sites are in older, urban industrialized areas, he said, the proposal would create an environmental and economical paradox.
"They will restrict development of the urban properties and encourage industry to move out into the country and develop pristine properties, while letting the center of our cities continue to rot," he said.
Among the experts who said that the standards were too stringent was William D'Angelo, president of Kaselaan and D'Angelo Associates, an environmental engineering company in Haddon Heights.
"There's been a great deal of concern that we're spending a lot of time and money getting down to numbers that really don't give us more risk reduction," he said. While removing 95 percent of the contamination might eliminate 95 percent of the risk, he said, removing the last 5 percent might cost more in time and money than the small reduction would warrant.
"Some cleanup projects will just never meet some of the standards they've set," Mr. D'Angelo said.
 
'Some Significant Concerns'
 But environmentalists said the standards were not strict enough.
"We have some significant concerns," said Edward Lloyd, general counsel for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, a public advocacy organization, and director of the Environmental Law Clinic at the Rutgers University Law School in Newark.
Mr. Lloyd said the environment was threatened by smaller levels of contamination than threatened people. "It's the D.E.P.'s duty to protect both the environment and human health," he said, "and we think this proposal totally fails to protect the environment."
Mr. Lloyd said his organization compared the proposed standards with Federal Environmental Protection Agency regulations governing land disposal of hazardous waste and "found that the E.P.A. standards were tens to hundreds to thousand of times more stringent than the D.E.P. standards."
"Toxins in the ecosystem can be far more toxic to fish or plants than to humans," he said. "We have to protect those ecosystems as well as protecting human health. And these standards fail to do that."
 
Suggestion Called Absurd
 On the deed restriction, he said: "I don't think deed restrictions protect either public health or the environment. We recommend that if you're going to put a deed restriction in, you should have the property fenced off and put up huge signs that say this site does not meet minimum cleanup standards."
But business people who sell industrial property call such a suggestion absurd.
"You do that and you destroy the tax base of every urban center in this state," said David T. Houston Jr., the president of a real-estate brokerage in Bloomfield that bears his name. He said the Department of Environmental Protection was already too intrusive in regulating industry.
"Some of the standards we've got are far too strict anyhow," he said. "Some of them aren't even achievable."
 
Worried About Legal Aspects
 David B. Farer, an environmental lawyer from Westfield, said he was worried about the legal aspects of the proposed regulations. He said he was particularly concerned about a provision that would allow "any citizen of the State of New Jersey" to sue a landowner whose property was subject to a deed restriction if the citizen believed that the landowner was violating the restriction.
"This substantially expands the rights of nonparties to sue individuals who enter these agreements," he said. Only people who are likely to suffer damage or the department should be allowed to sue, he said.
Despite his reservations, however, Mr. Farer, like most experts who have commented on the proposal, said the department should be commended for its efforts to solicit early recommendations.
"The D.E.P. is in a very difficult position here," Mr. Farer said. "On the one hand, they've got the environmental lobby watching every move they make, and on the other hand they have a very well-organized and intense business lobby telling them at every turn that they're pushing business out of New Jersey."
Mr. Miller, the department's assistant commissioner, said the agency had anticipated the debate that the proposal has generated.
"It is resulting in a lot of rethinking on our part," he said. "We didn't think we had all the answers when we put out this draft, and the comments we've received have affirmed that."

HEADLINE: County Considers Opening An Off-Track Betting Theater

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
"COME on, baby! You're all alone!" a gleeful supporter yelled at Mary in theMorning, a 3-year-old filly who had pulled out of the pack and was roaring down the backstretch on her way to winning the second race at Saratoga last week.
No matter that the man was a few hundred miles away in Connecticut, shouting at a giant video screen. In his air-conditioned grandstand seat at the Teletrack in New Haven, he was part of it all. The three-story-high screen simulcasts the latest odds and the race, while betting windows, snack bars and cocktail lounges are just a few steps away. 
 That scene may soon be repeated in Westchester, where county officials are negotiating a contract with the New York Racing Association to build a $10 million teletheater in the central part of the county, although no site has been picked.
The contract could be ready by the middle of September, Roger Biagi, the deputy county executive, said last week. But he added that the negotiations have been difficult and that the outcome is not assured.
If agreement is reached with the nonprofit racing organization and approved by the County Board of Legislators, Westchester's first venture into off-track betting could give the county an additional $6 million in yearly revenue, with another $1 million going to the municipality where the teletheater is situated.
 
A Rejection of OTB
 The latest of several proposals for an off-track betting system in Westchester came last year from County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke in his State of the County address.
After review by a special bipartisan legislative committee set up to consider revenue sources for the county and changes in state law governing off-track betting in Westchester, a decision was made to negotiate with the New York State Racing Association rather than to join the regional Offtrack Betting Corporation.
The teletheater would be the first off-track betting system in the state controlled by the association under contract with a county, and not by a group of cities and counties that have chosen to join one of the state's six regional OTB corporations.
The proposed single-site arrangement, advocates say, would give Westchester County more control over betting operations and a larger share of the profits. Up to this point the association has had no control over off-track betting profits, except those it generates from its track-to-track simulcasting system.
Under the OTB regional concept, participating local governments in a designated multi-county region share in a percentage of the profits under a formula based on each county's population and wagering totals. Because the OTB system allows the corporation to establish as many betting parlors as may be profitable and to override local zoning in determining their location, the concept has proved unpopular in Westchester.
Although the proposed teletheater would avoid these conflicts, it would compete with the Yonkers Raceway, the county's only professional sports arena and the only place to bet on horse racing, with live harness racing each night and simulcast thoroughbred racing every afternoon. Officials of the New York Racing Association insist that the Westchester betting market can accommodate both locations. But Yonkers political leaders and race track officials concede that they are worried about the future of one of the city's largest taxpayers and employers.
"I want to be fully versed on the potential impact before I sign off on it," said Katherine S. Carsky, a Republican legislator representing Yonkers. "If the raceway were to leave, it would not only leave a significant amount of space to be sold at a down time in the economy, but it would generate tax certioraris and threaten 1,200 jobs."
Mrs. Carsky is chairwoman of the Budget and Finance Committee, which would review a completed contract.
 
Fourth-Largest Taxpayer
 "Obviously, we are very concerned about the impact on the raceway and on the city," said Thomas J. McSpedon, Commissioner of Finance and Management Services for Yonkers. The raceway is the city's fourth-largest taxpayer.
"If the racetrack left, it would leave a $7 million hole in our budget, and I don't know where we would fill it," Mr. McSpedon said.
The raceway pays about $2 million in city taxes, but Yonkers receives an additional $4.2 million annual surcharge imposed on winning bets placed at state Offtrack Betting locations on races run at Yonkers.
The 92-year-old track has struggled to survive a series of misfortunes since the glory days of the 1960's. In those days, 30,000 to 40,000 fans crowded the grandstand every evening and helped make Yonkers the first harness track in history to handle $3 million in a single night.
 
Afternoon Simulcasting
 In the last 20 years, a series of setbacks, including competition from the Meadowlands, Atlantic City and the off-track betting market has contributed to an 88 percent decline in attendance, said Timothy J. Rooney, the raceway president. Last year, just when the situation seemed hopeless, simulcasting gave bettors a reason to come back to the track, or at least to the audio and visual coverage of other races that Yonkers Raceway now provides.
The introduction of afternoon simulcasting at the raceway, under a contract with the New York Racing Association, has kept the track alive, offering track-to-track telecasts of thoroughbred racing at Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga and providing a daily average handle of $330,000.
A competing teletheater, although operated by the same association, would provide the same coverage and have "an adverse affect" on raceway operations, Mr. Rooney said, referring to county and raceway studies that predict a 10 percent loss in the handle at the track.
A decline in revenue would also affect state and city shares of the fees and taxes paid by the Yonkers track, which are $7 million to the city and $8 million to the state.
"We have weathered lots of storms, but we have been doing it from much higher heights," Mr. Rooney said, adding that although he is worried, he would wait to see what the future brings.
"For years, we have known we could develop the property and make more money," but his sports-minded family, he said, "likes doing what we are doing."
The five brothers in the Rooney family also own the Pittsburgh Steelers football team, an organization founded by their father, Arthur J. Rooney, as well as dog tracks in Vermont and Florida.
 
Local Zoning an Issue
 Race track owners have realized that the dramatic switch from betting at a track to off-track betting, which they once vigorously opposed, must be accommodated, Mr. Rooney said, and they can do so profitably. "OTB brought us to the 20th century," he said. "Now closed-circuit TV will take us into the 21st."
Although the potential profits of off-track betting have tempted many Westchester political leaders, county legislators have refused to endorse an OTB system that would supersede local zoning. Neighboring Putnam County has been in turmoil over the issue since legislators there approved the measure last year.
In April, the State Supreme Court in White Plains threw out a challenge by Putnam County political leaders opposed to OTB. Current efforts by the Catskill Region OTB to place a betting parlor in Carmel have met stiff local opposition, and the town board has been flooded with petitions from angry citizens in the neighborhood.
 
Breaking a Monopoly
 Although New York was the first state to permit off-track betting, it did so over the objections of track owners, and it is now the only state in which the off-track betting system is not supervised by the race track owners.
If Westchester reaches an agreement with the New York Racing Association, it would break the monopoly that municipalities have held over off-track receipts, said John M. Dailey, director of racing and OTB for the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.
"The tracks will muscle in and take over," he said. "They want to market their own product."

HEADLINE: PROFILE;
Switch-Hitter Of Academe

BYLINE: By Roberto Suro

 BODY:
WHEN Barry Munitz was appointed Chancellor of the California State University, the nation's largest four-year university system, both supporters and detractors fixated on the uncanny ease with which he moves between the worlds of public service and private interests.
In the last 25 years, Mr. Munitz has switched from college teaching to foundation work to major posts at the Universities of Illinois and Houston to his most recent post as vice chairman of Maxxam Inc., a Houston-based holding company involved in several controversial corporate takeovers and in the failure of a large savings and loan association. 
 His most recent career change began on Thursday, when Mr. Munitz took office at Cal State, returning to the kind of job he once described as "caught between rising expectations of accountability and declining flexibility of action."
 
 
'That Fuzzy Ambiguity'
 The dilemma, he says, is now more acute than ever at Cal State, which has some 370,000 students on 20 campuses and is battling to defend its $2 billion budget from proposed cuts in the 5 to 10 percent range.
"Compared to the private sector," Mr. Munitz said, "where decisions can be made quickly and implemented relatively cleanly, I'm going back to that fuzzy ambiguity of faculty senates, deans and campus presidents, where you have to be extraordinarily cautious to be sure that every base is touched and every potential decision is adequately reviewed." To prepare for the switch, he said, "I have been adding several gates between my brain and my mouth."
At a news conference after his selection by the Cal State trustees was announced April 4, Mr. Munitz was asked why he took the job. He joked, "It's not for the salary," and indeed his pay of $175,000 a year as chancellor is less than half what he was making at Maxxam.
In a recent interview, he elaborated: "At a certain time I came to believe that to be truly useful in the broadest sense you had to understand both worlds, public and private. One of the reasons I'm going back is that there is a limit to what a corporation can or should do on public-policy issues."
There is no such limit to what the head of such a vast university system can do regarding national debates on educational policy, and Mr. Munitz is already sketching out a strategy for some fundamental issues.
He believes, for example, that a large public system like Cal State should make itself a bigger part of the educational process that begins in prekindergarten; that definitions of prestige should be revised to give undergraduate teaching greater recognition, and that the state should encourage the university to seek extra compensation for this mission from the private sector.
Mr. Munitz, who is 50 years old, approaches these tasks with a deep appreciation of the university's role in society. His own undergraduate experience was at Brooklyn College, which was then free of charge. "Like many Cal State students," he said, "I came from an immigrant background, and Brooklyn College was the only place I could go for an education. It was my only prayer for socioeconomic mobility."
Mr. Munitz's extended family came from Eastern Europe to the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, where he and his sister were born and raised. Only their father, Raymond, an accountant, had attended college. Raymond's talent for chess led him to the Marshall Chess Club in Manhattan, often accompanied by his son. Mr. Munitz said his father taught him to play chess before he learned to read.
His parents were divorced when he was 8; Mr. Munitz lived with his mother. During college, he held full-time night jobs to help support his family.
Typically, the career path that leads to top university posts is paved with faculty positions and jobs like provost or school dean, and Mr. Munitz began conventionally enough -- as a junior professor of comparative literature at the University of California at Berkeley. "I studied literature because I thought there was no better life style than to get paid to read and then have a bunch of people listen to you talk about what you've read," said Mr. Munitz, who earned his doctorate at Princeton.
He is still a voracious reader and jokes with friends that he maintains two lists on his refrigerator door: one of people who have died while reading, which so far has only one entry, Pope John Paul I, and another of the many people who have died while exercising.
After less than three years on the Berkeley faculty, where he went upon receiving his Ph.D., Mr. Munitz gave up teaching full time. He had caught the eye of Clark Kerr, then president of the University of Californa, and the first of Mr. Munitz's well-positioned mentors. When Mr. Kerr became chairman of the Carnegie Foundation Commission on Higher Education in 1968, he recruited Mr. Munitz as a staff associate.
Two years later Mr. Munitz moved to the University of Illinois, and was promoted to academic vice president of the Illinois system in 1972. At 35, he was appointed chancellor of the University of Houston-Central Campus in 1977.
By then Mr. Munitz was a professional university administrator. "Barry is a well-recognized student of the process of academic governance," said Harold Enarson, president of Ohio State from 1972 to 1981 and now a consultant to various universities, who has known Mr. Munitz since his Houston days.
In 1982, Mr. Munitz was a candidate for chancellor of Cal State when a friend and tennis partner, Charles Hurwitz, persuaded him to choose the business executive's life.
Mr. Hurwitz played the hardball game of corporate takeovers and leveraged buyouts during the 1980's. A worldly New Yorker, Mr. Munitz aidedhim in top management positions, but often specialized in tasks requiring diplomacy.
 
 
Large Rolodexes
 A man with large Rolodexes and many of them, Mr. Munitz even today is as likely to be found at a Hollywood party with his old friend, movie producer Sherry Lansing, as playing host at a fund-raiser for Senator Bill Bradley, whom he has known since Princeton.
"Someone on the ordinary academic career track could never have accumulated Barry's extraordinary network of individual and corporate contacts," said Alex Schilt, chancellor of the University of Houston system. "He will use those contacts to help his institution move forward in terms of fact as well as perceptions."
But Mr. Munitz may just as easily suffer from a corporate-life hangover. He has already had his first headache -- a meeting with faculty members at the Cal State Sacramento campus who were seeking his ouster even before he had assumed office. The professors, and some students, objected to Mr. Munitz's involvement with the Pacific Lumber Company, which increased the number of redwoods it chopped down after its hostile takeover by Maxxam. Greeted by protesters wearing six-foot cardboard cutouts of evergreens, Mr. Munitz tried to charm them by starting, "Good morning ladies, gentlemen, trees." The audience was amused but undeterred.
Initially, his major goals do not involve changing what Cal State does so much as how it is perceived. The prevailing definition of academic prestige is symbolized by the highly selective institutions that prize faculty research, Mr. Munitz says.
By contrast, the Cal State system is primarily designed to draw from a broad pool of high school students, including those of lesser economic means, and must accommodate nontraditional undergraduates, such as part-timers and commuters.
Given California's rapid demographic growth into a multi-ethnic society and its ever-increasing demands for a more skilled work force, Mr. Munitz says, institutions like Cal State can no longer be relegated to second-class status.
"Most of the recognition and the rewards have been going to people who discover knowledge through research rather than those who transmit knowledge through teaching," he said. "At Cal State we have a chance to be a national model in giving legitimate value to what happens in the classroom."
He finds ammunition for his case in the fact that the Cal State system produces 10 percent of all the elementary and high school teachers in the nation and 70 percent of those in California. Mr. Munitz said he wanted to broaden the university's links to the public school system through the creation of model schools on Cal State campuses and expanded consultation on issues like curriculum and teaching strategies.
And at a time of ever-tighter public spending, Mr. Munitz wants to turn to the private sector for money to improve the undergraduate education that for many students is still the key to socioeconomic mobility. He thinks the private sector may be delighted to oblige.
Business executives are unhappy having to train and retrain people at the entry level, he says. "So they are coming to institutions like ours across the country to see what support we can provide. We, in turn, will be asking them to think about endowing undergraduate faculty rather than, say, giving a grant to a research institute."
He speaks as something of an interpreter of academia's needs to the corporate world. Could he envision a return to that world? Said Mr. Munitz: "That yo-yo has snapped to the finger for the last time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barry Munitz, Chancellor of the California State University, has left the private sector to return to the public arena of campus life. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
Dollar bills come and go so quickly that hardly anyone ever thinks of the strange design on the back: the great seal of the United States, with its bristling eagle, strange pyramid and hovering eye.
Who would take the time, buying a cup of coffee or an ice-cream cone, to consider the mystery of these symbols, which change hands countless times every day? 
 Over the years many attempts have been made to give a reason for the presence of the symbols on the seal and the bill. One explanation is that many leaders of the American Revolution were Freemasons, and that the group's symbols might therefore have found their way into symbols of the emerging nation.
That is by no means the accepted explanation. In "The Eagle and the Shield: a History of the Great Seal of the United States," a 1976 State Department publication, Richard S. Patterson and Richardson Dougall argue that, "It seems likely that the designers of the Great Seal and the Masons took their symbols from parallel sources, and unlikely that the seal designers consciously copied Masonic symbols."
But the argument that there are Masonic elements in the seal can be a discussion-stopper. Who wants to think that a national symbol is linked with a secret organization?
Those who support the case for Masonic symbolism recall that in England in the late 1600's, stonemasons found their numbers declining. To bolster their rolls they began accepting honorary members: men who couldn't lay a course of stone but were highly regarded by their neighbors and might have had a few quid for refreshments.
By 1717, a Grand Lodge was formed in London, and by 1738 the old order of stonemasons had evolved into the Ancient Free and Accepted Masons, an order with few real masons but many "accepted," or honorary, members. The implements of masonry began to take on symbolic meanings, many of them religious.
American Masons first met in 1720 in Boston. Within half a century, Freemasons were meeting in the lodge rooms of Boston and at the Green Dragon Tavern there, plotting the overthrow of the British colonial authorities.
While many non-Masons were also involved, Masonic historians say that three of the best-known firebrands -- Peter Faneuil, Paul Revere and John Hancock -- were Masons.
With many of the 56 signers of the Declaration of Independence Freemasons, it is possible that when the great seal of the United States was to be designed, Masons were among those asked to help prepare it. While it is hard to know today what the designers were thinking, some modern Masons point out some interesting associations.
The eye, they say, is the eye of the all-seeing Grand Architect, a Masonic term for God. And to Masons the pyramid signifies the release of the Israelites from slavery in Egypt, a theme the economically enslaved colonists may have embraced.
There are certainly many symbolic elements that have less to do with Freemasonry than with the Revolution. The pyramid has 13 courses of stone, one for each rebel colony, and the date across the bottom, shown in Roman numerals, is 1776.
The motto "Annuit Coeptis," Latin for "He has favored our undertaking," appears above the pyramid. "Novus Ordo Seclorum," meaning "A new order of the ages," appears underneath.
On the right side of the reverse of the dollar bill appears the face of the great seal, the coat of arms of the United States. Here it is more difficult to make a case that the symbols are specifically Masonic. But some Masons assert that the eagle represents the patron of Freemasonry, St. John the Evangelist.
It might take the most imaginative of symbolists to find a Masonic connection in the number of feathers the eagle displays. But some who are that imaginative note that one wing has 32 feathers and the other 33.
Perhaps it is just chance: who would require an artist to depict the same number (or any particular number) of feathers in each wing of an eagle? But it is at least a coincidence that 32 and 33 are the highest number of degrees conferred on a Mason as he passes through the Scottish rites, one of two series available to a Mason. The other, called the York, has only 9 ranks -- the number of feathers in the eagle's tail.
Whether these symbols are truly derived from Freemasonry or were just an amalgam of popular designs of the late 18th century, no one may ever know. But the odd design can certainly give pause.

HEADLINE: Ledith M. Blair Marries in Dallas

 BODY:
Ledith Marie Blair and Lance Galen Gilliland, M.B.A. candidates at the University of Texas, were married yesterday at Casa View Baptist Church in Dallas. The Rev. Dr. Charles Haney Jr. performed the ceremony.
Mrs. Gilliland, 26 years old, graduated from Baylor University as did her husband, 23. Until recently she was a consultant in the financial-services group of Andersen Consulting in New York. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joe N. Blair of Dallas. Her father is the director of policy administration for Southwestern Life Insurance Company in Dallas. Her mother, Virginia Blair, is a vocational home-economics teacher at Skyline High School in Dallas. 
 The bridegroom was until recently a financial analyst in the fixed-income capital markets group at Kidder Peabody. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald C. Gilliland of Oklahoma City, where his father is in private practice as an ophthalmologist. The bridegroom's mother, Janice Gilliland, manages the office.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: July 28 - August 2

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Buffet Takes a Stake in American Express
Warren E. Buffett, one of the world's most successful investors, wanted more of the American Express Company than he actually bought last week. "But Jimmy didn't want to issue that many shares," he said referring to James D. Robinson 3d, chairman of American Express. So Mr. Buffett, who is chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., contented himself with a mere $300 million purchase of preferred shares, convertible into 12.2 million common shares at the discretion of American Express. The cash will help Mr. Robinson clean up his company's balance sheet. In return, Berkshire gets higher dividends than common shareholders (the ones that don't call Mr. Robinson "Jimmy"). Berkshire gets 8.6 percent, common shareholders are getting 3.6 percent. But share appreciation is limited. "This deal won't make us as rich as the last couple of deals," said Mr. Buffett. But then he is already a billionaire.
 
Dingell Takes On Citicorp
Representative John D. Dingell may be a powerhouse in Washington, but Citicorp thinks he's a pretty poor banking analyst. Last week, Mr. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and an outspoken foe of the Administration's proposal to give banks more powers, said Citicorp was "technically insolvent" and "struggling to survive." He also asserted that Citicorp was borrowing heavily from the Federal Reserve. Citicorp disagreed. So did L. William Seidman, the nation's top banking regulator, who added that he did not believe Citicorp was "insolvent under any standard." Citicorp issued a statement saying it had borrowed from the Fed just twice in the last 12 months and only for a day at a time. Not a bad record. The big bank's stock barely budged after Mr. Dingell's diatribe, closing the week at $14.25.
 
Stumbling Along at T.W.A.
 The best deal, they say, is the one that makes all parties equally unhappy. By that standard, Trans World Airlines's reorganization plan, still to be approved by Federal regulators, is a very good deal. Under it, T.W.A. would land in bankruptcy court sometime next year. Carl C. Icahn, who now owns 90 percent of the faltering airline, is to turn over most of his stock to T.W.A.'s creditors. He loses control. In return for stock, the creditors, who originally wanted cash, have agreed to wipe out about $1 billion of T.W.A.'s debt. But what about the airline? With the nation's oldest planes and a stripped-down route structure, it still needs money to survive. The deal may not give it enough.
 
B.C.C.I. - More Charges Fly
For nearly a month, tales of the misdeeds of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International have been circling the globe. The bank has been home to drug lords, terrorists, spies and money launderers, it is alleged. Last week, a grand jury in New York City handed up a 12-count indictment naming the bank and two of its officials: Aga Hassan Abedi, the Pakistani who founded B.C.C.I., and Swaleh Naqvi, its former chief operating officer. But also last week, William von Raab, the former Commissioner of Customs, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the Bush Administration had been dragging its feet. B.C.C.I. should have been investigated years before. Now the case is before a New York bankruptcy judge.
 
Those Irksome Gas Contracts
Long-term thinking is supposed to pay off big, right? It didn't for Columbia Gas System Inc., one of the nation's largest natural gas companies. It filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 last week. The company said its long-term supply contracts were forcing it to pay up to five times the current market price for natural gas. But according to David N. Fleischer, who follows the company for Prudential Securities, the company's net worth is far greater than the $1 billion it said it would lose from the contracts. The company agrees. Mr. Fleischer says the bankruptcy filing may be a ploy to force a renegotiation of the company's long-term contracts.
 
Helmsley Still Headed for Jail
 New lawyer or not, Leona Helmsley is likely to spend time behind bars. She was sentenced in August 1989 to four years in prison and ordered to pay a total of $9 million for, among other things, evading taxes by billing luxury items (and some not-so-luxury items, like girdles) to her hotel business. But last week the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in New York upheld the conviction. No new trial, the judges said. One concession: the sentence will be reassessed. The Supreme Court next?.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Favor for the U.S.S.R.
 The list of goods the Soviet Union has to trade reads like a description of a neighborhood lawn sale: lots of handicrafts, a few useful and not-so-useful scientific gadgets, but not much in the way of really tantalizing goods. So last week, when President Bush granted the Soviet Union most-favored-nation status, it was mostly symbolic. Yet, putting the Soviet Union on equal footing with America's other major trading partners makes it a full participant in the world economy. The change in status must be submitted to Congress.
 
Detroit Eats Japan's Dust, Again
In the technology department, Japan already seems to be positioning itself for the next oil shortage. The Honda Motor Company and Mitsubishi Motors last week revealed new fuel-efficient engines that will go on sale soon. These engines will improve mileage in cars by 10 to 25 percent -- much more economical than Detroit's offerings. "Ford and G.M. are working on the same technologies," said Richard Ko, an analyst in Tokyo. "But the speed with which Japan is bringing these to market will open the gap even further."
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
A Candle in the Gloom
 Some economists were beginning to fear the economy might lurch back into recession. Growth in the gross national product was as weak as a summer breeze. But last week even the gloomiest economists had at least some of their fears allayed. Personal income and consumer spending were both up by a surprisingly strong 0.5 percent for June, according to the Commerce Department. Since the consumer accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity, those numbers have real clout. "It's another piece of data that the third quarter is locked in as fairly solid," said Lawrence H. Meyer, an economist in St. Louis who heads his own forecasting firm.
 
The Economy's Slothful Growth
The Commerce Department's index of 11 leading economic indicators -- the Government's primary forecasting tool of economic growth -- grew by 0.5 percent in June. That's good news because the indicator usually gives a fairly accurate glimpse of economic activity six to nine months into the future. But a closer look at the components of the indicator reveals that all is still not well. Six of the 11 indicators shrunk back. "The increases are less than we've been accustomed to in a recovery," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. That means growth, but just barely.
 
Behind the Good Numbers
Unemployment dropped in July to 6.8 percent, from 7 percent, the Labor Department said last week. A tiny shift, granted, but at least a move in the right direction. Still, economists felt little joy. The drop in unemployment was accompanied by a decline in the size of the nation's payroll. According to the Labor Department, 51,000 jobs were eliminated in July, on top of 20,000 the month before. "The major message is that the decrease in unemployment camouflages weakness underneath," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago.
 
The Big Board Backs Off
Futurists say the world is supposed to be moving toward global, 24-hour trading. If it is, last week that march encountered an obstacle. The Big Board said it would backtrack from a plan to open half an hour earlier and stay open later at night. The Big Board currently does business from 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. The exchange's West Coast members, who work from 6:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. Pacific Time, do not want to start at 6:00 A.M. But what about the 24-hour day? "It will take 5 to 10 years to evolve," said Joseph Hardiman, president of the National Securities Dealers Association, a rival to the Big Board that is also attempting to trade securities on a longer day. That still assumes Californians -- and everyone else -- will give up some sleep.
 
Nice Try, Bridgeport
When Mayor Mary C. Moran, said Bridgeport, Conn., would seek protection from its creditors under Chapter 9 of the Federal bankruptcy law, it was a stretch. Especially since the city had $25 million in the bank. Last week U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Alan H. W. Schiff, ruled against the city. Chapter 9, he said, is for chronic problems, not for balancing a budget that is temporarily out of whack.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Bank Rates, Low Now, Even Lower Later

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
There are people around -- this columnist among them -- who can remember a savings account paying 3 percent interest. But for many Americans, such low interest rates seem outrageous.
"Savers rolling over C.D.'s are beyond being surprised," says Chuck Clough, Merrill Lynch's chief strategist. "Now they're getting madder and madder." Rates are nearing 5 percent. 
 Those persistently lower rates may tell the most important investment story of 1991. They are cited by bulls as providing fuel for booming stock and bond markets, and by bears as a sign of the deflationary credit crunch that may bring back recession.
The bullish case is more enjoyable to contemplate and has the virtue of having a lot of history on its side. In the past, low short-term rates have generally helped to spark rallies in stocks and bonds.
Investors who want yield must take some risk, and inevitably some of the money that had been in bank accounts will flow into other assets. Bulls talk of a return to the good old days of the 1960's, when stocks formed a much larger percentage of the average family's financial assets than they now do. Last week the Dow Jones industrial average fell just short of setting a new record, rising 33.76 points, to 3,006.26.
But before rushing to buy, at a time when low dividend yields on stocks already reflect a lot of optimism about the economy, it may be worth asking just why short-term interest rates are so low.
One answer is that banks don't want the money. They have been burned by bad loans, and new capital rules provide an incentive for banks to shrink assets. So the banks are, as Mr. Clough puts it, "bidding down" for deposits. Holders of maturing C.D.'s at Citibank are even being called these days by the bank and urged to consider other investments, including bonds.
During the real estate boom, many commercial mortgages were written to require balloon payments in a few years. The assumption was that they would be refinanced then. Now the question is who will step up to renew the loans. John Garamendi, the California insurance commissioner, says the banks are trying to get out, while insurers don't want to write new mortgages.
"In the past," says James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer and a bear on stocks, "the extreme of recklessness in credit has been corrected by an extreme of timidness."
Such a refusal to lend is bad news for job creation, and could be a precursor to more drops in asset values, with would-be buyers unable to finance purchases. Such declines could lead to an even greater hostility to lending and to more failures of financial institutions.
Mr. Clough, a bull on bonds, is not that pessimistic. "What this says to me is that there is a bit of a high wire act," with the risk being deflation and the hope being low inflation with decent growth.
But he is confident that lower short-term rates are here to stay. "The 3 percent savings account," he forecasts, "may come back."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Postwar Winners and Losers

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
THOUGH the United States and its allies were victorious in the fighting that grew out of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the impact of Saddam Hussein lingers on in some of the world's financial markets a year after the invasion.
Of the 24 stock markets followed in the Financial Times world index, only 10 have returned to or surpassed their pre-invasion levels since reaching their lows before the actual fighting began in January. 
 The 10 rising markets include those in the United States, up 9.5 percent over the Aug. 1, 1990 level; Great Britain, up 9.5 percent; Hong Kong, up 16.8 percent; Mexico, up 113.7 percent; the Netherlands, up 3.3 percent; South Africa, up 8.4 percent, and Canada, off now just 0.6 percent after passing the Aug. 1, 1990 level in March.
Of the remaining 14, 10 are still 10 percent or more below the Aug. 1, 1990. Of these, the Austrian market was off 31.2 percent; New Zealand, 25.1 percent; Italy, 21.6 percent; Norway, 18.7 percent; Germany, 17.7 percent; Japan, 14.6 percent, and France, 10.7 percent. (The Financial Times index will not match exactly the performance of the main local stock market indexes because the it may have a different mix of stocks and a different number than the local index.)
To be sure, President Hussein's invasion intruded on stock markets already weakend by rising interest rates, the onset of recessions in the United States and Britain and economies, like those in Continental Europe, that were slowing down.
But the shock that Iraq's invasion caused, the ensuing rise in oil prices and the drop in consumer confidence all combined to drive the markets down sharply. Returning from this extra-low point has made the struggle to come back difficult for many of the markets.
"There is no doubt that the downturn was made much more severe by Saddam,," said Geoffrey Dennis, a global strategist for James Capel Inc. in New York.
This has been especially true in Continental Europe, where stock markets declined sharply after the invasion. And instead of rebounding, these markets have had to endure a second blow from slowing economies and relatively high interest rates that have been mandated by Germany's tight monetary policy.
Though Japan's stock market is down, too, it seems to have suffered more from Japan's domestic economic and political problems -- and lately an embarrassing stock scandal -- than from the shadow of the invasion. Its economy was not slowed by concern over the invasion and its market plunge preceded the invasion and still continues. Japan's 14.6 percent market drop in the past year is still not as steep as those in many of its European counterparts.
The postwar bull markets have been in the United States, Britain, Mexico and South Africa. Their markets rose less than the world average of 16.4 percent during the war rally starting Jan. 16, the beginning of the bombing of Iraq, and ending Feb. 27, when President Bush declared a ceasefire. Since then, however, they have moved on to new record highs. In the United States and Britain, the moving forces were lower interest rates and the expectation of an end to the recession. In South Africa, the lifting of economic sanctions, a rally in gold stocks and a mad scramble of local investors for stocks has been more than enough, so far, to overwhelm the political scandals of the DeKlerk Government and the doubts about a smooth transition to a post-aparteid government.
In Mexico, the rally is one that just doesn't want to die. The Mexican market's 113.71 percent gain since the Iraqi invasion has been powered by the economic reforms of the Salinas Government and the hope for a successful negotiation of a free trade agreement with the United States.
The market in Hong Kong has also moved to record highs on the back of an agreement with China on a new airport in the colony, a rally in property stocks and the expected renewal of China's most-favored-nation trade status with the United States.
Other signposts in the year since the invasion of Kuwait: Bank stocks worldwide outperformed the aerospace and defense sector, with banks rising 4.5 percent in dollar terms while defense is up 2.2 percent since Aug. 1, 1990. Banks have had a small recovery from very low levels and got a big boost, rising 19.4 percent, during the rally in January and February.
Defense stocks received only a modest boost from the quick success of the war. Otherwise, the negative impact of defense budget cuts around the world seemed to hold sway as the Communist threat continued to diminish with the changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
The best performing sector worldwide since the February ceasefire has been precious metals and minerals, up 14.4 percent. The rise has been propelled by a rally in gold stocks.
The best performing sector in the year since the invasion was health and personal care, up 17.8 percent. The stocks are considered natural buys during economic slowdowns and recessions because of consistent consumer demand. The worst performers were automobiles, down 20.9 percent, and construction and building materials, down 21.0 percent.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 21; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 925 words

HEADLINE: Managing;
Generosity Toes the (Bottom) Line

SERIES: First of two articles on corporate philanthropy.

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
EXECUTIVES in charge of corporate contributions used to worry exclusively about society, while their counterparts on the business side tended to profits. The philosophical paths never crossed.
Now, as both sides try to make do with slashed budgets, the separatism is ending. "We won't make a grant that doesn't fit the business strategy," said Cornelia Higginson, the vice president in charge of overseas giving for the American Express Company. Neither will Paul M. Ostergard, director of corporate contributions for Citibank. "A professional contributions manager puts the company's interest first," he said. "It's a classic case of doing well by doing good."
The timing is no coincidence. As the 1960's hippies and the 1970's yuppies move into positions of power, social conscience and capitalistic pragmatism have replaced social climbing as a prime mover behind corporate giving. "Old-line C.E.O.'s used donations to get on symphony boards; today's C.E.O.'s use the money as a strategic tool," said Craig Smith, publisher of Corporate Philanthropy Report, a Seattle newsletter.
The recession has caused most companies to cut their marketing and contributions budgets at a time when nonprofit groups are also strapped for cash. While the trend may hurt small, esoteric nonprofit groups, the larger, savvier ones have used their new entree to marketing departments to get advertising and promotional advice. And they pander to self-interest -- pointing out that sponsoring an avant-garde arts show will position a company as innovative or that supporting child care programs will help it attract women as customers.
The result: The Chinese wall between giving and selling has come down. Mr. Smith says 55 percent of contributions managers have regular contact with marketing directors. Nissan Motor Corporation in U.S.A. asks line managers to review philanthropic projects. Citibank, American Express and GTE Northwest offer discounts or free tickets to customers at the events to which they contribute. When the American Telephone and Telegraph Company sponsors a play, its foundation often pays production costs, while marketing handles promotions.
The International Business Machines Corporation now authorizes local managers to make grants of up to $25,000 -- presumably to causes favored by local customers and employees. "If a customer is on the board of a worthy museum, why shouldn't that be the one we support?" asked Juan Sabater, director of corporate social policy.
Corporations have grown adept at finding causes that tie in with their products. Since its acquisitions of Kraft and General Foods, the Philip Morris Companies Inc. has sponsored hunger relief and nutritional education programs. "Our giving reflects that we're now a food company," said Stephanie T. French, vice president of contributions.
U S West Inc., whose business strategy includes upgrading rural services and courting small businesses, announced a program this year to offer financial help and advice to small businesses in rural areas. "We always try to marry corporate and community interests," said Jane J. Prancan, executive director of the U S West Foundation.
So does American Express, which is homing in on education projects that stress travel. It sponsors geography competitions for high schoolers and high school programs to teach travel and tourism. Local managers often invite airline and hotel executives to serve as program advisers.
Marketers are listening more closely to what their corporate givers have to say.
Stephen Spurgeon, who handles Nissan Motor's contributions, got marketing to join Tread Lightly!, which promotes the prudent use of off-road land. "It fit with Pathfinder, our off-road vehicle," he said.
And Penny Hunt, who handles philanthropy for Dayton-Hudson department stores, says her marketing counterparts used similar reasoning when they agreed to donate backpacks for kindergarteners. "The Minneapolis schools asked me to do it, but marketing seemed a better fit," she said.
 
 
HOW IT WORKS OVERSEAS
 As American companies expand overseas, so do their giving programs. Following is a sample of such programs.
* American Express is helping Eastern European countries promote tourism. It is preserving monuments in the Caribbean. It runs day-care referral programs in England. And in Mexico, it is coordinating an industrywide effort to start a high school travel academy. "We want the Mexican government to see the travel industry as a powerful coalition," said Cornelia Higginson, who runs the company's international giving programs.
* I.B.M. divides the overseas world into three regions -- Asia Pacific, Latin America and Europe -- and leaves project-picking, such as training in Brazil and environmental work in England, to local management.
* Citibank has taken the New York Philharmonic to Latin America, Europe and Asia. Its marketers hold opening night parties for customers in those areas.
* The General Electric Foundation fundseducation projects in "communities where G.E. does business," said Clifford V. Smith Jr., its president. It offers college scholarships in Mexico. It is paying to train doctors in Romania. And it is helping the Hungarian government teach people about capitalism.
* A.T.& T. funds dance projects in Brazil and in Egypt and has more overseas arts support on the agenda. "One reason we bought NCR was to expand internationally, so it makes sense that we'll do more projects," said Timothy J. McClimon, who handles A.T.& T.'s cultural donations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stephanie French of Philip Morris at a New York soup kitchen, stressing a role as a food company. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 14; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 807 words

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
10 Stubborn Plants That Bedevil Americans

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
EVERYONE who grows plants confronts weeds at one time or another. Some weeds are pretty to look at and some are just plain nuisances. Usually when weeds appear in someone's garden, the plants are frowned upon and the garden is relegated to an unkempt category. Besides, weeds compete with desirable plants for soil moisture and nutrients.
Other gardeners are tolerant of weeds, however, and consider them nothing more than plants out of place. After all, they admit, for every weed or unwanted plant there is someone in the world who likes it and covets it. 
 Not many serious gardeners view plants this way. In fact, a recent publication of the United States Agricultural Research Service contains an article called "10 Weeds We Could Live Without." The research service says about 1 of every 10 species of plants is considered to be a weed. Scientists believe that there are 30,000 weed species, with about 1,800 of them causing serious economic losses in crop production.
About 70 percent of the worst weeds in the world are said to grow in the United States. And American farmers spend an estimated $2.1 billion annually for herbicides, plus another $938 million in application costs. The expenditure for these herbicides accounts for more than 65 percent of all pesticide sales in this country.
The newer approach taken by the researchers is to use post-emergent herbicides, those that act on the plants themselves rather than the pre-emergents that are put on the ground to kill the seed. The findings are that the treatment of the weeds above ground is a boon for the environment.
Post-emergent herbicides are believed to be deactivated in the soil, broken down by microbes without the residue effect caused by other chemicals. This research is also leading to answers of why the weeds are killed and opening new discoveries in particular plant pathogens.
What are those 10 weeds that Americans could live without? Although all of them are plagues that farmers battle, many of them are weeds quite familiar to the home gardener. And one curious thing about them is that eight are plants that have been introduced from other lands, while only two are native to the United States.
The two native species that have grown to become weeds are pigweed, an amaranthus that is known to the Great Plains especially but is a familiar weed in almost any garden. If left to grow without any interference, it can become five feet tall.
The other native plant that has become a weed in this country is the common ragweed, which is found mostly in the Eastern and North Central states. It can reach great heights, too, if unwatched, and its pollen causes hay fever for about 35 million people in the nation.
The other eight weeds, introduced to this country, have become naturalized pest plants and serious troublemakers for many who raise plants for profit, nurserymen as well as farmers. Probably one of the worst is that pretty little, but aggressive, plant, annual morning glory. Any of these Ipomoea species are aggressive in fields, even though many admire their lovely flowers. It is one of the toughest plants to get rid of, because it has a strong clinging habit.
Its cousin, field bindweed, is also on the weed hit list and has the distinction of being one of the worst weeds in the world. Field bindweed can be found in 47 of the 48 contiguous states (all but Florida). One of the researchers described this weed as an "out of control morning glory." Its roots go down about six feet.
Canada thistle is another nuisance, and a tough one, because it has a deep root system. It is also perennial, as is the dandelion, and tops broken off only leave the root to remain and grow for another season. The common cocklebur is in the same nuisance category, a bushy plant with prickly seeds.
Lamb's-quarters, which was introduced from Europe, is a thin-leaved annual weed highly susceptible to drought. If it has enough moisture, however, it will thrive aggressively and become a nuisance.
Although many landscapers may not recognize it as a weed, nutsedge is becoming an increasing problem. It is a tough-leaved perennial grass with unattractive blades. Although it is rampant in the southern portion of the country, it does make its appearance in the colder states and may be due to invasive spreading by poor quality seed mixes. It needs to be routed out of lawns as soon as it appears, lest it take hold by its aggressive creeping tendrils.
Although the last two weeds are not seen much in the Eastern states, they are problems elsewhere. Velvetleaf, an abutilon that was introduced from India, is so named because it has velvet hairs on its many branched stems. This weed is a pest in soybean and corn fields. Wild oats, another aggressive field weed, causes problems for wheat farmers in the Northern Plains states.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 16; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 807 words

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
10 Stubborn Plants That Bedevil Americans

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
EVERYONE who grows plants confronts weeds at one time or another. Some weeds are pretty to look at and some are just plain nuisances. Usually when weeds appear in someone's garden, the plants are frowned upon and the garden is relegated to an unkempt category. Besides, weeds compete with desirable plants for soil moisture and nutrients.
Other gardeners are tolerant of weeds, however, and consider them nothing more than plants out of place. After all, they admit, for every weed or unwanted plant there is someone in the world who likes it and covets it. 
 Not many serious gardeners view plants this way. In fact, a recent publication of the United States Agricultural Research Service contains an article called "10 Weeds We Could Live Without." The research service says about 1 of every 10 species of plants is considered to be a weed. Scientists believe that there are 30,000 weed species, with about 1,800 of them causing serious economic losses in crop production.
About 70 percent of the worst weeds in the world are said to grow in the United States. And American farmers spend an estimated $2.1 billion annually for herbicides, plus another $938 million in application costs. The expenditure for these herbicides accounts for more than 65 percent of all pesticide sales in this country.
The newer approach taken by the researchers is to use post-emergent herbicides, those that act on the plants themselves rather than the pre-emergents that are put on the ground to kill the seed. The findings are that the treatment of the weeds above ground is a boon for the environment.
Post-emergent herbicides are believed to be deactivated in the soil, broken down by microbes without the residue effect caused by other chemicals. This research is also leading to answers of why the weeds are killed and opening new discoveries in particular plant pathogens.
What are those 10 weeds that Americans could live without? Although all of them are plagues that farmers battle, many of them are weeds quite familiar to the home gardener. And one curious thing about them is that eight are plants that have been introduced from other lands, while only two are native to the United States.
The two native species that have grown to become weeds are pigweed, an amaranthus that is known to the Great Plains especially but is a familiar weed in almost any garden. If left to grow without any interference, it can become five feet tall.
The other native plant that has become a weed in this country is the common ragweed, which is found mostly in the Eastern and North Central states. It can reach great heights, too, if unwatched, and its pollen causes hay fever for about 35 million people in the nation.
The other eight weeds, introduced to this country, have become naturalized pest plants and serious troublemakers for many who raise plants for profit, nurserymen as well as farmers. Probably one of the worst is that pretty little, but aggressive, plant, annual morning glory. Any of these Ipomoea species are aggressive in fields, even though many admire their lovely flowers. It is one of the toughest plants to get rid of, because it has a strong clinging habit.
Its cousin, field bindweed, is also on the weed hit list and has the distinction of being one of the worst weeds in the world. Field bindweed can be found in 47 of the 48 contiguous states (all but Florida). One of the researchers described this weed as an "out of control morning glory." Its roots go down about six feet.
Canada thistle is another nuisance, and a tough one, because it has a deep root system. It is also perennial, as is the dandelion, and tops broken off only leave the root to remain and grow for another season. The common cocklebur is in the same nuisance category, a bushy plant with prickly seeds.
Lamb's-quarters, which was introduced from Europe, is a thin-leaved annual weed highly susceptible to drought. If it has enough moisture, however, it will thrive aggressively and become a nuisance.
Although many landscapers may not recognize it as a weed, nutsedge is becoming an increasing problem. It is a tough-leaved perennial grass with unattractive blades. Although it is rampant in the southern portion of the country, it does make its appearance in the colder states and may be due to invasive spreading by poor quality seed mixes. It needs to be routed out of lawns as soon as it appears, lest it take hold by its aggressive creeping tendrils.
Although the last two weeds are not seen much in the Eastern states, they are problems elsewhere. Velvetleaf, an abutilon that was introduced from India, is so named because it has velvet hairs on its many branched stems. This weed is a pest in soybean and corn fields. Wild oats, another aggressive field weed, causes problems for wheat farmers in the Northern Plains states.
