HEADLINE: Senate Backs $291 Billion Pentagon Budget Bill

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Adapting only slightly to improved United States-Soviet relations, the Senate voted late Friday for a $291 billion military budget bill for the next fiscal year that continues to increase the nation's strategic weaponry.
Under the Senate bill, which passed by a voice vote, the Pentagon would heavily invest in radar-evading technology, buying more F-117 Stealth fighters and B-2 Stealth bombers. The United States would also begin deploying for the first time a ground-base defense against limited nuclear missile attacks, which arms control advocates fear could jeopardize the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, and reignite the nuclear arms race. 
 In three days of votes before the Congressional summer recess, the Senate also overturned a 43-year-old law that bans women from flying combat missions, and defeated an amendment to allow abortions at American military hospitals overseas. Reflecting pressure from constituents, lawmakers trimmed only one-third the number of reservists that the Pentagon had sought to cut.
The Senate bill is closely aligned with Bush Administration's military priorities for the next fiscal year, beginning Oct. 1. But the Senate bill is sharply different from the version approved by the House of Representatives in May. The House cut the budget for the Stealth bomber and the Star Wars antimissile program, and opted to continue production of many existing conventional planes, tanks and helicopters the Pentagon does not want.
Lawmakers from both chambers will meet in September to try to reach a compromise. The budget level itself is not an issue this year. Congress and the Administration agreed last year to budget ceilings for 1992 and 1993. The fiscal 1992 budget represents a 1 percent decline, after inflation is considered, from last year's budget.
 
Veto Threat From Bush
 The White House will be closely watching the deliberations in Congress and lobbying hard. President Bush has threatened to veto the entire budget bill if Congress follows the House lead to cut $1.7 billion from Star Wars and halt production of the B-2 at the 15 planes Congress has already ordered.
The Senate agreed to support the Administration's request to buy four more B-2's, and approved $4.6 billion for Star Wars. The Administration wanted $5.2 billion for the antimissile system.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, said this week that the bill "continues the process of reducing and restructuring our military establishment in an orderly process."
Critics of military spending, however, argued that the Senate vote was out of step with budget realities and improving East-West relations symbolized by the signing this week in Moscow of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty.
"The Senate actions are imprudent, wasteful and inconsistent with the new Soviet-U.S. relationship," a coalition of five lobbying groups on arms control said in a letter sent to senators."
The coalition was made up of the Council for a Livable World, the Union of Concerned Scientists, the Women's Action for Nuclear Disarmament, the 20-20 Vision National Project and the Professionals' Coalition for Nuclear Arms Control.
The President has also threatened to veto the bill if lawmakers overturn a three-year old Pentagon ban on virtually all abortions at American military hospitals overseas. The House voted to lift the ban in May.
At issue is whether American military personnel and their dependents stationed abroad should be given access to safe and affordable abortions. No public financing would be involved; patients would pay for the procedure.
But in a procedural vote on Friday, supporters of the amendment led by Senator Tim Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, fell 2 votes short of the 60 needed to cut off debate and permit a vote on the issue.

HEADLINE: Drought Taking Its Toll on California Environment

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The California economy has proved remarkably resistant to five years of drought, but the state's slow and short-sighted response may have inflicted irreversible damage on the environment.
That is a central conclusion of a broad study, made public on Thursday, of the economic and environmental effects of the severe drought that has gripped the West. The study was conducted by the Pacific Institute for Studies in Development, Environment and Security, a nonpartisan research organization based in Berkeley, and was requested by the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment, which held a hearing on the subject Thursday in Washington. 
 The authors charged that state leaders had been unwilling to recognize that the drought might persist for several years and had continued to support wasteful uses of water by drawing reservoirs down to dangerously low levels for the first four years of the drought. From this, the report drew a pessimistic lesson about how the region might respond to the possibility of permanent climate change. "The experience of the drought suggests that California will not address climatic changes with specific policies until long after the impacts are being felt."
 
Damage to Ecosystems
 The report found that while the effects varied, farming and ranching had survived well by switching crops, pumping more water from under the ground and making more efficient use of irrigation water. Strong demand for California products meant that gross agricultural receipts reached a record high last year, although not so high as they might have been with more precipitation. But the study predicted that the longer-term costs to agriculture could be far higher if the drought persists another year.
The state's fragile natural ecosystems, many already weakened by human activities, have fared much worse, according to the study, which was financed by the Environmental Protection Agency. While other factors contributed, the study cited these direct effects of the drought:
*The winter-run chinook salmon, already listed as a threatened species, is facing extinction because of low river flows. And the catch of coho and chinook salmon off the coast has plummeted, to 4.4 million pounds in 1990, a 70 percent drop in two years.
*The number of striped bass in the Sacramento Delta and in San Francisco Bay has dropped steadily since 1987.
*The herring fishery in Tomales Bay, north of San Francisco, has been destroyed because the reduced flow of fresh water has made the bay too salty; the fish may never recover.
*The decline in the number of water fowl has been quickened as wetland habitats shrink and deteriorate.
*Large patches of trees in the Sierra Nevada have died from lack of water and pest infestation.
In addition, the report said the drought posed added danger to numerous endangered and threatened animal and plant species, including bald eagles, the giant garter snake, 9 types of butterflies and 10 herbs.
 
Hydroelectric Power Loss
 Peter H. Gleick and Linda Nash, who wrote the report, said a a chief economic cost was the massive loss of hydroelectric power. In normal years such power accounts for 20 percent of the state's total electric supply, but it dropped to 12 percent last year. This meant that utilities had to replace it by burning fossil fuels, at an additional cost of $2.4 billion and increased air pollution.
While the overall economy appeared to be resilient to drought, the report said certain industries showed large losses, including skiing, boating and tourism.
The authors said the drought had a positive effect of forcing California to re-examine its water policies, but they found the short-term resiliency of the economy to be deceptive. Up to now, they said, well water and reservoir storage have been used as a buffer against more severe impacts, but those supplies would eventually be depleted if the drought persisted.

HEADLINE: The Region;
How Long Can New York Redistribute Wealth Before the Wealthy Leave?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
IN New York's City Hall last year, iconologists recorded a subtle shift by Mayor David N. Dinkins. The portrait of former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, a demigod of progressive urban policy, had been moved from Mr. Dinkins's inner office to a secondary place of honor, opposite a men's room. The picture of La Guardia, a Republican, was replaced with a photograph of Paul Robeson, a private champion of social justice and a socialist.
Last week, that shift seemed to have taken on new meaning. From behind his desk, Mr. Dinkins delivered a televised address in which he publicly questioned some of his fundamental assumptions about the government he inherited 19 months ago. He lamented that sharp declines in Federal assistance threaten to relegate the legacy of La Guardia and the New Deal to "a sad remembrance of the past." But he has begun to question just how to pay for some of the programs that they -- and he -- advocated and advanced. 
 Even before the public was invited to troop through his office tomorrow to register its constructive criticisms, Mr. Dinkins had gotten one message: that his government may have gone as far as it can go as a vehicle to redistribute wealth. New York is a city where the growing gap between rich and poor has precipitated a class struggle that elected officials merely referee.
"We let the battle over redistribution be fought out between those who are concerned with taxes and those who are concerned with services, and the politicians withdrew," said Edward V. Regan, the state Comptroller. Yet if New York is still viewed as among the last of the one-party social democratic governments, it is hardly alone in grappling with deficits.
In Connecticut, which boasts the nation's highest per capita income and the largest city trying to file for bankruptcy, a budget stalemate entered its second month because legislators were resisting Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s demand to impose an income tax that would be more progressive than the existing sales tax.
In New Jersey, a tax revolt terrified state legislators and forced Gov. Jim Florio to modify an education aid formula that would have sent more money from wealthier suburban districts to poorer urban school systems.
In New York State, similar attempts have been thwarted by suburban and upstate legislators. And two weeks ago, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo cautioned Mr. Dinkins not to count on Albany, which had earlier assumed New York City's financial liabilities for the courts, the City University and some long-term Medicaid care, to bail it out by taking over the roughly $2 billion the city pays in Medicaid -- a burden that few other states impose on municipalities. As a result of an array of rules and formulas, the city government exercises complete discretion over only between a quarter and a half of its nearly $29 billion budget.
"It's not only a New York problem," says Edward L. Sadowsky, a former city councilman from Queens who headed a city commission on tax policy. "State and local governments all over the country are beginning to bleed."
The hemorrhaging was hastened by the Reagan Administration's "new federalism," which shifted traditional national obligations to states and localities. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan reported last month that in 1990, each New Yorker paid an average of $1,178 more in Federal taxes than came back to New York in Federal outlays.
New York City's political configuration as a conglomerate of five counties and its historic charity -- few other municipalities provide so extensive a public hospital system or housing program, for example -- render it a paradigm either of profligacy or of responsibility to its neediest citizens, depending on whether the beholder is giving or receiving.
"It's not even the middle class subsidizing the poor any more," Mr. Sadowsky said. "It's the poor paying for the poorest: a nurse in a city hospital and her husband, a clerk with the Transit Authority. They're making $60,000 and they're the ones subsidizing the welfare rolls. You can't go on doing that. We cannot do everything."
In an unpublished manuscript titled "New York City Politics and Policy," Raymond D. Horton and Charles Brecher, president and research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, respectively, found that the proportion of the city budget allocated for things that redistribute wealth -- public assistance, health, social services and housing -- peaked in the late 1960's, but still accounts for nearly a third of the budget. Even so, the welfare grant is often insufficient to raise a family's income to the federally defined poverty level.
"The perception that New York City taxes its residents excessively," Mr. Sadowsky's commission reported, "derives in good measure from the fact that a significant portion of the taxpayer's dollar is spent on income transference from those who are better off to those in need, rather than for the delivery of such services as paved roads, clean streets and police protection, services that taxpayers have traditionally expected from municipalities."
The Mayor's speech represented "a 180-degree change," Mr. Sadowsky said. But Mr. Dinkins's view may not be much better in this direction. His promise of "reform and renaissance" was a political decision driven by economic realities.
The Mayor had been resistant, though, for political reasons and for philosophical ones. An experimental program to contain soaring Medicaid costs faced opposition because patients would no longer be allowed to choose their own doctors, and there was no guarantee that care would improve. Even cutting the city payroll has had a social dimension. After proposing that some services might be provided more cheaply by private contractors, Mr. Dinkins cautioned: "We will approach these choices understanding that the bottom line of government cannot be considered successful if it only leads to a longer unemployment line."
"The payroll has always been part of a redistribution system," said Richard C. Wade, an urban history professor at the City University of New York Graduate Center. "It was a way of taking care of people coming up. The city didn't want a large number of unemployed, so it bought off some social tension down the road. But it has just become too expensive."
White Resentment
Moreover, the rising proportion of city employees who are black and Hispanic has further infused the redistributive equation with a racial component that does not necessarily inspire the charitable instincts of the city's dwindling white middle class -- a group that Mr. Horton and Mr. Brecher found has usually been disadvantaged by New York's taxing and spending policies. Which is the reason, said Representative Major R. Owens, a Brooklyn Democrat, that the platform of his emerging Majority Coalition of New York promotes "policies that create a new middle class" -- in part by providing services financed by higher taxes on, among other things, incomes over $125,000.
Will there be enough wealthy people left to pay those taxes within the limits of a city defined 93 years ago by arbitrary geographic boundaries and confined by its inability to raise any tax without state approval except the one on property?
That New York City can only do so much by itself is one reality that the sagging economy is once again forcing it to confront -- just as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal that the Communist Party sever its philosophical lifeline to Marx and Engels is a reflection of economic realities in that country. During Mr. Dinkins's speech last week, the Mayor's eyes never darted to the picture of Paul Robeson. Instead, he quoted Walt Whitman: "New York gives the directest proof yet of successful democracy." The problem may be, though, that when the real-estate market recovers, more of the people who pay taxes to support the poor may vote with their feet.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
It Isn't Graceful, but the Laws Get on the Books

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE 102d Congress, like its predecessors, is hardly ever elegant in doing its business. It oversimplifies issues, works irregular hours, plays cheap politics and worships archaic rules that multiply its inefficiency.
And yet it legislates. Incompletely, so far, with action completed into law in only a handful of important instances, but far more seriously on subjects from abortion to energy to health care costs to the future of the military than its ways of doing business suggest. 
 Any look at a new Congress as it breaks for the summer vacation of its first year is inherently a view of no more than the late beginnings of a legislative effort, and so the small-mindedness stands out clearly against a small total of achievements.
But even so there is one profound exception to the petty air that surrounds so much congressional business: the decision to authorize President Bush to go to war in the Persian Gulf. A serious issue, seriously argued, with hardly an attack on personal motives in three long days of speeches. Representative Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader, thinks it was the most important moment of his 35 years in the House. Speaker Thomas S. Foley feels that the way the Congress approached the issue meant "the country as a whole had a strong and correct sense that there was a government that had gone through a process of decision and then stood by the decision."
The only other big decisions the Congress has finished with have been to grant the Administration more time for "fast track" trade negotiations and to spend $5.8 billion on extended unemployment compensation -- an action completed on Capitol Hill Friday and likely to be thwarted from Kennebunkport in a few days.
Squeezed by the self-imposed discipline of last fall's budget act, the appropriations process has moved ahead faster than usual. As Mr. Michel observed, last year's deal "really is a restraining mechanism on spending." Even so, the goal of passing all the appropriations bills by the beginning of the fiscal year in October is likely to be missed because of Bush vetoes over abortion.
But Congress does find a way to make a spectacle of itself. Filibusters, or threats of filibusters, keep the Senate from taking up some bills and the badly outnumbered House Republicans use meaningless roll-calls as their stock in trade to get the Democrats' attention and slow down the majority.
Those stunts are at least quasi-legislative; they keep things the minorities consider evil from happening, or at least make the majority change them a bit. But then there is Jesse Helms. He got the Senate to pass a bill mandating 10-year prison terms for surgeons with AIDS who operate without warning their patients. No hearings had been held, and the Senate action was "devoid of any careful study," as the majority leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, put it.
Mr. Helms does this from time to time, choosing some emotional issue from the news and forcing each Senator to make public his position on it, to take a controversial stand on a proposition that has no chance of becoming law, or on which everyone agrees to begin with. There has been, as Mr. Mitchell says, "an erosion of comity and restraint on such matters." And that is one reason the Senate is a cranky body.
A Helms amendment, even if it never becomes law, can always become a television commercial. A fair amount of congressional worry is devoted to fear of an electorate manipulated by television. When the Senate decided to raise its pay and eliminate speaking fees, it did so suddenly and quietly; otherwise the effort would probably have been thwarted by talk-show hosts.
Legislating with an eye toward commercials is not a uniquely Senatorial prerogative. The House of which Mr. Foley and Mr. Michel are so proud for its January debate on the war went to the other extreme on the civil rights bill in June. Hardly anybody took the floor to say what the problem was and why one approach was better than another. Instead the other side's motives were almost the only issue. Consider this typical exchange:
A Republican from Louisiana rose to say "The last thing our country needs is for us to divide ourselves along racial and ethnic lines. Like it or not, the so-called civil rights bill will do just that -- divide us -- because it is a quota bill." Then a Democrat from New Mexico went to the microphone in front of the ornate Speaker's Desk to proclaim: "This is not a debate on civil rights or job discrimination or capping punitive damages for sexual harassment. This is Presidential politics 1992," he said. "The White House has polled and found by using the word 'quotas,' they pick up votes."
Thus far the Senate discussion has been more restrained and more to the point of what is actually in various bills. But that may not stay true when the bill comes to the floor, and after Senate nerves have been scraped by the debate over Clarence Thomas.
 
Sets of Frustrations
 Congress gets this way because of various sets of frustrations. House Republicans see themselves as a permanent minority, able to stop things but very rarely to cause them. Some Democrats are frustrated because money and other obstacles prevent them from attacking the problems they care about, robbing them, as Mr. Foley put it, of the "psychic income from the job."
And then, when some wanted to follow Mr. Foley and solve one of those problems by rebuilding roads and bridges, paying for it with a nickel-a-gallon gasoline tax, others revolted this week and killed it. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, defended his restive colleagues, saying "Democrats are merely reflecting the frustration of the vast majority of American citizens about the fact that they are very highly taxed."
Washington finds it easy to judge a Congress by the faults to be found in its leaders. By those yardsticks, Mr. Foley and Mr. Michel are sometimes faulted as too reasonable; Mr. Gephardt and Bob Dole, the Republican Senate leader, as too partisan.
But as lawmakers are elected more and more on their own and owe less to parties at home and in Congress, and feel less obligation to chairmen and speakers, they look out for themselves, ducking issues they feel offer the slightest risk to re-election, arguing others in ways that make good TV spots but cheapen the process. Perhaps it is time to be concerned less with Congressional leadership, and more with followership.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "HOW FAR THEY GOT BEFORE THE SUMMER BREAK"
Actions taken by Congress on major pieces of legislation before going on vacation.
 
Gulf War
On Jan. 12, the Congress authorized President Bush to use military force to expel Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. The vote was 52 to 47 in the Senate and a more comfortable 250 to 183 in the House. Congress provided $42.6 billion to cover the costs of the war. The bill also included pay increases, educational grants and better health care for all veterans.
 
Unemployment benefits
Both Houses passed a $5.8 billion bill granting up to 20 more weeks of benefits to people who have been out of work for more than half a year. The President has threatened to block the benefits, arguing that the recession is ending.
 
Trade negotiations
The Administration's "fast-track" authority to make trade agreements was renewed so a proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico and a 108-nation pact to lower international restrictions could be negotiated.
 
Trade with China
Both the House and Senate passed bills putting conditions on renewal of most-favored-nation trade status for China: an end to some arms sales, the release of political prisoners, and a halt in exports to the United States of goods made by prisoners. The White House promised a veto.
 
Abortion counseling
Both Houses voted to allow abortion counseling in Federally financed family clinics. The Senate approved contradictory amendments about whether parents should be notified. President Bush has promised to veto easing abortion restrictions.
 
Military
The House passed a $291 billion military budget that holds production of the B-2 Stealth bomber to the 15 on order and makes deep cuts in the Star Wars anti-missile system. A Senate version pays for four more bombers and makes fewer Star Wars cuts; the two will go to conference. The Administration has threatened to veto the entire military budget if the B-2 or Star Wars is cut too deeply. Both bills allow women to fly combat missions.
 
Pay raise
By a 53-45 vote in an evening session, the Senate granted itself a $23,200 raise to $125,100 and banned the acceptance of speaking fees. The measure limits a senator's earned outside income to 15 percent of salary. The House approved the action.
 
 
Civil rights
The House made it easier for victims of job discrimination to sue. President Bush threatened a veto, calling it a "quota bill," and rejected efforts by moderate Republican senators to broker a compromise.
 
Crime
The Senate approved a bill making more Federal crimes punishable by death, limiting Federal court review of inmates' petitions, easing the admissibility of evidence and establishing a five-day waiting period for handgun purchases. The House passed a separate bill with a seven-day waiting period. A proposal by House Democratic leaders includes more money for beat-walking police, for states with lots of drug-related crime and for prison drug treatment. The White House favors the Senate bill.
 
Transportation
The Senate passed a $123 billion bill to repair roads and bridges and improve mass transit. It give states and localities more leeway in spending the money. The House Public Works Committee has approved a similar bill that offers $153.5 billion, but requires a 5-cent-a-gallon gas tax increase. The Administration has threatened to veto any increased gas taxes.
 
Campaign finance
The Senate passed a bill offering incentives like cheap television time to candidates who agree to spending limits. It would also outlaw contributions by political action committees to Congressional candidates.
 
Banking overhaul
The House Banking Committee approved a bill echoing the Bush Administration's plan: letting industrial companies own banks, allowing mergers of investment and commercial banks, dropping barriers to interstate banking. The Senate Banking Committee passed a variant that forces banks to serve lower-income customers and would not let industries own banks.
 
Energy
The Senate Energy Committee has approved an energy blueprint allowing drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, removing obstacles to nuclear power plants, deregulating natural gas pipelines, and repealing a law that limits who can enter the wholesale electric generation market. The Administration opposes plans to require better gas mileage on cars and may veto any bill without the Arctic drilling provision. House committees are still considering energy legislation.
 
Drawings

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Price of Gas Can Fall, But Taxes Defy Gravity

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
MISSED about as much as a headache that has quietly slipped away, the pain has gone out of gasoline prices lately, and adjusted for inflation, pre-tax prices in recent years have hovered around post-World War II lows. Almost unnoticed, however, something else has been creeping up: gasoline taxes.
The Federal Government raised its take a nickel a gallon last fall, and Arkansas, Idaho, Hawaii, Maine, New York and Rhode Island, among others, have followed suit. Last week, the House Ways and Means Committee approved a proposal for yet another five-cent increase, but Democratic leaders withdrew the measure, at least for now, as Congressional support for it began to crumble. 
 All of this has been camouflaged in part by the fall in oil prices since the height of the Kuwait panic last year. The American Automobile Association reported last week that the average price of a gallon of unleaded regular was $1.132, down 4 cents since early June and down about 25 cents from a year ago. At today's price, a gallon of gasoline made from oil imported from Saudi Arabiacosts less than a gallon of bottled water shipped from France.
It also makes gasoline cheap by historical standards, according to Daniel Yergin, a historian of the oil industry who in a recent study calculated prices since World War II in 1991 dollars. In 1947, the price at the pump read 23 cents, but adjusted for inflation that was worth $1.49. In 1972, the year before the beginning of the Arab oil embargo, the sign on the pump said 36 cents, which would be $1.22 today. The peak was in 1981, when the price was $2.04 in 1991 dollars.
But if the price is low by historical standards, the taxes are not. The American Petroleum Institute, the industry's main trade association, said earlier this month that taxes now average 32.4 cents a gallon, more than twice as much as a decade ago. On top of the Federal tax of 14.1 cents per gallon come state taxes ranging from 9 cents in Wyoming to 26 cents in Rhode Island. Mr. Yergin, who weighted the average tax by the volume of gasoline sold in each state, put the average figure at 36 cents.
 
'A Money Grab'
 This is not a record in inflation-adjusted terms; that came in the early 1960's, when taxes were nominally a dime -- nearly 50 cents in today's money. But today's taxes are near a record in a different way, as a percentage of the pump price -- currently about 32 percent, up from 9.5 percent 10 years ago. This would not impress motorists in the rest of the industrialized world, where taxes are two to eight times those in the United States. But it impresses some Americans.
"It's a money grab," said William Berman, the American Automobile Association's chief policy analyst in Washington. "For those states that have dedicated fuel taxes for highways and transportation, that's good news, because we need infrastructure improvement," he said. "But many of these states no longer have that."
Mr. Berman called it the "Willie Sutton source of revenue," referring to the notorious hold-up man who is reported to have said, when asked why he robbed banks, "because that's where the money is."
The budget pressures that led to the last increase will only get stronger in future years, said Catherine G. Schultz, a lobbyist with a Washington law firm who specializes in energy. She said that might lead to tax hikes of up to 50 cents in the next 10 years. "They'll never do it all at once," said Ms. Schultz. "They'll do a nickel here, a dime there, like they did with cigarette taxes."
The states are also likely to come back to the trough. Gasoline demand is stagnating, Mr. Berman of the A.A.A. pointed out, with sales down about 2 percent over the last year, mostly as a result of increases in fuel efficiency. "A lot of the state revenue people are watching that with alarm," he said. To get more revenue from gasoline when sales are declining requires raising the tax.
"We don't have to worry about Saddam Hussein starting a war," he said. "Most of our price increases from now on are going to come from politicians."
For the states, that is traditional, said Ed Rothschild, an energy expert at Citizen Action, a Washington-based non-profit activist group. But for the Federal Government, it is new. Citizen Action has mixed feelings on tax increases, he said; on the one hand the Government could use the money to improve mass transit and develop alternative fuels, but on the other hand, outside the big cities with public transit systems, a gas tax is a tax on the poor, he said.
 
Whither Energy Policy?
 But the increases are still too small to make much of a difference in America's driving habits, say experts. Thomas C. Jorling, the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation in New York, said, "To get meaningful decreases in vehicle miles traveled, you have to have 50 cents or more price increases." That, he said, would be a tax levied as part of an energy policy, instead of simply a device to raise revenue.
Such a policy might make sense as oil imports hover near 50 percent of consumption, with two-thirds of the oil going into the transportation sector. But it might also be difficult to implement, with opponents arguing that gasoline taxes burden the poor, who spend a higher percentage of their income on gasoline than the rich do. And anything that reduces the amount that motorists have to spend on new cars is harmful to Detroit, said David L. Lewis, a University of Michigan Business School professor who specializes in the auto industry.
"Right now, nobody wants to administer or receive the medicine," he said.

HEADLINE: The Perils of CAFE

 BODY:
A good way to clean the air is to burn less gasoline. And the best way to do that is to raise gasoline prices. But Congress doesn't have the stomach to levy substantially higher gas taxes so it has imposed regulations -- known as CAFE standards -- that have forced automobile manufacturers to raise fuel efficiency on new cars to 27.5 miles per gallon.
CAFE standards are better than nothing. But they have achieved only modest savings in fuel use and have created a slew of knotty problems. Yet bills before Congress propose sharply raising the required fuel efficiency, and in a way that threatens to make this second-best policy even worse. 
 Rather than setting, as under current law, the same miles-per-gallon standard for every manufacturer, Senator Richard Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, proposes that by 2001 each manufacturer raise the average fuel efficiency of new cars 40 percent. That would force manufacturers that have already achieved the best miles-per-gallon rating to make the most drastic improvements.
Toyota would have to achieve 45 miles per gallon while Ford would need only 37. Indeed, by saddling fuel-efficient Toyotas with expensive technological improvements, the bill could steer buyers toward, say, Ford, raising overall fuel use.
Manufacturers that did the best job of meeting Congress's will in the past would be punished for their effort. That sends a destructive signal. It's also offensively protectionist.
Yet Congress would create equally difficult problems if it continued the current practice of setting identical, but higher standards on every manufacturer. Japanese manufacturers achieve higher fleet averages primarily because they sell smaller cars. A uniform standard would penalize U.S. companies that cater to large families.
Here's another intractable problem. When CAFE was passed, unions insisted that manufacturers separate domestically made cars from their imported cars, and meet the standard on each group. But the regulations backfired. Because U.S. companies produce their largest cars at home, the regulations have forced them to use parts produced abroad. To meet the target on domestic fleets, they have substituted foreign-made parts, thereby qualifying some of the larger cars as imports.
Problems and more problems. CAFE only applies to new cars, leaving drivers of all other cars completely off the hook . . . As a substitute for higher gas taxes, CAFE keeps driving costs low and thereby encourages people to drive more miles; that offsets part of the impact of vehicle efficiency . . . CAFE standards have raised the manufacturing cost, and the price, of new cars, prompting drivers to keep old gas-guzzlers.
CAFE has meant more fatalities and serious injuries as manufacturers have been forced to sell smaller cars to meet the standards. And, by one estimate, it would have taken a tax of only a few pennies per gallon of gasoline to achieve the same fuel savings as the current CAFE standards -- at a fraction of the cost to consumers.
Yet Congress stonewalls. Last week, the House backed away from a proposed nickel-a-gallon tax hike. Even though consumers fret about some higher state gas taxes, and last year's nickel rise in the Federal tax, gas prices are the lowest they've been, after inflation, since World War II. And U.S. taxes are only a fraction of European levels. Besides, if Congress felt obliged to keep overall Federal taxes down, it could offset higher gas taxes with lower income taxes.
CAFE is an inferior policy that survives because Congress won't come clean: a stiff increase in gas taxes, not stiff regulations, is the way to conserve energy and protect the environment.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Do They Have the Nerve?

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
President Bush came home from his virtuoso performance in the Soviet Union only to resume the posture of a petulant preppy. Democrats are "frustratingly negative on everything" and "We need more farsighted people like me in Congress," he said like a Professor Henry Higgins lamenting Democratic Eliza Doolittles.
There is a way for Mr. Bush to have his wish and for Democrats to have a better chance to reclaim the White House -- if they have the nerve. Let's call the idea "modified parliamentary democracy," and it can be done without changing the Constitution. 
 The legislative process would work like this:
* The Democratic majorities in the House and Senate would pass bills as they see fit, representing the Democrats' approaches to dealing with domestic problems, and for which they would bear political responsibility. The Republican President could approve or veto.
* If the bill were vetoed, Democrats then would allow passage of the Republican bill on the same subject, for which Republicans would shoulder responsibility.
The idea is to break the political-ideological stalemate in Washington and establish greater responsibility as a basis for voter choice. Legislation could be passed with much less inter-party dickering and log-rolling. Whatever legislation became law would more clearly be labeled as Democratic or Republican. A confusing case would be where Mr. Bush supported a Democratic measure, but that would be unusual.
Problems would be addressed with either liberal or conservative answers, and voters would know better whom to blame and reward. An example would be the bill to extend unemployment benefits just passed by a large majority against the threat of Presidential veto.
Mr. Bush might have the guts to buy the idea. Republicans like Newt Gingrich in the House, strong believers with policy proposals, might see it as the only opportunity for Republicans to enact their programs and gain control of Congress.
Democrats would be reluctant. House Speaker Tom Foley and the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, seem to think they are being responsible by trying to compromise with Republicans. But the result is almost always either gridlock or mushy, minimal legislation that satisfies only backroom wheeler-dealers. Most committee chairmen prefer the present system for just those reasons. More difficult, many Congressional Democrats would gag at going along with Republican legislation after a veto of their own in areas like civil rights and unemployment compensation. To these Democrats, the only answer is that they have no hope of translating their beliefs into laws in the current system -- unless they capture the White House. Their best chance of doing that is by letting Republicans pass their laws, and triumph or hang themselves.
I turn to this kind of stark and mechanical idea only because the present situation is ridiculous, and I do not see another solution.
For months now Republicans and Democrats have pressed another idea -- urging Mr. Bush to shift his priorities from foreign to domestic. The hope was that if he paid more attention to what was going on in the United States, he would see the devastating problems and go to work. To which he answered on Friday that things were fine at home and "I am not going to lose interest in world peace."
One can only conclude from this masterly retort that Mr. Bush will continue to pay more mind to Cyprus than Cincinnati. Maybe it is better. Every time he resurfaces on domestic issues he scares the hell out of Democrats. Last week Mr. Foley seemed to back away from the Democrats' commitment to a bill that would provide $150 billion for highway and mass-transit construction and repair. Rank-and-file Democrats could not face the prospect of Mr. Bush attacking them over the five-cent-per-gallon tax increase needed to finance the bill.
Mr. Bush also said on Friday that "the last thing" he wanted from legislation was to "increase the deficit." But two weeks ago Richard Darman, his budget tamer, announced that the deficit would be $20 billion to $40 billion larger than predicted for the next several years due to "technical re-estimates" in tax revenues.
Hardly a whimper was heard in Washington. Allow me to grumble for the rest of us, and to search for a way out.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
How to Look for M.I.A.'s Travel Barriers Invite Scams

BYLINE: By DAVID C. UNGER

 BODY:
Even during the peak of America's influence in Vietnam two decades ago, many G.I.'s felt there was something otherworldly about the place. Since then, Vietnam's mysteries have deepened. Cumbersome Treasury regulations imposed after the war strongly discourage U.S. citizens from traveling to Vietnam and Cambodia. Hanoi's own bureaucratic rules have multiplied the obstacles.
That double paper curtain has worked to the advantage of unscrupulous con artists who prey on the emotional vulnerability of families of servicemen missing in action. In the absence of real information, it is all too easy to persuade M.I.A. families and friends that many middle-aged American slave laborers populate Indochina's jungles, villages and cities. 
 Pentagon investigators, who do have access to Vietnam and Cambodia, insist that almost all reported M.I.A. sightings turn out to be erroneous or fraudulent. Many Americans, however, are reluctant to take the word of faceless officials. A better response would be to reduce the obstacles to travel, giving ordinary Americans a chance to look around for themselves.
Last summer, I got some idea of what that might be like, visiting Vietnam on assignment. I spent most of my time in major cities and none of it trying to track down M.I.A. reports. If Americans were being held in rural villages or jungle prison camps, I wouldn't have run into them.
But my trip did have the salutary effect of demystifying Vietnam. And it suggested, further, that allowing Americans to visit Vietnam freely might do much to demystify the M.I.A. issue.
I saw an ideological police state, but the repression was not so tight as to smother unsolicited expressions of popular discontent. A sizable proportion of Vietnamese adults speak some English, and many have regular contact with relatives who now live in the U.S. If there were any number of living M.I.A.'s, it would be hard for Vietnamese authorities to prevent some detailed and verifiable information reaching Pentagon investigators -- or the ears of ordinary tourists.
I also found that even hard-line Communist authorities, aware of their country's catastrophic economic failures, were eager for outside investment. Vietnam may still be isolated from the United States but it is not isolated from the larger capitalist world. In addition to growing numbers of Western business people, Vietnam hosts a well-informed and inquisitive diplomatic community, including Australians, Japanese and Swedes. This international presence would surely complicate any hope of keeping large and explosive secrets.
The best reassurance, however, would come from changes permitting a sharp rise in the number of American travelers to Vietnam.
Hanoi has recently started doing its part, upgrading its hotels and simplifying paperwork. Washington still resists. The Bush Administration's policy is that normal diplomatic relations -- including freedom of travel -- cannot begin until there is government-to-government progress on resolving the M.I.A. issue, as well as Vietnamese cooperation in international peace efforts concerning Cambodia.
On the M.I.A. question, that seems to be putting things exactly backward. If there are in fact significant numbers of living M.I.A.'s in Indochina, encouraging American travel would greatly improve the odds of finding them.

HEADLINE: Save Bankers From Themselves by Regulation;
Stop the Big Kill

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your profile of President Bush's friend and policy adviser Thomas Ashley (July 19) began to develop a policy issue of profound significance to the future of our banking system and economy, but then you let Mr. Ashley dismiss it with the words, "We aren't putting trusts back together, we're lifting 50-year-old restrictions that have strangled the industry." 
 At issue is whether or not commercial organizations should control banks, and this was the focus of President Theodore Roosevelt's trust-busting activities at the beginning of this century. President Bush wants this ownership door opened wide. The matter is being hotly debated in Congress and in editorial columns.
Two voices should be set against Mr. Ashley's response. One is the highly regarded former Federal Reserve chairman, Paul Volcker, who on July 17 wrote to Donald Riegle, Senate Banking Committee chairman, expressing strong support for Senator Riegle's bill intended to maintain the separation of banking and commerce. Mr. Volcker stated:
"As time passes, it seems to be more evident that no case has been made, in the broader public interest, for changing the long United States tradition in that respect . . . little or no sympathy exists in other leading countries for such a banking structure, and banks are demonstrating their ability to raise capital in the markets as their circumstances stabilize and improve. I know a relative handful of firms want the option to buy a bank to further their commercial interest, but that hardly provides a dispassionate base for public policy."
John D. Dingell, House Energy and Commerce Committee chairman, who will, fortunately, be reviewing the Treasury proposal, was even blunter. In a June 6 letter to Thomas S. Foley, Speaker of the House, requesting the right for "close and careful" scrutiny of the proposal by his committee, Mr. Dingell stated, "this complex and dangerous proposal should not be railroaded through without that scrutiny."
The stakes in the pending financial reform bill are very high for every American. We are at a historic watershed.
 
KENNETH A. GUENTHER
Executive V.P., Independent Bankers Assn. of America
Washington, July 22, 1991

HEADLINE: Who Can Afford to Swap Income for Time?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Americans suffer from an overdose of work," writes Juliet B. Schor, associate professor of economics at Harvard, in "Americans Work Too Hard" (Op-Ed, July 25). "Regardless of who they are or what they do, Americans spend more time at work than at any time since World War II." 
 Only a professor sequestered in the ivory tower of academia could be so misguided.
The suggestion that the responsibilities of salaried employees can fit neatly into the punch-clock structure of a federally legislated 30-hour or four-day workweek demonstrates how far Professor Schor is from the realities that are faced by most working Americans. Anyone who has ever been a salaried worker in private industry knows what I mean.
Sure, many of us are overworked. Sure, many of us would like to spend more time with our families or benefit from paid parental leave. Sure, there is a growing scarcity of leisure. But can we really afford to swap income for time? Of course not!
Ms. Schor also ignores the reality that many salaried workers want to work 60 hours or more a week on their jobs. This is how some workers manifest a devotion to their chosen careers. Those of us who are in the professional service sector must put in the time to serve the client -- however long it takes. All lawyers, doctors, brokers, salespeople, business executives and other such professionals know this all too well.
To suggest that Congress can legislatively increase productivity by cutting the workweek is misguided and unrealistic.
 
CARLOS EDWARD PENA
Bethel, Conn., July 25, 1991

HEADLINE: All About/Foreign Exchange;
A Profitable Niche in Today's Grim World of Banking

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
GOVERNMENTS like to try to keep the value of their currencies stable. To do that, they buy and sell their currencies in the world's $600 billion-a-day foreign exchange market and coordinate their economic policies with one another. Corporations with large sales or operations abroad do not like volatility in the foreign exchange market either. It makes it difficult for them to produce relatively stable quarterly earnings.
But foreign exchange traders love movement: it is a time to make money, not only from trading one currency for another but also from hedging for corporations seeking to protect themselves from the impact of volatility.
Since 1973, when the world abandoned its post-World War II system of fixed exchange rates in favor of the current floating exchange-rate system, traders -- not governments -- have been getting their way. The markets have been volatile. From the beginning of this year until July, the dollar rose 27 percent against the German mark. In the last three weeks, the dollar has fallen 5 percent against the mark. In the same period, the dollar has moved up sharply against most other currencies.
The quarterly reports for the banks that are active traders in the foreign exchange market show that volatility has been good for them. Foreign exchange revenues for the first quarter, when the dollar was most volatile, were up 27 percent to $701 million for the 15 major trading banks in the United States, according to figures compiled by Shearson Lehman Brothers.
 
 
Two Who Have Won
J.P. Morgan and Bankers Trust
 For dozens of banks, revenue from foreign exchange operations has become much more important as other areas of their business have suffered. Banks earn fees on foreign exchange services for corporate customers and profit from daily and long-term trading, often with their own money. Fee-based operations, which carry less risk for the bank, are growing. This makes revenue from the category "foreign exchange" more reliable and stable than its name might otherwise imply.
James M. Rosenberg, a banking analyst at Shearson, has used this argument as the basis of his decision to raise the ratings recently of the stock of Bankers Trust Company and J.P. Morgan & Company. Both banks actively conduct trading and hedging operations for their clients. Mr. Rosenberg said this dependable stream of earnings means the banks' stocks were "materially undervalued."
In the first half of this year, J.P. Morgan, the parent of Morgan Guaranty Trust, had revenue from foreign exchange of $149 million, or 30 percent of net income. Bankers Trust did better, with revenue from foreign exchange of $182 million or 53 percent of net income.
"The balance has shifted a bit more toward customers," said Peter D. Hancock, the managing director for global markets at J.P. Morgan. "There is a recognition of the important niche that Morgan holds because of its customer franchise. But this is not to say that we do not have a certain appetite for risk."
 
 
What Customers Want
The Biggest Banks Are Most Popular
 With so many banks competing for business, which ones do corporations prefer? In foreign exchange, it does not hurt to be big. Of the top five banks rated as best by corporate treasurers and other customers in Euromoney magazine, four -- Citicorp, Barclays Bank, National Westminster and Union Bank of Switzerland -- are among the 30 largest banks in the world. Morgan Guaranty Trust, rated third, is 59th in assets worldwide.
The Euromoney list also showed that investment banks are making their mark. Goldman Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company are now rated among the world's 20 most preferred currency traders.
But the credit ratings of the banks themselves also seem to play a role in why some are favored. The banks that rose in the rankings -- like J.P. Morgan, which went from eighth place to third, and Union Bank of Switzerland, which went from 17th to fifth -- both had credit ratings from the Standard and Poor's Corporation of AAA, five levels higher than the rating for Chemical Bank, which fell from third to seventh, and Chase Manhattan, which fell from sixth to 14th in the rankings. These higher ratings bring in customers who are concerned about the state of the banking system and want to do their longer-term transactions with banks considered healthy.
The credit rating issue is very important to the new foreign exchange operations that will be created at the merged Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust.
In comments to analysts, John McGillicuddy, who will be chairman of the combined bank, made clear that the key to improving the new bank's foreign exchange revenues will be to make the financial moves necessary to raise the bank's credit rating first to an A and then to an AA.
"We really have professionals that can execute in these areas if we give them an improved rating to operate with," Mr. McGillicuddy told the analysts. "There are several banking institutions in this city, for example, that really kind of have the field to themselves right now, and it's not, in our judgment, because they're better than we are."
 
 
Traders Without Jobs
Cost Cutting In Currency Units

The explosive growth of the foreign currency market in the 1980's brought new banks and scores of new traders into the business. Now they are elbowing each other for a share. At the same time, cost cutting in the banking industry has spread even to lucrative areas like foreign exchange. Traders are beginning to feel the pain.
A few foreign banks, like Hill Samuel International of Britain, have closed their New York foreign exchange operations. On the West Coast, the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and Barclays Bank of Britain have closed their operations.
The New York market is especially tight. At Union Bank of Switzerland and many other banks, managers do not move quickly to replace traders who have left.
"Traders are suffering for the first time," said David Rivers, the executive editor of FX Week, a newsletter for currency traders.
Anthony G. Mecca, a former foreign exchange trader turned headhunter, said job listings are down about 40 percent from a year ago. He has had to turn the efforts of his own firm, the Paulen Company, toward other kinds of job searches because of the slowdown.
"A lot of the people who were unemployed last summer are still unemployed," he said, adding that he has seen more than 30 traders this year who had lost their jobs.
One of the reasons for the cutbacks, beyond cost, is that the boom in foreign exchange trading in the 1980's brought a lot of people into the market who are having trouble handling the business today.
"The 1980's brought in a lot of people who were not up to the quality and talent that you need today," said Robert A. White, vice president at First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. He said increased volatility and quick changes in the direction of the foreign exchange market make it much more difficult to make money now than when the dollar was generally going down every day in the mid- and late 1980's.
Traders hired now tend to be more experienced. "I would look for seasoned traders with a good track record," said Albert Soria, foreign exchange manager at Kansallis-Osake-Pankki, a Finnish bank in New York. "And a good track record does not mean volatile earnings. A good track record would mean an upward slope in earnings."
The threat of more bank mergers, like the joining of Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover, means there could be other traders on the street soon looking for jobs. Mr. Mecca believes Chemical has the stronger foreign exchange operation, which means it will be dominant in the combining of the companies' operations. But he believes David Puth, manager of foreign exchange at Chemical, will run counter to the rule in the market and take younger people so he can train them. This time "I think you will see a lot of senior people out on the street," he said. A bank spokesman, Joyce Oberdorf, said the bank will train younger traders, "but not at the expense of senior people."
For one senior trader in particular, the situation is a little queasy. J. Thomas Stanley, who was vice president and manager for corporate exchange at Chemical Bank, left three months ago. He left to do the same job at Manufacturers Hanover Trust. At this time, Mr. Stanley has no comment about his future.
 
 
THE DUAL ROLE OF OPTIONS
 ON the floor of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and in banks and investment banks around the world, currency options are being used increasingly to hedge against foreign-exchange losses.
Currency options are a type of right. They give their owners the opportunity to buy a unit of a currency at a prearranged price sometime in the future. As a result, they are an insurance policy against unwanted or unanticipated moves in the foreign exchange market. Options are traded on exchanges in a number of standard forms or individually crafted for special customer needs by banks and investment banks.
While options offer protection, they also give companies the opportunity to take advantage of a positive move. The cost of combining insurance and opportunity is much higher than traditional forms of hedging, which use forwards -- contracts to buy currencies in the future at current price.
Forwards also offer insurance against adverse moves by locking in an exchange rate, but they offer no chance for gains. According to International Risk Control Inc., a foreign exchange consulting firm in Redwood City, Calif., a three-month option can cost four times more than a forward contract or about 3 percent of face value.
Even though options are more expensive, their use is growing. According to Greenwich Associates, a foreign exchange consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn., companies that use options spent a median of $150 million on them last year, up from $90 million the year before.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 11, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a report in the "All About" column last Sunday, about currency options, misstated the median corporate spending on them. What rose to $150 million last year from $90 million the year before was the volume of median corporate trading; actual spending to buy these rights for future purchases of currency would amount to a small fraction of the face value of the contracts.

HEADLINE: Demand for Rentals Rises in Manhattan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
FOR Matthew Auerbach, a comedy writer, freelance rock critic and Manhattan renter, the real estate slump could be worse. Later this month, he will bid adieu to a quintessentially New York home, a fifth floor walk-up railroad flat on York Avenue in the 80's that he calls "the North Pole."
He is moving downtown and up scale, joining thousands of New Yorkers who have seized upon the depressed market to seek the best deals they can find in rental housing. 
 "I don't run my personal life on the basis of real estate cycles, but hey," Mr. Auerbach said, "this is a good time to move." He has signed the lease on a large, 16th-floor one-bedroom with curved walls, a bay window and keys to the health club at the Corinthian, a sleek condominium tower at 38th and First Avenue.
"Renters used to be treated like second-class citizens," said John Robertson, the owner of a Manhattan advertising agency who last month rented a large, fully furnished two-bedroom apartment on 66th Street off Park Avenue. "I was wined and dined," he added.
Mr. Auerbach and Mr. Robertson are among a new wave of renters who have entered the New York City market since the first unmistakable signs of a real estate downturn emerged in 1988. Unwilling to buy, they have reinforced New York's position as the nation's preeminent city of renters after the burst of co-op conversion and condominium construction of the 80's created a large new class of homeowners.
Demand for rentals has grown sharply, but so, too, has the supply, offering renters more options and a more inviting market than at any time since the mid-70's. That is because thousands of co-ops and condominiums have been put on the market as rentals by frustrated developers and owners who are unable to sell them.
The result, experts say, is a new dynamic in which many more apartments fall outside the city's rent-control and rent-stabilization laws, rates on most of the unregulated apartments have declined, and renters are bargaining hard to lower even more the rents asked by landlords. But demand is robust and rents are rising for some apartments, particularly large ones and those in a handful of fashionable new buildings.
One truism of New York living remains unshaken -- rent-regulated apartments priced below the market rate still are in intense demand, and are rarely advertised or listed with brokers. As always, these apartments tend to be passed on to people who know the landlord or are already living the building where a vacancy occurs.
Those looking for the bargain of a lifetime are likely to be disappointed. But because of the real estate slump and uncertainty about the market's near term prospects, executives say many more people, including the affluent, are in the market to rent for a year or two or however long it takes before confidence is restored that values will again begin to rise.
"THE rental market has zoomed," said Hank Sopher, president of J.I. Sopher and Company, a Manhattan brokerage. Its records show average rentals of 1,200 apartments a month in May, June and July, nearly double the number it rented in the same months in the previous four years.
"A lot of people who would normally buy are now renting," he added. "They consider a rental a safe haven."
Experts point to several recent developments that reflect the surge in rentals:
* At a time when the prices of the city's most expensive co-ops and condominiums have fallen sharply, in some cases more than 30 percent, a small number of expensive new rental buildings are in high demand. The Lucerne, a 45-story rental building at 79th Street and First Avenue, opened in January and all 236 apartments were rented by July. Rents are lofty, with two bedroom apartments fetching $3,800 to $4,750 a month.
* Although no precise count is available, the number of co-ops and condominiums now rented or on the market for rent has climbed into the thousands and continues to grow. Some brokers say less than half their rental listings are now in rental buildings.
* After a decline of over 10 percent since 1988 on most unregulated Manhattan apartments that are vacated and offered for rent, prices appear to have flattened out or increased slightly this year.
* Some tenants have negotiated lower rents -- or at least put off increases -- while remaining in their apartments. But in most cases -- almost always in apartments that are rent-controlled or rent stabilized -- tenants in occupancy have agreed to slight rent increases, and only those willing to move have been able to exploit their full negotiating clout to lower asking rents.
In one measure of how rents have declined on the most expensive Manhattan apartments, The Feathered Nest, a rental agency, has tracked thousands of transactions it has brokered since 1987. The company's inventory of rentals is evenly split among co-ops, condominiums and stabilized units in rental buildings, according to its president, Nancy Packes.
The analysis, which categorized apartments by neighborhood, size and other factors, found that a studio in an unregulated, doorman building on the Upper West Side would have rented for $1,225 in 1987, but the rent would have fallen to $1,000 by the first half of this year.
RENTS on one-bedrooms in unregulated Upper East Side buildings without doormen fell less, the study showed, from $1,350 in 1987 to $1,275 this year. Rents on some larger apartments rose. The study showed that a two-bedroom apartment in a unregulated doorman building on the Upper East Side would have rented for $2,950 in 1987, and was up to $3,000 this year.
The Feathered Nest inventory of current listings also made clear that many apartments in recently completed condominium buildings, which have been slow to sell, are now being offered for rent by their developers. Examples include a one-bedroom, two-bath unit at 3 Lincoln Center, completed in 1990, which is available at $2,180 a month, and a two-bedroom apartment at the Alexandria, a condominium completed this year at 72d Street and Broadway, which can be had for $3,999 a month.
Some real estate executives maintain that the increased rental activity represents a return to more normal times in a city where renters have always dominated the housing market. They say history may prove the 80's surge of co-op conversion and condominium construction to be an aberration.
"People were buying apartments because it was a way of going into business -- they were speculating," said Daniel Brodsky, a Manhattan developer, who in May began marketing the Concerto, a new, 35-story, 247-unit rental building at 60th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. So far, he said, 60 percent of the apartments have been leased at rents ranging from $950 a month for the smallest studio to $3,900 a month for a three bedroom apartment.
"We are going back to a state of normalcy, where New York is a rental town," said Mr. Brodsky, who added that he plans to break ground on another new rental building at 61st Street and West End Avenue next year.
Other new rental buildings, including some more expensive than the Lucerne or Concerto, have also been attracting tenants, albeit more slowly.
At One East River Place, which was completed in 1988 at 72d Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, 75 percent of 415 apartments have been rented at an average of $42 a square foot a year -- $4,100 to $5,300 a month for two-bedrooms.
Analysts say the success of the new buildings makes clear that, despite its economic duress, New York is still home to many wealthy people willing to pay a high price for a fashionable address, a sweeping view, marble bathroom fixtures, and perhaps a doorman with that properly authoritative style of calling a cab. The difference now, they say, is that many would prefer to rent.
"We have a different profile of the renter now," said Jack Heller, a Manhattan developer and president of Heller Equities. "These are high income people who don't want to be required to purchase, and for the first time we have buildings where they can get the amenities they want in a rental."
Mr. Heller said he, too, is planning at least one new rental building.
STILL, although the success of the new rental buildings is heartening to some, landlords and apartment owners in other relatively expensive buildings, including rentals, co-ops and condominiums, are struggling to find tenants.
"The buildings in secondary locations are taking a beating," said Allan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, a brokerage and management company in Manhattan.
"We are seeing much more mobility within the market, more tenants moving from building to building," he added. "But people are still nervous about New York and their own positions. They are reluctant to spend the maximum they can for housing."
One renter with fresh experience in the market is Harvey Kaufman, the comptroller of a women's apparel company who in July rented a large, 45th floor studio for $1100 a month at the Sheffield, a rental building on 57th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. He looked at 20 apartments before signing a lease.
"This is a renter's market, but not everyone seemed to be facing reality," he said, adding that he had looked at several far less attractive apartments -- including a tiny one room studio without a kitchen -- whose owners were asking over $1,000 a month.
For Mr. Robertson, the advertising executive, finding a luxurious rental at a price he considers a bargain came as consolation for other another real estate headache. Having purchased a four-bedroom, waterfront home in Stamford, Conn., at the height of the boom in 1986, he now owns what he refers to as the "Stamford turkey."
When he decided to move into Manhattan this year, Mr. Robertson said he did not even try to sell the Connecticut house after it was appraised at far below what he had paid. Instead, he has rented it out, fully furnished, and rented his current apartment from a couple who, like himself, have been forced into the role of landlord because of the housing slump.
Even by Manhattan standards, the East 66th Street apartment is not inexpensive -- his rent is $2,800 a month. Still, he estimated that the rent is $2,000 a month less than he would have had to pay for a comparable furnished Manhattan apartment in the mid-80's.
And for Mr. Auerbach, the comedy writer, the move to the Corinthian condominium, which he is renting from the apartment's owner, will mean higher rent checks. Currently paying $850 a month for his York Avenue walkup, his new rent is $1,600.
Still, he said, he will pay less than he expected for what he is getting. "This is a big step up from York Avenue," he said. "As a renter, I've found New York a very friendly place."

HEADLINE: SPECIAL REPORT;
A Milieu Apart

BYLINE: By Laura Mansnerus

 BODY:
AT TEMPLE University in Philadelphia, about 350 students pledged fraternities and sororities last year. Staff members at the university's day care center estimate that they fielded inquiries from more than 1,000 students. And the university's Adult Program, whose hottest workshops are "Assertiveness Training" and "Going to College as an Adult," heard from about twice that many.
At Temple, as at many American universities, to be 25 is to be more typical than noticeable. But it is also to be an adult, with adult concerns and an unmistakable sense of purpose. For mny students, college is no longer a stage of life but a place to do work. 
 The campus "is not my life, as it was when I was 18," said Brenda McBride, a 25-year-old senior majoring in journalism, during a break from her job as a lifeguard, which pays tuition.
Ms. McBride lives in Philadelphia's suburbs, works in center city, rarely socializes with students and seems to be talking about another person when she recalls her days at the University of Arizona, where she enrolled at age 18 and quit three years later. "Those were my friends, the people I was going to spend four years with," she said. "Now, I do my work, I listen in class and I leave."
 
A Sizable Majority Over 22
 So do many other Temple students, judging from the university's demographic profile. In the spring semester, more than three-quarters of its 20,000 undergraduates were 20 to 29 years old, with a sizable majority over 22; only 8.7 percent were 18- and 19-year-olds.
There are, of course, plenty of students on campus who took the direct route from high school. There are fraternity mixers and football games and group bar-hopping.
There is even enough youth around to make some of the older students feel conspicuous. "At first I had a complex," said Patty Kahn, a 30-year-old senior literature major. "I wouldn't tell anybody how old I was." (She was 27.)
But Ms. McBride said that she, like other older students interviewed, does not feel self-conscious in the least. As to how these students fit in with younger students, "The only contact I have with them is in the classroom," she said.
These students do not socialize with classmates partly because they have no time, partly because they completed adolescent rites of passage at some other time and place don't want to relive them. "Freshman dorms are terrible," said Ms. Kahn, who lived in one at Ithaca College in New York 12 years ago. "Girls crying on the telephone, men sneaking into bathrooms . . ."
Kate Bovich, who enrolled at Temple at age 32 and graduated with a journalism degree last year, fondly recalls her teen-age years at Reed College in Oregon. But she says that as an older student -- a working, divorced student with a small daughter -- "getting drunk and stupid and worrying about my love life was not something I missed."
"There is a generational difference," said Ms. Bovich, who is now the college's adviser for student publications. "Their experience is different from mine. They watch different TV shows. They didn't go to school when I did. They didn't have the Vietnam War."
At the same time, there seems to be a consensus on the nation's campuses that age does not matter the way it did a generation ago. As young people delay life decisions, it seems that 30-year-olds are dressing and talking more like 20-year-olds than they used to. "I've met 25-year-old mothers of three who look like everybody else to me," said Rebecca Alpert, associate director of Temple's Adult Program, the counseling service for adults (anyone 22 or older, by Temple's definition). "They wear jeans and blend right in."
It is not just to their elders that so many older students look like, well, students. Dina Levy, a 20-year-old junior at the University of Wisconsin, said: "The freshmen somehow you can pick out, and the oldest people you can pick out. But otherwise, when I sit in class, it's not easy to tell how old anybody is."
At the University of California at Berkeley, where in 1964 students were cautioned against trusting anyone<pl48,3.2over 30, age differences are "overwhelmed" by disparities in cultural and economic background, said Anthony J. Cascardi, a professor of comparative literature.
Still, Professor Cascardi said that in class older students were noticeable for taking strong positions. "And when you're teaching literature," he said, "sometimes you're just dying for a solid position to use, other than the one you want to tease out of the students, for the basis of a dialogue."
 
 
Where the Age Difference Shows
 In Paul Sunstein's Intellectual Heritage course at Temple, which runs from Genesis to Kafka, there is much probing of characters' emotional crises. In those discussions the difference between 18 and 28 shows.
"The older ones are better at dealing with the emotional content of literature," Professor Sunstein said. The 18-year-olds, he explained, "think everyone's a fanatic. They're all rational calculators. When in their lives have they ever had a strong experience?"
Jonathan Friedlaender, a Temple anthropology professor, said of his older students: "They're much more likely, if they're paying instead of mommy and daddy, to demand more out the course than just a good grade."
Older students acknowledge that they are nervier than many classmates. Patty Kahn said she often doesn't bother to raise her hand before she speaks. Bill Roper, 34, who returned to the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, said he found class discussions more interesting -- if sometimes elementary -- because of his experiences after dropping out in 1977. Besides starting a textbook-sales business, writing computer programs and running a mortgage-finance corporation, Mr. Roper served on the Republican City Committee in Boston, the finance committee of the Massachusetts Republican Party and the National Highway Safety Committee. In Philadelphia, he is active in ward politics.
"Now, if you're sitting in a survey course in political science, you know some of that," he said, adding that he is delighted to debate with the recitation leader.
The same is true of her undergraduates who have worked, said Frances E. Zollers, a professor of law and public policy at Syracuse University's School of Management. "They'll draw a parallel with what they're hearing in class and offer it as an example if I'm struggling," she said. Older students are not necessarily better students, Professor Zollers warned. "They make the same reasoning errors that everybody going through a first-year law class does. They're also not in test-taking mode, which hurts them."
But most professors say older students compensate by asking what they are doing wrong. "Age changes the nature of the exchange," said Jim Gibson, who also teaches Intellectual Heritage at Temple. "They're able to negotiate." Then, he said, they improve quickly.
"I beg for them," said Professor Gibson, who spends much of his class time coaxing and lighting upon hesitant comments from students. "And when they walk in the door I thank them and I coddle them."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 15, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Education Life section on Aug. 4 about older undergraduates misidentified Temple University's adviser for student publications. She has pointed out in a recent letter that her name is Kate Bozich.

PUB-DATE: August 4, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk
