HEADLINE: One Day, Junior Got Too Big

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash.

 BODY:
TEN years ago this month, the International Business Machines Corporation introduced its first personal computer, changing the computer industry forever. Almost overlooked at the time was the company chosen to provide key software for the machine, headed by a nerdy programmer young enough to be the son of many of the I.B.M. executives.
 No one is overlooking the results of that decision today. Seizing on that initial opportunity to provide the MS-DOS operating system for I.B.M. personal computers and the clones that followed, the Microsoft Corporation has grown into the world's largest software company, with revenues of $1.8 billion for the fiscal year ending in June. Its reach expands into nearly every nook and cranny of the software business. 
With a market capitalization of $12.8 billion, Microsoft is also one of the 50 most valuable companies in the nation, according to a Business Week ranking, ahead of all computer companies except I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard and in the company of Ford Motor, Dow Chemical and other industrial giants with many times its revenues. The nerdy programmer, William H. Gates, now 35, owns enough of Microsoft to make him worth $4 billion, more than the gross national product of Nicaragua.
 But it is getting lonely at the top. On the way to its current dominance, Microsoft and the intensely competitive Mr. Gates have angered many rivals and even some former partners, including I.B.M. Now, almost everyone in the industry is hatching plans to try to compete with Microsoft for control over the industry's direction. And the resulting massive realignment of forces that is reshaping the industry could pose a severe challenge to Microsoft's hegemony.
 "Our belief is that Microsoft has peaked," said George Colony, president of Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass. "They have enough hubris now to believe they don't need I.B.M., that they don't need anybody. I think Microsoft will be a big, struggling company in two years."
 Microsoft's relationship with its former mentor, I.B.M., indeed is in a shambles. After a falling out over the joint development of a successor to MS-DOS, I.B.M. is now competing head to head with the software company in what promises to be one of the nastiest personal-computer industry battles of the 1990's. Each company is already trashing the other's product in public. Under the old rubric that "My enemy's enemy is my friend," I.B.M. has even joined forces with its former rival, Apple Computer Inc., to develop software that will compete with Microsoft's offerings. I.B.M. has also formed smaller alliances with other software companies, including the Lotus Development Corporation and Borland International Inc.
 
Others Are Joining Forces
 Novell Inc., which so far has bested Microsoft in software for controlling networks of personal computers, recently strengthened its hand by buying Digital Research Inc., which makes a program that competes with MS-DOS (Page 4).
 And the Federal Trade Commission is investigating Microsoft's practices, spurred in part by complaints from competitors that Microsoft's dominance in operating systems gives it unfair advantages in other categories.
 The key threat to Microsoft, however, is not other companies but a big technology change. With MS-DOS and its newer product called Windows, Microsoft dominates the market for software that controls personal computers. But personal computers are increasingly being linked in networks and with larger machines called servers to handle computing tasks now handled by centralized mainframe computers.
 Not only has Microsoft had little experience with networked systems, but such an interconnected computing world is likely to require cooperation among companies. Some say Microsoft will have a tough time going it alone, especially against I.B.M., which wields considerable influence with corporate data processing departments.
 "No one really likes to do business with Microsoft," said Philippe Kahn, the founder and president of Borland, who predicts that the falling out with I.B.M. will hurt the software company. "He didn't need to declare war on I.B.M.," Mr. Kahn said, referring to Mr. Gates. "That will turn out five years from now to look like his biggest mistake. That's ego."
 To be sure, there is an element of wishful thinking and jealousy in predictions of Microsoft's downfall. For all their moaning that Microsoft was lucky to be anointed by I.B.M., or that it abuses its control over the key operating software, rivals also acknowledge that Microsoft is a superb competitor and has executed its strategy with precision.
 Moreover, most of the threats to Microsoft from new alliances might take two or more years to materialize. In the meantime, Microsoft will likely continue its rapid growth merely by selling Windows to as many as possible of the 70 million users of MS-DOS PC's. "Until anyone sees evidence of a broadside hit, it's just a war of words in my opinion," said David Readerman, a software analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "The product momentum is very much on Microsoft's side."
 
10 New Workers a Day
 And what momentum it is. Net income has been growing at an average of 64 percent a year over the last five years and revenues at 56 percent. With 8,200 employees, Microsoft has been hiring 10 new people a day, and its campus here, outside Seattle, is in a perennial state of construction.
 Mr. Gates is not unaware of the challenges. "I think I need to work extremely hard if we are to do anywhere near as well as we've done," he said. But he also added that challenges are not unusual. "Name a year and I'll name the people out to get us," he said.
 Mr. Gates also dismissed talk that his behavior has angered his partners and that he, or his competitors, were driven by emotion and ego instead of business sense. "This is business. This is not Divorce Court or Psychology Today," he said. In forming their alliance, he said, I.B.M. and Apple are acting out of perceived needs.
 "I won't take any credit for that wildness," he said, explaining that he thinks the partnership makes little sense, particularly for Apple, which will sacrifice its uniqueness by sharing software development with I.B.M. "Why do they need help? What are they missing?" Mr. Gates said. "It's certainly a huge step backward to have to smoosh it together" with I.B.M.'s effort, he said.
 I.B.M.'s need for Apple and other partners stems in large part from the void left by Microsoft. I.B.M. and Microsoft initially worked together on OS/2, which was supposed to be a successor to MS-DOS, with more sophisticated features. But now Microsoft is backing its own program, Windows, which it began developing long before it started work on OS/2.
 For I.B.M., OS/2 is crucial to tying personal computers to its larger machines. It also needs its own operating system to help differentiate its personal computers from the legions of cheaper clones that have severely cut its market share.
 But clearly, emotions are playing a role as well. Industry executives say I.B.M. feels betrayed, like a father whose son has turned against him. Mr. Gates and I.B.M. executives have not spoken for months. For his part, Mr. Gates said he is angry about a demonstration by I.B.M. a few months ago in which it showed how easy it was to make Windows "crash" or stall. Microsoft responded last month by showing securities analysts how easy it was to crash OS/2 as well.
 Mr. Gates said Microsoft tried to accommodate I.B.M. in every way but at some point, I.B.M. had asked too much. For instance, he said, I.B.M. asked that Microsoft stop work on future versions of Windows, a request Microsoft rejected.
 
A Swollen Budget
 Mr. Gates said he was also worried when the number of I.B.M. people working on OS/2 began to mushroom and costs to escalate and when I.B.M. began pressuring Microsoft to "fund the bloat." Mr. Gates argued that the software could never be profitable if so much was spent developing it.
 Indeed, a March 1990 audit by a leading expert from I.B.M. and one from Microsoft compared the companies' contributions to OS/2. The software written by Microsoft was characterized as "O.K." and in some cases as "slick" or "great," while the portions by I.B.M. were usually characterized as "fat," "slow," "disorganized" and "inappropriate." An I.B.M. spokeswoman this week acknowledged problems existed but said the company has long since taken corrective steps.
 To that extent, not having to work with I.B.M. could be a relief for Microsoft. But Mr. Gates said that he is not relieved and that I.B.M.'s attempt to steer corporate data processing managers away from Windows is Microsoft's single biggest threat.
 With relations with I.B.M. broken off, however, Microsoft is fully committed to Windows. It has sold more than 4 million copies since a revamped version appeared a little more than a year ago, dwarfing the 600,000 copies of OS/2 sold since 1987. Windows works on top of MS-DOS, making it an easier transition than OS/2, a replacement for DOS.
 But being tied to the older technology of MS-DOS could also be a drawback for Windows. So Microsoft is developing a new operating system, known as Windows NT, which it says will be ready next year. The project, which could be the key to Microsoft's future, is being headed by Dave Cutler, formerly a key designer at the Digital Equipment Corporation, a balding, grizzled veteran who stands in sharp contrast to the youthful programmers he commands.
 
Versions of Windows
 NT -- which stands for new technology -- will run on powerful personal computers using different kinds of microprocessors and will be better geared for use in networks. Indeed, Microsoft plans a whole series of versions of Windows for different machines, ranging from pocket-sized personal information organizers to supercomputers. The company is also looking at using Windows to help control computerized facsimile machines, voice-mail systems and high-definition television sets.
 Windows, however, is more than just an operating system. Microsoft is using it to increase sales of applications products like Microsoft Word, its word-processing program, and its Excel spreadsheet by tailoring these programs to run with Windows.
 Competitors are following suit, after having initially ignored Windows in favor of OS/2. Some, in fact, say Microsoft misled them into supporting OS/2, a charge Microsoft denies.
 In any case, Microsoft has had the market for applications that work with Windows nearly to itself. "It's almost like taking candy from a baby," said Scott Oki, senior vice president of sales, marketing and services for Microsoft.
 Microsoft said that in the last year its share of the United States markets for spreadsheets and word processing for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers have both doubled to about 30 percent, as measured by revenues. Mike Maples, the senior vice president of applications software for Microsoft, predicts Microsoft will surpass Lotus in spreadsheets in 12 months. Wordperfect, he said, is a little tougher: "We're not that far, but it's a very steep hill."
 Hogwash, replied Frank King, senior vice president of Lotus, who called Microsoft's market-share claims exaggerated. In units sold, he said, Microsoft is still "solidly in third place" behind Lotus 1-2-3 and Borland's Quattro Pro.
 Moreover, Microsoft's honeymoon is about over. Lotus has said it will have a version of 1-2-3 for Windows out by September and Wordperfect is not far behind. If there is any consolation for Microsoft, it is that the debut of all these new products will help increase sales of Windows.
 Mr. Gates seems determined to enter every major area in the personal computer software business. To develop new software concepts, the company has started a lab, headed by Nathan P. Myhrvold, a physicist who worked with the noted British astrophysicist Stephen Hawking before being bitten by the software bug.
 Rivals have long complained that the rest of the industry has served as Microsoft's R.& D. lab. Windows was clearly inspired by Apple's work with the Macintosh, so much so that Apple is suing Microsoft for copyright infringement. While the Go Corporation has pioneered development of new software to control pen-based computers, Microsoft is adding extensions to Windows to handle pen input. Even MS-DOS, the program that put Microsoft on the map, was acquired from another company.
 "You will have a hard time finding anything that Microsoft pioneered," said Mr. Kahn of Borland. "Guys like Steve Jobs have contributed tons more to the industry than Bill," he added, referring to the founder of Apple and of Next Computer Inc.
 That might be somewhat unfair. Microsoft has been early in some technologies like combining video with computing, and has kept up its investment for years even though a big market has yet to materialize. As the Japanese have proved, what matters most is not the basic invention but the ability to commercialize it. Mr. Gates has proved to be a master at quickly positioning Microsoft to take advantage of new developments.
 Mr. Gates is, by all accounts, a demanding boss. Employees who enter meetings not fully prepared can leave carrying their head in their hands. "At least three times in a meeting he'll say 'That's the stupidest thing I've ever heard,' " said Paul Maritz, vice president for advanced operating systems.
 But Mr. Gates also inspires loyalty. Microsoft has had very little turnover in its top management.
 Mr. Gates works at the same relentless pace as in 1975, when he dropped out of Harvard at age 19 to start Microsoft, staying up late to reply to some of the more than 100 electronic mail messages he gets each day. "You see mail from Bill at 2 in the morning," said Mr. Oki, the senior vice president. It is somewhat disconcerting to Mr. Gates, then, that some of his thirtysomething lieutenants are starting to marry and have kids, and sometimes can't reply to his messages until the morning. A couple of executives have retired to enjoy the wealth they've earned from Microsoft.
 
An Underground House
 Mr. Gates has not had much time to enjoy his fortune, with the exception of a penchant for fancy cars and of a new house he is building, most of it underground, with a garage the size of an airplane hangar and space to seat 250 people for dinner. High-definition television screens will display artworks that can be changed to suit the tastes of guests. The house will also have four children's bedrooms, perhaps a sign that Mr. Gates will someday settle down and marry.
 But most of Mr. Gates's efforts will be occupied with making Windows a broad-based success and extending Microsoft's reach throughout the software business, which could be among the most important industries of the coming decade.
 Said Paul Grayson, chairman of Micrografx, a Dallas software company that was an early supporter of Windows but is now working with I.B.M. on OS/2: "If Bill succeeds in his strategy, in my opinion he'll become the wealthiest, most powerful person in the history of mankind."

 
MICROSOFT'S DIVERSITY STRATEGY
 In an industry in which many companies focus on one type of product, Microsoft has long been known for diversity, from its Flight Simulator game to its Basic programming language. While it is best known for its systems software, Microsoft is also the largest supplier of personal computer applications software like word-processing programs and spreadsheets. It trails companies like Lotus and Wordperfect in individual categories, but has the largest overall revenues, $935 million in the last fiscal year.
 Microsoft continues to expand into new categories. This fall, it is expected to introduce software aimed at homes and small businesses. Microsoft Publisher will be a low-end desktop publishing program to print fliers, say, or menus. Microsoft Money will be for personal finance management. Later on will come programs for checkbook balancing.
 The company is also making a big push for programs, exchanging and commenting on documents and routing forms from place to place.
 Microsoft does not have a data-base program, an important category controlled by Borland International and Ashton-Tate, which are merging. Mike Maples, senior vice president for applications software, said that about 18 months ago, Microsoft realized it was working on the wrong approach to such a product, scrapped its efforts and started over.
 The product it will introduce, next year at the earliest, will allow computer users to retrieve and analyze data without knowing how to program. He said the program might be similar to one by Metaphor Computer Systems that brand managers at companies like Proctor & Gamble use to analyze competitive data.
 
AVOIDING BIG MERGERS
 Will Microsoft jump into the computer industry mergers and alliances frenzy? William H. Gates, its chairman, does not completely count it out. Among computer companies, "Every combination of A with B has not only been thought about, there's been at least one meeting on it," he said.
 Microsoft has made a few small acquisitions but has stayed away from large ones, in part because of the difficulty of merging technology companies. Antitrust concerns could also prevent such mergers.
 Would Microsoft be interested in buying Novell, which is beating Microsoft in the crucial area of networking software? "It'd be interesting," Mr. Gates replied. "It would be new for us to do a big acquisition."
 Industry curiosity was piqued recently when Mr. Gates met with Scott McNealy, president of Sun Microsystems. Sun champions the Unix operating system, a direct competitor to Windows NT. Mr. Gates denied rumors that Sun and Microsoft would join to counter I.B.M. and Apple, or that Microsoft would make a version of its new Windows NT operating system for Sun's Sparc microprocessor. "There's nothing going to happen between us and Sun," he said.
 Microsoft does hope to work more closely with the Digital Equipment Corporation, an I.B.M. rival. But Mr. Gates said there would be no formal alliance. Microsoft and Digital, along with Compaq Computer, are in a consortium trying to set standards for a new generation of desktop computers.

PUB-DATE: August 4, 1991

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1368 words

HEADLINE: Urban Outposts Keep Fighting the War on Poverty

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
WHEN the United States declared war on poverty in the 1960's, New Haven was one of the first targets. In 1962 the nation's first community-based antipoverty agency, Community Progress Inc., opened in the city and became the incubator for lasting national programs like Head Start, the Neighborhood Youth Corps and others that offered legal services and job training.
Like other Great Society initiatives, Community Progress ultimately suffered from a tarnished reputation and was replaced by a reconstituted successor. But in New Haven and 13 other communities in the state, local agencies begun in the idealism of the 60's have survived into the 90's, serving some 400,000 people. And as the Federal Government seeks new directions for its current scaled-back efforts to address the lingering problems of poverty, the people who run those programs say they are eager to offer ideas as well as evidence of success, despite the less-than-enthusiastic support they have received from Washington. 
 "The Government set us up to fail," said the executive director of Community Action for Greater Middletown, Idella W. Howell, who has worked for the agency since 1964. "It gave us some money and told us to go out and get rid of poverty within 10 years. Then it started cutting off our funding.
"But the fact of the matter is that, no, of course we couldn't get rid of poverty in that amount of time, and yes, we did make some big mistakes. But we survived, and we have continued to fight the battle we were created to do and with a fair number of successes."
Mrs. Howell, raised outside of Florence, S.C., moved to Connecticut in the late 1940's. While working at a parachute factory, she created a neighborhood organization, La Bonhomie, in her predominantly black neighborhood in Middletown. Members helped each other by minding children, assisting elderly neighbors and holding classes for teen-agers.
Her efforts caught the attention of the four staff members at the city's newly opened Community Action Agency. She was recruited as a neighborhood organizer, going door to door throughout the city, listening to people's concerns. The information was later used to begin or expand programs of job training and child care.
After serving the agency in several administrative positions, Mrs. Howell was appointed executive director in 1977. Since then she has been responsible for raising the funds to support the organization's 11 programs, including $300,000 in local donations toward building a day care and Head Start center in the early 1980's. Most recently Mrs. Howell moved the agency, which now has a staff of 105 and a budget of more than $6 million, to a newly renovated school building in the heart of the city. State funds helped pay for the $1.2 million renovation project.
Though her work consists mainly of administrative tasks, Mrs. Howell remains a consummate outreach worker who will stop vagrants on the street and ask how she can help them. She recently invited a group of alcoholics to the agency's board room to voice their fears about the future.
"First we go out and try and find the need," said Mrs. Howell. "Then we find a way to take care of that need by building a program around the people that we serve."
 
'Try and Break the Cycle'
 The executive director of Norwalk Economic Opportunity Now, Robert Burgess, said his agency's goal is to give people the skills to help themselves. "But we're realists," said Mr. Burgess, who played in the band that toured with the popular music stars Wilson Pickett and the Temptations, until Mr. Burgess began working for community action agencies in the early 1970's. "Whenever you're dealing with human beings, there are bound to be failures.
"The reality is that most people want to be helped out of poverty, yet some people just don't. Nevertheless, it's our job to try and break the cycle of poverty through education, job training and, when necessary, teaching people how to be good parents."
Among the agency's 25 programs is one that offers a supervised alternative to incarceration for some offenders, including the nation's first halfway house where children are allowed to live with their mothers.
Cle Johnson, 18 years old, and his friends Andre Brown and Joseph Mann, both 17, are graduates of the Norwalk agency's youth development program, which serves high school juniors and seniors from low-income families. Through the program they received tutoring that helped them raise their grades and advice on how to study for the College Board exam, they said.
All three will be attending college in Virginia this fall and are currently working as counselors in the summer camp program based at the agency's four neighborhood centers. The camp serves some 600 children each summer.
Mayor Frank Esposito of Norwalk said the Community Action Agency has had a major impact on the city. "Every project they set out to do," he said, "has turned out to be excellent."
 
A Setback in New Haven
 Community Progress Inc. in New Haven, founded in 1962 with help from the Ford Foundation, served as the model for hundreds of similar projects around the country. Its innovations included Head Start, the Neighborhood Youth Corps, the Legal Services Program and the Comprehensive Manpower Training Program. But by the mid-1970's the organization had fallen into fiscal and administrative chaos and became known as a political pork barrel. After a Federal and state investigation, the program was stripped of its government funds and eliminated as the antipoverty agent for New Haven.
In 1977 the Community Action Agency of New Haven was created to replace Community Progress. The successor agency now administers 11 programs, including one that transports elderly residents to medical appointments and another that offers computer training.
Marcial Cuevas, the agency's executive director since 1978, said that although it is able to provide services for some 32,000 residents, it must compete for funds with 200 nonprofit agencies in the city. As a result, "you've got people who need four or five services who have to go four or five places to get them," he said. "It gets to be very frustrating."
The New Haven debacle of the 1970's, like those at community action agencies throughout the country, had a lasting effect on the programs. James H. Gatling, the president of the state Community Action Association and executive director of New Opportunities for Waterbury Inc., said it took years to mend the agencies' image.
"Everyone had such grand ideas in those days," he said referring to the bold social reforms of the Great Society years. "The Feds were pumping money into communities without setting up regulations and allowing people with no management or even social work experience to take charge of hundreds of thousands of dollars. Few considered the consequences."
 
Keeping Pace With the Times
 But as the Federal Government backed away from its promise to fight poverty, he said, many community action agencies matured, built strong local ties and were able to obtain funds to maintain and create programs. And unlike the mid-1960's, when it was assumed that job training was the key to reducing poverty, he said, the rise in AIDS, drug abuse and homelessness and the breakdown of the family have made the agencies' mission much more difficult.
As one of the largest community action agencies in the state, with 45 programs, New Opportunities for Waterbury has tried to keep pace with the times, Mr. Gatling said. New programs offer homemaking skills to young adults who have grown up in the foster care system, therapy for families whose children are at risk of being placed in foster homes and AIDS-prevention education for prostitutes, low-income young people and pregnant women.
Still, Mr. Gatling said he wished that community action agencies could afford to do more. The recession has brought them a new wave of clients, he said, referring to the swelling numbers of middle-class residents who have lost their jobs.
"No matter what the conservative politicians say," said Mr. Gatling, "the community action agency remains one of the few true voices left for the people."

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: NORFOLK;
Businesses Are Joining Forces To Lure More Tourists to Town

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE

 BODY:
THE citizens of Norfolk have banded together against the British, a pack of wolves on Haystack Mountain, the Confederacy and even progress. But in the last few years they have come up against a most formidable foe: the economy.
Michele Sloane, the 37-year-old owner of the Mountain View Inn, issued a call to arms in March, rallying local business owners to respond to last summer's poor economic showing. True to the town's history, they rallied. 
 "We had about 45 at the first meeting," said Ms. Sloane, seated at a dining table in the rambling Victorian-style inn. "I was shocked."
 
18th-Century Tavern
 Norfolk's winter population is 2,200. In the summer, however, it swells to 3,000, owing to the Yale Summer School of Music and Art, the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival and the town's reputation as a summer resort.
The 46.7-square-mile town sits about 1,300 feet above sea level in the Litchfield Hills, its pre-Revolutionary town green flanked by a handsome spired Meeting House; the former Battell Stoeckel mansion, called White House, now a part of the Yale Summer School; an 18th-century building that once served as a tavern and stagecoach stop; a Victorian public library, and several 18th-century homes. The town remains much as it once was.
Down the hill from the green is a modest business district, with a restaurant, grocery store and a few other retailers as well as "For Rent" signs, empty storefronts and, around town, an occasional notice of foreclosure.
With last year's summer business estimated to have been off by 50 percent from the year before, Ms. Sloane said, she was was compelled to form the Norfolk Merchants Association. Since its founding in March, 47 diverse businesses have joined. The group has published a comprehensive and attractive brochure aimed at prospective visitors, complete with three maps, descriptions of the businesses, a brief history and a list of points of interest.
"We printed 5,000, and they're going like wildfire," Ms. Sloane said. "At the end of June we distributed them through all of the merchants, through Yale and the New England Vacation Center in Rockefeller Center. I see people walking in from town for a room, and they're holding the brochure."
A lot of music lovers are drawn to the town by the Yale summer program and the Chamber Music Festival, which run from late June to Aug. 10. Last year the festival celebrated its 50th season.
"We're the centerpiece of the tourist trade here," said Michael Geller, 29, the festival's manager. "When you say tourism, some of the locals are skeptical, because Norfolk is a special place. The Merchants Association is about keeping that special, but letting more people in on the secret."
The Norfolk Chamber Music Festival's 1904 Music Shed seats 2,000, and concerts are frequently sold out. Last year ticket sales were up 19 percent from the previous year.
Also dependent on the summer season are Fred and Mary Ann McGourty, horticulturists and owners of Hillside Gardens, open from May through September. The McGourtys' 18th-century home is surrounded by 25 different perennial borders on five cultivated acres, and they sell a wide selection of uncommon perennials. During the cold months, the couple, authors and editors of a variety of gardening books, lecture across the United States and Canada. Mr. McGourty, who has lived in Norfolk since 1963, said he, too, was surprised by the number of people who attended the first meeting of the Merchants Association.
The group "brings together a lot of individuals in the town," he said. "As far as the business end goes, everybody tends to keep a low profile. It is part of the psychology of Norfolk. Even now I suspect we only know a fraction."
Mrs. McGourty added: "There are a lot of very talented people in town. These are solitary arts, people need space and quiet. The Merchants Association creates a common bond among the business community.
"We joined the Merchants Association because we'd like to promote our own business. But we'd like to see the businesses in town succeed, year-round and week-round, so we're not entirely dependent on weekenders."
But those who hope to promote Norfolk face a paradox, Mrs. McGourty said: "You need to promote yourself, and yet the rural character is what attracts visitors." The association's brochure shows the diversity of the businesses in town. A visit to the local Artisans Guild, where works of many local people are displayed, confirms this. In the corner of what used to be a bank (the vault is used as a walk-in display area), a clavichord made by Carl Dudash awaits a home. His workroom is in a carriage house a few winding blocks away.
Mr. Dudash makes harpsichords and clavichords for musicians from California to Switzerland. His wife, Marilee Wagner Dudash, creates the painted finishes of marbling, arabesques, trompe l'oeil designs and Latin lettering.
 
'A Very Bad Year'
 The Dudashes said they joined the Merchants Association because they thought it would be good for their business.
"Last year was a very bad year, I have to be honest," Mr. Dudash said, noting that sales of luxury items drop when the economy is tight. His instruments start at $5,000 and can go as high as $30,000, depending on decoration. Mr. Dudash said his new line of harpsichords is selling well in Europe, so his own outlook has improved.
"The Merchants Association will stimulate people to come here," he said. "This town has a tremendous potential, which I'd like to see realized. There is a wealth of talented people here and highly diversified: a canoe maker, a guitar maker, furniture makers.
"I can go two blocks away and have the legs turned for these instruments. Or if somebody has a better piece of machinery for something, no problem to borrow it. It's a very nice environment."
For visitors an unusual way to see Norfolk is by horse and carriage. Beth Denis, 37, and her partner, Judy Wiltse, 35, also instrumental in the formation of the association, have operated the Horse and Carriage Livery Service for 10 years, serving weddings and special occasions all over the Northeast. They offer hourlong historic tours of Norfolk in a French vis-a-vis carriage.
With her enormous Belgian horse chomping at the bit, Ms. Denis, elegant in her coachman's hat, guided the carriage up the hill toward the green.
"Business has been a little slow this year as far as hayrides and carriage rides go because of the economy," she said. "The Merchants Association is a great group, because there hasn't been anything cohesive like it. We felt there was a need for everyone to do some referrals back and forth.
"It's critical for us to have people in town be aware of us. And it's nice to have a whole sheet of information to give to guests. There's a lot hidden away here."
As the carriage drew near to the closed railroad station, Ms. Denis said: "The town of Norfolk is so unique. Norfolk has never changed. It still has that old traditional village life. Where else can you go without passing a McDonald's?"

HEADLINE: Leaking Water in Yaphank Dump Stalls Ash-for-Garbage Exchange

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
A CONTROVERSY over a proposed solid-waste agreement between the Towns of Brookhaven and Hempstead is being complicated by the discovery of excess water in the Brookhaven landfill.
The identification of the water, originally feared to be leaks in the liner of the Cell 4 land area, has led the State Environmental Conservation Department to postpone the agreement, which was to have taken effect on June 1. Cell 4 is nicknamed Ski Bowl because of its high hill, inside of which is a carved-out area. 
 Under the pact, known as Ash for Trash, Hempstead would be permitted to bury up to 230,000 tons of ash a year at the Brookhaven landfill, which is in Yaphank. In return, Brookhaven would send 600 tons a day of garbage to the Town of Hempstead incinerator in Garden City.
 
No Environmental Review
 Other municipalities have forged cooperative agreements. Islip and Babylon are trading yard waste and garbage, but the Brookhaven-Hempstead exchange is apparently the first with ash and garbage in the state.
For five years, civic groups and residents near the dump have strongly opposed the proposed exchange, largely because of concerns over the potentially toxic ash to be buried there.
An agreement cannot be enforced or permits issued to the towns without safe conditions, said Assemblyman I. William Bianchi Jr., Democrat of Patchogue. He pointed out that there had been no environmental review of the cell.
When the state serves as the lead agency for a project, an environmental impact statement has always been required, he said, adding that in this case the town of Brookhaven is the lead agency and has not required an environmental review.
"It's a legal and technical point," Assemblyman Bianchi said.
"There is so much water in Cell 4 right now," Mr. Bianchi said, "that if you had a small sailboat, you could sail in it. We're asking the Governor for personal intervention to safeguard the environmental safety at the location."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has stepped into two related cases. He closed the Port Washington Landfill after many complaints over the odors emanating from the site, and he named Richard M. Kessel ombudsman to investigate smoke and odor problems at the Glen Cove incinerator. The incinerator has been ordered closed for at least a month beginning last Thursday.
Two civic groups have united to hire a lawyer to represent them in their fight against the exchange in Brookhaven. The groups have expressed their opposition at Town Board meetings and in testimony, and the groups have proposed alternatives like recycling and composting.
The state is holding up its approval of the exchange pact until Cell 4 has a new liner and tests determine whether it will prevent leachate from reaching the ground water. Brookhaven garbage is being dumped in the Cell 3 area.
In a double-lined landfill like the one in Yaphank, one liner is on top, and a secondary collection system is between the two liners. Less than 150 gallons of water should come out of the secondary system each day, said Ray Cowen, regional environmental director for the state. The amount has been 800 to 1,000 gallons a day.
The excess water, Mr. Cowen said, may be a combination of water that seeped between the liners during the construction of the landfill and leachate seeping from Cell 1, adjacent to Cell 4.
In the interest of time, Mr. Cowen said, Brookhaven has decided not to repair the secondary liner, but to install a new one. He said the town would then have to certify that the liner is effective and correctly installed, as well as demonstrate that less than 150 gallons a day passed through it.
But many residents voice skepticism that a new liner will be able to handle the ash to be dumped in the landfill. Ash is heavier and more concentrated than raw garbage, which has already been deposited in the landfill, said James Fuchs, president of the Brookhaven Village Association, one of the groups opposing the exchange.
"Four tons of garbage are reduced to one ton of ash," he said. "We are concerned that the concentrated ash will tear the liner and, consequently, pollute the ground water."
An assistant commissioner of environmental conservation, Gary Striar, said that the liners were designed for the weight and that there was no chance that ash would tear the liner.
Mr. Fuchs said the weight of the ash on top of garbage would distort the liner.
The Town of Hempstead has no system to remove toxic substances before burying wastes, Mr. Fuchs said, adding that five schools are within two miles of the dump.
 
Risk to Children
 "No one has done any reports on windblown ash," he said. "We fear that the children will be at risk from ash particles' blowing around in one of the windiest places on the Island.
"The town says that they'll be burying the ash. But it is, in fact, a mountain 200 feet up in the air. Our welfare and safety should be first and foremost. We've given the town documentation, but they don't want to listen."
Brookhaven Deputy Supervisor Peter A. Scully said the ash arrived in concrete form and could not blow around. It hardens in the ground, he added, and it is not very likely to permeate into the ground water.
"There has been a tremendous amount of less-than-accurate information," Mr. Scully said. "Safety requirements for landfills of ash residue are stringent, and we have a great deal of confidence that the exchange will not impact in any way on the water quality."
The battle over the dump has been brewing for years. Opened in the early 70's, it was promoted as an asset that would be used for a finite number of years and then capped, closed and possibly used as a skiing hill like the former Bald Hill Ski Bowl in Farmingville.
 
More Leachate Than Expected
 A liner was installed to prevent leachate from seeping into the ground, and pipes were placed around the edge to collect water and drain it into a designated area. But more leachate was produced than anticipated, and over the years it has overflowed and leaked through the liner.
As far back as 1986, when a proposal was made to turn the landfill into a regional ash-fill site, Brookhaven supported community opposition to the plan, said Lillian Depaolo, another member of the Brookhaven Village Association.
"The Town Board supported us and said they'd never make it a regional dump site," Ms. Depaolo said. "But incineration companies have become big business. Incineration offers a high profit, but is not a good means of eliminating waste."
Federal law has favored incineration, she added, but offered scant tax breaks for recycling or other alternatives.
"This is absolutely a done deal," Ms. Depaolo said. "As a group of civic associations, we have been silenced, and many people in the immediate area do not even know what ash-for-trash is."
 
Divided Views in Hempstead
 Hempstead officials applaud the proposal as a big plus for managing trash and saving considerable tax dollars, said a spokesman for the town, Anthony Santino.
Some residents say they have questions and concerns, but a majority also do not know what ash-for-trash is, said the chairwoman of the Citizens Committee for Civic Action, Viki DeJong.
The town has given the impression that the trade has already begun, she said, adding that informed residents are somewhat concerned about the possible environmental effects on Brookhaven and the economic effects on Hempstead if the ash created problems and Hempstead was forced to look for other alternatives to dispose the ash.
"The ash-for-trash plan is an excellent one," Mr. Cowen said. "Long Island needs to become self-sufficient in solid-waste management, and intermunicipal arrangements are one of the only effective ways to do this. I am not concerned over any health hazards. As a matter of fact, ash is more innocuous than raw garbage."

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Heard the One About Henny and Recession?

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
A little light touch goes a long way at corporate gatherings in these gloomy days.
ON a stifling Sunday night in late July, 200 people gathered at New York's Pierre Hotel in tuxedos and party dresses for the annual dinner of the Cultured Pearl Association of America. Just after 10:15, the evening's celebrity star, Henny Youngman, broke through the heat and the cigar smoke.
"I feel right at home here," Mr. Youngman told the crowd. "My grandfather had a jewelry business, too. He had an antique watch and on his deathbed guess what he did? He sold it to me." 
 The audience loved it, and that was good news for Jerry Kravat, the entertainment impresario responsible for hiring Mr. Youngman. His New York-based firm, the biggest in the corporate entertainment business, provides everything from opera singers to ice skaters for corporate events -- but fewer stuntmen during this lingering recession. Sending a 150-piece marching band into the Plaza Hotel's ballroom or ordering a unicyclist to ride across a wire in a bank's boardroom is definitely out.
"People aren't asking for as many stunts today," Mr. Kravat said. "They may be too flashy, too 80's."
Indeed, the recession has made many companies more discreet about hiring high-priced entertainers, although they continue to do so. "People are definitely more subtle," he said. "They don't want to rub anybody's nose in it. They want to keep a low profile."
By contrast, stand-up comedians like Mr. Youngman are hot commodities. "People have to lighten up; they're so serious about business these days," said Lee Yoselovsky, co-chairman of the pearl group's dinner and president of Ben Yoselovsky & Company, a New York jewelry company. "We needed a good act this year. We wanted to make people smile."
That's why Mr. Yoselovsky turned to Mr. Kravat, whose business, with 30 full-time employees and sales exceeding $20 million, serves clients like Anheuser Busch, Coca-Cola, DuPont, I.B.M. and Price Waterhouse. Although many companies are cutting costs, Mr. Kravat expects to book more than 1,000 corporate engagements this year, up 15 percent from last year.
"In tough times, people want employees and customers to be happy," Mr. Kravat said. "They don't want to skimp on things that can motivate them to do better work."
Vincent King, senior meeting planner for the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche, which recently held a new-partners dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria, agrees.
"It's important to have quality entertainment," as Mr. King put it. "It lets people know you appreciate their hard work."
Quality entertainment doesn't come cheap. "If you've heard of an artist, he's going to be expensive," said Mr. Kravat. Big-name performers may charge anywhere from $20,000 to $100,000 an appearance, and top stars like Liza Minnelli may command as much as $200,000 for a couple of hours -- plus expenses including airfare, hotel rooms and other incidentals.
But Mr. Kravat, ever the pitchman, says price should not be a deterrent. "I prefer to think of it in reverse," Mr. Kravat said. "It's really inexpensive to bring in Liza Minnelli if she gets the message across to your board of directors or your salespeople."
In the past few months, Mr. Kravat has booked Kid Creole and the Coconuts for a convention of the National Cable Advertisers Association, and Kool and the Gang for a sales meeting held by Pitney Bowes, the computer company. He also landed Patti Lupone for a Fendi perfume introduction, and scheduled Liza Minnelli for a 1993 directors' meeting at a major Midwestern food manufacturer.
Unlike theatrical agents, who receive a percentage of entertainers' pay, Mr. Kravat charges a production fee for each event. This may include arranging lights, sound, housing and transportation -- as well as consulting with the client's top executives about the selection. "You have to match the artist to the event," he said. "You don't want the entertainment to be out of sync with the company's image."
Before signing up an act, Mr. Kravat considers several things. "I ask, 'Who is the audience? What is the message?' " he said. "You wouldn't have a rap group for a staid company, but it could be right on target for a hip, trendy company."
For example, Mr. Kravat booked Yakov Smirnoff, a regular on the talk-show circuit, to perform at a sales meeting of Sanofi Beauty Products Inc. in the spring.
"We have a new fragrance called Tsar," said Joseph R. Messina, Sanofi's vice president for creative services. "We liked the idea of making the connection between a Russian-inspired product and a Russian-born comedian."
And Mr. Smirnoff tailored his material to the cosmetics executives in the audience. "I'd better watch what I say around this group," he told them. "I can't use any dirty words, like Estee Lauder or Calvin Klein or Lancome."
Things don't always run smoothly. Mr. Kravat tells of booking a well-known cabaret singer to perform at the "21" Club for the New York sales representatives of a Texas electronics company. Hours before the event, the performer came down with laryngitis. Panicked, Mr. Kravat called Bobby Short and begged him to substitute. "We sent a limo over to get him at 8:30 and he went on at 9:00," he said. "It could have been a complete disaster if we didn't have a replacement."
Having replacements is one rule of thumb. So is knowing that certain performers are off limits -- regardless of the sponsor.
"If an act is offensive, or ostentatious, it isn't suitable for a business function," Mr. Kravat said. "You want people to enjoy themselves, but you don't want to take any risks."

HEADLINE: Decline in Fish Spurs Moves To Limit Catch

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

 BODY:
THE populations of several of the most popular species of edible fish have been so severely depleted that state and Federal agencies have begun to draft regulations to reduce the size of the catch for commercial and recreational fishermen off the New Jersey coast.
One such proposal would reduce the allowable catch of fluke and weakfish by more than half, starting next season. Also under consideration is a plan to place limits on fishing of bluefin tuna, mako and other open-sea sharks, sea bass, porgy and bluefish. 
 "Before the end of this decade, every fish species in New Jersey will have some kind of regulation on it," said Thomas P. Fote, president of the 25,000-member New Jersey Coast Anglers Association, a group of recreational fishermen.
With the exception of limits on the taking of surf clams, begun in the late 1970's, and limits on striped bass, begun in 1984, there has never been strict regulation on saltwater fishing off New Jersey.
But marine fisheries experts now say that fish populations probably will have to be subjected to the same conservation measures as land animals and birds have been since the turn of the century.
 
Agreement on Overall Need
 Commercial and recreational fishermen, while they do not all agree on the specific size and catch limitations, agree that there is a need for some regulation to preserve their livelihoods and pastimes.
In 1989, fishing was a $2.1 billion industry in New Jersey, according to the latest figures available from the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife.
Statistics provided by a Toms River office of the National Marine Fisheries Service showed that commercial fluke catches alone were generally between 4 million and 6.8 million pounds in New Jersey from 1980 to 1988. By last year, those catches had declined to 1.5 million pounds.
Bruce Freeman, a fisheries biologist and chief researcher for the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, said both recreational and commercial fishermen "are fishing to the extent that that we must reduce the allowable catches of fluke and weakfish by 70 percent and 53 percent respectively" in coming years "to protect the immature fish so they can breed once in their lifetimes."
Commercial and recreational regulations calling for new size, catch and season limits on these popular species have been proposed by the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council, a regional policy group that has jurisdiction of Federal waters 3 to 200 miles offshore, as well as state and interstate commissions that help regulate waters out to 3 miles.
 
Public Hearings Planned
 John C. Bryson, the executive director of the council, said in a telephone interview from Dover, Del., that the council's proposal called for a 25 percent to 50 percent reduction in the catch of weakfish and fluke, beginning next spring. Public hearings on the proposed regulations will be held in Cape May and in Wall Township on Tuesday at 7 P.M.
After the hearings, the fluke and weakfish management plan will be submitted by the council to the United States Department of Commerce. Once approved by the department, the plan and its regulations will be enforced as Federal law by special agents of the National Marine Fisheries Service and conservation officers of the State Department of Environmental Protection, who are also Federal deputies.
Mr. Freeman said compliance by commercial and recreational fishermen was mostly voluntary. But under the new regulations a spot-check of a vessel's dockside catch that revealed violations could result in a fine of up to $100,000, "a considerable incentive to obey the rules," Mr. Freeman said.
Mr. Bryson said, "And there is going to have to be a lot of give-and-take by the recreational and commercial people."
The fluke and weakfish regulations are viewed by experts as merely the beginning of a new wave of regulation that will be extended to species, large and small, to stave off the effects of overharvesting and, to a lesser extend, pollution of the estuaries where the marine species breed.
The National Marine Fisheries Service, the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife and their advisory groups, which are made up of recreational and commercial fishermen and scientists, are forming plans to regulate bluefin tuna, mako and other pelagic sharks, sea bass and porgy.
 
Bluefish in Trouble
 In addition, New Jersey has been the only state, Mr. Bryson said, that has not considered the council's 10-catch limit for recreational fishermen on bluefish, which was adopted in 1989. Breeding stocks of bluefish are in trouble along much of the East Coast, he said, and further regulation is being considered.
Axel B. Carlson Jr. of Manasquan, the chairman of the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council and an avid commercial and recreational fisherman since 1937, said he was concerned "about the future of fishing itself because I've seen it going downhill for sometime."
"There are more boats out there fishing in the ocean, both recreational and commercial," he said, "and they are bigger, better equipped with sophisticated electronics, nets and other new gear. After a while they could, indeed, catch that proverbial 'last fish.' "
Comparing the massive catches of fish in New Jersey to hunting in the Wild West, Bill Figley, a fisheries biologist with the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife at its Nacote Creek research station, said the spate of new regulations was a sign that "the last of the buffalo hunts are over."
Mr. Freeman and Mr. Bryson said state and Federal surveys showed that small fluke -- 1 to 2 years old -- were being caught in large numbers, thereby reducing the species' potential spawning stocks in the Middle Atlantic States to only 2 percent.
Mr. Freeman said a normal unfished population of fluke required a 20 percent spawning stock to maintain itself. This 20 percent, he said, is normally made up of a variety of year classes up to about 14 years old, with the average spawning fish about 7 or 8 years old.
 
Fluke Minimum Considered
 The council wants to establish a 12-inch minimum size for fluke caught by recreational fishermen and a limit of three fish a day per angler. Commercial fluke fishermen would be subjected to catch quotas for the first time and would be required to use only nets with a 5 1/2-inch mesh, permitting a maximum size of about 14 inches, Mr. Bryson said.
Weakfish would be limited to 10 fish per recreational angler and a maximum size of up to 14 inches and a 5 1/2-inch commercial mesh size would be established, according to some proposals.
Mr. Bryson acknowledged that New Jersey fishermen were adamant about placing regulations on large shrimping vessels in the Carolinas that have a significant incidental catch of small weakfish, which are sold as crab bait. Catching these small fish, New Jersey fishermen say, is one of the major causes for the depletion of the stocks along the East Coast.
"Everything we do here in New Jersey to protect weakfish will be fruitless if there is no size limit placed in the Carolinas," said Raymond Bogan of Point Pleasant, the legal counsel for the United Boatmen of New Jersey and New York, a group that has 320 party and charter boat owners and captains as members.
One of the owners in Point Pleasant Beach is Bob Bogan, a cousin of Raymond Bogan. Bob Bogan said in an interview at sea aboard his vessel, the Gambler, that if state and Federal agencies spent more time and money educating fishermen about dwindling fish populations, there would be less of a need for regulations, which, he said, are too stringent.
He said his clientele had decreased over several years because of a substantial increase in small, privately owned recreational boats.
According to the State Division of Motor Vehicles, there are 164,000 licensed recreational motorboats in New Jersey, excluding most large commercial boats, which are licensed by the Coast Guard.
 
'Fish Don't Have a Chance'
 Mr. Figley, of the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, said the smaller, privately owned recreational vessels had "very sophisticated and very expensive electronic gear like fish finders and radios, and it's devastating; fish don't have a chance."
Raymond Bogan said that because of the difficulties already being experienced by party boats, "the three-fish limit proposed for fluke is absolutely unacceptable to us and we plan to propose a limit of six fish at the hearings."
Commercial fishermen generally approve of the latest regulations "as long as they treat recreational and commercial guys the same," said Nils Stolpe, president of the New Jersey Commercial Fishermen's Association. He said he had seen no evidence that the Magnusson Fishery Conservation and Management Act, passed by Congress in 1976 to protect domestic fishermen from foreign fishing fleets, had done much to conserve fish populations over the years.
 
First Major Attempt
 The act was the nation's first major attempt to regulate coastal fishing. It established authority within the National Marine Fisheries Service and through interstate advisory commissions and councils to assess and set limits on fishing. It also established the Exclusive Economic Zone, known as the E.E.Z., the 200-mile territorial limit that keeps out the foreign vessels.
Mr. Stolpe said the law did "a wonderful job of keeping foreigners out of the E.E.Z., but I don't know of any fish population on the East Coast that's been improved because of it."
Others disagreed. Mr. Figley said the striped bass was the first species whose population had been restored because of the regulations put in place in 1984. Although even more needs to be done to continue to help the striped bass, he said, its success story has inspired many fishermen to be more open and receptive to management plans for other species.
"The buffalo-hunt mentality is slowing dying in New Jersey," Mr. Figley said, "and fishermen at least have begun to accept a new conservation ethic that will be needed if fishing is to survive at all."

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Called Unlikely Soon

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
A continued stalemate between the United States and Western Europe over agricultural subsidies is making the completion of a new global trade agreement increasingly unlikely this year, Administration officials and private trade experts say.
Indeed, the inability of negotiators to agree on new cuts in trade barriers could make it hard for the Bush Administration to win Congressional approval for an agreement before next year's elections. 
 At stake is the opportunity to set global rules for trade that could influence world economic growth into the next century. The question of how to approach agriculture in the talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has bedeviled American negotiators since the current round of negotiations began in Uruguay in 1986.
At the economic summit meeting in London last month, the leaders of the seven leading industrial nations pledged that they would personally try to insure the successful completion this year of the Uruguay Round of talks. But the round was scheduled to end last year, and the summit meeting last summer in Houston produced similar expressions of commitment to free trade without any real compromises.
Even the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, a longtime optimist, sounded a gloomy note at a news conference on Wednesday in Hungary. "I think that it is going to take four, five or six months after we see movement in agriculture to wind up the other 14 areas" of negotiations, Reuters quoted Mrs. Hills as saying.
"So it is possible, but probably not likely, that we would finish precisely on Dec. 31, but I think it is very, very important that we complete our discussion very, very soon thereafter," she added.
 
No New Agreements
 Mrs. Hills had just come from Brussels, where the day before she and Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan had met with their two European Community counterparts. The meeting produced no agreements on how to approach the community's domestic and export subsidies for agricultural products.
The United States and other leading grain exporters have sought the virtual elimination of these subsidies, saying they encourage excessive, inefficient and environmentally destructive production while depressing world prices.
But European countries, led by France, have opposed a reduction in subsidies because such a move could lead to demonstrations, contribute to rural unemployment and make the community's current agricultural policies even more expensive.
 
Paradoxical Effect
 The export subsidies have the paradoxical effect of limiting the cost of the community's agricultural programs. The subsidies allow food bought from farmers at high fixed prices to be resold for part of its current price instead of sitting in warehouses and not being sold at all.
Both the GATT negotiations themselves in Geneva and consultations within the European Community on a compromise position have now been put on hold during August, when many officials go on vacation.
The critical question for many years has been whether Germany is willing to put pressure on France to change its opposition to dropping the subsidies. Herman Otto Solms, the leader of the Free Democratic Party's deputies in the German Parliament, said on a visit to Washington last month that the German Government was moving in this direction.
But the Free Democratic Party is the minority partner in Germany's ruling coalition, and has a history of advocating free trade. Mr. Solms acknowledged that German influence in the community and in Paris might now be muted. "It is a very difficult situation because France is not very fond of the German unification process," he said.
European Community leaders are due to meet next month to review a plan to cut substantially the fixed prices offered to farmers and to encourage their early retirement. But some of the same leaders have been slow to act on less ambitious plans in recent years, so no immediate change in policy is expected.
Mrs. Hills said in a recent interview that she understood the community's political problems in dealing with the opposition to trade liberalization. But the evolution of Western European economies and the soaring cost of agricultural subsidies -- budgeted by the community at $37 billion this year -- means that such support for farmers has "served its day," she added. "It's obsolete; it's wrong now."
 
Potential Political ProbLem
 Delays by the European leaders are creating a potential political problem for the Administration. Before a final agreement can be submitted to Congress, accompanying legislation must be drafted to amend United States laws and Government programs that do not comply. Drafting this legislation is likely to take at least three months, Congressional experts estimate.
The "fast track" procedures for the consideration of such trade pacts then call for Congress to vote on the agreement within about four months. So even if an agreement were finished at the end of this year, a final vote would be unlikely until late next summer. Each month of delay in international negotiations pushes the vote another month closer to next year's elections.
Trade agreements tend to be controversial even outside of election years. Industries facing the loss of their protection from imports have a greater incentive to lobby than industries that may share hard-to-measure future gains from free trade.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Scanning the Sky Over Mexico's Parade

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
In struggling to see the future of the stock market in Mexico, investors abroad have faced an unusual quandry: not only has the market's trajectory been steadily upward, its pace has quickened. For those who turn to the closed-end funds that invest in Mexican stocks, their steady ascent raises questions about how long the dizzying growth can be sustained.
So far, there are few signs of a pause. After grabbing attention with its generally strong performances in 1988, 1989 and 1990, for example, the 10-year-old Mexico Fund, managed by a Mexico City investment firm, has jumped an additional 78 percent so far this year. And after sputtering debuts in the second half of last year, two New York-based funds that invest in Mexican stocks have hit stride. 
 The Emerging Mexico Fund, which includes some unlisted companies and second-tier stocks as well as some of the best-known plays on the Bolsa, as the Mexican market is called, has climbed 79.5 percent this year. At the end of June, it ranked fourth -- just above the Mexico Fund -- on the Miami investor Thomas J. Herzfeld's list of the top-performing country funds.
By comparison, the Mexico Equity and Income Fund has struggled, even though its 31.6 percent rise since January is hardly anemic. The fund had planned to invest about half its assets in convertible-debt securities, but after almost a year its managers have found only one issue they wanted to buy. Even now, 51 percent of its assets are invested in equities and 37 percent in bonds.
With all the good news, Mr. Herzfeld and other analysts have been hearing voices. "Everybody wants to know," he said, "'Where's the bad news?' "
But conversations with a dozen analysts and investors around the United States indicate there is relatively little bad news about Mexican stocks to be found.
"The fact that the local market was up 73 percent in dollar terms in the first six months of the year means that a lot of the good news is already in," acknowledged William Dinning, an investment strategist at Paine Webber Inc., the lead underwriter of the Emerging Mexico Fund. But Mr. Dinning and other analysts say that does not mean investors should now look elsewhere. Instead, the analysts say, investors should begin looking at Mexico differently.
"To go in at this point -- at least if you have a short-term perspective -- is not that attractive," said Antoine W. van Agtmael, president of Emerging Markets Management in Washington. "But for the long run, the Mexican market remains extremely attractive."
On the landscape of emerging markets, where some risks loom like mountains and others nestle in their shadows, concerns about Mexico have not disappeared.
The country's current account deficit has risen steadily, to a projected $7 billion this year from $1.7 billion in 1986. And even though the Government has continued its slow mini-devaluation of the peso, some economists still consider the currency overvalued.
Still, the developments that have sparked foreign interest in Mexico have not been merely frequent, analysts say, they have been fundamental.
As President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has sold off state companies and loosened restrictions on foreign investment, he has nearly closed the budget deficit, which not so long ago stood at 17 percent of gross national product. And inflation has been falling, down to 29.9 percent last year from 160 percent in 1987. This year the inflation rate is expected to slip below 20 percent.
While bankers have not forgotten about the roughly $80 billion that Mexico owes abroad, the debt has meant relatively little to investors since early last year, when Mexico became the first Latin debtor nation to embrace the Brady Plan, named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; the plan provides a framework for reducing and revamping a nation's debt in return for economic reforms by the debtor nation. And even more encouraging news has come this year from Washington, where Congress has voted to give the Bush Administration "fast track" authority to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico.
With foreign involvement already the principal engine in the $42 billion Mexican market, the attraction for investors "is the recognition that there is stability in Mexico," said Luis R. Luis, a Latin America analyst at Scudder, Stevens & Clark in Boston.
The stability has already drawn more conservative institutional investors like pension funds to both the closed-end funds and to Mexican blue-chip stocks like the state telephone company, Telefonos de Mexico, known as Telmex; Cemex, Mexico's leading cement company, and Kimberley-Clark de Mexico. But to some investors with longer experience in Mexico -- players who boast of having bought what are now nearly $4 shares of Telmex at less than one-tenth that price three years ago -- stabilization means the time has come to look elsewhere.
"The guys like me who were looking at Mexico five years ago are now looking at Argentina and Brazil," said Charles H. Brandes, a San Diego investment adviser.
And Douglas A. Campbell, an institutional broker in Los Angeles who has specialized in Mexico since 1986, said, "Let me assure you, the great gains in Mexico are behind us."
Whether Mexican equity funds remain good values is another matter.
Though all the Mexico funds are still discounted, with their prices below the values of their net assets, the discounts vary. The discount on the Mexico Fund, which several analysts pronounced unattractive at less than 5 percent, now stands at a more alluring 10 percent. The Emerging Mexico Fund is discounted by 13.2 percent, and the Equity and Income Fund by 13.56 percent.
Judging the stocks by the ratios of their prices to earnings prompts even more debate. At average prices of 15 or 16 times 1990 earnings, the market already looks expensive to some.
But other investors, who value the stocks at 11 to 13 times projected earnings, find the multiples seductive by comparison to those of emerging markets in Asia, where stocks routinely reach price-earnings ratios of 30 of more.
That can be a tricky comparison, however. Many investors who use it to label Mexican stocks cheap are betting on a continued strong rise in the market. They predict that the Mexican economy will jump from last year's 3.9 percent to an average of 6 percent during the 1990's, as the country's long-repressed consumers gain buying power. Some economists, however, consider such numbers optimistic, if not fanciful.
All of the investors and analysts interviewed expected some market correction down the road. Many considered current demand for the stocks to be inflated, with high turnover rates. (Jose Luis Gomez Pimienta, president of the Mexico Fund, said about 70 percent of the fund's shares had already traded hands this year.)
In the meantime, while one advantage of the closed-end funds rises and ebbs with the size of their discounts, another has seemed almost to disappear. When compared with markets in Brazil, Chile and Argentina, which foreign investors are hard pressed to play on their own, the Bolsa looks positively inviting. More foreign investors might be tempted to bypass the equity funds and invest in shares of specific Mexican companies.
With the opening of Mexico's economy, foreigners are allowed to purchase nonvoting stock directly and other stocks through trusts. Many blue-chip issues -- which, unlike the funds, consistently outperform the market as a whole -- are now offered through American depository receipts, which investors in the United States can buy through American stock exchanges.
In Mexico City, Mr. Pimienta argued that the diversification of his portfolio will provide some insurance if the market falls. But he acknowledged that not all his biggest clients seemed to care.
"I think some of the big players in the Mexico Fund are now going directly into Mexican stocks," he said.

HEADLINE: Acharnai Journal;
An Odyssey Ends With a Homecoming to Greece

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ACHARNAI, Greece

 BODY:
The sun is roasting the rugged slopes of Mount Parnes, driving families into the strips of shade next to their hot, new cement homes. From the sandy road, this looks like another fresh urban explosion north of Athens.
But telltale crates covered with Cyrillic writing sit in almost every yard. Ask the people who arrived with the crates where they traveled from and they give names of far-off Soviet cities in the Ukraine, Georgia and even Kazakhstan. Many have spent days riding by train from Central Asia or aboard freighters crossing the Black Sea. Yet no one is complaining. For the tens of thousands of newcomers, what matters most is that they have come home. 
 They are the Pontians, or ethnic Greeks of Eastern Europe, a people whose plight has attracted little attention over the nearly 70 years since many of them were forced to flee from Turkey to the Soviet Union and were then persecuted and resettled by Stalin. Now, feeling insecure and harassed by nationalists in several Soviet republics, many have once more had to start a new life.
Arriving at a rate of more than 1,000 a month, they have been able to move because Moscow has eased travel restrictions. The Greek Government says that of the Soviet Union's 500,000 ethnic Greeks, about 30,000 have arrived here in the last two years. Many more are expected.
 
'I've Come Home'
 "Yes, I've come home," exulted Dimitris Apatzides, displaying four gold-framed teeth and explaining that he was born in Kazakhstan, the place where Stalin sent his parents. There he had driven a farm tractor until his family decided they could no longer bear hostility against Greeks.
"The police, the neighbors kept telling us go back to your own country," he said. "Our women were afraid to go out after dark."
Pontians, though, are only some of the refugees pouring through mountain passes or landing in the harbors of Greece. Upheaval among the neighbors to the north, the Government says, has brought perhaps as many as 150,000 newcomers in the last two years.
Among them are about 50,000 immigrants who who came from Albania this year, close to half of them ethnic Greeks. As many as 8,000 Romanian gypsies, Government officials said, have moved into Greece's traditional gypsy camps. Thousands of Bulgarians and Poles have come as tourists or traders and have stayed to look for jobs. The police say undocumented travelers regularly arrive from Sri Lanka and Afghanistan.
"We are a door to the West and many people just see us as a first stop," said Vlassis Socratides, who leads an organization that helps returning Greek-Albanians. "Some want to stay but many want to go to America."
Nonetheless, the influx is causing controversy in this nation of 10 million people. By European standards, this country is sparsely populated and Greeks are rarely xenophobic. But they are used to seeing foreigners as tourists bringing money rather than as dependents or competitors.
Greeks still see their country as a disadvantaged nation that remains entitled to help and favorable treatment from richer European neighbors to the west. But while the treasury may be depleted because of past Government mismanagement, Greece looks enticing to its Balkan neighbors. This is a realm where cars and modern gadgets are as normal as a busy taverna, a land where one in three families owns a second home.
Several Socialist newspapers have therefore prodded Greeks to be generous and recalled that Greece itself until recently sent hundreds of migrant workers to northern Europe or to settle in North America. But critics have charged that the newcomers are aggravating unemployment, crime and health problems. The Government is seeking $2 billion in refugee aid from the European Community.
Generous or not, some Greeks have welcomed the new flow of cheap labor. An Athenian businessmen boasted that he had hired an Albanian gardener for half the going rate. "You pay a Greek cleaner $25 per day," said Eleni Floros, a shopkeeper. "We can now get Polish help for $18 and Albanian for $15."
 
'People Do Not Trust Us'
 One morning on Omonia Square, the busy heart of Athens and current labor market for refugees, clusters of Albanian men sat around, looking gloomy. Adriano Gjinis, a 26-year old farmhand from Argyrokastron in southern Albania said he had walked a day and a half to cross the border, slept outdoors, washed dishes and cleaned floors and gardens but could not land a steady job. "People do not trust us," he said, "and landlords think we cannot pay the rent."
Besides, there was nervousness around Omonia as word spread of new police roundups. This year, the police have deported more than 10,000 Albanians who have come without documents.
The Pontian Greeks have had a slightly warmer reception, even though a cultural divide exists. Pontians, by some accounts, take their name from their homeland, Pontus, the ancient kingdom on the south shore of the Black Sea. Many were forced into Greece in 1922 after Turkey's wars with the Greeks and Russians. Others fled to Russia, where they kept their religion, music and language, an archaic form of Greek.
"We are well -- we only wish we had electricity," said Sofia Kianzeva, who came from Sochume, Georgia, and brought her own prefabricated house because she could not bring rubles. Now unpacked, the modest wooden home stands in the new Pontian neighborhood on the slopes of Mount Parnes. It is full of Georgian beds and chairs to accommodate her four daughters, their husbands and her three grandchildren. Some fellow Pontians have had to sell their rugs and samovars in the Athens flea markets to make ends meet.
For its part, the Greek Government is working on new settlement plans. It has started sending groups of Pontians, most of whom are Greek Orthodox, to the northern province of Thrace. There they are to provide a balance for the Turkish Muslim minority. The Turkish Government has protested. Greece has replied that this is an internal affair.
