HEADLINE: Fearing Bad Harvest, Gorbachev Moves to Spur Imports of the Basics

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Concerned about the dearth of consumer goods as another worrisome harvest approaches, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued an executive order tonight restricting luxury imports and easing customs duties to spur imports of food, medicine and other badly needed basics.
In effect, the Soviet leader was testing his improving relations with the republics by attempting a device -- the executive order -- that was widely ignored a year ago when the economy plummeted and he was deep in a power-sharing fight with the republics. 
 In this new order, Mr. Gorbachev, who has been negotiating a new union treaty of closer relations with the republics, called on the republics and the central Government in the Kremlin to "haul the country's economy out of crisis" with a series of measures ranging from factory incentives to republic bartering, all directed at bracing the life of the battered Soviet consumer.
As the order was announced, the now familiar annual warning about "a real threat of famine" was being issued by Mr. Gorbachev's chief economic officer, First Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Shcherbakov, who implored the nation to pitch in and see that this year's grain harvest was a success.
 
Good Crop Last Year
 Similar invocations of famine fears a year ago by the Government proved unfounded as a bumper crop partly compensated for breakdowns in the delivery and storage system that allowed thousands of tons of produce to rot before it could be delivered to packing houses, mills and store shelves.
Soviet consumers scrambled through another demoralizing season of hunting and foraging for needed goods whose shortages were severe but somewhere short of a threat to life.
"There is no time for idle talk," Mr. Shcherbakov declared on television in what the Soviet public takes as a mid-summer pep talk as the grain waits for harvesting. "Everything has to be done to bring the harvest in."
The Bush Administration has had a team of technical specialists visiting the hinterlands in an attempt to recommend improvements for the badly outdated and overcentralized Soviet farm distribution and storage systems.
Mr. Gorbachev made no mention of this or of the broad technical advice pledged to the last month at the London summit meeting of the seven major free-market democracies.
 
Short-Range Help
 But instead of dealing with the longer-range plans for transition to a market economy, the Soviet leader focused on testing once more whether there was enough cooperation between the central Government and the republics to patch together special short-range help this year for the consumer.
On one level, Mr. Gorbachev's order is intended to offer a bit of consumer hope to the public as it awaits the deeper economic changes that President Gorbachev promised during the Group of Seven summit talks last month. The precise nature and timing of those plans, after six years of floundering reconstruction, have not been announced, but the public is bracing for the pains that they are likely to inflict.
The omnibus package of measures that Mr. Gorbachev cited in his order were all directed at consumer shortages, as were similar orders a year ago that proved ineffective. This time, the Soviet leader decreed that more raw materials should be channeled by the Government to consumer goods industries, and that the nation's scarce hard currency supplies would be devoted "first and foremost" to the basics: grain, medicines, building supplies and spare parts for household goods.
 
Extra Incentives
 No longer able to dictate economic life as his predecessors did, Mr. Gorbachev sought in his order to encourage the republics to offer extra profit incentives to farmers who do well with the harvest and to factories that lift consumer production.
He also authorized the auction of unfinished consumer factories to independent bidders, including foreign investors, in order to speed construction and increase consumer output.
The order included some general language urging the speeding up of the "denationalization" and "demonopoly" steps toward a market economy. But once again there was no precise definition of whether Mr. Gorbachev was moving wholeheartedly toward the idea of private property that critics stress is basic for market economics.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes;
Little Rock newspaper War May Be Heading for a Truce

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
WHEN the Gannett Company bought The Arkansas Gazette in Little Rock for $60 million in 1986, the popular wisdom within the industry was that Gannett would make short work of the rival Arkansas Democrat, which was smaller and locally owned.
But it has not turned out that way. 
 Indeed, speculation has begun to mount that Gannett might be considering a joint operating arrangement with The Democrat, in which the production, advertising and circulation operations would be merged, but the news operations would stay separate.
In a J.O.A., as the arrangements are known, both money-losing papers would be able to raise advertising and circulation rates and become profitable. Both now appear in the morning, but under such an arrangement one would likely be shifted to the less-desirable afternoon position.
Walter E. Hussman Jr., the owner and publisher of The Democrat, said he would enter a joint operating ar rangement with Gannett only if he became the senior partner, with the final say in all business affairs, including which paper moves to the afternoon.
"I won't do a J.O.A. if I can't control it," said Mr. Hussman, who makes up The Democrat's losses with profits from his cable televi sion systems and other businesses of his Wehco Media group. He added that he had not discussed the subject with Gannett.
The prospect of being a junior partner in a joint operating arrangement is something Gannett "would definitely not prefer," said Shiela Gibbons, a Gannett spokesman.
But if Gannett is to make a profit in Little Rock, that may be the only way. In 1986, The Gazette's circulation exceeded The Democrat's by 45,000 daily, and by 14,000 on Sunday, the Audit Bureau of Circulations reports.
Though circulation has grown at both papers, The Gazette's average weekday circulation of 134,000 is barely ahead of The Democrat's, at 132,000, and The Democrat outsells The Gazette 236,000 to 222,000 on Sunday, which is the most important day of the week for advertising.
And everyone agrees that The Democrat now has the greater share of advertising.
In a frantic effort to increase Sunday sales last year, The Gazette offered home delivery on Sunday for $6.50 a year, or 12.5 cents a Sunday. The Democrat of fers free classified ads to readers selling baby car riages, cars and such. The Gazette followed suit. But none of it worked very well.
In May, Gannett brought Moe Hick ey, a former pub lisher of The De troit News, out of retirement to run The Gazette. Mr. Hickey stopped giving away clas sifed ads, raised the price of the Sunday paper, and said he was "taking the long hard road back to selling advertising for what it's worth."
Such moves could reduce what analysts estimate is a $5 million annual deficit at The Gazette, but it could also open the door for The Democrat to widen its lead.
In Detroit, Mr. Hickey helped guide The News to a J.O.A. with The Free Press, and his experience in that regard has not gone unnoticed in Little Rock. He declined comment on the prospects of a J.O.A. there.
 
A Glut of Newsprint
 In a newspaper landscape nearly barren of advertising and rife with competitors, there is one sweet spring of relief: the low, low price of newsprint. If the newspaper publishing business is bad, the newsprint business is terrible -- at least for the manufacturers.
"This may be the worst time since World War II," said George B. Adler, a forest-products analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
In January, many newsprint producers tried to raise the price to $710 a metric ton, but had to roll back the official price to $685. And the decline in advertising combined with a glut of newsprint has prompted further discounts of up to 23 percent.
As a result, newsprint is selling below what it cost in 1987. Indeed, with the inflation factor removed, newsprint is trading at levels equivalent to those before 1970. Mr. Adler said that prices could go even lower.
For newspapers, especially the big chains that can buy in great volume, such prices offer the windfall of a decline in one of their larger annual costs. For instance, John Morton, an newspaper analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, said 17.1 percent of Knight-Ridder Inc.'s total operating expense in 1990 was spent on newsprint, compared with 19.3 percent in 1989. With advertising down, he said, Knight-Ridder will need less newsprint this year, and it will cost even less because demand is so slack.
Newsprint companies are in a terrible bind. When newsprint demand was at its peak in the late 1980's, the companies committed millions of dollars to build new mills that would increase production. But demand has declined steadly since 1989. The American Newspaper Publishers Association reported that newsprint consumption in the United States dropped more than 8 percent for the first four months of this year, compared with 1990 levels.
 
Furloughs vs. Layoffs
 The Philadelphia Inquirer and Newsday have started offering voluntary unpaid leaves as a way to cut labor costs without layoffs.
At both newspapers, the programs have been available only to employees not covered by labor contracts that included specific manning levels, like those for pressmen. In general, the programs have been limited to news, advertising, clerical and other employees whose absence would not require overtime or a replacement.
"It's a hell of a lot better than layoffs," said James M. Naughton, managing editor of The Inquirer, which is owned by Knight-Ridder Inc..
Early this year, The Inquirer and its sister publication, The Philadelphia Daily News, notified the 1,500 eligible employees that they could take up to six months of unpaid leave. They would not be guaranteed of receiving the same jobs upon their return, but they would retain such benefits as insurance during the leave.
"You don't need to have a good cause, so long as we can afford to let you go," Mr. Naughton said, describing the paper's policy. Thus far, about 34 employees have taken advantage of the offer, which is ongoing.
Newsday, which is owned by the Times Mirror Company, has offered unpaid leaves of up to three months to about 2,900 of its 3,900 employees at both its Long Island and New York City operations, provided they get the approval of their supervisors.
Newsday is also allowing employees to extend their weekends this summer by taking Fridays and Mondays off, without pay of course.
Chiara Coletti, a Newsday spokesman, said 111 employees have exercised the option, including 30 from the news staff, who have tended to take extended leaves.
Advertising employees, she said, favored the long weekend.

HEADLINE: Strike Aims to Bleed Cameroon's Economy to Force President's Fall

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: DOUALA, Cameroon

 BODY:
The shuttered boutiques along Douala's broad boulevards and the empty berths of its port seem poised for a long holiday.
There are no taxis and few cars in the streets. Except for small clusters of people trudging along the roadside in the blistering sun, little stirs. 
 The commercial life of this once-thriving city has largely stopped since an anti-Government coalition called a general strike in late June. Opposition leaders talk of Douala as a "ghost city," and of this Central African nation of 11 million people as a "dead country."
The aim of the strikers is to bleed the economy slowly, and to keep the Government of Paul Biya, Cameroon's President for the last nine years, off balance. The opposition seems to sense some vulnerability in the Government and is hoping to bring about a change.
"What we aim to do is to bring down Biya," said Alexander Taku, a spokesman for a coalition of 24 political parties. Most of the parties gained legal status only within the last six months.
"Our strategy has been to make it impossible for the Government to pay the salaries of the civil servants," said Mr. Taku, an American-trained political scientist, noting that the Government was losing revenue from the closings of shops and other businesses.
Opposition leaders say they will not end the strike unless Mr. Biya convenes a national conference of political groups at which accusations of abuses under Mr. Biya's autocratic rule would be aired. Mr. Biya has repeatedly rejected calls for such a conference.
What makes the opposition's quest for change so hard-hitting is that this port is a conduit not only for Cameroon, but for the trade of landlocked countries like Chad and the Central African Republic.
While the strike in Cameroon is ambitious, it has its accommodating side. The clampdown on business activity extends from Monday to Friday, with weekends set aside to allow people to shop and run errands.
 
Only the Capital Is Spared
 "There are a lot of people suffering, but no one's starving because of the strike -- at least not yet," an African diplomat here said. So far, only Yaounde, Cameroon's capital and administrative center, and the region surrounding it have been spared the effects of the strike. Diplomats say at least seven of Cameroon's 10 provinces have been effectively shut down.
James Onibiono, an entrepreneur in Douala who is also a member of the ruling party's Central Committee, said, "I had expected the strike would last for one or two days and maybe stop, but there seems to be no limit to it."
One reason the strike has been so effective, Mr. Onibiono and other business leaders say, is that protesters seem to have targeted prominent enterprises. Mr. Onibiono's eight-story headquarters has been attacked twice and extensively damaged since the strike began.
"Instead of attacking the leaders of the ruling party," Mr. Onibiono complained, the opposition "is attacking everybody."
Abodel Karimou, editor in chief of The Gazette, a weekly newspaper in Douala, said that while there is scattered support for the strike, "most people are simply afraid," and are staying away from their jobs because of the threat of retribution.
Opposition leaders say the Government has been brutal in quelling peaceful protests, with at least 40 people killed in demonstrations in recent months. Government officials say that figure is highly inflated.
Cameroon is one of several African countries -- ranging from Mauritania, Mali and the Ivory Coast to Zaire and Tanzania -- where opposition movements have challenged single-party or military regimes since the beginning of the year.
Mr. Biya has generally been cautious in yielding to any demands for greater political freedom. But he has retreated in recent months from his once-adamant opposition to multiparty politics.
In April he announced that legislative elections would be held before the end of the year and that a new prime minister would be appointed. He also promised to call a special session of the National Assembly to draft revisions in the Constitution and a new election code, and pledged an amnesty for political prisoners.
The opposition gives Mr. Biya little credit for those developments, saying that he acted out of political necessity.
But some citizens express apprehension about the tactics of the opposition leaders. "It's one thing to want to get rid of Biya," said a schoolteacher here, "but it doesn't make sense to ruin the economy in trying to do so."
During the first half of the 1980's, oil brought Cameroon an average annual growth rate of 7 percent, the highest on the continent. Oil also brought skyscrapers to this muggy port, a fast rail link inland to Yaounde, and, for the first time, television.
Cameroon became black Africa's No. 3 oil exporter, after Nigeria and Angola. But the boom years ended abruptly in 1986. As world prices for major export commodities like oil, cocoa, coffee and cotton tumbled, export earnings were halved.
Mr. Biya has taken tentative steps to resuscitate the economy in recent months, including cuts in the salaries and benefits of civil servants to reduce Government spending.
Government officials say they plan to announce other austerity measures recommended by the International Monetary Fund. But the general strike has offset any gains expected from the economic program.
"In the short term, the opposition has got the upper hand, and Biya seems on his way out," a student of Cameroon politics said. "In the long run, though, we're sinking further and further into economic chaos."

HEADLINE: Japan May Delay Buying U.S. Military Planes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 4

 BODY:
In what may be the start of a new dispute between Tokyo and Washington over military technology, Japanese officials say they may be forced to delay or cancel plans to buy a fleet of American-made surveillance aircraft.
The purchase of the Airborne Early Warning and Control System, or Awacs, planes has drawn considerable political attention on Capitol Hill -- for reasons of trade as much as national security. Earlier this year, 70 Representatives and Senators pressed the Bush Administration to get Japan to buy a large fleet of the aircraft, which would cost billions of dollars. 
 In the past, Japan has said it was willing to buy four planes in a package estimated at about $1 billion. But they now say the price of the aircraft has soared because the Boeing Company has begun to close its Awacs production line in the absence of new orders.
 
Underlying Political Issues
 "It now looks as if it will cost far, far more than anyone expected," a senior official of Japan's Defense Agency said last week, after several newspapers here reported that the plans would be delayed or shelved. "So we are reconsidering the whole program."
An American official familiar with the negotiations said it was "now 50-50" whether Japan would buy the four planes.
While Japanese officials are trying to discuss the Awacs purchase in purely economic terms, some political issues underlie the debate.
The aircraft are a crucial element in American plans to get Japan to assume a greater responsibility for patrolling its air space and sea lanes. But there is some question about how quickly Japan plans to fulfill its commitment to patrol sea lanes up to 1,000 miles from its borders.
So far, the country's ability to project power beyond its shores has been sharply limited by interpretations of its Constitution, which was written by the United States and was intended to check the kind of expansionism that led Japan into World War II. Those same interpretations have meant that Japan has no aircraft carriers or bombers; both are considered offensive weapons.
 
Bitterness Lingers Over FSX
 In 1981, the Japanese Government committed itself to defending its surrounding sea and air lanes, and the Defense Agency used that as the basis for a huge increase in the Japanese military budget. Now Japan's self-defense role is made more urgent by the reduction of the United States military presence in Japan, South Korea and the Philippines.
Some Japanese, however, have urged a slower pace, saying that the delicate issue of Japanese military power is getting increasing attention in Asia from the continuing discussions in Parliament over whether the Japanese military can -- or should -- participate in international peace-keeping forces.
The Awacs purchase is also being discussed just as the Bush Administration and the Japanese Government are trying to move past the bitterness generated by the last big Japanese acquisition of military aircraft technology from the United States. Two years ago, plans to license Japan to build the FSX, a new fighter plan based on the F-16, touched off months of arguments in Congress over whether America was "giving away" critical technology that Japan would later turn to commercial purposes.
After President Bush interceded, an agreement was worked out that gave a larger role in the production of the aircraft to the General Dynamics Corporation, the maker of the F-16. But over the last two years the cost of the FSX has doubled, in part because the Japanese must themselves develop crucial components that the United States refused to transfer.
The Awacs, however, is a different kind of deal. Unlike the FSX, the Awacs would be imported from the United States, not made in Japan. In the past, the Japanese have ordered no Awacs, though they do fly 13 of the E2-C Hawkeye short-range radar aircraft made by the Grumman Corporation.
 
Congressional Pressure
 In a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d earlier this year, members of Congress insisted that to cover "the vast area Japan has agreed to defend requires betwen 12 and 14 Awacs planes and at least 20 tankers."
That figure, however, appeared rooted more in trade considerations than in security concerns. "What we have been talking about is four -- no more," said a Japanese official.
Now, even those four are imperiled. Boeing is delivering the last of its Awacs orders, to Britain. Although there has been talk of additional purchases by the United States and Saudi Arabia, there have been no new orders in years. Boeing says it has begun to pack away equipment and gradually close its production line. As a result, the price of restarting the line to build the Japanese aircraft has increased greatly.
 
Japanese Budget Deadline Near
 Over the last two weeks, as Japan's end-of-August budget deadlines near, there have been frantic efforts to save the project, including attempts to get Boeing to lower the price.
"We think we could solve it if the Americans and the Saudis also ordered planes," the Japanese official involved in the controversy said.
One option would be to delay the purchase, but that might result in making the warning aircraft even more expensive later on. Another would be to buy a stripped-down version of the Awacs, or to find another surveillance aircraft. But none of the others are as capable as the Awacs, Japanese officials say.
The final decision seems likely to be made by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and his Cabinet. In the past, Mr. Kaifu has been inclined to give in eventually to American pressure, even at considerable economic cost to Japan, as he did when Japan contributed $13 billion to the Persian Gulf war effort.
But with growing impatience here over American trade demands, and an election for the leadership of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party approaching, Mr. Kaifu's intervention on behalf of American aircraft makers may be subdued.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

The Economy
Bank loans for real estate projects are likely to be restricted again, a number of senators and the head of the nation's bank insurance fund say. The curbs, which were lifted in 1982, would be added even as real estate values continue to decline, more banks totter near insolvency and developers face bankruptcy. [Page D1.] 
 The military industry has begun an environmental cleanup that may well become one of the biggest engineering projects ever undertaken. But some Federal managers say the program could well result in one of history's costliest failures. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Cabinet Backs Shamir on Peace Talks

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Cabinet gave resounding approval today to his conditional agreement to attend a Middle East peace conference under American and Soviet auspices.
Sixteen Cabinet ministers backed the the agreement that the Prime Minister reached on Thursday with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, but three ministers led by Housing Minister Ariel Sharon voted against Mr. Shamir. 
 The Israeli radio reported that the four-hour session was marked by personal argument between the Prime Minister and Mr. Sharon, both members of the Likud party. The hard-line Housing Minister accused his leader of having "fixed" the outcome with Mr. Baker before they met. Mr. Shamir responded by charging his rival with being motivated by lust for power.
 
Sharon Sees 'Big Lie'
 Interviewed after the session, Mr. Sharon denounced the Government for placing trust in an apparent change of heart by President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, who in his meeting with Mr. Baker reversed Syria's rigid stand against negotiations with Israel.
He called Mr. Assad a "tyrant like Saddam Hussein" and termed his assent to the conference "a big lie."
Science Minister Yuval Neeman and Minister Without Portfolio Rehavam Zeevi, who represent small parties that reject any compromise with the Arabs living in the occupied territories, also voted against the Prime Minister.
In giving his approval to Mr. Baker, Mr. Shamir said Israel would attend only if the Palestinian representatives at the conference were not members of the Palestine Liberation Organization or residents of East Jerusalem, which Israel has annexed. When they met with Mr. Baker on Friday, Palestinian leaders made participation contingent on American guarantees that would in effect nullify Israel's restrictions.
 
P.L.O. Believed Ready
 Despite this apparently irreconcilable difference, Palestinians interviewed today in East Jerusalem expressed a belief that the P.L.O. had decided to accept a formula discussed with the United States that would permit Palestinian participation.
[In Tunis, a spokesman for the P.L.O. said that the Palestinians were "ready to attend" the session and that no obstacle was "big enough" to keep them away.]
"The Palestinians have to choose between another Camp David or trying to improve the conditions while accepting the present peace process," said Radwan Abu Ayyash, a journalist considered a possible representative for the Palestinians at negotiations. "I think they have chosen the second option."
Mr. Assad's agreement to take part in the peace process without exacting a solution to the Palestinian question has awakened angry memories of what the Palestinians view as their betrayal by President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt. In 1978, he concluded a separate peace with Israel at the American Presidential retreat at Camp David.
Mr. Abu Ayyash, speaking in the office of his Arab Media Center, said that he believed that the people of the occupied territories placed little faith in the possibility of a positive outcome, but that intellectuals believed that Palestinians could not afford not to take part.
The Palestinians said the P.L.O. leadership would adhere to its position that no one could interfere in its independent right to choose its conference delegates. But without directly conceding the point, the Palestinians conveyed the view that the P.L.O. would not choose representatives who would fall under Israel's veto. They made clear, however, that such a compromise must not be construed as a concession to Israel's claim that its annexation of East Jerusalem is irreversible.
"To give up on Jerusalem would be not only a national sin but a religious, historical and spiritual sin," Mr. Abu Ayyash said. "Jerusalem is a rose that everybody has a right to smell, but nobody can pick it for himself."
On Friday, after three Palestinian leaders spent four hours in difficult discussions with Mr. Baker, they and other Palestinians in East Jerusalem concentrated their arguments on their right to choose their representatives. Today, , they appeared to shelve that issue, focusing their discussions on a demand that Israeli settlement in the occupied territories must stop no later than the beginning of a peace conference, which is sought for October.
"They rob the land under my feet," said Hanna Siniora, editor of the newspaper Al Fajr, who is considered a spokesman for moderate nationalists.
Mr. Siniora, who just returned from a visit to the United States, said a halt to settlement was more vital than the issue of who represented the Palestinians. "If this is not provided, there is no use going to the conference table," he said. "The Israelis will continue to delay until in 10 years there is nothing left to negotiate about."
The leaders interviewed expressed pessimism on the outcome of negotiations because, they said, they were facing not only Israeli intransigence but also a lack of support from Arab nations. They spoke critically of Mr. Assad's agreement to meet with Israel without exacting conditions favorable to the Palestinian cause as a price.
The Palestinians acknowledged that the P.L.O.'s support for Iraq in the Persian Gulf war was the critical factor in its lowered standing and placed a low ceiling on their expectations from the peace process. But only Mr. Siniora went so far as to call the organization's stand a "big mistake."
Prof. Saeb Erakat, a political scientist at An Najah University in Nablus and a participant in earlier talks with Mr. Baker, said, "We may not have the power to get the solution that we want, but we have the power to prevent a solution that we don't want."
Professor Erakat hinted at an increase in violence resulting from Palestinian frustration. Speaking of what he called Mr. Shamir's "economic war" against the Arabs of the occupied territories, he said: "He thinks Palestinians will carry their bags and leave. Actually, in such a war, if you had a knife factory, you might as well build another branch."
Violence against the Palestinian leaders taking part in the negotiations with the United States was threatened by the Islamic Holy War organization in the Gaza Strip in a leaflet distributed today on Gaza's streets. They threatened Faisal al-Husseini, who led the negotiators with Mr. Baker, and his colleagues, Hanan Ashrawi and Zakaria al-Agha, with assassination.
Mr. Abu Ayyash said the threat must be taken seriously. Islamic Holy War is regarded as responsible for much violence against Arab moderates or those suspected of collaboration with Israel.

HEADLINE: Japan's New Finance Official Plots an Independent Course

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 4

 BODY:
When Tadao Chino won a scholarship to study economics at Stanford University during Japan's dark postwar years, he leapt at the chance. "The United States was the model of success that Japan had to learn from," he recalled.
Now Mr. Chino, who is 57 years old, takes a far different view of the country he once idolized. He is the newly appointed Vice Minister of Finance for international affairs, which makes him the top financial policy maker for the world's largest creditor nation, and he promises to chart a course that is defiantly independent from the United States. 
 In an interview last week in his large, sparsely furnished office, Mr. Chino indicated that Japan would become even more assertive in pushing its financial objectives, whether in the World Bank, among the Group of Seven industrial democracies or in trade negotiations with the United States.
Mr. Chino, a genial yet cautious man who is 57 years old, is at the head of a generation of Japanese that has reshaped Japan's international financial policy, much as the Ministry of International Trade and Industry developed and implemented Japan's now-famous industrial strategy.
These financial experts seek to insure that the tens of billions of dollars in capital Japan sends abroad every year -- to buy everything from United States Treasury bonds to Hollywood movie studios -- contribute to the Government's policy goals and strengthen Japan's economy.
In perhaps his most significant comment, Mr. Chino said Japan wanted to transform its substantial foreign aid into a magnet for private capital. Japan will increasingly use its aid, he said, as seed money to attract Japanese manufacturers or other industrial concerns with an attractive investment environment.
 
Ambitious Program
 It is an ambitious program that could encourage more developing countries to adopt economic policies similar to Japan's, in which the Government works closely with industry to increase exports under the aegis of large corporate groupings.
"This represents new thinking," said Mr. Chino. "We are fully committed to this change."
In the interview, Mr. Chino outlined a range of other issues on which Japan intended to exert its considerable financial influence, among them the following:
*He insisted that the keiretsu, Japan's groupings of industrial companies, had many positive features and that Japan was unlikely to bend to American demands that they be changed. Mr. Chino disputed assertions by United States trade negotiators that the keiretsu exclude foreign competition and engage in unfair practices.
*He said he would fight the United States' policy of forgiving some of the debt of friendly countries, like Poland and Egypt. "This is quite an aggravation," he said. "I intend to be stubborn on this, which I think will be-
 *He said he would fight the United States' policy of forgiving some of the debt of friendly countries, like Poland and Egypt. "This is quite an aggravation," he said. "I intend to be stubborn on this, which I think will become a major historical point."
*He said the Soviet Union would receive no financial aid from Japan until it clarified the relationship between the central Government and the republics, reformed its economy, returned a group of northern islands seized from Japan in the waning days of World War II, and reduced its military presence in Asia. Until those conditions are met, he said, Japan will offer only technical advice.
*He said that while Japan would contribute aid to Eastern Europe, it was more interested in Asian countries. Japanese companies have established dominant positions in East Asia, turning the region into a low-cost manufacturing base that is an integral part of Japan's industrial strategy.
In the Japanese system, the Finance Minister is a political appointee who tends to address immediate issues and problems, like legislation, strategies in trade negotiations and responses to crises like the war in the Persian Gulf.
The vice minister, the highest career post in the ministry, tends to be more intimately involved in shaping long-range policy and putting it into effect. After 31 years at the Finance Ministry in various posts in which he helped formulate international policy and fleshed out strategies, Mr. Chino can now put his personal stamp on Japan's financial course.
 
Strong-Willed Predecessor
 Though direct in expressing his views, Mr. Chino is in some ways regarded as less independent than his strong-willed predecessor, Makoto Utsumi. Mr. Utsumi was an urbane, French-speaking bureaucrat with an un-Japanese gift for sharp-tongued repartee. He also did not hesitate to overrule his staff when he felt strongly or to demonstrate flexibility in negotiations, both rare traits in Japan.
By contrast, Mr. Chino is known as more of a traditional consensus-builder. He is said by Finance Ministry officials and others who know him to be steady and cautious, but less inclined to improvise.
Mr. Chino's policies could have a big impact on Japan's role in the world, enhancing its commercial influence while encouraging developing countries to adopt Japan's system of industrial development through a close partnership of government and the private sector.
 
Impact of Policy Change
 Although it may take years to see the changes, Mr. Chino's aim of using Japan's aid to attract private investment could both increase the competitiveness of Japanese industry and extend Japan's influence abroad. Japan's trade surplus is soaring this year after shrinking for three years, which should lift Japan's already high level of foreign investment. That capital will be in strong demand in a world that is starved for funds.
Japan's huge capital outflows are a loose end that the Finance Ministry wants to tie and channel more carefully. That means that countries whose policies Japan prefers stand to gain not just from government-to-government assistance, but from billions of dollars in investment from Japan's industrial groups in the form of real estate developments, manufacturing plants and large purchases of stocks and bonds.
"The purpose of recycling is to stimulate and assist private capital flows," Mr. Chino said, referring to the process of Japan's investing its huge trade surpluses abroad. This is one reason Mr. Chino said he felt so strongly that the United States' policy on debt forgiveness for developing countries was misguided.
"If you let countries avoid paying their debts, that will damage their credibility in the financial markets and make it difficult to attract private capital," he said. He added that forgiveness also tended to discourage countries that shoulder their debt burdens, and pushes them to seek debt forgiveness rather than financial discipline.
"That kind of forgiveness is a serious moral hazard for those who are being responsible," Mr. Chino said.
 
Seeking Less Regulation
 In one area at least, Mr. Chino advocated less change rather than more. In Japan's current stock market scandal, there have been demands that the Finance Ministry end its paternalistic system of regulating the financial markets. Instead, some are pushing for an independent agency, similar to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Mr. Chino was polite but firm in rejecting this notion. He argued for a policy change away from Government efforts to build the financial markets at all costs and toward making the markets more equitable and open, particularly to foreigners.
But he said people should not forget Japan's special history and the fact that the current system has worked well for most of the postwar era. It all came down, he said, to whether Japan wanted a market like the United States', where it is easy to get into the securities business but where there are many regulators, or one that is difficult to enter but where regulators cooperate with brokerage houses to keep order.
"I don't like a society that requires so many people to watch everything," Mr. Chino said. "I like a more cooperative society with a smaller number of regulators."

(Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Curb On Banks Expected

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Restrictions on bank loans for real estate projects, which were removed in 1982, are likely to be reimposed, a number of senators and the head of the nation's bank insurance fund say. The curbs would be added even as commercial real estate values continue to decline, more banks totter near insolvency and once-wealthy developers face bankruptcy.
Members of the Senate Banking Committee decided on Friday to give regulators nine more months to devise new restrictions on real estate lending, after which Congress is likely to be asked to put the rules into law. The House had already passed similar legislation. 
In a little-noticed amendment to the banking-overhaul bill that was approved on Friday by the Senate Banking Committee, Senator Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, proposed reimposing the strict loan-to-value lending rules that were lifted when the Garn-St Germain Act was passed in 1982, deregulating banks.
 
Wirth-Garn Compromise
 On Friday, Senator Wirth and Senator Jake Garn of Utah, the ranking Republican on the committee, struck the compromise that grants Government regulators the nine months to come up with the new restrictions on real estate lending by banks. Congress then began its summer recess, leaving the Senate vote on the bank-overhaul bill until after the lawmakers return in the fall.
The restrictions in Senator Wirth's amendment will likely become part of the law if interagency regulators from the Comptroller of the Currency's office, as well as from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Treasury Department, are unable to agree on new lending guidelines within the nine months.
The Wirth amendment dictates that bank loans backed by commercial real estate cannot exceed 80 percent of the value of that real estate. In instances where the commercial property backing the loan is only partly developed, the lending limit would be 70 percent. For undeveloped land, the loan limit would be 65 percent of the appraised value.
 
Bar to Repeating Mistakes
 Some banking executives and members of Congress, and L. William Seidman, who is chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, say that adopting many of the previous regulations, perhaps with some refinements, will help prevent banks from repeating the lending mistakes they made in the 1980's.
The restrictions are also intended to force developers to contribute more of their own money to projects that are mostly financed by insured bank funds, thereby making the developers take more of the risk from their projects.
Yet the White House and many top legislators and regulators -- as well as most bankers -- oppose reviving the strict regulations on real estate lending, saying it is akin to locking the barn door after the horses have escaped. Rather, they say, what is needed is more intense and consistent oversight by regulators.
In 1982, the Garn-St Germain Act lifted the restrictions that limited what percentage of a real estate project's value banks could lend against and on what kinds of property they could lend. Now many people say that this deregulatory step gave the banks a freedom that worsened the lending mistakes they were making with real estate clients.
In the late 1980's, banks often lent developers 100 percent of their acquisition and construction costs, plus additional amounts for developer fees. Restrictions on loans for undeveloped land were lifted, as were provisions governing how much money developers were required to contribute to projects.
 
'Big Fees Up Front'
 As property values soared, this kind of lending often paid off handsomely. "The banks got caught up in a booming market," said Cheryl Swaim, a banking analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, a Wall Street brokerage. "Commercial real estate loans, when they work, are very profitable, because you get big fees up front and you get higher interest rates on them than on other commercial loans."
With the recession and the recent decline of property values, many real estate projects are now insolvent, with little prospect of finding buyers or lenders willing to refinance their mortgages.
If Congress restores the lending restrictions, the effects would probably not be immediately noticeable, real estate executives said. Banks have already sharply reduced their lending for commercial and residential property development, and tighter restrictions on loan amounts would hardly affect lending patterns. Eventually, however, the rules would probably reduce the flow of bank funds to property development, and because of this, real estate industry representatives are expected to lobby against new restrictions.
 
Strict Regulations Backed
 Mr. Seidman said recently that the bulk of loans that got most major banks in deep trouble were exactly the kind of construction and development loans that had been prohibited before deregulation. He is an advocate of reimposing the regulations because he says bank examiners have trouble enforcing regulatory guidelines that are not ironclad.
"We looked at Firstrepublic Bank, the largest loss to the Government ever in Texas, and of the roughly 77 loans that broke the bank, 75 of them would have been illegal prior to 1982," Mr. Seidman said. "That is true for almost all of the big banks, and it was certainly true in the Bank of New England."
The failure of Firstrepublic is expected to cost the Government at least $2.9 billion, and the rescue of the Bank of New England is seen costing at least $2.5 billion.
 
Separate Units Opposed
 John G. Medlin Jr., chairman and chief executive of the First Wachovia Bank, which is based in Winston-Salem, N.C., said he favored reimposing the restrictions as an alternative to forcing banks to separate into core bank units allowed to make a few kinds of loans and other units that do not use insured funds to do the most risky commercial lending.
If the rules are put in place, banks would still be able to use insured deposits to make real estate loans. "I'd prefer to have some of these restrictions rather than go to the sort of core-bank changes that are now being talked about," Mr. Medlin said.
Robert C. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency and the nation's chief bank regulator, contends that regulatory guidelines are needed for the future but said he did not want Congress to set restrictions because regulators would lose all flexibility.
"The kinds of things that we are thinking about are the loan-to-value ratios that would apply, the circumstances under which you make these loans, construction loans without permanent financing in place and raw-land development loans," Mr. Clarke said.
His office, with the Treasury and the F.D.I.C., has formed a group to put together new lending guidelines.
In their competitive dash to capture fat fees and high interest rates in the 1980's, many banks continually lowered their standards, failed to perform standard reviews of the financial condition of their borrowers and often simply lent hundreds of millions based on project studies and cash-flow projections that later proved to be extremely optimistic. Many risky construction loans were made with no provisions for how they would be refinanced.
Now, with scores of developers seeking to renegotiate their huge debts, it has become clear to what extent many banks lent large amounts of money with only cursory reviews.
"The belief that the borrower had a lot of equity made the banks somewhat lax," said a top executive at one of the nation's biggest banks who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "If you think you have a customer with a $300 million net worth and he has some accounting problems, you might not let that worry you because you figure it's a problem of a couple of million dollars at best. The big thing that people missed was not understanding the volatility of real estate values."
 
No Thorough Kalikow Audit
 In the case of Peter S. Kalikow, the New York City developer who is trying to revise the terms of more than $1 billion in debt, some banks lent him hundreds of millions of dollars for specific projects, but never performed a thorough audit of his financial records and those of his company, H. J. Kalikow & Company.
According to a preliminary report recently prepared by Ernst & Young, the accounting firm hired by the Kalikow lenders, H. J. Kalikow has no accounts-payable system in place; maintains one bank account for several projects and commingles tens of millions of dollars borrowed for completely unrelated projects; has not yet designed an annual budget for its operating companies; does not regularly reconcile intercompany financial reports; holds cashed checks in various places and has a scant record of checks, and has not yet closed the general ledger for the fiscal year ended December 1990.
And in the widely watched renegotiation of Donald J. Trump's debt and the revamping of his empire, it became clear that none of the banks that lent him a total of about $2 billion had ever audited him. Instead, those lenders often based their loans on Mr. Trump's own appraised value of his buildings.
 
Rise in Aggressive Competition
 What led the banks to do business in this fashion? One major change that made lending much more competitive in the 1980's was that deregulation brought into commercial real estate lending thousands of savings and loan institutions, which began to aggressively chase developers with cheap, Government-insured funds.
That, in turn, contributed to the savings industry debacle. In addition to the saving and loans, banks had to compete with insurance companies, which also moved to capture more real estate lending and now have their own problems with many of these loans, and foreign banks, which were increasing their presence in the United States.
A confluence of all these factors, plus the deregulation of interest rates, caused banks to pursue real estate lending aggressively and also to lose sight of fundamental underwriting standards.

HEADLINE: 3d Sales-Tax Budget Is Voted in Hartford; Shutdown Is Averted

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The General Assembly moved to end Connecticut's five-week-old fiscal crisis tonight by adopting, for the third time, a budget based on an expanded sales tax, ending yet another attempt by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. to win an income tax.
With a shutdown of state government threatened if a temporary spending measure expired at midnight without a budget in place, the House of Representatives gave final approval to the sales-tax plan in a 77-to-70 vote at 11:25 P.M. 
 Fifteen minutes later, Governor Weicker said he would not close down state services but would study the Legislature's budget carefully this week before deciding whether to sign it.
Criticizing the Legislature's failure to act until so near the deadline, he said, "I will not permit this late action by the General Assembly to force the people of this state, or the Governor, into any action more motivated by the clock than by principles of economics and the law."
The Senate had earlier passed the budget by a 19-to-17 margin after determining that there were not enough votes for the income-tax plan.
"Every conceivable way to try to bring about consensus has been tried," said the Senate President pro tem, John B. Larson, referring to the summit meetings, caucuses, lobbying and private talks that have filled the draining weeks since the state began the fiscal year without a budget on July 1.
 
Two Previous Vetoes
 "But consensus," he continued, "still comes down around a conventional budget, a budget whose salient point is that it does not include an income tax."
The spending-and-tax plan approved tonight is the third put together by a coalition of moderate Democrats and Republicans that precariously balances a budget by applying Connecticut's 8 percent sales tax to more goods and services. It would raise $740 million in new taxes and fees, about $300 million less than other plans.
Mr. Weicker vetoed the two earlier budgets on May 31 and July 1. The second veto left the state with no budget as the new fiscal year began and led to a partial shutdown of state government and the furlough of 20,000 employees for three days.
That shutdown ended when the Governor allowed a temporary spending measure adopted by the General Assembly to take effect without his signature. The state continued operating on temporary spending measures.
Governor Weicker said he vetoed the first two no-income-tax budgets because they failed to reduce the state's high sales and business taxes and were not properly balanced. But he had no success with his alternative, an income tax that would provide the revenue to both balance the budget and cut other taxes. On May 24, and again on July 2, the Senate rejected income-tax plans.
After five weeks without a budget, the General Assembly met today to debate proposals that differed only in details from those defeated or vetoed earlier. Mr. Weicker's personal lobbying and public appeals had produced no change in his opponents' positions.
The income tax failed again today because of opposition in the Senate from not only Republicans, but also the top Democrats, Mr. Larson of East Hartford and the majority leader, Cornelius P. O'Leary of Windsor Locks.
Today's vote was proving a perverse success for Mr. Weicker, Connecticut's first independent governor in more a century.
Taking office as a governor without a party, he appealed to the General Assembly for a bipartisan effort to solve the state's fiscal problems. But when Democrats and Republicans did put aside their long-standing differences, it was to block his income tax and produce the budgets allowing the state to continue its reliance on the sales tax.
The no-income-tax budget approved by the Assembly tonight applies the sales tax for the first time to goods and services from haircuts to dry cleaning to extended warranties, and exemptions are being repealed for such things as nonprescription drugs.
 
State Services Maintained
 After the budget was passed, Mr. Weicker issued an executive order maintaining state services through the five-day period the Constitution allows him for reviewing emergency acts like the budget passed tonight.
He said that the latest temporary spending measure had been for just one week, expiring at midnight tonight, but that its appropriations were for a two-week period, allowing him to extend the measure.
"There'll be no shutdown," he said. "No lockout, or layoffs, or furloughs, or call it what you will."
Governor Weicker said he would review the budget line by line to see whether it met his four requirements: that it pay off the state's deficit, help business, not be based on financial gimmicks, and not rely too much on bonding.
"This has nothing to do with income tax or non-income tax," he said. "It has everything to do with whether it's balanced and it works for Connecticut."
Going strictly by those requirements, the Governor would have little choice but to veto the bill, since it makes no payments on the deficit, does not cut business taxes, uses several financial gimmicks and adds to the state's borrowing.
But the changed circumstances for the Governor were just as clearly indicated by his decision to keep government going while carefully examining the bill, rather than to issue an almost immediate veto and shut down the state, as he did on July 2.
The state's fiscal condition worsened under the temporary spending measures, which added $17 million each week to the state's billion-dollar deficit.
To make up for the increased deficit and the extra cost of borrowing during that period, the coalition budget calls for an additional $88 million in bonding and extends the sales tax more broadly than before, eliminating the exemption for adult clothing and sharply cutting that for children's clothing.
It also would force Mr. Weicker to deal with a $20 million in personnel cuts, most likely in layoffs, while counting on $327 million in union concessions that Mr. Weicker won this spring by promising no layoffs in the next year. And it provides the barest surplus for the fiscal year: $400,000.
The budget passed by the Assembly achieves a remarkable goal: the total $7.627 billion appropriated for the general fund, a transportation fund and other costs is $53 million less than Connecticut spent in the last fiscal year. Then again, last year's spending exceeded the state's 1990-91 budget by $632 million, or 9 percent.

House approves Senate budget.
 
May 31
 
Weicker vetoes. State's first budget veto in 20 years.
 
June 5
 
Legislative session ends with no budget. Early next morning legislative leaders, not waiting for Weicker, call a special session and begin it immediately.
 
June 12
 
Weicker proposes compromise budget that includes limits on spending. Tax rates are higher - top income tax rate is 6.75 percent, sales tax is 4.5 percent - because of state's deteriorating finances.
 
June 29
 
House rejects Weicker's compromise budget, approves second budget based on expanded sales tax.
 
June 30
 
Senate approves House budget.
 
July 1
 
Weicker issues second veto and Connecticut begins new fiscal year without a budget.
 
July 2
 
House approves budget with 4.75 percent income tax. Weicker declares emergency and orders shutdown of state except for essential services; within a day, 20,000 state employees are out of work. Senate kills income tax plan.
 
July 8
 
Weicker allows temporary two-week budget approved by House and Senate to take effect without his signature. State employees return to work.
 
July 22
 
Second two-week budget takes effect.
 
July 24
 
House fails to override Weicker's veto of budget based on expanded sales tax.
 
July 29
 
Third temporary budget, for only one week, takes effect.
 
Aug. 4
 
General Assembly passes third sales-tax budget. (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Penny M. Stern, Physician, Weds

 BODY:
Dr. Penny M. Stern, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stern of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Paul A. Zarowin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Zarowin of Brooklyn. Rabbi Ephraim Kanarfogel performed the ceremony at the Glen Island Casino in New Rochelle, N.Y.
Dr. Stern, who is keeping her name, is the medical editor of "Family Practice Update," a weekly program on Lifetime Medical Television, a cable network in Astoria, Queens. She graduated from Queens College of the City University of New York and received an M.D. degree from Yeshiva University. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Her father, who is retired, was the president of the Edwill Woodworking Corporation in New York. 
 The bridegroom, an associate professor of accounting at New York University, graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and received a doctorate in business economics from the University of Chicago. His father, who is retired, was an assisant principal of Brooklyn Technical High School.

HEADLINE: 30-Year-Old Film Is a Surprise Hit In Its 4th Re-Release

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4

 BODY:
She may not match the form-changing cyborg of "Terminator 2: Judgment Day" for pure evil, but Cruella DeVil, the villain of Disney's 30-year-old "101 Dalmatians," is proving to be an astonishingly strong box-office draw this summer.
"101 Dalmatians" is, in fact, the biggest surprise hit of the season for Hollywood. Executives at the Walt Disney Company had expected it to do well in this, its fourth re-release since its original run in 1961. But no one in the industry expected it to gross $41.8 million at the box office in its first 24 days, through this weekend. 
 At that pace it stands to take in at least $50 million and perhaps as much as $60 million by the end of the summer, a level that only a handful of first-run, live-action films will reach during that period. If the film does more than $54 million, it will surpass Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" to become the biggest animated hit ever, based on cumulative box-office grosses over the years, adjusted for inflation.
"It's enormously pleasing to all of us who have worked in animation to see that quality still has that kind of popularity and value 30 years down the road," said Roy E. Disney, the nephew of the company's founder and still one of the guiding spirits of Disney's animation division.
 
Little Family Entertainment
 Industry executives and analysts attributed the film's popularity in part to the endearing story of the two Dalmatians, Pongo and Perdita, who brave fearsome odds to save their puppies from being made into fur coats by the wicked Cruella.
But the film is also benefiting from what many parents, now deep into the summer vacation, would undoubtedly consider a dearth of family entertainment.
"It's the only thing out there that's really for the family audience," said Philip Garfinkle of Entertainment Data Inc., which tracks box-office results. " 'Problem Child 2' or 'Terminator' or 'Robin Hood' are not the same as a G-rated picture."
The success of "101 Dalmations" is also the latest evidence of the immense profitability in Disney's library of animated classics, profitability that is especially noticeable when huge production budgets have made it difficult for studios, including Disney, to make money on their current movies.
The production costs of "101 Dalmatians" have long since been recouped. With the exception of advertising costs and the costs of making more than 1,800 new prints -- a total that analysts said was probably at least $5 million -- virtually all of Disney's income on the movie this summer is profit.
 
A $20 Million Profit
 Studios typically keep about half the box-office gross, with the rest going to theater owners. At $50 million in box-office gross, Disney could cover its costs and still have a $20 million profit. In contrast, the studio's live-action summer release, "The Rocketeer," cost at least $35 million to make and probably at least $10 million more to market and distribute.
To break even, "The Rocketeer" would have to do $90 million at the domestic box office, a level it is highly unlikely to attain (through this weekend it had done $42.3 million). "The Rocketeer" is likely to be profitable in the long run for Disney after counting foreign box-office and home-video sales.
Disney can also look forward to the home-video release of "101 Dalmatians." Studio executives said no date had been set, but Disney typically releases its classics on video within a year after their re-release in theaters. And the company is also benefiting from a surge in demand for Pongo and Perdita stuffed animals, T-shirts, lunch boxes and other merchandise linked to the film.
"All of us knew it is one of the all-time favorite animated movies, and we all expected it to perform very well," said Richard Cook, the president of Disney's movie distribution operation. "But I don't think any of us expected it to do this kind of business."
Mr. Cook said that with each release, classic animated films appeal not just to a new generation of children but also to their parents and in this case to some grandparents lured back by the memory of having seen the film themselves as children and parents. "Dalmatians," he said, is also drawing people who come without children, what he called "the dating crowd."
 
The Return of Animation
 If nothing else, the movie's strong showing will cement the belief throughout Hollywood that animation's time has come again. Disney and other studios have been expanding their animation production in recent years, both for television and movies. This month Warner Brothers will release "Rover Dangerfield," in which Rodney Dangerfield will supply the voice for the animated canine hero. Disney plans to release a new animated musical version of "Beauty and the Beast" at Thanksgiving.
After its original run in 1961, "101 Dalmatians" was released in 1969, 1979 and 1985. Going into this summer, its cumulative box-office total, adjusted for inflation, was $89.7 million, Disney said.
That put it in sixth place on the list of all-time animated hits, behind "Snow White" ($143.6 million), "The Jungle Book" ($130 million), "Bambi" ($109.9 million), "Cinderella" ($95.5 million) and "Lady and the Tramp" ($93 million). This weekend, "101 Dalmatians" passed "Jungle Book" to go into second place.
The largest single release of an animated movie was "The Little Mermaid," from Disney, which grossed $84 million in its original run two years ago.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A scene from "101 Dalmatians," which is proving to be an astonishingly strong box-office draw in its fourth re-release. (The Walt Disney Company)

HEADLINE: GOLF;
In Golf, Integration Is More Than 9-Iron Away

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ

 BODY:
The sociological shock surrounding last year's P.G.A. Championship at Shoal Creek carried more force than any off-course event in golf's history, but even that impact hasn't shaken the game from its inherently leisurely pace.
As golf has settled back into its own tempo, the true significance of the protests that forced the country club outside Birmingham, Ala., to accept a black member has become difficult to measure. While the sanctuary of privilege that all-white private clubs long enjoyed has come under more critical scrutiny than ever before, minority groups, and particularly black people, are still far outside golf's mainstream. 
 On the eve of this year's P.G.A. Championship, which begins Thursday at Crooked Stick Golf Club in Carmel, Ind., the changes made since last year's event are still in the eye of the beholder.
Those who say Shoal Creek irrevocably changed the face of the game point to the way this country's four major golf organizations -- the United States Golf Association, the Professional Golfers' Association of America, the PGA Tour and the Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour -- all drafted new policies requiring the private clubs that play host to their tournaments to move decisively toward integrating their memberships.
In addition, the Augusta National Golf Club, the home of the Masters, independently admitted its first black member.
"I think that on balance the golf world has surprised me with how aggressively they have gone after change since Shoal Creek," David Fay, executive director of the U.S.G.A., said recently. "Some might say we are not doing it quick enough, but I think there is proof across the board that important changes are continuing to be made."
Others contend that the only changes brought on by Shoal Creek were forced by financial expediency, and that next to nothing has been done to motivate the true integration of the game at the nearly 6,000 private clubs in the United States that have no intention of holding major professional tournaments. About three quarters of these clubs do not have a black member. Moreover, critics say, golf's leadership has done little to integrate the business and administration of the game.
"There has been a beginning, but I think it has all been token," said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, the president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, which focused national attention on Shoal Creek by threatening to picket last year's P.G.A. Championship. "What hasn't been done has given affirmation to the critics who said golf's leaders responded only because of economic pressure. There was no moral impetus, no repentance of our sins."
Those sins were symbolized last July in the words of Shoal Creek's founder, Hall Thompson, when he told a Birmingham newspaper reporter that "we don't discriminate in every other area except the blacks." Suddenly, what had been tacitly accepted for generations had been too bluntly stated in too visible an arena to be ignored.
The S.C.L.C.'s subsequent threat to picket the P.G.A. Championship unless Shoal Creek took in a black member led some corporate sponsors to withdraw their advertising from the telecast of the tournament. With its golden egg under siege, golf's leadership responded posthaste.
Louis Willie, a prominent black Birmingham businessman, was admitted as an honorary member at Shoal Creek. The PGA Tour drew up a firm anti-discrimination policy for its host clubs to follow, as did the P.G.A. of America and the U.S.G.A. Although the PGA Tour's policy did not stipulate that every host club had to have minority members, it stipulated that each club had to demonstrate an ongoing commitment to non-exclusionary membership.
"There wasn't any point in kidding around," said Tim Finchem, deputy commissioner of the PGA Tour. "If a club didn't want to take steps, we wanted to know up front because sooner or later it was going to be a black eye for them and for us."
Since then, 11 private clubs have dropped out as hosts of national championship tournaments or tour events rather than adopt more inclusive membership practices. The clubs that withdrew are: Butler National (Centel Western Open), Cypress Point Golf Club (AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am), Old Warson Country Club (Southwestern Bell Senior Classic), Skokie Country Club (Ameritech Senior Open), Amarillo Country Club (Ben Hogan Amarillo Open), the Golf Club of Louisiana (Ben Hogan Baton Rouge Open), St. Louis Country Club (1992 United States Women's Amateur), Chicago Golf Club (1993 Walker Cup), Annandale Golf Club (1993 United States Women's Amateur), Merion Golf Club (1994 Women's Open) and Aronimink Golf Club (1993 P.G.A. Championship).
Conversely, most of the host clubs on the PGA Tour, the Senior PGA Tour and the L.P.G.A. Tour that did not have minority membership at the time of Shoal Creek have since admitted at least one black, most recently the Colonial Country Club, site of the Southwestern Bell Colonial, and Castle Pines Golf Club, site of The International.
Of the 123 courses used by the three major tours in 1991, 43 had no black members before Shoal Creek (55 of the 123 are either public or resort courses). Although neither the PGA Tour or the L.P.G.A. Tour would supply any information, telephone checks with the clubs showed that only about 10 clubs now have either no minority members or refuse to comment on the subject.
Meanwhile, future United States Open sites like Baltusrol in 1993, Oakmont in 1994 and Oakland Hills in 1996 recently admitted blacks. Shinnecock Hills, the proposed site of the 1995 United States Open, has yet to admit its first black, though club officials have said they are committed to doing so.
While golf leaders have had a strong lever in the integration of private clubs that want to hold tour events and championship tournaments, there is no such inducement for the vast majority of private clubs in the country. On the contrary, the Constitution guarantees clubs the right of free association, making most forms of discrimination legal.
According to a recent survey in The Chicago Tribune, only 10 of the 74 clubs in the Chicago area have black members. The Detroit Free Press found only 11 of 38 private clubs in the Detroit area with black members. When The New York Times recently surveyed 39 private clubs in Westchester County, 11 said they had black members, while 15 clubs did not respond to the survey.
Similar ratios have been found elsewhere in the country, which leaves even Lowery resigned to the idea that the integration of America's private clubs will be slow.
"It's not going to be easy for any of these clubs to find a whole lot of black people who are willing to put up the kind of money needed," he said. "We aren't talking about integrating a hot dog lunch counter. Golf is an elitest, expensive type of thing. You aren't going to see any mad rush at any level."
 
'A Trend Is Percolating'
 But the change is coming. Even Bill Colley, general counsel for the National Club Association, an organization that advocates the right of clubs to discriminate in their membership practices, admits that.
"I would say there is a trend that is percolating in which clubs are reviewing their admission procedures and admitting more blacks and minorities," he said. "The reasons can be economic, the stigma from the community, or the feeling that it's time to catch up with reality and get into today's mainstream. Just the idea that the things that were done 20 and 30 years ago doesn't apply socially in today's environment."
Lowery is more concerned with the integration of golf's administration and business than he is with the integration of clubs. None of the four major golf organizations has a black in a management capacity. Only the P.G.A. of America has a black in a high-ranking advisory capacity, while the PGA Tour recently hired a black for its on-site promotions staff. Only 25 of some 20,000 P.G.A. club pros are black.
"They've asked the clubs to do what they themselves have not done, which is to desegregate their boards and staff," Lowery said. "The symbolism of black staff, as much as its actual worth, is extremely important. It makes the entire game more accessible to blacks."
But according to Finchem and Fay, integration in golf is difficult to achieve on both a participant and a business level.
"That's what we are trying to get a handle on for the next four or five years," Finchem said. "We are making some progress in that regard, but the first thing we found out is it's not easy."
They agree that promoting golf participation among young members of minority groups is difficult because access to courses is often a problem, as is the lack of role models in the game.
Jim Thorpe and Calvin Peete are the only blacks who regularly play on the PGA Tour, and National Golf Foundation statistics indicate that blacks make up only 3 percent of the nation's golfers, and that about only 1 in 50 blacks play golf. There is one example of promise in this regard: On July 28, 15-year-old Eldrick Woods, who is black, became the youngest winner ever of the United States Junior Amateur.
Because relatively few black people grow up around golf, blacks are rarely among the candidates for jobs where a lifelong background in the game is highly desirable.
"Minorities don't appear in that area because they are not playing the game," Finchem said. "So what we are faced with is growing people with internship programs and recruiting programs in entry-level positions."
Fay, who said the U.S.G.A. is aggressively seeking a black to sit on the association's excecutive committee by next year, agreed.
"Right now, the pool is not there," Fay said. "When Branch Rickey brought Jackie Robinson in, once the floodgate was opened, then you had the Negro leagues to provide more talent. In golf, it's more difficult to get black participants."
"I don't buy that," Lowery said. "We have blacks in space travel, and everywhere else. They haven't asked me to recommend anybody, and I know several people they could involve. And so do they. They just haven't been willing to commit."
 
'We'll Find Ways'
 Lowery is skeptical that the momentum of Shoal Creek will continue without pressure from civil-rights groups.
"Right now the song seems ended, and I don't know if the melody lingers on," he said. "The integration of golf may not be the highest-priority item for us, but we are not going to let it die. We'll find ways to keep their feet to the fire."
In the meantime, the game is likely to change as it always has, gradually.
"Americans like to move fast, but nature doesn't operate that way," said Willie, still Shoal Creek's only black member. "It doesn't discourage me that the progress is slow. But it is encouraging to me that clubs have opened which had not had their consciousness raised to this extent before.
"I believe this issue will fade as an outstanding social barrier to blacks in the future. I am encouraged by what has happened since last year."
