LENGTH: 1244 words

HEADLINE: If Bush Offers Good Target, Democrats' Aim Is Shaky

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats agree that President Bush could be vulnerable on domestic policy matters. But they cannot agree on how to capitalize on that vulnerability or just how potent such an approach might be.
By the time Congress left town this weekend for its August recess, leaders in both the House and the Senate had spent weeks trying to muscle through bills on transportation, abortion rights, crime, civil rights and unemployment, all of which President Bush has threatened to veto. 
 Democratic strategists and lawmakers are convinced that this is potentially strong campaign ammunition. The lawmakers have delivered dozens of floor speeches criticizing the President on racial issues, unemployment and even drought relief. They are trying to paint Mr. Bush as a President with a one-word answer to every domestic problem: no.
"The President has acknowledged his interest in foreign affairs," Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said in an interview last week, "and his disinterest in domestic affairs is now obvious to all Americans."
 
Criticism From Gephardt
 At a news conference on Friday, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said: "Up until now, the President has found a lot of emergencies, aid to the Kurds, aid to many different countries around the world. But he can't quite bring himself to see that there's an emergency here in the United States with people who are out of work, who've exhausted their unemployment benefits and are having trouble taking care of their families."
The coordinated Congressional attack has clearly hit its mark. In a response in a Friday news conference, the President said Americans should "not listen to the charges by frantic Democrats trying to say we don't have a domestic policy.
"And I am not going to lose interest in world peace, and I don't think the American people want me to."
But Democrats remain divided about whether forcing vetoes that Congress cannot override is a good political strategy for a sometimes disorganized caucus of lawmakers who have a wide variety of priorities and, as yet, no compelling Presidential candidate to take on the President directly.
In short, the Democrats have figured out just how to call George Bush's bluff, but they cannot agree on the message or the messenger. "They have themselves over a barrel," Eddie Mahe, a Republican campaign consultant, said. "They cannot come to any consensus in any real way."
Mr. Mahe, like Republican partisans in Congress and in the Bush Administration, is gleeful about the Democrats' problem. On Friday, Mr. Bush met with House Republicans to assure them that he was prepared to work with them to promote the Republican party's domestic agenda.
That agenda is likely to repackage issues like home ownership for the poor, education and preventive health care espoused by such Cabinet members as Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services; Lamar Alexander, the Secretary of Education, and Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
"There are ideas on the table that change the way government interacts," said Rich Bond, a Republican strategist with ties to the White House. "What's wrong with that idea?"
Republican strategists inside Congress and out expect the President to redefine the nation's domestic agenda to fit his own definitions, continue to veto what he does not like and blame Congress for stalemates.
And Republicans are gearing up to dispute the Democrats' contention that the President has no domestic policy.
"It's the only strategy they have," Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, the chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Commmittee, said of the Democrats. "In politics, you go to your strong suit, even if the highest card happens to be the seven of spades."
But for all their boasting that the White House has a domestic agenda, Republicans are aware of the polls that show how vulnerable the President may be on domestic policy. A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted June 3-6 found that while 68 percent of those questioned said they approved of the President's handling of foreign policy, 48 percent disapproved of his handling of the economy and only 41 percent approved. The telephone poll of 1,424 adults had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Even more recently, a Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll of 1,004 registered voters conducted July 26-29, showed 74 percent approved of the way Mr. Bush has handled foreign policy, while 52 percent disapproved of his handling of the economy. Thirty-eight percent said they approved of his handling of the economy. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Yet, with precious few Presidential candidates on the horizon to articulate Mr. Bush's perceived weaknesses, the Democrats are essentially stymied.
"We have had an inability to create an awareness of our policy," Mr. Mitchell said. "Obviously, we're not doing it as effectively and as well as we could, but it is very hard to compete with the President for access to the attention of the American people."
Mr. Bush has shrugged off such challenges with a series of veto threats -- at least 10 made during the 102d Congress. Since he took office in 1989, Mr. Bush has vetoed 21 pieces of legislation. None of the vetoes has been overriden by Congress.
"I think vetoes are a dangerous strategy for him," said Kevin Phillips, a Republican political analyst, "except he has enough credentials in foreign and defense policy not to have to worry about the losses he is likely to absorb if he vetoes domestic issues."
Mr. Phillips, like other Republicans, says Democrats are not well equipped to take on the President. "They have an instinct for the capillaries, not the jugular," he said.
Part of the Democrats' problem is that they do not adhere to a single political discipline. This was demonstrated again last week, when two strong-willed committee chairmen, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois and Representative Robert A. Roe of New Jersey, argued to a standoff over the gas tax as part of the transportation bill.
"If the Democratic Party were in Europe, it would be five distinct parties," said Representative Joe Moakley of Maasachusetts, the chairman of the Rules Committee, where the gas-tax negotiations fell apart. "We have an awful big umbrella covering an awful lot of different people."
Mr. Rostenkowski is no fan of forcing vetoes to make a political point. Democrats, he said, should be expending more energy negotiating legislative differences so that Congress can produce a bill the President would sign.
"The problem with Democrats is we promise more than we can deliver, and then we don't deliver on the promises we make, and people view us as irresponsible," Mr. Rostenkowski said.
No one knows those weaknesses better than George Bush. "Clearly, Bush is playing a political game where he's trying to use Congress as his foil," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic consultant. "A good Presidential campaign by the Democrats will take an awful lot of the pressure off of Congress.
Democratic leaders are counting on the White House to do some of their dirty work for them. "We don't think they run a domestic policy effort at the White House," said Paul Tully, the political director of the Democratic National Committee. "We think they run a continuing election campaign."

HEADLINE: A Range War of Words On Grazing in the West

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOULDER, Utah

 BODY:
Tired and sore from tending the cattle, hauling water and mending fences, Arthur Lyman, a fifth-generation cowman, bristles at the signs and stickers placed along the road that declare: "Welfare rancher."
"It really burns my hide," said Mr. Lyman, a 40-year-old rancher in the Escalante River Valley, who works a second job. "I work like a danged fool from sunrise to dark. And I'm still pretty much in a poverty situation." 
 But Mr. Lyman and other ranchers who use public lands pay a grazing fee that is only a fraction of what it costs cattlemen who lease private land. Critics of the fee programs for Government land, including Representative Mike Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, say the programs amount to a subsidy that costs taxpayers millions of dollars and harms the public land by encouraging too much grazing.
"It's a sweetheart deal that ought to end," said Mr. Synar, who has led an effort in Congress to increase the fees sharply.
 
What Is the Land For?
 The debate is about more than fees. It has raised deep questions about the very purpose of public land: Should it be used to foster economic interests, as it has in parts of the West for generations? Or should it exist to be admired but be relatively untouched, even if some people go broke?
It is a debate as old as the saga of cattle barons and range wars of the late 1800's, when the powerful ran roughshod over rivals and some ranchers controlled as much as a million acres of public land.
The central issue is the condition of the land. Environmentalists have asserted that public tracts are being ruined by livestock who eat away the vegetation and pollute streams with their wastes.
"The damage has been quite severe," said Nancy Green of the Wilderness Society. "It will take decades to restore some of these areas, at a cost of many millions of dollars."
 
'In the Right Direction'
 But the cattle industry, as well as officials of the Bureau of Land Management, say the public land is in relatively good condition and is improving with time.
"You can find trouble spots here and there," said Sy Jamison, head of the bureau, "but over all, the trends are in the right direction." He said 14 percent of public land was considered to be in poor condition. In the 1930's, he said, about 36 percent was judged to be in that condition.
Mr. Synar's measure, which has passed the House as part of the Interior Department's budget, would increase grazing fees to $8.70 from $1.97 for each "animal unit month," or, the vegetation consumed in a month by one cow and her calf, or by one horse, or by five sheep.
A portion of the increased fees would go toward restoring range lands, especially the lush areas near streams. Currently, the fees are used to pay for the Interior Department's maintenance of range lands and they fall slightly short of covering the costs.
The Senate has yet to act on the department's budget.
 
Ruin for Many Ranchers?
 Mr. Jamison has estimated that such an increase would drive out of business more than 90 percent of the ranchers using public land. About 8 percent of western ranchers, or 31,000 people, use public land, and they produce 3 percent of the nation's beef. But the cattle industry says the figure for full-grown beef animals is misleadingly low, because many calves born on public land are sent to feed lots in the Midwest and elsewhere to be fattened.
Mr. Jamison said it was just not true that huge sums of public money subsidize the grazing. He said that in 1990 cattlemen paid $1.81 per animal unit month to graze their herds on land managed by the bureau, amounting to a subsidy of 2 cents per animal unit month. Moreover, he said, 40 percent of the bureau's cost to maintain public land has nothing to do with cattle grazing.
Mr. Lyman owns about 300 head of cattle that he grazes in the canyons and jagged ridges of the Utah mountains. "It makes no difference to the big old United States if this ranch goes under and goes to sagebrush," he said. "But this is my way of life."
Mr. Lyman and other ranchers say it is unfair to compare fees for public and private pastures. Private land is much more lush, they say, so cattle can be fattened more quickly, and landlords provide fencing and water.
Indeed, one study concluded that ranchers who use public land pay more because of the costs of maintenance, water development and transportion to and from grazing areas.
The study, conducted by Darwin Nielson, a Utah State University professor and a member of the National Cattlemen's Association grazing fee task force, found that a rancher pays $14.26 an animal unit month to operate on public land, as against $10.41 on private land.
A rancher like Mr. Lyman typically will truck his cattle to public range lands on Oct. 15. The cattle will graze on the range until April, when most of the cows have given birth. After the rancher loads the cattle and trucks them back to his own land, the animals are sold to a cattle buyer and eventually go to, say, a Kansas or California pasture or a Midwestern feed lot to be further fattened for slaughter.
Cattle have been grazing on public land in the West for many decades. Throughout the 19th century, they were allowed to roam free and free of charge. In the 1930's, Congress enacted legislation setting aside specific tracts of range land for grazing at a fee.
Ranchers say environmental groups are actually pushing for an end to livestock grazing on public lands, not just a reduction. They point to the slogan of the environmental group Earth First: "Cow free by '93."
Ranchers blame environmental extremists for scattered acts of vandalism and violence on ranches in the West. A year ago, 24 cows and calves were shot to death on Mr. Lyman's ranch. Not long before the killings, Mr. Lyman found a sign placed on his ranch that read: "Stop Destructive Welfare Ranching."
"It's really been a scary thing," said Mr. Lyman. "I used to let my 16-year-old, Chad, ride the range all day, like my dad let me when I was a boy. I can't do that anymore."
Sheriff Than Cooper of Garfield County sought to cool tempers. "I told them, now you can't go shoot somebody just because you want to," he said. "And I think most of the ranchers understood that."
The major environmental groups say they abhor violence and threats. "We're not opposed to grazing, per se," said David Alberswerth of the National Wildlife Federation, "but we think the burden of proof should be on the livestock industry to show why they deserve to stay on public lands."
The dispute has spilled over into entertainment and advertising. Cattle interests have mounted a protest against the broadcast on the Public Broadcasting Service of "The New Range Wars," a documentary on the grazing debate produced by the Audubon Society. Earlier this summer, the Ford Motor Company canceled its advertising shortly before the program was to be shown on the Turner Broadcasting System network. (In New York, the PBS broadcast is scheduled for 8 P.M. Aug. 12 on Channel 13.)
Ranchers argue that increasing numbers of tourists and hikers on public land cause more damage than their livestock.
Some of the ranchers in the Escalante River Valley, for example, say they can no longer drive their herds to pasture in the traditional manner because tourists get out of cars to take pictures and try to pet the animals. As a result, more ranchers now truck their stock to pasture.
Indeed, those who oppose grazing say that ranchers' political power is ebbing as they are outnumbered by environmentalists and others who wish to see the land preserved.
In their book, "Sacred Cows at the Public Trough," Nancy and Denzel Ferguson write: "For every person grazing livestock on public lands, there are about 195 who read Outdoor Life. Add the millions of other hunters, fishermen, sightseers, birdwatchers, members of conservation organizations and just plain citizens who care about natural resources, and you have an imposing constituency."
The public mood is changing, even in the West, where the cattle industry has held sway since the region was settled. Many ranchers say they worry that their children will not be able to carry on the tradition of running cattle.
"This ranch has been in the family for 200 years," said Louise Liston, a rancher in Garfield County. "We've scraped and struggled and fought to survive. But we've stayed because we love it. We love the land. And this is where our roots are. It is very hard to leave your roots."

And I'm still pretty much in a poverty situation." Critics say the use of public land amounts to a subsidy that costs taxpayers millions of dollars. (Terrence Moore for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush's Domestic Record Is Assailed by Mitchell

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The Senate Democratic leader challenged President Bush today on issues from civil rights to unemployment compensation to health care, and said Congress should pass bills it believed in even if Mr. Bush vetoed them.
The leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, said it was not true, as Mr. Bush said at a news conference on Friday, that the Democrats in Congress were "frustratingly negative on everything." 
 "The facts are clearly the opposite," Mr. Mitchell said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." He went on to say: "The President's strategy is very clearly a negative veto strategy. He has very little in the way of a domestic program of his own, and I think what you'll see is a political plan over the next year and a half, which will be for the President simply to veto whatever the Congress does and then to run against Congress."
 
Aggressive Domestic Agenda
 Roger Porter, assistant to the President for domestic policy, appeared on the same program and insisted: "The President has an aggressive domestic agenda of bills that he has sent to the Congress. He has submitted for them major legislation dealing with education, with banking reform, with crime, with energy, and now we're waiting for Congress to take action on them."
Mr. Mitchell said the breakdown of discussions on civil rights legislation between Mr. Bush and Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, meant it was now time for Democrats to get behind Mr. Danforth's legislation and pass it with a veto-proof majority if Mr. Danforth can bring enough Republicans along with him. Sixty-seven senators are needed to override a veto when all senators vote; there are 57 Democrats in the Senate.
Mr. Mitchell said he did not believe there was any chance of cooperation with Mr. Bush on civil rights. "It's very clear the President wants an issue, not a bill," he said. "It's the first time a President has used the racial issue in this manner in modern times."
But Mr. Porter insisted that Mr. Bush wanted a civil rights bill. He said Mr. Danforth's proposal would "undermine the President's educational program." The Danforth proposal would prohibit employers from imposing standards not related to job performance if they have a discriminatory effect.
He said Mr. Bush "believes very strongly that it is important that employers inquire as to whether people have dropped out of school and how well they have done in school."
Mr. Mitchell said Congress would pass legislation dealing with health care and health insurance costs next year. Mr. Porter said he did not know when Mr. Bush would make his own proposal on those issues.
Mr. Mitchell also urged President Bush to sign the unemployment compensation bill passed Friday and to allow the extended benefits it provides to reach Americans who have been out of work for more than half a year.
Renewing the Democratic charge that Mr. Bush is more interested in foreign affairs than domestic ones and quicker to aid Kurds, Turks or Israelis than Americans, Mr. Mitchell said: "We don't think that aid ought to only go to people outside this country. We think when Americans need help, they should get it."

HEADLINE: As Many Democrats Seek a Shift, One Hopeful Clings to Liberalism

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 4

 BODY:
They have watched the Republicans turn "liberal" into an insult. They have been told, again and again, that their national party is out of touch, enfeebled, doomed to fail unless it changes. They are heading into a Presidential campaign that is widely expected to be their fourth straight defeat.
It is not surprising then that many of the Democratic faithful are ripe for Senator Tom Harkin, the rough-edged, true-believing Iowan testing the waters for a Presidential campaign. 
 "We Democrats have nothing to be ashamed of," he shouted on a recent golden New Hampshire afternoon, resurrecting memories of Roosevelt, Truman and Humphrey while his partisan audience cheered him on.
On issue after issue, Mr. Harkin declared, "We weren't wrong; we were right."
 
Message of True Belief
 Wiry and angry, punching the air with evangelical passion, Mr. Harkin offers his beleaguered party a potent mix of old-time Democratic religion, prairie populism and group therapy. There is no need to surrender to the Republicans, he says, no need to "walk a little bit more and talk a little bit more like Republicans."
Democrats need only believe in themselves again, he says, and get off their knees. But amid the cheers there are some private doubts among Democrats: This may be good psychology, but is it good politics?
A coal miner's son who boasts that he grew up on the wrong side of the tracks, Mr. Harkin sneers at much of the conventional wisdom in politics these days. While Democratic centrists fret about toughening the party's image on national security, Mr. Harkin says he has absolutely no regrets about his vote against the use of force in the Persian Gulf.
While many of the party's thinkers search for a new economics, Mr. Harkin calls for Democratic fundamentals: a major new program to rebuild the nation's roads, bridges and other infrastructure. Asked how he would pay for it, he shoots back, "When Ronald Reagan came in and said he was going to increase defense spending, cut taxes and balance the budget, did you ask him how?"
In 1990, Mr. Harkin's voting record made him one of the 15 most liberal members of the Senate, according to the annual ranking by The National Journal, a Washington publication.
The Republicans cast him as one more "in a long line of very liberal Democrats who are out of the mainstream of American public opinion," in the words of Charles Black, a top adviser to the Republican National Committee. "I describe him as George McGovern with hair," he added.
 
Still an Exploratory Stage
 There is always an audience among party activists for the traditional organ music of the Democratic Party; Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, for example, placed second in the Iowa Presidential caucuses in 1988 with a plea for "a government that cares."
Mr. Harkin, who combines his Democratic orthodoxy with a full-throated attack on the Republicans, has drawn a particularly strong response from organized labor.
"Win, lose or draw, he speaks our language," said Bill Holayter, director of the legislative and political action department for the machinists' union. "He's got a Hubert Humphrey-type message that speaks to people's needs and desires."
The party may be particularly open to his appeal in the summer of 1991; when so many Democrats seem to be shrinking from a challenge to Mr. Bush, Mr. Harkin gets points with party officials for simply being out on the stump.
"There is a premium to the guys who show the guts to get out there," said Phil Angelides, chairman of the California Democratic Party.
Mr. Harkin is still in the exploratory phase of a candidacy, but says he is "moving toward a positive decision" and will announce his intentions around Labor Day.
Other Democrats, notably the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of centrists and conservatives, assert that the party's repeated losses of Presidential races indicate the need for fundamental change in its message and a new appeal to the middle class.
"He's right that we shouldn't be more like the Republicans, but if he thinks the public hasn't formed some distinctly bad impressions of the party's message in the last several elections, he's missing something," said Will Marshall, president of the Progressive Policy Institute, an offshoot of the leadership council.
"We would say it behooves the Democrats to offer something other than a recycling of the old politics in 1992 if you want to make a credible bid for the White House," Mr. Marshall added.
Mr. Harkin, who is 51 years old, said in an interview that he had thought about the Presidency much of his life but only began considering a 1992 candidacy last fall, after he was elected to his second term in the Senate. He says he is convinced that the Democrats can win the White House if they stand proudly for their traditional values -- he draws an analogy with "new Coke" and "classic Coke" -- and hit the Republicans hard.
"I do believe that Democrats down deep inside feel they got cheated in 1988," he says. "They got cheated because our candidate and our campaign didn't fight back, cheated because Bush played dirty and should not have been President of the United States."
Mr. Harkin touts the benefits of a base west of the Mississippi. "There's a Western strategy out there that no one's talking about," he says. "It's going to take someone from out there who understands that populism."
There is little dispute about Mr. Harkin's skills on the stump, much appreciated in a party whose last nominee, Michael S. Dukakis, rarely approached the foothills of oratorical passion.
Mr. Harkin has that constant edge of anger that puts the power in populism, railing against "George Herbert Walker Bush" and "J. Danforth Quayle." He chips away at the Republicans' proud record of job creation, telling of a couple in Iowa -- the husband lost a $14-an-hour job, replaced it with a $7-an-hour job, saw his wife forced to work at a $4-an-hour job -- a family working harder and losing ground.
 
Homefront Problems Cited
 "The issue, George Herbert Walker Bush, is not jobs," Mr. Harkin declares. "Hell, slaves had jobs. What we want in this country are decent, well-paying, secure jobs."
Like other Democrats, he hammers away with accusations that Mr. Bush is neglecting the homefront. While Mr. Bush was flying off to Moscow for the summit meeting, Mr. Harkin was at a health clinic for women and infants, talking about nutrition and breast-feeding.
At a Democratic picnic in New Hampshire, Mr. Harkin held aloft a suitcase emblazoned with stickers for recent Presidential destinations around the world. "I say, George Herbert Walker Bush, unpack your suitcase, stay here in America a little bit longer," he said.
Mr. Harkin was vague on his programmatic intentions. For example, he said he would not raise taxes for his major new infrastructure program, saying only, "The money's there, if we have the guts to invest it where it ought to be invested." How big a program is he calling for? "Big time," he says, "nothing small potatoes here."
But at the moment, in the summer of 1991, Mr. Harkin's appeal to the Democratic faithful has more to do with passion than programs. Jacket off, sleeves rolled up, leaning into the microphone, finding his cadence, he carries the crowd with him: "When Franklin Roosevelt initiated Social Security and the Republicans all voted against it, we were right.
"When Harry Truman brought the boys back from Europe and said, 'we're going to send them to school, we're going to build houses for them,' Republicans said, 'no, we can't afford it.' We were right."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We Democrats have nothing to be ashamed of," said Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa as he spoke at a New Hampshire Democratic picnic in Manchester. Mr. Harkin is testing the waters for a Presidential bid. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times) (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Con Ed Is Told To Shift Goal To Efficiency

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
For close to 20 years, the clean, cheap power generated by Canada's dams has been the solution whenever New York's utilities have looked for more electricity. Now, pressure is mounting on the state and the Consolidated Edison Company to put their long-term investments into something even cleaner and possibly cheaper: conservation.
 Mayor David N. Dinkins plans to ask New York State today to delay signing a new contract that would provide Con Ed with large amounts of hydroelectricity from Canada from 1995 to 2016. His administration says that the $6.1 billion that the contract would cost Con Ed would be better spent on subsidies to businesses and homeowners to adopt a variety of energy-saving devices. Investing in conservation and buying electricity from small independent generators, city officials say, would be cheaper and possibly more secure. 
Con Edison is already planning to spend $4.1 billion over the next 17 years on conservation programs intended to save 26 percent of its current generating capacity, a savings of five times as much power as the hydroelectric contract would bring. But as New York State approaches a deadline to complete the Canadian contract, utility officials say they are not sure they can rely on conservation to achieve more than they have already planned.
 Rejecting new hydroelectric purchases in favor of more conservation would be a huge change in the state's energy policy.
 While utilities around the country have recently moved heavily into promoting energy efficiency rather than new construction, and while the New York Public Service Commission has made it financially attractive for utilities here to do the same, the real decisions have not confronted Con Ed yet. The utility began the 1990's with surplus capacity and has not thus far used increased efficiency as a substitute for pouring concrete or signing new contracts with suppliers.
 Howard F. Squadron, the city's Commissioner of Telecommunications and Energy, described the city's argument in an interview as "part of an overall turn in the road," in which the way electricity is used has become as important as the way it is generated.
 
How Much 'Enlightened Energy'
 But the company has a marked reluctance to rely on more demand-side management, as efficiency is known in the industry, than it has already planned for in its current campaign, called Enlightened Energy.
 The company plans to spend $73 million on promoting conservation this year, which is equal to about 10 percent of its capital budget, and $4.2 billion between now and 2008.
 "The issue on Enlightened Energy is how much more you can get," said John E. Deegan Jr., senior vice president of the company.
 Among other goals, Con Ed already plans to subsidize or otherwise encourage the replacement of 89 percent of the commercial and industrial lighting in its 660-square-mile service territory, along with 64 percent of the commercial electric air conditioners and 60 percent of the residential refrigerators.
 
Like an Extra Indian Point
 By 2008 Enlightened Energy is supposed to reduce the summer peak load by 2,425 megawatts and winter load by 955 megawatts. (The summer effect is higher because Con Ed has focused its efforts on summer demand, which is higher, and its steps to make air conditioners more efficient and switch some air conditioners to steam or gas power do nothing to affect winter demand.)
 Stated differently, conservation by 2008 will give Con Edison as much electricity in winter as another Indian Point nuclear plant would. In summer, it would be like having another Indian Point plus another Astoria complex.
 These gains are far larger than anything Con Ed has tried before, and utility experts outside the company are not certain they are possible.
 "They probably won't get everything they want to get, but they'll get a good chunk of it," said William J. Balet, the executive director of the New York Power Pool, a utility consortium that helps plan power supplies and arrange power transfers between utilities. It may be 10 years, he said, before it is clear how much power is available through conservation.
 Con Edison has gone after efficiency improvements in part because it can make a big profit that way. In addition to selling high-efficiency light bulbs at subsidized rates, it is offering businesses subsidies if they will replace motors, air conditioners and lights with equipment that does the same work for less power. The initial response has been good from businesses and nearly overwhelming from residences, where 106,000 customers have taken up the utility on its offer to sell cut-rate bulbs that use only 25 percent of the electricity used by regular ones.
 On the commercial side, Con Ed is helping big buildings in Manhattan pay for installing air-conditioning equipment run by steam or natural gas, both of which are in surplus in summer.
 Although Con Ed loses money on each bulb it sells, it can recover its expenses through electric rates, both for the subsidies it pays and for the lost profits on power it no longer sells. And if it passes certain milestones in energy conservation, it is allowed to earn a higher rate of return on the money its shareholders have invested in the electric system.
 The State Power Authority is nearing the December deadline to decide whether to give final approval to the contract to import 1,000 megawatts from Hydro Quebec. In the past, the utility, which is owned by the province, has supplied up to 10 percent of the state's electricity in normal years.
 A spokesman for Mr. Squadron said that Mr. Dinkins would send a letter today to Richard F. Flynn, the chairman of the Power Authority, seeking a delay in the deadline for approving the contract, to leave time for more analysis of economic and environmental issues.
 
Electricity Market Changed
 Negotiations began in the late 1980's and a preliminary version was signed in 1989. Since then, the electricity market has changed substantially, with conservation measures and independent producers put into direct competition with traditional generators.
 While the cumulative goal of Enlightened Energy is huge, the proposed Hydro Quebec contract would also represent a large chunk of electricity for the state, more than the Indian Point 2 reactor provides. At 1,000 megawatts, it could be the largest block of energy added in the state in this decade.
 Under the contract, the New York Power Authority would sell 200 megawatts to its government customers in southeastern New York, including the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Port Authority and the New York City Housing Authority; 482 megawatts to Con Ed, 218 megawatts to the Long Island Lighting Company, and 100 megawatts to Orange and Rockland Utilities. The Public Service Commission began hearings last week on Con Ed's request for a rate increase, and the role of the proposed contract may come up in testimony this week.
 The agreement would run for 21 years, beginning in May 1995. Con Ed's cost would be $6.1 billion.
 
New Savings Estimates
 Mr. Flynn, the chairman of the Power Authority, once predicted that the contract would save New Yorkers $1 billion. But a spokesman for the authority said last week that with changes since the signing in 1989, that savings estimate was no longer valid, although the savings would still be substantial.
 The city bases its calculations on the costs and savings for Con Ed, assuming that the findings will hold true for the whole contract. The city estimates that one kilowatt of electricity -- the amount needed to keep 10 100-watt light bulbs burning -- will cost $3,551 through the 21 years of the contract with Hydro Quebec, and $721 through energy savings.
 Con Edison calculates the cost differently and reaches a different result, with the energy from Hydro Quebec coming out cheaper. But Con Ed does not dispute the city's method.
 Last Thursday, the New York State Energy Office, Public Service Commission and Department of Environmental Conservation jointly released a draft of their New York State Energy Master Plan, which said that a new contract with Hydro Quebec could raise rates slightly.
 
Debate on Which Plan Is Cleaner
 But shunning the contract, the report said, would increase use of coal, natural gas and imported oil, along with emissions of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, nitrogen oxide, which contributes to smog, and carbon dioxide, which contributes to global warming.
 City officials, on the other hand, argue that increased reliance on conservation and independent power producers could be used to sidestep the nagging environmental questions about new dams in northern Quebec, at a price lower than what the Canadian power would cost.
 Environmental groups have been fighting against the contract. The contract is not tied to any particular project, but would lead Hydro Quebec to build new dams near Hudson Bay to generate the power, flooding the hunting grounds of the Cree Indians.
 New York first seriously sought hydroelectric power from Canada after the oil shock of 1973-74, and again after the oil shortage of 1979. In recent years as much as 40 percent of the state's electricity has come from oil, far higher than the national average. But last year, electricity came in almost equal parts from oil, coal, natural gas, hydroelectricity and nuclear reactors. Natural gas use seems poised to increase in coming years, with new pipelines and new constraints on utilities under the Clean Air Act. Nuclear power will not expand in this decade. Hydroelectricity depends in part on rainfall; this year, New York took very little from Canada because of a drought there.
 Reflecting the changed nature of the utility business, in an interview last week at his office at Con Edison, Mr. Deegan spoke at length about conservation and purchases from other electricity producers. The company began to assemble land on the Hudson River more than a decade ago to build a new generating station of its own some day, but neither Mr. Deegan nor a longtime spokesman for the company, Daniel Walden, could remember at first where the land was. It is in Red Hook.
 Con Ed's newest plant, the Indian Point 2 reactor, went into commercial operation 17 years ago this month.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 5, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about energy conservation policies of New York State's utility companies misidentified the New York City Commissioner of Telecommunications and Energy. He is William F. Squadron.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Note Rate Raised to 8.80% By Ford's Associates Unit

 BODY:
The Associates Corporation of North America, a Dallas-based unit of the Ford Motor Company, increased the interest rate on its $300 million seven-year note issue yesterday to 8.80 percent from 8.75 percent, according to Morgan Stanley & Company, the lead underwriter. Based on the pricing last week, the yield has been increased to 8.829 percent.
The move came because Moody's Investors Service recently placed the debt of Associates under review because of the company's aggressive acquisition policy. Recently Associates said it was purchasing $900 million in assets from the Chase Manhattan Leasing Company. 
 Also, yesterday, Ford Capital B.V., another Ford unit, issued $400 million of noncallable guaranteed notes through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 9 percent notes, which mature Aug. 15, 1998, were priced at 99.571 to yield 9.084 percent, or 118 basis points over Treasury notes of similar maturity. A rating of A2 is expected from Moody's. Ford Motor guarantees the notes.

HEADLINE: Dominican Journal;
Filthy Rich With a New York Cocaine Connection

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO DE MACORIS, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
Almost as if embarrassed by the conspicuous prosperity, an army lieutenant smiles as he speaks of the riches of this city, where sumptuous villas with satellite dishes appear suddenly amid open plains of verdant farmland in a country where per capita income is less than $900 a year.
"San Francisco is the richest place in the republic, not just now, but always," the officer said. "We produce the most rice, the most coffee and the most cocoa. Just ask anyone here and they'll boast about how often they travel to New York -- not to stay there, but just to visit." 
 It is true that these crops, nourished in dark, well-irrigated soils, stoked the growth of this once-sleepy town, now a city of about 300,000, two hours north of Santo Domingo.
But once the ice is broken, most people readily tell visitors that the sprawling new neighborhoods, with their spacious, high-walled, brightly painted homes with two- and three-car garages, are the creation of "Dominican-Yorks," the daring youngsters who make their way to New York where small fortunes are said to be waiting to be made in the local and international drug trades.
 
New Money 'From Over There'
 Elsewhere in this country of seven million people, where virtually everyone has a relative or close friend living in the United States, the term Dominican-York can simply mean anyone who has lived in New York, usually laboring long hours to support a family back home. But in this city the inference is invariably to drug traffickers.
"We have lots of honest people who have earned good livings in farming and commerce, but all of this new money is from over there," said Julio Antonio Gonzeles Burell, who owns the local radio station, H-102 FM. "All of our nouveaux riches earned their money in drugs in New York."
Last month, Dominican police seized a cargo of more than 700 pounds of cocaine on the outskirts of town, where the police say a group of Dominican-Yorks had apparently betrayed their Colombian partners, robbing them of a shipment they themselves were ultimately forced to abandon.
If the drug seizure was spectacular, residents say it was also atypical. Most Dominican-Yorks, they say, lead quiet, almost staid, lives when at home, housing their families in luxury and going out little at night -- for fear, some say, of being assassinated, even though no one could remember the last murder in the city.
Asked why this city was considered a relatively safe haven, a man who identified himself as a Dominican-York and who gave his name only as Pedro, reached under the seat of his fancily stenciled pickup truck for a 9-millimeter pistol and answered with a grin, "Because everyone here has one of these."
Fineta Camilo Fernandez, a local journalist, said, "We are the most corrupt town in the whole country, but generally we have very little crime here."
While the abundance of Dominicans living in the United States has had a profound effect on this island nation's culture, introducing fancy discos, New York fashions and American-inspired argot into the smallest hamlet, it appears that many of those who have gone to work in the drug business have deliberately avoided bringing the most disturbing aspects of their New York way of life home with them. "The unwritten code says that the things they go to do in New York -- violence and drugs -- are O.K. over there, but are not permitted at home," said Wilfredo Lozano, a Dominican sociologist.
Others who have studied the behavior of the Dominican-Yorks say that typically the youngsters, sons of modest families, are sponsored in the drug business in New York by people already living there.
 
Victims of the Violence
 Leading a spartan life in small rented apartments, the workers pursue two- or three-year assignments that can vary from running drugs to performing hits ordered by their superiors. When their debt to a sponsor is paid and they feel they have earned enough money to build a home, most are said to return home.
Sometimes, however, the emigrants fall victim to the violence of New York. San Franciscans say that a man in his early 20's was shot recently before he could return home, but that he had already left enough money for his family to buy a home.
With the remainder, an elaborate funeral was conducted in which the dead man's coffin was escorted in a limousine followed by a band, which played his favorite music as the procession stopped at several popular restaurants where he was toasted before his burial.
"I sell 90 percent of my homes to these people," said Amado Then, who owns a construction company that has thrived on building houses costing three million pesos, or $250,000, paid for with Dominican-York money. "They don't sell the drugs here. They do their business over there and come home to live in peace."
Asked if anyone had tried to stop the growth of the community, Mr. Then said, "They say there is an agreement on sharing information on money flows between the Dominican Republic and the U.S., but up till now that doesn't seem to have stopped anyone."
What does seem to have stopped, or at least slowed, the boom is the economic slowdown in the United States, particularly in New York, and what San Franciscans speculate must be that city's improved law enforcement measures against their traffickers.
"There is a recession and a crackdown in New York, and a lot of killings of our people over there," Mr. Gonzeles said, "All these things have been bad for business. When things in New York begin to fall apart, you can immediately feel our economy falling apart too."

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Allocating Funds For New Therapy

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
HEALTH insurers say they badly need clearer guidelines for allocating the billions of dollars that pay for expensive new medical technology. No one knows exactly how much is at stake, but Government economists estimate that new procedures are adding at least $12 billion annually to national medical spending.
"There is a glut of new technology, and our ability to assess it and determine the appropriate uses has not kept pace with our ability to produce it," said John L. Cova, director of medical technology assessment with the Health Insurance Association of America, an insurers' trade group in Washington. "We are attempting to play catch-up ball." 
Insurers do not usually pay for treatments with experimental drugs, instruments or procedures, holding back until they have been approved as safe and effective. Manufacturers finance research if a new product is involved, and doctors, hospitals and universities contribute time and money. The Government also contributes, but Federal research grants have not kept up with the explosion of new therapies. And in an era of publicized medical "miracles," patients often demand unproven treatments.
When insurers balk, the patients may go to court. A Federal district judge in Alexandria, Va., ruled last year that Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Virginia had to pay for a bone marrow transplant for a breast cancer patient, even though the National Cancer Institute says the procedure's effectiveness has not been proved. The judge said the Blue Cross contract had failed to detail its criteria for refusing payment.
That can be difficult. "From the point of view of science, there is no sharp boundary between what is and is not experimental," said Dr. John E. Wennberg who heads a medical evaluation center at the Dartmouth Medical School. The Public Health Service is taking up the problem.
"Where is the great divide between experimental on one side and the cutting edge or state of the art on the other?" asked Dr. Thomas W. Holohan, director of the Office of Health Technology Assessment in the Federal Agency for Health Care Policy and Research. Insurers, Government officials and spokesmen for doctors, lawyers, educators, ethicists and drug and device makers will seek answers at a conference in November. "There is no real consensus," he said.
Employers and insurers are especially concerned. Dr. John Burns, vice president for health management with Honeywell Inc., which makes electronic control systems, said he had asked Dr. William Vaughan, an authority on bone marrow transplants at the University of Nebraska, for advice on the issue.
"We need a major public dialogue," said Susan Gleeson, executive director of quality assessment at the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association in Chicago. Blue Cross recently pledged $36 million for a large-scale study of autologous bone marrow transplants -- the removal and later reinsertion of bone marrow -- in breast cancer patients after high doses of chemotherapy, which is toxic to blood cells. The National Cancer Institute will analyze the results. It has approved bone marrow transplants for some cancers like leukemia but not for breast cancer.
Most marrow transplants cost at least $100,000, but Ms. Gleeson said a study at Duke University showed that patients could spend 19 days in the hospital instead of the usual 43 days, reducing costs to $75,000.
Doctors note that expensive new procedures often burst on the scene, only to be discarded later. "We spend a lot of money for new applications and shortly find out that this may not be the best place to spend it," said Dr. Robert E. McAfee, a surgeon in Portland, Me., who is vice chairman of the American Medical Association's board of trustees.
He said some surgeons used expensive lasers, for example, when electric cutting might work just as well. "Our system encourages overcapacity," Dr. McAfee added. "A good part of the research comes from the private sector. One has to be careful not to allow any special interest of the funder to interfere with the impartial assessment of a new technique."
Unlike drugs and devices, medical procedures like surgery do not come under Food and Drug Administration rules. "Even the definition of whether something is research or not is left almost entirely to the discretion of the surgeon," said Arthur L. Caplan, director of the University of Minnesota biomedical ethics center.
Dr. Wennberg and a group of Dartmouth and Harvard scientists have been working with the American Urological Association, a physician specialty group, to develop tests for a variety of treatments currently used for prostate hyperplasia, one of the most common surgical procedures. He said they were seeking Federal money and help from insurers for full-scale clinical trials. Having doctors and researchers as sponsors, Dr. Wennberg said, "provides a scientific umbrella to deal with the complexities and any conflicts of interest."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Rivals in Travel Industry Encouraged by Joint Drive

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
IN the spring, battered by war and recession, leading hotels, airlines, car-rental companies and other travel-related businesses joined forces for the first time, setting aside traditional rivalries to promote travel.
Now, encouraged by the campaign's results, top executives of these companies are working to hold this coalition together. 
 A total of 61 marketers contributed about $7 million toward a print and broadcast ad campaign produced by FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York. The membership of Go USA! The Travel Coalition, as the organization is called, includes usually fierce competitors like the Hilton, Holiday Inn and Marriott hotel chains; American, Delta and United airlines; Hertz, Avis and Budget car-renters; American Express and Visa U.S.A. charge-card companies, and the Walt Disney and Universal Studios theme-park operators.
"It was amazing that all these companies pulled together to try and get travel jump-started for the spring and summer," J. W. (Bill) Marriott Jr., chairman of the Marriott Corporation and head of the coalition, said in a telephone interview. "And I think we ought to keep it together."
The coalition's campaign, which carried the theme "Travel moves people," was aimed primarily at business travelers who were citing the war and/or the recession as reasons to cancel or postpone traveling for business within the United States.
One print ad had the headline "You can't shake hands with a fax," while a radio commercial promoted "the special feeling that comes only from being there."
The coalition united "competitors who literally never talked to one another," said Laurel Cutler, vice chairman of FCB/Leber Katz, which also handles Marriott's advertising, "to do a job they never could have done on their own." She expects the members to keep the coalition intact, "and when it is appropriate to do something together," she added, "they will."
Though "it is awfully hard" to measure the effectiveness of the campaign, Mr. Marriott says he believes it did "reasonably well." "Occupancy in our hotels is better than it was a year ago," he said, "and we are starting to see some pretty good improvements in some parts of the country."
"It helped, but I don't think it was a total answer," Mr. Marriott continued. "The recession was stronger than we thought it would be."
The coalition sponsored two surveys to gauge the impact of the campaign. One, conducted by the Wirthlin Group, showed that 53 percent of the traveling public and 67 percent of frequent business travelers were aware of the campaign, which ended its run in May.
That survey also found that 20 percent of the traveling public and 17 percent of frequent business travelers specifically noted the coalition by name -- very high figures, Wirthlin says, given the campaign's duration.
As the campaign concluded, coalition members decided to spend about $500,000 to expand the reach of their message to business travelers overseas. A newspaper ad was produced showing Andrew Jackson's face on a $20 bill surrounded by faces from other countries' currencies. The headline: "Face to face is the best way to do business in the U.S."
"We always thought that 'Go USA!' had the potential to mean 'Go to the USA!' " said David Curtis, executive vice president and creative director at FCB/Leber Katz.
Enticing more international visitors here is a project that Mr. Marriott cited as an example of what the coalition might do in the future.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Worldwide; Gold Advances in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined on world currency markets yesterday, falling sharply against the German mark.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose 60 cents, settling at $356.20 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $356.35 an ounce, up 15 cents from Friday. 
 The dollar was under pressure worldwide, but a wave of technical selling was prompted by a drop in the dollar below 1.73 German marks.
In New York, the dollar lost nearly 3 pfennigs, settling at 1.7168 marks, down from 1.7415, and traders expected further declines.
"The fundamental impetus for the decline is the interest rate differential," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at Algemene Bank Nederland. The consensus is that the United States has room to lower interest rates, while the Germans are not only expected to hold rates steady but also possibly raise them.
Separately, the United States credit markets have been rallying, pushing bond prices higher while interest rates decline. That also has a negative effect on the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors.
"It looks like the dollar will continue to drop since there is nothing on the horizon to alter its course," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the financial advisory firm IDEA.
But the market is ignoring two factors that have the potential to support the dollar -- the continuing scandal in Japanese securities industry and the political turmoil in Yugoslavia, Mr. McCarthy said. Both have the potential to attract dollar buyers on the theory that the dollar is a haven in times of world distress.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 137.30 yen, down 0.23 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted lower at 136.55 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 136.65 yen, down from 137.20 on Friday.
The British pound was quoted at $1.7095, up from $1.6945 late on Friday. In New York, it cost $1.7110 to buy a pound, up from $1.6890 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late rates, included: 1.4960 Swiss francs, down from 1.5147; 5.8410 French francs, down from 5.9210; 1,283.68 Italian lire, down from 1,301.50, and 1.1495 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1505.

HEADLINE: Taxpayer Role Sought In Bailing Out Banks

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Buried in the debate over bank reform is a struggle involving Congress, the White House and the Federal Reserve over whether taxpayers should be given a permanent role in paying for future bank bailouts.
Congress has never granted any agency a blank check to spend taxpayer money in private-sector bailouts; a special law has financed each rescue. But in a strange twist to a reform movement intended to shield taxpayers, the House and Senate Banking Committees would change the rules so that taxpayers henceforth absorb some of the cost of rescuing commercial banks.
 
Softened Senate Bill
 The original bills were much tougher on taxpayers than the version that emerged on Friday from the Senate Banking Committee -- a version negotiated by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, that preserves taxpayers' responsibility in principle, but in practice might drain away little public money. A consensus appears to be emerging in Congress for the mild Senate version. But whatever the actual language, the Fed and the White House have said in recent days that they will go along with a Congressional desire to recognize a taxpayer role.
The goal in Congress is to discipline the Fed, reflecting wide discontent with the Fed's practice of propping up failing banks. By forcing the Fed to draw on public funds when it lends to some weak banks, Congress hopes the central bank will become more reluctant to make loans from its "discount window" -- especially if they extend the life of a dying bank, adding to a bailout's cost.
"The Fed would be forced to think twice about making the no-brainer kinds of loans it is now making," said Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.
The House and Senate panels would alter a practice that has existed since the 1930's: having the banking industry alone bear the cost of bailouts through premiums paid to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Fed, after lending money to banks that later collapsed, has always gone to the F.D.I.C. for reimbursement.
Now, the House Banking Committee, in a bill approved in June, and the Senate committee's milder provision, adopted on Friday, would require the Federal Reserve to justify lending to some banks in danger of failing and to draw on taxpayer funds if the loans exceeded certain limits set by Congress.
The Fed endorsed the tougher House version before the Senate acted on Friday. The Fed governors have not considered the Senate version, a spokesman said yesterday. A White House official yesterday praised the Senate version, mostly because the Senate dealt more to the White House's liking with the separate issue of rescuing big banks.
"We think 'too big to fail' rescues should be done, but only in extraordinary cases of risk to the economy," said Robert R. Glauber, a Treasury under secretary. "The Senate bill provides the necessary hurdles."
The American Bankers Association, representing the nation's 12,000 commercial banks, did not pick between House and Senate versions, but is lobbying for the principle that taxpayers, as well as the banking industry, must pay the cost of failures.
The association's support for a taxpayer role is understandable: Its insurance fund is nearly gone and the premiums paid by the nation's banks have tripled in recent years, to 23 cents for each $100 of deposits.
 
Study of Practices
 A House Banking Committee study, released in June, spotlighted the Fed's lending practices. The report found that over the last six years, the Fed had made loans to more than 300 banks that ultimately failed. The Fed has not challenged this. The resulting extra losses from extending the lives of dying banks were less than $2 billion over five years, said L. William Seidman, the F.D.I.C. chairman.
If Congress does, in fact, approve legislation that restricts Fed lending, the depositors most likely to be affected are those with uninsured funds -- more than $100,000 a depositor -- in a failing bank.
The Fed, by keeping a weak bank afloat, gives depositors time to transfer uninsured funds to healthy banks. If a weak bank was closed more quickly, people might not have time to do this.
Allowing deposits to migrate can make a bailout more costly. When the bank does fail or is merged, the F.D.I.C. has lost the opportunity to draw on uninsured deposits to help reimburse insured depositors or subsidize the merger.
"The principle on which most of the people in Congress are operating is to try to prevent us from covering depositors over $100,000," Mr. Seidman said.
 
Limits on Lending
 The House bill, in a key provison, limits to five days the period of time that the Federal Reserve can make loans to a bank whose capital, or available cash, falls below 2 percent of its outstanding loans. Any lending beyond five days would not be eligible for reimbursement. And the Fed could not collect collateral from the bank to assure F.D.I.C. reimbursement.
Instead, the money would have to come from the Fed's reserves. If it was lost, the Federal Reserve would have less to give the Treasury to help pay Government expenses, in effect putting more of a burden on taxpayers.
The House bill also permits the Treasury to rule whether a given bank's sudden failure would damage the financial system or a regional economy. Such a designation -- known as "too big to fail" -- would, when reported to Congress, enable the Fed to lend money to the bank to keep it going until a buyer could be found or the bank could be closed in some orderly fashion. The recent bailout of the Bank of New England is this sort of case. But under the House bill, the money would have to come from the Fed's pocket.
 
Compromise Is Accepted
 The original Senate version would have imposed even tougher restrictions, requiring the Fed to lend from its own pocket to any "significantly undercapitalized" bank, whatever the period of time. But on Friday, the committee accepted a compromise pushed by Senator Gramm.
If a loan of, say, $10 million to an undercapitalized bank goes beyond the five-day limit or some other specified period, and the money is lost in a failure, the Fed would have to pay from its own pocket only the lost interest, say $400,000, but not the principal, as in the House version. The F.D.I.C. would repay the principal.
The Gramm compromise also changed the too-big-to-fail provision, requiring more public debate than the House version. Under the Senate provision, not only the Treasury, but also the President and five of the Fed's seven governors, must decide that a bank is too big to fail. Only then can the Treasury advance to the Fed the money to keep the bank temporarily alive. But the payout would not come from the taxpayers' pocket; the Treasury would eventually recover the outlay through a special assessment on commercial banks.
 
Champions of Restrictions
 The Congressional goal of restricting the Fed is set forth most passionately by Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, chairman of the House Banking Committee, and Senator Riegle. This camp argues that the Fed too frequently tries to prolong the lives of banks that are clearly doomed and, as Mr. Gonzalez puts it, is "cavalier" in failing to report its lending practices to Congress.
Still, Senator Riegle's committee accepted a compromise put forth on Friday by Senator Gramm that assigned most of the bailout expense to the F.D.I.C. while preserving the principle of Fed accountability.
"We never intended that the taxpayer should play a role; it is an unfortunate byproduct of an attempt to change the Fed's incentives," said Patrick Lawler, chief economist for the Senate Banking Committee. "We think we now have something that deals with incentives, without putting any appreciable burden on the taxpayer."
Although the Fed is not publicly fighting the Congressional effort, the restrictions run counter to the Fed's view of its role as an independent supplier of emergency funds.
"I don't know that we are jumping up and down with joy, but we can understand what they are trying to do and we can live with it," John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor, said last week. "But my own view is that the lack of any discretionary flexibility is a mistake. One of the principal reasons for the Fed's existence is to provide emergency liquidity."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Little Changed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Treasury note and bond prices were little changed yesterday as dealers and investors were plotting strategies for the flurry of Treasury auctions that start today.
"With no economic news of import, the market is preoccupied with gauging demand for the Treasury auctions," said one Treasury note trader. 
 In the days and hours before the 1 P.M. auctions, securities dealers survey their clients to determine what level of interest rates would attract investors. The dealers' goal is to buy the securities at the lowest possible price, but not submit bids so low that the securities are awarded to other firms.
In advance of today's $14 billion sale of three-year Treasury notes, dealers offered the issue in the wholesale market with a yield of about 7.01 percent, down from 7.03 percent late Friday. For the 10-year notes to be sold tomorrow the yield is a full percentage point higher at about 8.02 percent, down from 8.03 percent late Friday.
 
Long-Term Treasury Bonds
 Among long-term Treasury bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue due in 2021 rose1/4 point yesterday, and closed with an offered price of 98 30/32, to yield 8.22 percent. Late last week, the bellwether Treasury bond yield was 8.24 percent. On Thursday, the Treasury auctioned $12 billion of new 30-year bonds.
In the short-term market, the Federal Reserve did not make any move to signal a push to reduce short-term rates, as some traders were hoping. But even in the absence of a visible Fed move, expectations of lower rates were enough that rates fell slightly at yesterday's regular auction of Treasury bills.
The new three-month bills sold at an average rate of 5.51 percent, down from 5.58 percent last week, while six-month bills were 5.59 percent, down from 5.69 percent.
Prior to this week's offering of $750 million of New York City bonds to be handled by Merrill Lynch & Company, securities dealers tentatively set interest rates ranging from about 7.60 percent for bonds due in 1995 to 7.90 percent in 2000, 8 percent in 2003 and 8.20 percent or slightly less in 2012. The official interest rates and prices for the bonds are expected tomorrow.
Yields on the city's bonds are much lower than March of this year, when bonds due in 20 years and longer were trading around 8.60 percent. Since yields for long-term bonds have fallen only about a quarter of a percentage point in that period, New York City bonds have improved relative to the rest of the market.
Jeffrey B. Augustine, portfolio manager at the Colonial New York Tax-Exempt Trust, said the strength in New York City bonds was due to "the fact that despite fiscal siege, they did meet the deadline for presenting a plan for a balanced budget." In additon, he noted that the supply of bonds issues by all local governments and authorities in New York State had fallen sharply. Since local buyers of a high tax state like New York absorb the vast majority of local government issues, changes in the supply of securities can cause significant changes in prices.
Mr. Augustine noted that data compiled by The Bond Buyer, a trade paper covering municipal finance, show that the volume of bonds by New York governments and authorities fell to only $434 million in July from $2.2 billion in February.
 
New York City Financing
 The city's financing also includes taxable bonds, meaning that bond interest payments are subject to Federal income tax. For taxable bonds due in 10 years, securities dealers said yesterday that the yield could be about 2.40 percentage points greater than 10-year Treasury securities, or slightly less than 10.5 percent based on yesterday's market conditions.
For New York investors who want bonds with interest payments exempt from state, city, and Federal income tax, but prefer higher-quality securities than offered by New York City, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is expected to offer $370 million of new bonds later this week. Underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds expect to announce interest rates on the bonds Thursday. Because interest and principal on the Triborough bonds will be insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, they will be rated triple A and carry much lower yields than New York City bonds. Other triple A rated, M.B.I.A. insured bonds due in about 13 years have been traded recently at about 6.85 percent, or about 1.15 percentage points lower than the yield expected for New York City bonds of similar maturity.
The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority plans to sell another $245 million of uninsured bonds about 30 days after this week's sale.
Following are results of yesterday's auctions of new Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Our Towns

BYLINE: By Wayne King

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
The flock is always sparse on a weekday, but the Rev. Michael Doyle believes that Mass is a wonderful way to start the day. So he says the Mass and has communion at Sacred Heart even though there are only two of the devout there to share it.
Carmella Labato, who has lived only a block or so away from the church for 77 years, is one of them -- the other is the church secretary -- and Mrs. Labato leads the prayer. She prays for the 230 children who attend the parish school, for everyone in her family, for Father Doyle and everyone in the church, many of whom she names, for all the cars parked around the church that they be protected from vandals, and for two bills pending in Trenton, one to reduce everyone's sewer bills and the other to allow the church to create a credit union. 
 "Amen," says Father Doyle.
"Carmella says a wonderful prayer," he observes. "She prays for absolutely everything."
Indeed, there is much to pray for in South Camden, the poorest, grittiest of neighborhoods in what is conceded to be the poorest and grittiest city in New Jersey, huddled on the banks of the Delaware in the Philadelphia shadows.
It is by most standards a depressing neighborhood, dominated by a huge scrap-metal yard and a sewage-treatment plant and a trash incinerator that seem to symbolize its fall from grace as a bustling blue-collar economic power a half-century and more ago. Its shipyard is long gone, and more recently Campbell Soup and RCA also fled for more promising climes.
So South Camden, in decline for years, now has almost nothing left. Its streets are bleak and shabby, lined with boarded-up homes, snaggletoothed and burned out, empty warehouses and vacant lots choked by weeds.
But Father Doyle somehow sees beauty in it. "It's panther beauty," he says in his soft Irish burr.
Panther beauty?
"Yes," he says. "Beauty you don't want to mess with."
At 56 years old, an Irish priest who left the little town of Longford to come to America 23 years ago and landed in Camden, Father Doyle is the spiritual engine driving a small renaissance in decaying South Camden.
Last week, Heart of Camden Inc., which is Sacred Heart's own neighborhood housing authority, completed renovation of the 48th house it has reclaimed from the rubble in the past five years, with the help of prison inmates, Sacred Heart's own parishioners, volunteers from suburban churches and anyone else who can swing a hammer or lay a brick.
The church is also the driving force behind a citywide effort by a coalition of churches to protect poor neighborhoods from continued proliferation of unwanted projects like the county trash incinerator, a state prison and the huge sewage-treatment plant that loom across a vacant lot from Sacred Heart.
The coalition blocked a second prison and successfully lobbied for a bill in the legislature that would allow compensation to residents who live near the treatment plant.
"Carmella has been praying for that one for three years," observed Father Doyle. It now awaits Gov. Jim Florio's signature. Mrs. Labato is now praying for legislation the coalition is pressing that would allow the 18 member churches to create credit unions to serve the poor who now cannot get loans or even cash their meager checks.
Besides the abandoned houses it is renovating, the church acquired a vacant lot from the city for a neighborhood garden. Father Doyle admits he simply put a fence around it first and then set about negotiating a lease.
"Well, you know, if we hadn't fenced it," says the good father, who denies any larcenous intent, "it would have just been filled up with people dumping their trash."
Though fenced, the garden, in the middle of blocks of squalor, is recently acquired and yet to be planted by the people. The soil, like the neighborhood, is depleted, and Father Doyle says it must be fertilized and renewed before it is properly planted in the spring.
But even so, there is life already, rough grass and weeds pushing through. "The life always comes through," says Father Doyle, who says he finds that alone sustaining. "That's the beauty."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rev. Michael Doyle, who is a spiritual engine driving a small renaissance in decaying South Camden, N.J. (Sal DiMarco for The New York Times)
