HEADLINE: B.C.C.I.'s Best Customer Is Also Its Worst Customer

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 5

 BODY:
At the heart of the scandals surrounding the Bank of Credit and Commerce International are three Pakistani brothers, the Gokals, whose tangled finances, soured loans and powerful political connections here are subjecting their powerful but publicity-shy family to unwanted attention from investigators from around the world.
The Gokal brothers, through a collection of shipping companies known as the Gulf Group, were the bank's largest customer -- as well as principal bad debtor, according to auditors who have reviewed B.C.C.I.'s records for the Bank of England, Britain's central bank and top banking regulator. 
 Investigators say the Gokals may owe B.C.C.I. more than $700 million and that loans to the brothers and their companies were made through false documents and surreptitious money transfers involving nearly 750 B.C.C.I. accounts.
False documents and sour loans dominated the books of B.C.C.I., regulators and auditors say. But the story of the Gokals provides one answer to the question many regulators have asked: Where did all the money go? B.C.C.I. is insolvent by at least $5 billion, auditors say, a staggering amount for a bank that had reported assets of $20 billion.
 
Bankruptcy Is Reported
 The European-based shipping empire created by the three brothers -- Abbas, Murtaza and Mustafa, who left Pakistan together nearly 30 years ago -- is now said to be on the verge of collapse.
Shipping industry publications in Europe have reported that a Luxembourg-based holding company for the Gokals, Gulf International Holdings, filed in Luxembourg for protection from its creditors in early July, just as bank regulators in seven nations seized B.C.C.I.'s operations in more than 60 countries and accused it of widespread fraud.
Pakistani businessmen acquainted with the Gokals suggest that much of the explanation for the collapse of B.C.C.I. may lie in a secretive financial alliance struck years ago between the brothers and the bank's Pakistani founder, Aga Hassan Abedi.
The partnership extends back to at least 1976, when one of the Gokal brothers tried -- and failed -- to buy a small New York City bank, with the backing of Mr. Abedi's bank.
The extended Gokal family, which numbers in the hundreds, remains something of a financial dynasty in Karachi, the Pakistani port city that is the nation's financial capital.
The Gokals have refused to comment on their connections to the bank or on the condition of their shipping business. "They are very private men, and they don't like to see their names in the newspapers," said a London spokesman for the brothers.
Mr. Abedi, who is ailing after two heart attacks and a heart transplant, has declined interview requests from foreign journalists.
In brief interviews with Pakistani reporters, Mr. Abedi, who remains a visionary hero to many of his countrymen despite the scandal surrounding the bank, has said that the troubles that brought down B.C.C.I. began only after he left the bank in 1988.
 
First Stop: Iraq
 The saga of the Gokal brothers begins in the early 1960's, when the young Pakistanis, seeing the limitations of Pakistan's economy, joined with an uncle to set up a trading company in Iraq.
Family members interviewed in Pakistan said the trading company was successful, but the brothers were forced to leave Iraq after the 1968 revolution that brought the Baath Party to power and led eventually to the installation of President Saddam Hussein. The uncle was reported to have been executed in Iraq.
The brothers fled to Europe, where they began a shipping business that transported dry cargos, including grain and cement from the subcontinent of Asia to Europe and the Middle East.
With the assistance of large loans from B.C.C.I., the business grew into a shipping empire that rivaled any in the world, with more than 150 vessels in its fleet by the mid-1970's.
It was in 1976 that Abbas Gokal traveled to New York and sought permission from banking authorities in New York State to purchase a small bank, Chelsea National, with the assistance of B.C.C.I.
In a telephone interview today from New York, John G. Heimann, who had been the state's banking superintendent and is now an executive with Merrill Lynch & Company, said he recalled an "awfully strange" meeting with Mr. Gokal.
"Mr. Gokal was in the shipping business, and he made no pretense of having any experience in banking," Mr. Heimann said. "He indicated he would be heavily relying for advice, counsel and guidance on B.C.C.I."
Mr. Heimann said he had turned down the application because of Mr. Gokal's admitted lack of banking experience and because of concern that B.C.C.I., with its many operations scattered around the world, lacked a "primary regulator" responsible for assuring its adherence to international banking practices.
 
A Potential Front Man?
 Mr. Heimann said he now suspects that Mr. Gokal may not have wanted the bank for himself but was instead acting as a front for B.C.C.I., which went on to take control of other American banks including one in New York. That bank became part of First American Bankshares Inc. of Washington, which the Federal Reserve Board says B.C.C.I. purchased by lending money to a group of Middle East investors who were "front men" for B.C.C.I.
"As I look back now and learn that B.C.C.I. had an extraordinary relationship with the Gokals, it just gives rise to the speculation that he was buying it for B.C.C.I., but I didn't know that at the time," Mr. Heimann said.
Pakistani businessmen said that some of the rapid growth at B.C.C.I. and at the Gokals' shipping enterprises could be explained through their mutual ties to the Government of Pakistan -- specifically, to the nation's former leader, Gen. Zia ul-Haq.
"If you look closely you could find that Zia helped the Gokals, the Gokals helped Abedi and the bank, and Abedi and the bank helped Zia's Government," said a shipping executive in Karachi.
In the early 1980's, Mustafa Gokal was appointed by General Zia as his chief shipping adviser, a role that gave Mr. Gokal expansive powers over Pakistan's merchant shipping industry.
 
Zia Intervenes
 According to news reports in Pakistan, it was Mr. Abedi who introduced Mustafa Gokal to General Zia and recommended Mr. Gokal for the shipping post.
Mr. Gokal's tenure as shipping adviser would later come under intense scrutiny by a parliamentary committee investigating corruption in General Zia's martial-law Government.
According to the committee's investigators, General Zia intervened in 1981 and 1982 to provide a shipping company owned by Mr. Gokal with a $75 million Government contract to transport Australian wheat, even though there had been a far lower bid on the job.
News reports at the time said that Mr. Gokal denied any impropriety in the awarding of the contract, and he was never charged with any crime. General Zia was killed in a 1988 plane crash.
The general and Mr. Abedi were close, and General Zia was considered a good friend of the bank. His son once worked as a B.C.C.I. executive in the Persian Gulf emirate of Dubai.
 
Sapped by Diversification
 Karachi shipping officials say the Gokals' troubles had begun when the brothers diversified in the late 1980's into oil, foreign exchange and other riskier markets.
"They were considered good shippers, among the very best," said a Karachi shipping agent. "They should have stayed in shipping."
As the Gokals' losses grew in the late 1980's, so too grew their debt to B.C.C.I., which was at the same time coming under scrutiny by regulators and other investigators who suspected that the bank was dealing with drug smugglers and arms dealers.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Sales of cars and trucks made in North America fell 9.2 percent in late July, but analysts, dealers and industry executives continued to express optimism that the market for new vehicles was climbing out of a recessionary trough. [Page D1.]
The nation's military contractors and their lobbyists, under intense pressure from sharply shrinking Pentagon budgets and the collapse of cold war tensions, have developed new and in some ways more aggressive strategies than ever to tailor their tactics to the changing times. [A1.] 
 Buried in the debate over bank reform is a struggle involving Congress, the White House and the Federal Reserve over whether taxpayers should be given a permanent role in paying for future bank bailouts. [D1.]
 
COMPANIES
Chase Manhattan plans to sell most of its leasing businesses in the U.S. and Canada to four finance companies, including subsidiaries of General Electric and Ford Motor. The sales will reduce Chase's asset size by about $2.2 billion. [D1.]
Andrew Lloyd Webber is selling a stake in his company to Polygram. The European record company agreed to acquire a 30 percent interest in Really Useful Holdings for about $117 million. [D1.]
Macy said sales in stores at least a year old had risen 0.2 percent, after three straight quarters of declining sales. But sales for the year were down. [D3.]
Time Warner's $2.75 billion rights offering expired. It was the last day rights holders could buy a share for $80. [D17.]
Anheuser-Busch will move the advertising for Michelob to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. [D18.]
 
INTERNATIONAL

HEADLINE: BAGHHAD REVEALS IT HAD PLUTONIUM OF WEAPONS GRADE

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Iraq has disclosed that its scientists were secretly able to extract a small amount of plutonium, suitable for making an atomic bomb, from spent fuel at a nuclear installation whose operations came under international safeguards, United Nations officials said today.
Officials said the disclosure was troubling new evidence that Iraq's efforts to produce a nuclear weapon were significantly more extensive than previously known, even given Baghdad's piecemeal acknowledgements to United Nations monitors since the Persian Gulf war. 
 The latest disclosure and a separate new admission by Iraq that it had deliberately misled United Nations inspectors about a secret biological weapons program raise new doubts about Baghdad's willingness to forswear weapons of mass destruction.
 
Meeting on Sanctions
 Further, the disclosure about the plutonium extraction calls into question the effectiveness of international efforts to monitor ostensibly peaceful nuclear programs to prevent the spread of nuclear arms.
The disclosures came as the Security Council was meeting today on whether to lift the sanctions imposed against Iraq, a move that Baghdad insists is vital to its reconstruction. Officials said such a step was unlikely now in light of the new information.
Robert L. Gallucci, the deputy chairman of the United Nations commission charged with eliminating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, said that the Iraqis in recent days acknowledged extracting three grams of plutonium from spent fuel in a small research reactor at Tuwaitha, an industrial town outside Baghdad. He said that the amount was far short of the quantity needed to produce a nuclear weapon and that Baghdad denied it was meant for a bomb.
 
'A Very Serious Matter'
 Mr. Gallucci said, however, that the disclosure clearly confirmed that Iraq had been able to obtain nuclear-weapons-grade material in a laboratory that had been under United Nations scrutiny even before the gulf war. He said the plutonium extraction had begun before the war.
"This is a very serious matter," Mr. Gallucci said. "The facility was under safeguards, but the activity was not reported. It is of concern whenever practice that should be safeguarded is done outside of safeguards."
Mr. Gallucci also said United Nations inspectors now in Iraq were looking for electronic triggers necessary to detonate a nuclear bomb. Baghdad has not declared any of the devices, but is believed to have acquired them.
After the war, Iraq, which as a signer of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty had already committed itself to international safeguards and inspections, at first denied having any programs to process uranium. But in recent months, as it has sought to have United Nations trade sanctions lifted, Iraq has disclosed three secret uranium processing programs. Today's disclosure about the plutonium is the fourth program that could have been meant to develop a nuclear bomb.
Even before today's new information, the United States had criticized Iraq's disclosures as inadequate, saying they concealed the true extent of its weapons programs. Washington has not ruled out new military attacks to finally destroy them, although it has had trouble achieving a consensus among its gulf war allies over any new use of force.
Paul L. Leventhal, president of th Nuclear Control Institute in Washington, said today's revelation was the clearest and strongest to date that Iraq was on the track toward developing a nuclear bomb.
"This represents fair warning," he said.
Since its defeat in the gulf war, Iraq has been required under the United Nations cease-fire resolution to list all types, amounts and locations of chemical and biological weapons, as well as all material that could be used in making nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles. In April, Iraq informed the United Nations that a substantial arsenal of chemical and ballistic weapons survived the war, but it denied having nuclear arms, nuclear-weapons-grade materials or biological weapons.
Mr. Leventhal said the acknowledgement of a plutonium-processing program was significant because, though it is extracted by a procedure "messier" than trying to build a bomb from enriched uranium, it also is one that is easier to conceal.
"In some ways plutonium is the preferable material because you don't need as much of it for a bomb," he said.
Mr. Leventhal said about eight kilograms of plutonium -- which can be chemically separated from spent fuel from a research or production reactor -- are needed to make an imploding nuclear device, compared with about 25 kilograms of highly enriched uranium.
"Presumably they're processing their own spent fuel," he said, which means Iraq could easily keep such a program hidden from international inspectors.
Mr. Gallucci said Iraq, as required under the nonproliferation treaty, had told the International Atomic Energy Agency about the reactor at Tuwaitha, which is just southeast of Baghdad. But it had operated the plutonium separation clandestinely.
Other officials said that Tuwaitha was one of the sites on the United Nations inspection team's list and that the Iraqis had probably decided to acknowledge operating the secret plutonium program there rather than have the inspectors learn this on their own.
Most experts agree that unless Iraq could greatly expand and improve its uranium-separation capacity, its production of uranium-fueled weapons is years away.
Plutonium has certain advantages over uranium as a bomb fuel. It is denser than uranium, and less of it is needed to achieve "critical mass," the weight above which a chain nuclear reaction begins.
 
Process Would Take Years
 But the amount of plutonium that can be produced by treating the spent wastes of an ordinary nuclear power reactor is limited by the size and capacity of the reactor, the rate at which it is kept running and other factors. If Iraq has only purified three grams of the silvery, white metal, its production rate is presumably so low that it would take years to make one bomb.
United Nations officials said Baghdad also has admitted that it falsely stated that a plant at Salman Pak near the capital was used for food analysis when in fact it was used for biological weapons research. The Iraqis said they had withheld the information until now "because it would have been misconstrued by the world at large."
The admissions were both made within the last several days to the 28-member Special Commission team that arrived in Iraq on Friday to check the country's claims that it does not possess biological warfare capability.
 
'Fairly Horrific Facts'
 The British representative to the Security Council, Sir David Hannay, described the new revelations as "fairly horrific facts" that once again brought suspicion on Baghdad.
"The vast majority of the council has taken the view that there's no justification for changes in the sanctions regime," Sir David told reporters as he left the council meeting today.
The Iraqi report -- delivered as the first step toward the compulsory destruction of its chemical, biological and nuclear weapons sites -- said it had nearly 10,000 nerve-gas warheads, 1,000 tons of nerve and mustard gas, nearly 1,500 chemical weapons bombs and shells, 52 Scud missiles and 30 chemical and conventional warheads.
The United States challenged Iraq's claims as understated, saying American intelligence reports showed that Iraq was researching and developing biological weapons at a number of sites, including the Salman Pak plant, 22 miles southeast of Baghdad.
 
Secretary General Reports
 The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, told Security Council members today that Iraq had informed the inspection team late last week that it had carried out biological research for defensive military purposes at Salman Pak. The Iraqis said the research began in 1986 and ended in August 1990, at which time all the nerve agents were destroyed.
"The Iraqi Government had previously notified the Special Commission that the purpose of the Salman Pak facility was the inspection and analysis of foods and liquids for human consumption, and for identifying chemical and biological contamination by laboratory diagnosis," Mr. Perez de Cuellar told Security Council members during the meeting.

HEADLINE: For Israel, Navigator Of Finance

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The Israeli economy is at a crossroads, and the man chosen to lead it out of the socialist wilderness is a well-connected economist who favors hard money, open trade and free markets.
After about 20 years in the United States, Jacob Frenkel, 48 years old, is returning to Israel on Aug. 15 to become head of Israel's central bank and the Government's top economic adviser -- the "compass and conscience," as one former governor of the Bank of Israel put it, of the country's economic policy. 
 Mr. Frenkel, who is now chief economist at the International Monetary Fund in Washington, spent most of his academic career in a redoubt of laissez-faire thinking, the University of Chicago economics department.
But Mr. Frenkel is no ideologue. He points fondly to a giant bust in his office of John Maynard Keynes, the groundbreaking British economist who was an opponent of laissez-faire thinking and the patron saint of government interventionists. And he prides himself on being a pragmatist.
 
Little Growth, Much Inflation
 The appointment of a respected professional with no apparent political ties is widely seen as a sign that Israel's politically gridlocked Government is still committed, even if with mixed feelings, to economic restructuring.
Although Israel has thriving private enterprises, its welfare state swallow up nearly half the nation's gross national product. The Government controls a big chunk of industry. And Israel's labor market, dominated by big union federations, is hamstrung by restrictive practices. The result: too little growth and too much inflation in the last couple of decades.
In early July, a fact-finding mission from the International Monetary Fund complained that the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was not moving fast enough with its reform program. The mission also raised concerns about "a major risk" of inflation and too much government largess.
Mr. Frenkel made it clear that he shared these concerns. "Between the I.M.F. team and Israeli economists," he said, "there is complete agreement on the key principles."
 
Some Changes Under Way
 At the moment, the I.M.F. team said, the Israeli economy is growing briskly. Some reforms, especially freeing up financial markets, eliminating Government subsidies and lowering import barriers, are under way.
"Things are moving in the right direction, said Michael Bruno, Mr. Frenkel's tough-minded predecessor. "Too slowly, but there is an improvement, nonetheless."
What makes economic change a burning issue these days is that Israel must create hundreds of thousands of new jobs to make room for the flood of new Soviet emigres -- as many as one million. If the economy cannot absorb the emigres, more than 200,000 of whom have already arrived, the nation risks losing a vital human resource that could fuel future economic growth.
Recently, unemployment has reached almost 10 percent and, more likely than not, will head even higher. Israelis worry that, without radical reforms, job growth will be so sluggish that more Soviet Jews will be discouraged from coming or that young Israelis will leave.
 
A Lot of Influence'
 In Mr. Frenkel's view, making Israel more attractive to foreign investors, selling state-run companies and loosening labor-market restrictions deserve top priority as a way to encourage job growth in private enterprise. To be avoided: establishing big new state job programs that create deficits and, ultimately, higher inflation.
Mr. Frenkel's views are likely to command a wide audience, people involved in Israeli economic policy say.
"He'll bring a lot of influence to the job; his opinion will be very much respected," said Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Richard M. Nixon.
"He's an economist who's sat at the bedsides of sick economies all over the world," said Richard T. McCormack, former Under Secretary of the Treasury. "The I.M.F. is the doctor to sick economies. He knows what works, what doesn't."
Because Israel expects the refugees to arrive within a few years, it intends to borrow much of the money it will need abroad. To improve the loan terms, Israel is seeking $10 billion in loan guarantees from the United States.
 
U.S. Treasury to Back Debt
 Under such guarantees, the United States Treasury would promise to repay creditors if Israel were to default on its debt. The guarantees would pry open global capital markets.
"It would be seen as a vote of confidence in Israel's capacity to manage its debt," Mr. Frenkel said.
Helena Hessel, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, said Israel has never floated bonds on international capital markets other than below-market-rate bonds sold primarily to supporters of Israel.
At this juncture, Mr. Frenkel's popularity among the movers and shakers making policy in many countries is likely to be a major asset.
"Jacob knows everybody," said Stanley Fischer, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a longtime adviser to the Israelis. "That is very important for Israel. They're really trying to get back into the international community."
 
To Face a Major Test
 Mr. Frenkel indicates that he will make maintaining the gains of Israel's 1985 battle against hyperinflation a priority. Inflation, once over 500 percent, has been running 15 to 20 percent.
He will face a major test within weeks of his arrival. The Finance Minister will present the 1992 budget to the Cabinet in September. Mr. Frenkel said that he will fight to hold the line on spending and to gain a commitment now to lower deficits in the future.
"Jacob talks, he's easy, he appears flexible," said Rudiger Dornbusch, who has known Mr. Frenkel since the two were students at the University of Chicago. "But don't arm-wrestle him."
Born in Tel Aviv, Mr. Frenkel worked his way through college cutting and polishing diamonds. As a University of Chicago graduate student, his sharp insights in international economics so impressed his professors, including Milton Friedman, that he was invited to join the faculty in 1970.
 
Big Cut in Salary
 Seemingly tireless, Mr. Frenkel proceeded to write, collaborate on or edit more than 200 scholarly papers, 15 books and a number of journals.
When Mr. Frenkel was about to go to the International Monetary Fund in 1987, Mr. Friedman advised him not to. "I said he could do more good by making contributions to scientific work than by becoming a bureaucrat," he said. "Of course, Jacob has been enormously productive there." He credits Mr. Frenkel for revitalizing the I.M.F.'s research department.
Plunging into Israeli politics will cost Mr. Frenkel more than the chance to publish more scholarly papers. His take-home pay will be the equivalent of less than $30,000 a year, compared with his $150,000 salary at the I.M.F. His wife, Niza, will have to disrupt her career as a cancer researcher.
But Mr. Frenkel said he felt "extremely privileged."
"There's a lot to be done," he said. "But we're not talking about mission impossible."

HEADLINE: Can't Count on Numbers;
The Elaborate Effort to Adjust the Census By Using Statistics Adds Up to Ambiguity

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Most experts agree that the 1990 census failed to ferret out about four million to five million Americans, a disproportionate number of them probably black, Hispanic or Asian. Most also agree that the Census Bureau's statistical fix would better reflect the nation's total population.
But they are deeply divided on the critical question of whether the adjustment would provide more accurate -- and fairer -- counts for individual cities and Congressional districts. 
 Judging the case for adjustment to be "inconclusive and unconvincing," Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher declined on July 15 to "abandon a 200-year-old tradition of how we actually count people." But Mr. Mosbacher's words will certainly not be the last on an issue that mixes race and money with a dollop of partisan politics.
New York City is challenging his decision in Federal court, and parallel suits have been filed in Georgia and Illinois. But unfortunately, the experts on whom the plaintiffs and the Commerce Department will be calling for support will not be able to lean too heavily on science.
For while statisticians had high hopes for straightforward answers as to whether the adjustment would be an improvement, they have instead found disappointingly ambiguous results, because of the sheer complexity of the adjustment process. What began as an attempt to clear the air has further clouded it.
David Freedman, a statistician at the University of California at Berkeley, said the Census Bureau did a better job in the actual 1990 census than anyone might reasonably have expected. In just one year, the bureau hired and trained about 500,000 temporary employees -- more than the work force of the General Motors Corporation. And by independent analysis based on birth, death and immigration records, just 2 percent of the population escaped the bureau's dragnet -- half the rate of undercount that marred the 1950 census, a particularly inaccurate count.
But for some purposes, a good job may not be good enough. According to the Census Bureau's own demographic analysis, the percentage undercount of blacks has been three to four times as large as nonblacks in the last three censuses. And it has been widely assumed that the effects of the undercount have been magnified in big cities, where nonwhites represent a larger fraction of the population and the practical problems of finding residents are greatest.
That is why a slew of cities and states filed suit a decade ago to block the use of the 1980 census, and why, in 1989, the Bush Administration agreed to the elaborate post-census survey to create a "dual system estimator" of the true population in 1990.
 
Counting Fish, Counting People
 Statisticians explain their approach to correcting the census by the analogy of counting fish in a pond. There may be no practical way of enumerating the fish without draining the pond. But census takers could catch, say, 100 fish, tag them and throw them back alive. Then they could go fishing once again. If one-third of the fish caught the second time around had tags, it would be reasonable to infer that a total of 300 fish actually lived in the pond.
With the 1990 census, statisticians essentially went fishing a second time, sending surveyors to do a careful recount in 5,000 randomly selected census blocks with a total population of about 400,000. They then matched every individual with the original census data to estimate how many people had been missed, as well as how many people had been counted more than once.
For example, in a block with an original count of 1,000, they might have discovered 50 people who had not previously been found, along with 10 who had been counted twice. The net undercount of 40 represents a 4 percent undercount.
Had the focus of the recount been to re-estimate the total population, that might have been the end of the story. If, on average, there had been an undercount of 4 percent in the 5,000 sample blocks, one would infer that the undercount averaged 4 percent in the census blocks not surveyed. But a major concern -- indeed, the assumption driving the survey effort -- was that the undercount was not uniform among groups or geographic areas.
 
1,400 Pigeonholes
 That explains the next step in the process. Every person in the 5,000 blocks was classified according to race, sex, age, ethnicity, whether he or she lived in a central city, suburb or other area and whether the person owned a residence or rented. Each person was then assigned to one of 1,392 categories according to these characteristics, with each category containing at most a few thousand people. Then, an undercount was estimated for each of the defined groups.
One category, for example, consisted of white Hispanic women age 10 to 19 who lived in rental housing in central cities in Middle Atlantic states. The original census in the 5,000-block sample may have counted 200 in this group, while the post-census survey may have found 202. The undercount for this category would thus be 1 percent. Another category -- say, black men ages 20 to 29 in owner-occupied housing in Middle Atlantic region suburbs -- might have an estimated undercount of 3 percent.
Similar calculations for each of the 1,392 categories allow an estimate of the undercount for any geographic area simply by reassembling the pieces in the correct proportions. Newark, with its heavy representation of black men, showed an undercount of 6.7 percent. By contrast, Saratoga County, N.Y., which is largely rural, actually showed an overcount of 0.7 percent.
These new estimates of population are just that: estimates. If a different set of 5,000 census blocks had been randomly selected, the results would have been different. And in an effort to refine the process, the Census Bureau used a variety of statistical techniques to "smooth" the estimated undercounts.
 
Accurate Enough for Some
 Smoothing tends to narrow the range of results. For example, with the smoothing method finally selected, Newark's undercount comes down to 3.8 percent, while Saratoga's overcount erodes to 0.2 percent.
Does the tortuous process, from re-sampling the census to smoothing the raw estimates of the undercount, really improve the quality of the census?
The results certainly pass an initial test. The nation's total estimated population came out 5.2 million larger than the original enumeration, right on the target identified with records of vital statistics. As expected, the estimated black undercount was 4.8 percent, three times the rate for nonblacks. And the undercount rate for men was substantially higher than for women.
That, augmented by evidence from a number of internal studies, was good enough for a committee of senior Census Bureau professionals who voted 7 to 2 to adjust the census. And it was good enough for Barbara Bryant, the Census Bureau director appointed by President Bush. "While far from a perfect procedure," Ms. Bryant wrote, it "will on average increase the accuracy of the 1990 census."
 
Why No Definitive Answer?
 But a panel of outside experts advising the Census Bureau split evenly on the question. And Michael Darby, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs who happens to be an economist with expertise in statistics, came down strongly against adjustment.
While the overall adjusted count may well be more accurate, he wrote, the Census Bureau's own analysis suggests that it is less accurate on the issue of where the undercounted people live -- the issue that matters for purposes of apportionment. The adjusted estimate of the fraction of the population living in 28 states, he reckoned, was probably a step backward from the census itself.
Why aren't some experts satisfied? The problems are not the mechanics of the post-enumeration survey, or the re-match. Ken Wachter, a member of the advisory panel who teaches statistics at the University of California, said the "census did itself proud in bringing this off." But each step in the estimation process, he argues, introduced potential sources of error. And in the end, the sample proved too small to erase the uncertainty linked to the sampling process.
One unanticipated complication, Mr. Wachter says, is that a major source of differences stemmed from overcounting rather than undercounting -- reporting people twice or reporting people who were not there in the first place. But the survey was intended to find systematic differences in the way various categories were undercounted, not in ferreting out random errors in the original count.
 
Adjusting the Adjustment
 A more fundamental complication is the role of smoothing, the mathematical manipulation of the initial estimates of the undercount. The point of smoothing is to prevent a few large errors from muddying what would otherwise be a clear result. But there are a wide variety of defensible choices in smoothing techniques. And Peter Bounpane, an assistant director of the census, confirms that "if you change the smoothing procedure you get very different results."
The census received financing to survey 400,000 people -- half the sampling size the big-city plaintiffs initially wanted. Was Washington pennywise?
John Tukey of Princeton, one of America's most distinguished mathematicians and a member of the advisory panel who favored adjustment, doubts that the larger survey would have made much difference. The larger the sample, he notes, the smaller the uncertainty inherent in sampling: Catching 50 fish rather than 10 the second time around would give you a more reliable estimate of the total number of fish in the pond.
But the maximum possible gain from a larger survey would have been modest -- probably too modest to overcome the critics' objections. And in any case, Mr. Tukey says, the measurement errors introduced in trying to manage a larger survey would probably have offset the sampling gains.
 
Less Effect Than Expected
 One consolation to those who labored to no definitive end, Mr. Darby suggests, is that the practical impact of the adjustment decision is smaller than anticipated. Using the adjusted population figures would move just two Congressional seats, with Arizona and California gaining at the expense of Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.
Many states, including New York, that expected to win billions in Federal money with the adjustment would be virtually unaffected because the potential gains in some communities are offset by losses in others. And many big cities, including New York City, have only modest stakes in adjustment because their piece of a total aid pie set aside for cities would increase very little.
The real costs, many experts fear, will be the intangible ones. Adjusting the count by a complicated statistical technique that everyone agrees is flawed would feed the resentment of people already suspicious of Government's means and motives. On the other hand, failing to adjust a census that undercounts blacks and Hispanics would alienate minorities.
Heads you lose, tails you lose.

HEADLINE: Let Unemployment Benefits Run Out

BYLINE: By E. Clay Shaw Jr.; E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, is a member of the House Ways and Means Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If the Democrats had their way, the nation would have a new system of increased benefits for unemployed workers. Though President Bush is expected to kill the Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act that Congress approved last week, the Democratic leadership has already promised to push similar legislation when Congress returns in September. The debate, in short, is just beginning, but almost no one, least of all elected officials, is willing to be identified with the strong case against these benefit increases.
The U.S. has a basic unemployment system in which qualified workers receive 26 weeks of benefits averaging about $160 a week. If unemployment in a state is very high -- between 9 and 12 percent -- then workers in that state who use up their benefits can qualify for an additional 13 weeks. In 1975 and 1982, the two most recent recessions, Congress added another tier of temporary benefits, which generally extend the payments for a year or longer. 
 Though we seem to be at the end of a recession, the Democrats have proposed a revamped unemployment system that would provide millions of workers with benefits for 20 weeks beyond the basic 26 weeks. While both parties agree that the U.S. should provide unemployment benefits and that we should give additional benefits in high unemployment states, the agreement ends there.
The Democrats, for whom labor has been a major constituency, want more benefits for more people. The image of unemployment portrayed by the Democrats is of a worker laid off by declines in his industry, spending every day looking for a job, running out of money.
Many Republicans want basic coverage and additional coverage under truly difficult circumstances as well. But unlike the Democrats, we realize that the U.S. economy is dynamic; capitalism is creative destruction. Between 1970 and 1988, for example, the primary metal industries lost half a million workers, or 40 percent of their workforce. Over the same period, the number of employees in business services increased by nearly four million people. Despite the loss of millions of jobs and types of jobs, employment rose from 58 percent to 62.6 percent of the adult population.
Of course, everyone agrees that a representative government must help citizens victimized by the inevitable processes of capitalism. But how much help? Is 26 weeks enough? Should the nation, as the Democrats have argued, provide 46 weeks of benefits to some workers? Will their jobs return at the end of 46 weeks?
Someone must pay the bill. And under today's unemployment system, we tax productive industries and productive workers to provide benefits for less productive workers in struggling industries. Our unemployment system must try to balance market realities with compassion.
The recession has not pushed employment to the point where emergency measures are necessary. The current system will provide $25 billion in benefits this year, up from $18 billion last year; 10.7 million workers will receive benefits, up from 8.1 million last year; workers in nine states will receive up to 13 weeks of extended benefits, up from four states last year; 160,000 workers will receive extended benefits, up from 40,000 last year.
Moreover, all recessions are not equal. In 1982, the last time Congress voted for emergency benefits, unemployment was at 10 percent and had been above 7 percent for 31 consecutive months. Today unemployment is 6.8 percent and has exceeded 7 percent only once in the last 31 months. When Congress last ended emergency benefits in 1985, unemployment was at 7.2 percent -- higher than the rate at which Democrats would begin such aid today.
We have a reasonably effective system of unemployment benefits. We had a mild recession and the system responded properly. Congress would enact emergency benefits if there were an emergency, but the numbers tell us there is not. We should continue to support the existing unemployment insurance, which balances benefits against costs.

HEADLINE: Protecting Employee Privacy Too Far

 BODY:
Employer intrusions into employees' private lives have provoked wide, healthy reaction. Now it's the reaction that risks going too far.
Some states, most recently New Jersey, have outlawed company rules against smoking at home, without disturbing a smoke-free workplace or anyone's right to charge higher health insurance rates for extra health risks. Other states have moved to protect personal life style choices that don't affect job performance. 
 Now New York's Legislature has passed a bill prohibiting discrimination against workers for "legal activities" off the job. This time, however, the worker protection sweeps broadly across long-disputed labor-management terrain. Gov. Mario Cuomo, who vetoed a similar bill last year, is prudently calling for further fine-tuning.
As in other states, New York's life style battle is a blend of ideals and economics. Companies meddle in their workers' off-the-job activities chiefly because measures like incentives to lose weight or quit smoking tend to reduce costs. The American Civil Liberties Union proclaims the liberty of working Americans -- in agreement with organized labor and cigarette makers.
New York's Assembly and Senate have approved a bill giving workers and the State Attorney General the right to sue employers who refuse to hire or promote people because of engagement "in a legal activity during non-working hours." Supporters say this insulates workers from unreasonable discipline for things like overeating or riding motorcycles that might be motivated by concern for health -- or merely the boss's whim.
Business groups and the State Newspaper Publishers Association lobby against it. They argue that companies must retain leverage over some after-hours activities, like moonlighting for a competitor or marching in a demonstration against a company's product.
The bill, sponsored by Assemblyman Frank Barbaro and Senator James Lack, has an exception to protect an employer's "legitimate conflict of interest policy" but only to the extent that those policies safeguard "trade secrets, proprietary information" or undefined "other proprietary interests." That's too narrow an exception for a broad and still novel right.
Proponents of these privacy measures are pressing the right questions. They don't contend that smoking is a civil right. They simply ask by what authority employers extend their supervision into the living room or kitchen. Employers, too, may argue their side.
Further clarification of the New York bill is in order before the Governor acts. Properly defined, life style laws can protect the legitimate interests of the worker and respect those of the boss.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

HEADLINE: Can't Count on Numbers;
The Elaborate Effort to Adjust the Census By Using Statistics Adds Up to Ambiguity

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Most experts agree that the 1990 census failed to ferret out about four million to five million Americans, a disproportionate number of them probably black, Hispanic or Asian. Most also agree that the Census Bureau's statistical fix would better reflect the nation's total population.
But they are deeply divided on the critical question of whether the adjustment would provide more accurate -- and fairer -- counts for individual cities and Congressional districts. 
 Judging the case for adjustment to be "inconclusive and unconvincing," Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher declined on July 15 to "abandon a 200-year-old tradition of how we actually count people." But Mr. Mosbacher's words will certainly not be the last on an issue that mixes race and money with a dollop of partisan politics.
New York City is challenging his decision in Federal court, and parallel suits have been filed in Georgia and Illinois. But unfortunately, the experts on whom the plaintiffs and the Commerce Department will be calling for support will not be able to lean too heavily on science.
For while statisticians had high hopes for straightforward answers as to whether the adjustment would be an improvement, they have instead found disappointingly ambiguous results, because of the sheer complexity of the adjustment process. What began as an attempt to clear the air has further clouded it.
David Freedman, a statistician at the University of California at Berkeley, said the Census Bureau did a better job in the actual 1990 census than anyone might reasonably have expected. In just one year, the bureau hired and trained about 500,000 temporary employees -- more than the work force of the General Motors Corporation. And by independent analysis based on birth, death and immigration records, just 2 percent of the population escaped the bureau's dragnet -- half the rate of undercount that marred the 1950 census, a particularly inaccurate count.
But for some purposes, a good job may not be good enough. According to the Census Bureau's own demographic analysis, the percentage undercount of blacks has been three to four times as large as nonblacks in the last three censuses. And it has been widely assumed that the effects of the undercount have been magnified in big cities, where nonwhites represent a larger fraction of the population and the practical problems of finding residents are greatest.
That is why a slew of cities and states filed suit a decade ago to block the use of the 1980 census, and why, in 1989, the Bush Administration agreed to the elaborate post-census survey to create a "dual system estimator" of the true population in 1990.
 
Counting Fish, Counting People
 Statisticians explain their approach to correcting the census by the analogy of counting fish in a pond. There may be no practical way of enumerating the fish without draining the pond. But census takers could catch, say, 100 fish, tag them and throw them back alive. Then they could go fishing once again. If one-third of the fish caught the second time around had tags, it would be reasonable to infer that a total of 300 fish actually lived in the pond.
With the 1990 census, statisticians essentially went fishing a second time, sending surveyors to do a careful recount in 5,000 randomly selected census blocks with a total population of about 400,000. They then matched every individual with the original census data to estimate how many people had been missed, as well as how many people had been counted more than once.
For example, in a block with an original count of 1,000, they might have discovered 50 people who had not previously been found, along with 10 who had been counted twice. The net undercount of 40 represents a 4 percent undercount.
Had the focus of the recount been to re-estimate the total population, that might have been the end of the story. If, on average, there had been an undercount of 4 percent in the 5,000 sample blocks, one would infer that the undercount averaged 4 percent in the census blocks not surveyed. But a major concern -- indeed, the assumption driving the survey effort -- was that the undercount was not uniform among groups or geographic areas.
 
1,400 Pigeonholes
 That explains the next step in the process. Every person in the 5,000 blocks was classified according to race, sex, age, ethnicity, whether he or she lived in a central city, suburb or other area and whether the person owned a residence or rented. Each person was then assigned to one of 1,392 categories according to these characteristics, with each category containing at most a few thousand people. Then, an undercount was estimated for each of the defined groups.
One category, for example, consisted of white Hispanic women age 10 to 19 who lived in rental housing in central cities in Middle Atlantic states. The original census in the 5,000-block sample may have counted 200 in this group, while the post-census survey may have found 202. The undercount for this category would thus be 1 percent. Another category -- say, black men ages 20 to 29 in owner-occupied housing in Middle Atlantic region suburbs -- might have an estimated undercount of 3 percent.
Similar calculations for each of the 1,392 categories allow an estimate of the undercount for any geographic area simply by reassembling the pieces in the correct proportions. Newark, with its heavy representation of black men, showed an undercount of 6.7 percent. By contrast, Saratoga County, N.Y., which is largely rural, actually showed an overcount of 0.7 percent.
These new estimates of population are just that: estimates. If a different set of 5,000 census blocks had been randomly selected, the results would have been different. And in an effort to refine the process, the Census Bureau used a variety of statistical techniques to "smooth" the estimated undercounts.
 
Accurate Enough for Some
 Smoothing tends to narrow the range of results. For example, with the smoothing method finally selected, Newark's undercount comes down to 3.8 percent, while Saratoga's overcount erodes to 0.2 percent.
Does the tortuous process, from re-sampling the census to smoothing the raw estimates of the undercount, really improve the quality of the census?
The results certainly pass an initial test. The nation's total estimated population came out 5.2 million larger than the original enumeration, right on the target identified with records of vital statistics. As expected, the estimated black undercount was 4.8 percent, three times the rate for nonblacks. And the undercount rate for men was substantially higher than for women.
That, augmented by evidence from a number of internal studies, was good enough for a committee of senior Census Bureau professionals who voted 7 to 2 to adjust the census. And it was good enough for Barbara Bryant, the Census Bureau director appointed by President Bush. "While far from a perfect procedure," Ms. Bryant wrote, it "will on average increase the accuracy of the 1990 census."
 
Why No Definitive Answer?
 But a panel of outside experts advising the Census Bureau split evenly on the question. And Michael Darby, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs who happens to be an economist with expertise in statistics, came down strongly against adjustment.
While the overall adjusted count may well be more accurate, he wrote, the Census Bureau's own analysis suggests that it is less accurate on the issue of where the undercounted people live -- the issue that matters for purposes of apportionment. The adjusted estimate of the fraction of the population living in 28 states, he reckoned, was probably a step backward from the census itself.
Why aren't some experts satisfied? The problems are not the mechanics of the post-enumeration survey, or the re-match. Ken Wachter, a member of the advisory panel who teaches statistics at the University of California, said the "census did itself proud in bringing this off." But each step in the estimation process, he argues, introduced potential sources of error. And in the end, the sample proved too small to erase the uncertainty linked to the sampling process.
One unanticipated complication, Mr. Wachter says, is that a major source of differences stemmed from overcounting rather than undercounting -- reporting people twice or reporting people who were not there in the first place. But the survey was intended to find systematic differences in the way various categories were undercounted, not in ferreting out random errors in the original count.
 
Adjusting the Adjustment
 A more fundamental complication is the role of smoothing, the mathematical manipulation of the initial estimates of the undercount. The point of smoothing is to prevent a few large errors from muddying what would otherwise be a clear result. But there are a wide variety of defensible choices in smoothing techniques. And Peter Bounpane, an assistant director of the census, confirms that "if you change the smoothing procedure you get very different results."
The census received financing to survey 400,000 people -- half the sampling size the big-city plaintiffs initially wanted. Was Washington pennywise?
John Tukey of Princeton, one of America's most distinguished mathematicians and a member of the advisory panel who favored adjustment, doubts that the larger survey would have made much difference. The larger the sample, he notes, the smaller the uncertainty inherent in sampling: Catching 50 fish rather than 10 the second time around would give you a more reliable estimate of the total number of fish in the pond.
But the maximum possible gain from a larger survey would have been modest -- probably too modest to overcome the critics' objections. And in any case, Mr. Tukey says, the measurement errors introduced in trying to manage a larger survey would probably have offset the sampling gains.
 
Less Effect Than Expected
 One consolation to those who labored to no definitive end, Mr. Darby suggests, is that the practical impact of the adjustment decision is smaller than anticipated. Using the adjusted population figures would move just two Congressional seats, with Arizona and California gaining at the expense of Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.
Many states, including New York, that expected to win billions in Federal money with the adjustment would be virtually unaffected because the potential gains in some communities are offset by losses in others. And many big cities, including New York City, have only modest stakes in adjustment because their piece of a total aid pie set aside for cities would increase very little.
The real costs, many experts fear, will be the intangible ones. Adjusting the count by a complicated statistical technique that everyone agrees is flawed would feed the resentment of people already suspicious of Government's means and motives. On the other hand, failing to adjust a census that undercounts blacks and Hispanics would alienate minorities.
Heads you lose, tails you lose.

HEADLINE: Soichiro Honda, Auto Innovator, Is Dead at 84

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 5 S

 BODY:
Soichiro Honda, a rebellious auto mechanic who defied the Japanese Government and built one of the world's biggest and most innovative auto companies from the ruins of World War II, died today. He was 84 years old.
 Mr. Honda, who appeared to be in vigorous health until he was hospitalized recently, died of liver failure, a spokesman for Honda Motor Company said. 

 
Maverick Who Became Symbol
 The son of a blacksmith, Mr. Honda left a small Japanese village in 1922 to
seek his fortune in Japan's capital and ultimately became a symbol of Japan's remarkable postwar industrial rise. But he was hardly typical of his generation. A fiery maverick who spoke his mind, he was always something of an outsider in his own country, his success spawning as much jealousy in Toyota City as it did in Detroit.
 Following the strategy Mr. Honda laid out, Honda Motor was the first Japanese auto company to build factories in its main market, the United States. This year Honda is expected to become the third-largest producer of passenger cars in America, displacing Chrysler.
 
Conquering U.S. Market
 Indeed it was in America, not Japan, that the balding engineer with a broad smile and a razor-sharp temper found his greatest success. Taking on an American industry that seemed invincible, in the 1970's he won over a generation of young drivers who were drawn to the fuel efficiency and low emissions of his company's CVCC engines.
 It was a generation that Detroit's Big Three never really won back. Honda's
two biggest sellers, the Civic and the Accord, emerged as the basic family cars for millions of Americans, and in recent years the company has pushed into the luxury-car market. Toyota and Nissan, which once thought his American auto plant ideas were foolhardy, soon followed.
 The story about how Mr. Honda infuriated the bureaucrats of Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry, who ordered him to keep making motorcycles because they had drawn up plans for Japan to have only a handful of auto makers, has become one of the most oft-repeated legends of the Japanese industry. He drew a lesson from it: Government officials, Mr. Honda said a few years ago, "tend to become an obstacle when you try to do something new."
 Indeed, Mr. Honda reveled in his David-vs.-Goliath approach to auto making, and in his later years he delighted in offering stinging critiques of corporate Japan and the way it controls the lives of its workers.
 Always the maverick, he bristled at the most frequently offered explanation of Japan's industrial success: that its population is able to sublimate individual needs to those of the group.
 "Each individual should work for himself -- that's important," he said in a rare interview several years ago. "People will not sacrifice themselves for the company. They come to work at the company to enjoy themselves."
 Whether that credo still applies today is an arguable point. Since he retired in 1973, saying that Honda should be run by young Japanese, not aging executives, Honda Motor has become a huge and far less personal company. Its headquarters tower in Tokyo is now a place of considerable corporate intrigue, though it is still a hotbed of innovation. Only last week the company announced a new, highly fuel-efficient engine, using an approach that Detroit's auto manufacturers have largely dismissed as unworkable.
Mr. Honda's interest in cars and racing was so intense that even in his last days he liked to wander Honda's research labs, inspecting the work of new engineers and seeking explanations for things he did not like.
 
Learning From Defeats
 "He hated to lose," Shoichiro Irimajiri, who ran Honda's American manufacturing operations through the 1980's and today is the head of the company's research and production, said in an interview today. "But he always
made us learn something from losing."
 Soichiro Honda was born in 1906 in a village just outside Hamamatsu, in Shizuoka Prefecture, a place known today largely for its giant Honda factory. His father, Gihei, was a blacksmith who fixed bicycles on the side, and Mr. Honda's recollections of his youth mostly centered on the family's poverty. Five of his eight brothers and sisters died in childhood.
 Even as a child Mr. Honda was fascinated with the sound and smell of motors, and he would often travel with his grandfather to see a rice-polishing mill, one of the few motor-driven devices in his remote town. He went to school for only 10 years, and at age 15 struck out for Tokyo, eager to become a mechanic. He quickly got a job at an auto shop, only to discover that his only responsibility was babysitting. But the next year a tremendous earthquake destroyed Tokyo and Mr. Honda got his break: he filled in for mechanics who left their jobs to rebuild their homes.
 Eventually he returned to Hamamatsu to open a branch of the auto shop and quickly became something of a delinquent. He spent much of his time in the company of geisha, and once when he was drunk he went off the side of a bridge
with several geisha riding in his car. Fortunately, everyone survived that incident.
 
Formal Education Scorned
 In the mid-1930's, Mr. Honda became a race-car driver. He almost died in a crash that left him with a permanent scar. Later in the '30's he married and settled down, but could not sit still for book learning at a technological high school. He never received a diploma, which he said was "worth less than a movie ticket."
 During World War II Mr. Honda's company, which he was then running, built engines for aircraft and for the Imperial Navy. After the war he sold it to the company that would become his nemesis, Toyota, and spent the year brewing his own alcohol.
 But soon he found opportunity in the wreckage of the war. Obtaining some military surplus engines, he attached them to bicycles and sold them to people who desperately needed transportation to farm areas to ward off starvation. From that emerged the motorcycle, and soon Honda's own engines.
Soon Mr. Honda's first popular model, the Dream, covered the Japanese
islands. Impatient with anything but engineering, he brought in Takeo Fujisawa, a businessman, who obtained the company's financing and became Mr. Honda's closest partner.
 
From Motorcycles to Cars
 His motorcycle business prospered: one of Honda's factories became the biggest in the world. But the engineer's mind was on a car. In 1957, he came up with one, called the N360, and fended off the bureaucrats who thought he should merge his company into other, stronger automakers. He refused.
 The car project created a generation of Honda disciples, many of whom are running the company today. Few have forgotten their awe and fear of Mr. Honda. In the mid-1960's, Mr. Irimajiri designed a new piston for a Grand Prix race car, "Theoretically it should have worked," Mr. Irimajiri said ruefully today. It burned out in mid-race.
 Mr. Honda ordered the engine reconstructed and soon found the culprit. "I hate college graduates," he told Mr. Irimajiri. "They only use their heads." Under questioning, Mr. Irimajiri conceded that he had not sought the advice of
the old mechanics with less book learning and more experience. On the founder's orders he then walked through the tooling shops, bowing and apologizing profusely. "I looked behind me," Mr. Irimajiri recalled today, "and he was following my every step."
 But Mr. Honda never used his reliance on experience to stifle innovation. The true test came with the CVCC.
 The engine used a startling new design, one that burned a leaner mix of gasoline and passed emissions tests -- the main barrier to the American market -- without using a catalytic converter. Until then Japanese makers had slavishly followed Detroit. But the new Honda Civics captured the low end of the market, and gave Honda, which has never been as popular with Japanese auto buyers as with Americans, the wedge it needed.
 
New Plant in U.S.
 Mr. Honda retired the next year, 1973, and watched from the sidelines as his successors built a sprawling factory in Ohio.
 To other Japanese automakers, it was a proposition that seemed to make little
economic sense at the time. But quickly such "transplants" became linchpin of Japan's trade strategy with the United States, a response to Detroit's efforts to limit the import of cars from Japan. It was successful beyond anything envisioned by the Big Three, or by the unions, which have not been successful at organizing workers at the plants.
 Honda is still enmeshed in the political debate over whether it is truly an "American" or "Japanese" auto company. Mr. Honda's vision of building a totally independent company in the United States, one that designs and makes and markets its cars without much oversight from Tokyo, has not yet been fulfilled. But the American-made Accord became the first "foreign" car to take the title as the best-selling model in the United States, and Honda has begun importing some of its American-made cars to Japan.
 Mr. Honda spent his retirement administering the Honda Foundation, a private group that promotes new uses of technology. He lectured regularly on management. "The worst kind of president is a person who eats in fancy restaurants, smoking a fat cigar and thinking well of himself while employees work in a dirty factory with their hands dirty,"' he said. "If you're like a god, people will respect you, but they won't come close."
 Two years ago he received a long overdue acknowledgement from his American competitors. He was inducted into the Automotive Hall of Fame, taking a place next to Henry Ford, Alfred Sloan of General Motors and Karl Benz, the builder of the Mercedes-Benz. His last trip to the United States came earlier this year, when he visited Honda's new test track in Nevada and was driven in his company's first commercial sports car, the $70,000 NSX, in many ways the most advanced car Honda has ever built.
 "At the end of the day," Mr. Irimajiri said, "he looked around and said, 'I love it here.' And he wouldn't leave."
 Mr. Honda is survived by his wife, Sachi, two daughters and a son. Funeral services will be private, but Honda officials said the company would hold a memorial service at a later date.

HEADLINE: Booming Orlando Becomes a Magnet for Prosperity and the Ills It Conceals

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla.

 BODY:
It may be just an illusion, but there are times when this city, the adopted hometown of Mickey Mouse and Shamu the whale, seems to be enchanted. Take Orlando's Naval Training Center, a big base of 17,000 people that until the end of June was on a list to be closed. At the last minute, when things looked bleakest, a Federal panel stepped in and spared the base.
 Then, while other big airlines were going bankrupt, United Airlines announced it would nearly triple the number of its flights to Orlando's fast-growing international airport and perhaps build a $1 billion jet maintenance center there. 
Orlando, or the big, four-county area of Central Florida that many people think of as Orlando, is leading a charmed life. After Walt Disney World opened 20 years ago in Lake Buena Vista, about 18 miles south of downtown Orlando, other theme parks quickly followed: Sea World, Universal Studios and dozens of smaller attractions like the Elvis Presley Museum and Xanadu, Home of the Future.
 
Magnet for Corporations
 The parks draw hordes of tourists, 14 million last year alone. While Disney has made no secret of its intention to keep as many of them as possible on its own 28,000 acres, the spin-off business, what local merchants call the D.A.D. or day after Disney, spreads the good fortune over a wide area.
 Improvements at the airport designed to serve the tourists have also provided convenient connections for corporations, which are flocking here. A 4 percent county tax on hotel rooms generated so much money in the last decade that it paid for the construction of the 350,000-square-foot Orange County Convention/Civic Center, half of the Orlando Arena, and a portion of the renovation of the Citrus Bowl. Convention business, virtually non-existent in the early 1980's, is now nearly a $1-billion-a-year industry.
 True, not everyone shares in the prosperity. Underneath the glitter of the theme parks and the tidy streets of downtown is a medium-sized city with typical urban problems of homelessness, drug addiction and runaway traffic congestion, the latter a troublesome byproduct of growth.
 The Orlando area's population has soared to more than one million, and business keeps expanding in spite of the economic slowdown. There are 78,000 hotel and motel rooms here, including the new 891-room Peabody Hotel, where ducks waddle to a marble pool in the lobby every day, just as they do in the original Peabody in Memphis. The state Government is helping to build a rail line that will float on magnets. The city did not get a major league baseball team, but it does have a team in the National Basketball Association, the Orlando Magic.
 The aura of fantasy and unreality created by the theme parks shimmers like a rainbow over the area, Florida's only major inland city. And even though attendance at many parks is down because of the recession, this magic kingdom is still growing.
 Consider a proposal by a group of Soviet and Alaskan businessmen who want to build a theme restaurant and exhibition center called Perestroika Palace. And not far from Disney, the magician Doug Henning and Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, former guru to the Beatles, plan to build a 450-acre theme park filled with magic illusions and wild rides called Maharishi Veda Land -- Veda being what Mr. Henning says is the Sanskrit word for knowledge.
 
A 'Heavenly Garden'
 "One of the themes of our park is man's harmony with nature," said Mr. Henning, who traveled around the world nine times before deciding to build the first Veda Land in Central Florida. "We feel that in Orlando we can build the most magical heavenly garden."
 But when familiar urban problems occur against a backdrop of fantasy (some traffic signs in Lake Buena Vista are adorned with mouse ears), they create striking images.
 Orlando carefully waters the grounds at its landmark Lake Eola park every night, which not only makes a good impression on tourists but keeps the homeless from sleeping there. Labor pools have sprung up over the city to recruit and place cheap day laborers, and in the busy season they take homeless people to work at Walt Disney World and the other parks.
 "There's a perception that Orlando isn't a real city, but it is," said Homero Leon Jr., a lawyer at Greater Orlando Area Legal Services.
 
Dashed Expectations
 Mervyn J. Cordner, an assistant at the legal services office, visits the city's homeless shelters daily, often coming back with tales of how image clashes with reality.
 Mr. Cordner recently saw a 28-year-old Hispanic woman from New Hampshire who had read about Orlando and decided to make a life there. She and her two children drove down and rented a mobile home on Orange Blossom Trail. It did not take long before she had exhausted her savings, been evicted from the mobile home and entered a shelter where she and her children were sleeping on mats on the floor.
 "People give up all their possessions and come here with expectations that are never met," Mr. Cordner said. "It makes them sick."
 Officials say they understand the clash between image and reality. "People do come here with expectations of streets of gold," said Bill Frederick, Mayor for the last 11 years.
 Orlando's 165,000 residents know precisely how the streets are paved and how the city runs. Orlando is expanding so fast that it has outgrown its 34-year-old City Hall and had to build a $33 million, copper-domed building three times as large right next door.
 Orlando itself continues to annex small bits of Orange County, but the bulk of the area's one million residents live in unincorporated areas of Orange, Osceola, Seminole and Lake counties.
 
Business and Pleasure
 This is a strange mix of vacation resort and contemporary office complex, a world where visitors far outnumber permanent residents and business often mixes with pleasure. The strip of Interstate 4 between Disney World and downtown Orlando has become a field of themes: billboards along the way advertise Sea World, Universal Studios, King Henry's Feast, Fun 'N Wheels and the Queen of the Universe Shrine.
 "All of us who were born and raised in Central Florida feel we've had just about enough of theme parks," Mayor Frederick said. While tourism is important to Orlando's economy, he went on, international commerce and convention businesses are growing, too. "Disney and the others tend to eclipse what we really are about," he said.
 But the prospect of pulling in even a fragment of the 14 million annual visitors who come to Orlando makes entrepreneurs of all types glow with anticipation. Disney, the largest and most energetic of the parks, continues to churn out ideas for its 28,000 acres, and occasionally that growth causes problems. Last year, Federal environmental officials ordered Disney to stop using a wetlands sewage treatment area that was producing too many nutrients.
 Right now, welding sparks fly late into the night on the Magic Kingdom's Splash Mountain, a log flume ride that is expected to draw large crowds when it opens next year.
 By the end of the decade, Disney also will open a fourth theme park, joining the Magic Kingdom, Epcot and the Disney-M-G-M Studios. Word in Orlando is that the attraction will feature animals, perhaps from the sea. Disney officials will not disclose their plans.
 
Work, School, Fun
 Disney is also getting ready to begin construction on a new town of 20,000 residents called Celebration that will pioneer ways of combining work, school and fun. But environmentalists have met with Disney officials to express their concerns about company plans to possibly build in areas it had promised to keep open.
 Universal Studios is also still hot here. In May, it opened a $40 million ride based on the film "Back to the Future" in which tourists ride a flight simulator inside a seven-story domed theater for a trip back to the Ice Age.
 The most unusual projects coming to Orlando are the Perestroika Palace and Veda Land. Perestroika Palace was first planned as part of Universal Studios, but the deal fell through, and now the developers, a consortium of Alaskan businessmen and entrepreneurs from the Soviet Union's Russian Republic, want to build the 30-acre attraction on their own. It is to have a restaurant, theater and meeting hall designed in the style of St. Basil's Cathedral in Moscow.
 Veda Land, as planned, will give as many as 2.8 million visitors a year a transcendental experience of grand magic illusions in a setting as serene as an Infiniti automobile commercial. Situated on 450 acres of hardwood hammock and swamp near Walt Disney World, Veda Land will feature more than 30 major attractions, including a building that appears to levitate above water. The total cost of the park and a 500-room hotel is $1 billion.
 Mr. Henning has been a disciple of the Maharishi since 1976 and now lives in Vlodrop in the Netherlands, the world headquarters of the transcendental meditation movement. He said the park would not try to proselytize any aspect of religion or transcendental meditation.
 Mr. Henning said contracts should be signed in three months and Veda Land could open in 1993.
 
SOME VISIONS WERE ONLY MIRAGES
 With Gatorland, Flea World, the Elvis Presley Museum and Xanadu, Home of the Future, along with several religious mega-shrines and the better-known attractions of Walt Disney World, Sea World and Universal Studios, Orlando already has an excess of excess. But there has also been a long list of failed projects whose hope was exceeded by hype. These famous would-have-beens include:
 *Little England, a grandiose recreation of an ancient British village, meticulously recreated in the hardwood hammock of Kissimmee. Started in the early 1980's by Louis Cartier, a millionaire British grocer, the project went bust before it ever opened.
 *Hurricane World, described as a glorified wind tunnel that could transport tourists into the eye of a storm. Proposed but never started.
 *Bible World, a panoramic journey into Christendom. Never started.
 *Western Fun World, a Wild West theme. Project abandoned in the mid-1970's.
 *Winter Wonderlando, skiing in Central Florida. Great name. Lousy concept. Never started.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Federal Gold, Census Rainbow

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE nation's governors and mayors are sure that some five million Americans slipped through the census net in 1990. And they know that about $60 billion in Federal aid -- $236 per person in 1989 -- is linked to population. That, in part, explains why New York City and dozens of other localities are demanding that the census be adjusted to compensate for the undercount.
It will not be easy to convince a Federal court to second-guess the Bush Administration's decision to stick with the initial count. But even if the cities prevail, suggests Michael Murray, an economist at Bates College in Maine, the plaintiffs will be disappointed: There simply is no pot of gold at the end of the legal rainbow. 
 More people ought to mean more money, he acknowledges in an analysis released by the Commerce Department. But since Congress does not have the cash to enrich the total aid pot, only the localities whose numbers were adjusted by more than the average stand to gain. And in any event, winning the census readjustment game is not all it has been cracked up to be because allocations are not proportional to population size. Mr. Murray estimates that, all told, just $2 out of every $1,000 in population-linked aid would change hands.
The failure of the census to locate 2 percent of the population, roughly a third of whom are minorities living in cities, is widely acknowledged. And under legal pressure from states and cities, the Bush Administration agreed in 1989 to finance an elaborate post-census survey of 165,000 households that could be used to adjust the 1990 count.
Barbara Bryant, the director of the Census Bureau, thinks the statistically based adjustment is closer to the truth than the census itself, and recommended that it be used. But on the advice of his own staff Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher balked, setting the stage for what could be a protracted court battle in which both sides rely heavily on technical arguments.
The size of four Congressional delegations is at stake: Arizona and California would take seats from Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. But for most states, cities and counties, the Federal case is mostly about money. And here, Mr. Murray thinks there is less to the debate than meets the eye.
The adjustments would, indeed, increase the estimated population of every state, as well as every city over 200,000. But with the exception of Medicaid, the flow of cash from Washington would not increase automatically. The only localities likely to benefit would be ones with census adjustments exceeding the 2.1 percent average.
The big potential winners would be Western states (in particular, Arizona, California, New Mexico), Sun Belt cities (including Los Angeles, Dallas, Houston, Memphis, Miami, San Diego) and the District of Columbia. New York City's population gain (3 percent) is medium potatoes. And there would be some surprising losers: New York State (1.7 percent), New Jersey (1.4), Illinois (1.4), Cleveland (1.4), Philadelphia (1.3).
Winning, moreover, might not mean much, for much of the Federal cash is apportioned by formulas as Byzantine as the political bargains that hatched them. In one highway aid program, for example, money is divided according to a weighted average of a state's surface area, its urban, suburban and rural populations, and the mileage of its rural mail routes.
States may, however, opt for a different formula -- one that counts just urban and rural population. And once each state has chosen the formula that gives it the biggest slice, each share is rescaled to add up to 100 percent. Is that all clear?
Mr. Murray estimates that a total of $83 per undercounted person in winning communities would shift pockets if the census were adjusted. But some changes would offset others. On average, communities benefiting from the adjustment would gain just $56 for each miscounted individual. By this reckoning, New York City might expect to pick up some $10 million annually -- a nice piece of change, surely, but hardly enough to dent the city's budget for filling potholes.
For Robert Rifkind, an attorney at Cravath, Swaine & Moore who represents cities and states seeking adjustment, that is not quite the end of the money story. The biggest stakes in census adjustment, he argues, are within states. Higher population figures would mean more state aid to urban localities -- and in sums far exceeding the reshuffle of Federal grants.
Perhaps more important, adjustment would tilt the balance of political power toward urban legislators and toward the concerns of blacks and the Hispanic population, whose rate of undercount is three times as high as non-blacks. And "money," said Mr. Rifkind, "tends to follow power."
