HEADLINE: Home Resales Up in Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON. Aug. 6

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes posted double-digit gains in 20 states in the second quarter as the housing industry emerged from the recession, a real estate trade group said today.
But as demand rose, so did prices, which advanced in nearly 80 percent of the 119 cities in the National Association of Realtors' survey. Prices had dropped in 40 percent of the cities in the first quarter. 
 Over all, the realtors said, 34 states and the District of Columbia recorded sales gains, raising the national rate by 3.5 percent over April-June 1990, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.82 million units. The sales rate was also 12.1 percent above that of the first quarter.
The survey, which covered sales of single-family detached homes, town houses, condominiums and cooperatives, showed that sales in the Northeast shot up 6.3 percent, to an annual rate of 680,000 units. Still, only four of the nine states in the region recorded gains, led by a 11.6 percent jump in New Jersey.
All 16 Southern states recorded sales increases, including 13 with jumps of more than 10 percent, the realtors said.
Delaware, in the realtors' southern region, had a 30.2 percent sales rise; Louisiana, 29.1 percent; Mississippi, 26.4 percent; Alabama, 24.7 percent, and Tennessee, 19.2.
Hawaii was at the bottom of the list with a 43.7 percent drop. Next was Oregon, where sales were down 16.4 percent; Washington, down 10.2 percent; Pennsylvania, 9.4 percent, and Nebraska, 7.8 percent.
The national median price of a used home rose 4.7 percent from the second quarter of 1990, to $101,100, according to the realtors' survey. The median price means half of the homes sold for more and half for less.

HEADLINE: U.S. Posts Rise In Productivity

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers rose at an annual rate of 1.9 percent in the spring, the biggest advance in almost three years, the Government reported today.
The Commerce Department said the strong advance in productivity from April through June followed dismal showings in the two previous quarters when the country was mired in recession. Productivity, defined as output per hours worked, fell at a rate of eight- tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter and showed no improvement in the first quarter. 
 Analysts said the improvement in the April-June quarter was an indication of a rebounding economy. The Government had earlier reported that the nation's total output of goods and services, or the gross national product, rose at an annual rate of four-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June quarter after falling in the two previous quarters.
The 1.9 percent rise in productivity in the spring stemmed from a 1.3 percent increase in non-farm output and a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in the number of hours worked. The 1.9 percent increase was the biggest jump since a 2.7 percent rise in the third quarter of 1988.
For 1990, productivity fell by six-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department said today, revising an earlier estimate that put the drop at an even larger nine-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: U.N. Journal;
World's No. 1 Guessing Game Is Coming This Fall

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Floating around the United Nations Secretariat is an agenda for the 46th General Assembly, which begins here on Sept. 17. A modest document by United Nations standards, it manages nevertheless to include some 30 pages of listings, day by day and hour by hour, of ceremonies, meetings and consultations meant to involve every member nation by the time the Assembly ends in mid-December.
But nowhere in it is there any mention of what will be the most popular topic of the session: the selection of a new Secretary General. Javier Perez de Cuellar, the 71-year-old incumbent, will complete his second five-year term on Dec. 31., and he has indicated he has no desire for another term. 
 United Nations officials hope to have the next Secretary General elected by the end of the session so he or she can have a staff in place by Jan. 1.
The selection of a successor to Mr. Perez de Cuellar, a Peruvian, has taken on particular significance in light of recent world events. The easing of worldwide tensions and the new spirit of cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union could mean a new, more powerful role in international affairs for the world organization, diplomats here say.
 
The 2 Front-Runners
 Recent events have prompted even critics of the United Nations to see it in a new light. One of them, the Heritage Foundation, said in a recent report, "The U.N.'s international prominence is the highest it has been in years."
The permanent members of the Security Council, who control the final selection of candidates for Secretary General, are said to be looking for a more charismatic leader to take the helm of a reinvigorated United Nations.
The summit meeting of the industrial powers in London last month called for a tougher, activist United Nations, ready to intervene in world trouble spots. The Bush Administration has taken no position so far on the United Nations post, but is known to see it as a key factor in what President Bush calls the new world order.
The two prime candidates at the moment, diplomats say, are Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, who served as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for 12 years and more recently was the Secretary General's personal representative for humanitarian relief in Iraq, and Boutros Ghali, Egypt's Deputy Prime Minister for foreign relations, who was closely associated with the Camp David peace treaty between Egypt and Israel.
Prince Sadruddin was born in Paris in 1933, lives in Geneva and carries an Iranian passport. He is a Harvard graduate who has spent his entire professional life in international affairs. He received more votes than Mr. Perez de Cuellar in the 1981 election for Secretary General, but was vetoed by the Soviet Union, presumably because he was favored by the United States and was known for his commitment to free-market economies.
Mr. Ghali, who was Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs from 1977 until earlier this year, is President Hosni Mubarak's candidate and appears to have support from a number of European countries.
A professor of international law at Cairo University, Mr. Ghali was brought into political life by Anwar el-Sadat, Egypt's President until his assassination in 1981. Mr. Mubarak has reportedly asked President Bush to support Mr. Ghali. Prince Bandar, Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to Washington, is said to have called Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to express his Government's support for the Ghali nomination.
Both Prince Sadruddin and Mr. Ghali have been campaigning for the job; the Prince discreetly, Mr. Ghali openly. Old United Nations hands say Prince Sadruddin has been campaigning for the post for 20 years. Aside from his vast experience in international and specifically United Nations affairs, one of his chief assets is a close relationship with President Bush. The Bushes have stayed at Prince Sadruddin's home in Geneva and at his horse farm in Middleburg, Va.
 
4 From Black Africa
 Prince Sadruddin's Western leanings are said to antagonize conservative Muslim leaders. His closeness to the United States is expected to hurt his chances in parts of the world where anti-Americanism persists.
Mr. Ghali's chances could be hampered by age -- he is 69 -- and by the fact that he is not from sub-Saharan Africa. There has never been a Secretary General from sub-Saharan Africa, and nations there assert that it is their turn.
Among the African candidates are Bernard T. G. Chidzero of Zimbabwe, Kenneth Dadzie of Ghana, Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria and Olara Otunnu of Uganda.
Mr. Chidzero, an economist, is Finance Minister of Zimbabwe and spent years as a United Nations civil servant. Mr. Dadzie is secretary general of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and has held posts in Ghana's foreign service and at the United Nations.
General Obasanjo took power in Nigeria in a 1975 coup, then stepped down after democratic elections were held in 1979. Mr. Otunnu studied at Oxford and Harvard and once had his own law practice in New York City. He served as Uganda's representative at the United Nations in the Government that overthrew Idi Amin.
 
3 Europeans
 The only woman currently considered a serious candidate is Gro Harlem Brundtland, now Prime Minister of Norway for the third time, and head of the Norwegian Labor Party for the past decade.
Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, and Margaret Thatcher, the former Prime Minister of Britain, have also been advanced as candidates, but, diplomats say, mostly by the press.
The next Secretary General will be expected to have managerial skills to match the diplomatic prowess that is required. The United Nations has long been considered to be a bloated, inefficient bureaucracy.
Leading member nations, led by the United States, have made it clear that the new Secretary General will be expected to clean house and reorganize the United Nations into a leaner, more responsive organization.

(Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines After Fed Acts to Trim Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower yesterday as the Federal Reserve took steps to push interest rates downward.
The Fed added reserves to the nation's banking system, a move that makes it cheaper for banks to borrow money. The step was seen as a signal by the central bank that it wanted lower interest rates to stop the economy from slipping back into recession. 
 Analysts said the Fed had reduced its target for the Federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans to 5.5 percent from 5.75 percent. When the funds rate declines, other interest rates often follow.
Since the dollar is supported by higher rates, news that the Fed had relaxed its stance hurt the currency.
"As long as the economy flutters and the Fed needs to ease monetary policy, the dollar will suffer in the short run," said Ronald H. Holzer, chief foreign exchange dealer with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
Analysts said the Fed was forced to move to reduce interest rates after a surprisingly weak unemployment report last week and other data that have cast doubt on the economic recovery.
The British pound gained against the dollar. Sterling rose to $1.7145 in New York, from $1.7110 late Monday, and to $1.7125 in London, from $1.7095.
The dollar also weakened against the Japanese yen amid reports that the Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, under pressure to resign over Japan's stock scandal, has decided to step down.
In the stock scandal, Japan's leading brokerages compensated well-heeled clients approximately $1.3 billion for losses, angering small investors. The scandal involves 17 brokerages.
John McCarthy, chief dealer with Algemene Bank Nederland, said the reports pushed the yen higher against the dollar and the German mark.
The dollar fell sharply to 135.50 yen in New York, from 136.65 late Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.62 yen, to 136.68, and in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 135.60 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.7085 German marks, down from 1.71675; 1.4930 Swiss francs, down from 1.4960; 5.8125 French francs, down from 5.8410; 1,279.00 Italian lire, down from 1,283.675, and 1.14825 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14945.
Gold edged higher in New York, picking up 50 cents and closing at $356.70 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $357.20, up 85 cents.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Fall in Week

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on short-term securities, both money market funds and certificates of deposit, moved down significantly during the last week, continuing their recent downtrend.
Rates will probably drop ven lower, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest-rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla. 
 "Banks came to the realization this week that there is no quick fix for the economy," Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday. "This thinking is dragging savings yields downward even faster than in recent weeks. The numbers are bound to get lower, especially on short-term certificates of deposits."
Sharply lower yields on three-month Treasury bills had an important impact, closing at 5.42 percent yesterday, compared with 5.51 percent Monday.
Among the major banks in the New York area, the largest change in the return on money-market accounts was reported by Citibank, down 25 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Also, both Citibank and the Bank of Tokyo in New York reduced their yields on three- and six-month certificates of deposit by 20 basis points, a sharp reduction.
The average six-month certificate of deposit among major New York area banks was down 6 basis points, to 5.53 percent, while the average on three-month certificates was down 7 basis points, to 5.34 percent. Money market accounts at these banks dropped 5 basis points, to 5.07 percent, on average.
The decline at savings institutions was 2 basis points in all three categories, taking the money market accounts on average down to 5.52 percent, three-month certificates to 5.70 percent, and six-month certificates to 5.98 percent.

HEADLINE: Marketing Deal by Vitro And Corning

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
In an indication of the quickening pace of economic integration between the United States and Mexico, Corning Inc. and Vitro S.A., Mexico's giant glass manufacturer, agreed yesterday to market their housewares together around the world.
Pending final negotiations and approvals by the directors and the governments, the partnership would create jointly owned companies in each country with combined annual sales of more than $800 million. 
 The transaction was valued at nearly $300 million, including a cash payment by Vitro to Corning of more than $130 million.
Officials of the two companies insisted that the prospect of a North American Free Trade Agreement had been only one of several incentives. But it appeared to have been an important one.
For Vitro -- which seized more than a quarter of the United States glass container market with its acquisition of the Anchor Glass Container Corporation in 1989 for about $900 million, including $460 million in debt -- the alliance is a powerful shield against the new competition that free trade is expected to unleash in Mexico's glass and housewares industries.
The joint venture follows a familiar pattern at Corning, which has moved into areas like optical fibers and television glass through deals with conglomerates from Germany to Japan. But by its timing, analysts said Corning's accord with Vitro could hardly be more propitious.
After years of failed efforts by the company to force products like its Corning Ware and Pyrex through protectionist barriers along the Rio Grande, Corning gets with this deal a strong foothold in Mexico when consumer buying power is on the rise and tariffs are on the wane.
Perhaps most important, analysts say, the two companies will merge product lines that have been struggling to grow in recent years but appear quite complementary. To the Corning Ware and Visions cookware, Pyrex bakeware, Revere Ware and Corelle dinnerware of its American partner, Vitro will add its Crisa glassware and stemware, Termocrisa and Fortecrisa dinnerware and Cien and Kristaluxus crystal ware.
"The consumer-products division has unquestionably been Corning's sore spot over the last couple of years," said Jonathan Goldfarb, who follows the conglomerate for Merrill Lynch Research. "There is a reasonable chance that with this combination, the new company is going to make strategic sense."
Corning stock rose $1.50 yesterday, to $65.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Officials of the two companies said their distribution networks for housewares would probably be only the first thing they would share.
Down the road, a Vitro official suggested, the two companies might get together to sell products like Corning's fiber optics technologies to Mexicans, who are abused by what they are certain is some of the worst telephone service in the world. A Corning official, on the other hand, said he thought the fiber-optics division would be able to market its products in Mexico without any help.
Amid the increasing number of Mexican-American joint ventures that have taken place since Mexico began knocking down trade and investment barriers in 1988, the letter of agreement signed yesterday formalizes at least one of the largest. But more than its scale, the accord is distinguished by its balance.
The deal differs from the one last month that joined the two countries' biggest retailers, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Cifra, S.A., in a plan to open warehouse-style stores in Mexico.
"What distinguishes this joint venture from the others is that it goes both ways and encompasses true globalization," Julio Escamez, the president of Vitro-Crisa, the group's glassware division, said from the company headquarters in Monterrey, Mexico. "We both needed to broaden our product lines."
Corning's chairman, James R. Houghton, said in a telephone interview that he expected the deal to be completed by the end of the year. He and Richard Dulude, Corning's vice chairman for consumer products, recalled that the company had sought a way into Mexico for years. Until two years ago, they were daunted by Mexican tariffs on housewares of 100 percent. But the continued drop of tariffs now at 20 percent is just part of the attraction, Mr. Dulude said.
"Whether the Mexican market opens or not, the standard of living is going to increase and the consumer housewares business is going to increase as well," he said. "Someone is going to take advantage of that."

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Yields Cut as Demand Rises For New York City Bonds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Strong demand yesterday for a $749.5 million issue of New York City bonds led securities dealers to reduce bond yields by about a tenth of a percentage point from the levels proposed earlier in the week.
Underwriters led by Merrill Lynch late yesterday set yields for $705.9 million of tax-exempt bonds ranging from 6.40 percent for bonds due in 1993 to 7.70 percent in 1998, 7.80 percent in 2002 and 8.10 percent in 2012 through 2021. 
 The financing also included $43.6 million of taxable bonds, whose interest payments are subject to Federal income tax but exempt from state and city income tax. Yields were set at 9.78 percent for bonds due in 1996 and 109.90 percent in 2010 and 2011.
Non-interest-bearing zero-coupon bonds were offered with a top yield of 7.80 percent for tax-exempt bonds due in 2001 and 10.36 percent for taxable bonds due in the same year.
An official at Merrill Lynch, said the bond sale had benefited from an intensive effort by city officials to make telephone calls and personal visits with major investors at insurance companies and mutual funds.
"There was much more broad-based institutional business than earlier sales," he said. Yesterday's move by the Federal Reserve to reduce short-term interest rates "didn't hurt," he added, although it was clear even before the Fed's move that the interest rates on the city bonds would be reduced.
Analysts noted that in the last few months a very light supply of new bond issues from local governments and authorities in New York State, plus the city's progress in creating a plan for a balanced budget, had allowed interest rates on New York City bonds to decline sharply from March.
The 8.10 percent yield for long-term city bonds offered yesterday was well below the 8.60 percent yield at which similar bonds traded in the late winter. During the same period, other bond yields have declined by about three-tenths of a percentage point.
The next city bond sale is a $950 million financing planned for October, with proceeds to be used for defeasing outstanding bonds that are backed by insurance companies or commercial bank letters of credit. By defeasing those bonds, a process where payment of interest and principal will come from a pool of Treasury securities rather than from the city, the city will be able to issue more bonds in the future backed by insurance companies or bank letters of credit. Those institutions are unwilling to provide backing for more city bonds at present because it would result in too great a concentration of risk to one borrower.
By December, the city plans to take advantage of the renewed willingness of bond insurance firms and banks to back its debt by issuing variable-rate bonds. Those bonds, on which interest rates could be adjusted as often as daily, generally require backing by banks, but can be sold with interest rates as low as 2 percent or 3 percent, according to Michael W. Geffrard, deputy executive director in the city's Office of Economic Development.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Zeroing In on Oil Far Below the Sea

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
Three discoveries this spring of large oil and gas deposits miles beneath the surface of the Gulf of Mexico marked a triumph for one of the newest advances in exploration technology: the precise, three-dimensional mapping of rock layers under the ocean floor.
The latest exploration techniques, combined with new methods of drilling in deep water, promise to substantially expand the nation's oil resources and lower production costs. The Gulf of Mexico discoveries buttressed 1989 estimates by the United States Geological Survey and the Minerals Management Service that the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico could eventually yield nearly as much oil as the estimated 10 billion barrels of Prudhoe Bay in Alaska. 
 The technique, known as seismic analysis, was once a clumsy art of bouncing sound waves off rock layers miles below the earth's crust, then recording the speed of the echoes' return to the surface. Now, elaborate electronic measuring devices and high-speed supercomputers are able to render three-dimensional maps and pictures of geological formations 8,000 feet below a sea floor, itself under more than a mile of water.
During the last five years, seismic analysis has been transformed into a booming multibillion-dollar business. The move into deep-water regions, including the Mississippi Canyon area southeast of New Orleans, the site of the three new fields, was hastened in the late 1980's by advances that have lowered exploration and development costs and improved drillers' chances for direct hits.
Drilling platforms tethered to the seabed by steel cables have the potential to extend drilling and production to depths of 7,000 feet of water before the end of the decade. Most platforms are now supported by towers, some taller than Chicago's 1,454-foot Sears Tower, that allow drilling in water no deeper than 1,350 feet.
The new discoveries in the gulf were in water as deep as 4,300 feet, in the case of an Exxon find. The current depth record for oil production is held by a Conoco platform in 1,750 feet of water that began producing oil and gas in 1989.
The placing of wells drilled from these tethered platforms has been sharply improved by clearer mapping of geological formations, thanks to three-dimensional seismic measurements, which are more precise over water than on land. Supercomputers now process huge amounts of seismic data at faster speeds and lower costs than ever before.
"Three-D seismic is not a magic bullet, but it is playing a major role in the deep-water gulf," said Paul R. Leibman, oil analyst at Petrie Parkman & Company, an investment banking firm in Denver. "The industry is simply dealing with much better data."
The biggest of the oil and gas discoveries, by a partnership of Shell Oil and B. P. Exploration in 3,100 feet of water 130 miles southeast of New Orleans, has some industry experts estimating that it could prove to be the gulf's largest ever, the equivalent of more than 700 million barrels of oil.
Shell Oil was cautious, describing the find as "potentially significant." But the company added that the discovery might be larger than another site found in 1989 that is likely to yield more than 220 million barrels of oil. Soon after Shell's announcement this spring, Exxon and a Conoco-Oryx Energy partnership told of their own discoveries.
 
Making a Gamble Safer
 A deep-water drilling effort can cost as much as the $1.3 billion, more than half for the platform, that Shell has budgeted to develop its 1989 find. The Shell platform is scheduled to produce oil at a new record depth of 2,860 feet of water beginning in 1993.
The new seismic exploration technique has increased the willingness of oil companies to make such huge wagers. "This has had a powerful effect on oil-drilling economics," said Suzanne L. Cook, an oilfield services analyst at Merrill Lynch. "You can explore with seismic and save the costs of drilling in the wrong spot."
Scoring a hit with one of every six wells drilled with the aid of 3-D seismic studies now is considered a good average, compared with one of every ten wells in 1980, when this technique was rarely used, she said. Each deep-water platform can drill as many as 20 wells. With the promise of a quicker payoff, oil companies have decided it makes sense to raise their capital spending on the new exploration techniques despite the unpredictability of oil prices.
Mrs. Cook estimated that demand for seismic services, to record and analyze data from around the globe, will more than double, to $6.3 billion, in 1995, from $2.6 billion this year.
 
Helping an Aging Field
 Most of the work is focused on aging oilfields. Production in an aging and once-prolific field off the coast of Louisiana, Bay Marchand, more than doubled last year after Chevron obtained 3-D seismic data of the area from Western Atlas International. Bay Marchand has been the most productive field in the gulf, with more than 500 million barrels of oil pumped since the 1940's.
As oil executives gain more confidence in 3-D seismic mapping, more companies have begun using the technique to explore for huge new fields. Many companies have to rely more on outside help since they slashed their own research staffs when oil prices plunged in 1986. They are now, in effect, leasing the latest in computer-related analytical tools and expertise from a handful of oilfield service companies.
These companies, Western Atlas, Schlumberger, Halliburton and Landmark Graphics among others, have poured millions into developing new products and services in a bruising but so far profitable battle.
 
Four New Ships
 Western Atlas, the leader in acquiring seismic data, is gambling $130 million on four new ships that it expects to lease to oil prospectors at monthly rates as high as $2 million. The company now operates 30 ships around the world that are equipped to scan rock layers eight miles below the sea floor.
"We're at the stage where it takes big investments to get big multiples" in new business, said Neal P. Cramer, president of Western Geophysical, the seismic services unit of Western Atlas. Its capital budget for the 1992 fiscal year, which begins Thursday, is up 70 percent, to $204 million.
The dominance of Western Atlas, based in Houston, in collecting seismic data on land and sea has made it the fastest-growing unit of Litton Industries. Sales are expected to reach $1.1 billion for the fiscal year that ended July 31, up from $750 million in 1988. Litton has owned 70 percent of Western Atlas since the company was formed in a 1987 merger. Dresser Industries owns 30 percent.
Western Atlas is betting that more oil companies will buy 3-D seismic maps of regions in the gulf where those companies are considering bids for offshore leases from the Government.
Landmark Graphics, the leading supplier of computer software for transforming seismic surveys into three-dimensional color images, posted $89.9 million in revenues for the fiscal year ended June 30, up from $68.7 million in the 1990 fiscal year.
Oil experts have long seen promise in unexplored rock formations lying beneath at least 3,000 feet of water, and more than 100 miles south of the coast stretching from Louisiana to Florida.
The sloping, undersea terrain holds the sort of thick sand layers that often contain oil. Yet these reserves had been difficult to find with older seismic studies that portrayed the seabed in one two-dimensional slice at a time. The sands are below wide salt layers that distort the sound-reflection measurements at the heart of seismic pictures.
New methods that generate far more data yield a clearer view of oil deposits below the salt layers.
A ship trolling at about 4 miles an hour fires dozens of submerged air guns in a timed sequence. The reflections of each signal change speed each time they pass through a different rock layer beneath the seabed; the more dense the material, the slower the echo.
In the most advanced Western Geophysical system, these sound reflections, or echoes, are captured thousands of times a second by 7,700 very sensitive fiber-optic recorders positioned behind the ship in each of two three-mile-long cables that flank the air guns.
The staggering numbers of measurements contribute to sharper readings of rock layers just as a CAT scanner helps physicians see into a patient's body. Computers on the ship record the signals on magnetic tape that is later processed by supercomputers at Western Geophysical's data center in Houston.
The seismic portrait is then analyzed by the oil companies, who compare it with information stored over the years from rock samples taken from wells drilled in the region.

Running on either side of the air guns are two three-mile-long detector cables containing thousands of receivers. These pick up the sound waves as they are reflected from the layers of rock beneath the ocean floor. (Lon Harding/Litton Industries)
 
Diagram: "A New Way of Exploring for Oil"
 Seismic technology now makes it easier to find oil reserves by mapping rock formations under the seabed.
 In the most advanced system, signals from eight rows of seven air guns are bounced off the rock formations and collected in thousands of receivers, known as hydrophones, attached to three-mile-long cables running on each side of the air guns.
 The data are gathered by a computer that creates a detailed map of the geology under the seabed. (Source: Western Atlas International) (pg. D7)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Article Raises New Concern About Family Media's Fate

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
FAMILY MEDIA, the New York publisher whose magazines include Health and Discover, has been in precarious financial condition for well over a year. And now its fate has been clouded further by the publication of an article in Advertising Age that portrays the company as urgently trying to sell its titles to other publishers and nearing bankruptcy.
The article, on the trade weekly's front page this week, has once again stirred concerns within the advertising and media communities. In January, speculation about the survival of the company, which has about 200 employees, grew when it closed one magazine, Savvy Woman, and put its six others up for sale. But when no sales were forthcoming, the speculation died down -- until now. 
 "They seemed to be slogging along," Roberta Garfinkle, vice president and director of print media at McCann-Erickson, New York, said in an interview yesterday. "Then it all started up again with a vengeance."
"This really adds fuel to the fire," Ms. Garfinkle said of the article. "I don't see how they can survive this."
What becomes of Family Media is of intense interest to advertising and media executives. If it goes out of business, it will underscore the severity of the magazine ad slump, now in its second year and threatening to become the worst in decades.
"It really addresses what has gone on during the recession," said Bob Zach, senior vice president and media director of Chiat/Day/Mojo, New York. If leading magazines are doing so badly, he added, "what happens to the tertiary titles that a Family Media represents is that they dry up and go out of business."
Repeated requests over the last two days to talk to Robert E. Riordan, Family Media's chairman, or Bruce Barnet, its president, were answered yesterday by Leslie Jay, a company spokeswoman. She said that Mr. Riordan would not be available until today.
Family Media employees, who asked not to be identified, said the company had scheduled staff meetings for this morning at its offices in Manhattan. Some employees said their colleagues were packing their belongings. Others said they had been told not to continue work on coming issues.
Family Media's titles, in addition to Health and Discover, are Golf Illustrated, Homeowner, 1,001 Home Ideas and World Tennis, which is being renamed Tennis Illustrated. They generally face fierce competition from magazines published by larger, better-financed companies.
"If they had books that were strong books, primary books in their categories, perhaps the company, if scaled back, could survive," Ms. Garfinkle said.
The Advertising Age article paints a portrait of a publisher forced to offer its magazines for sale, in a market in which media properties are selling for far less than they did five years ago, to meet a debt load estimated at $60 million to $70 million.
Executives at Veronis, Suhler & Associates, the investment banking firm that Advertising Age named as having been retained by Family Media, did not return telephone calls made over the last two days.
During the 80's, Mr. Riordan, a longtime magazine industry executive who specialized in circulation, was lionized as a "Mr. Fix-It" of magazines. He bought troubled titles -- like Discover, which he purchased from Time Inc. -- improved their circulation and financial operations, then sold them or used the profits they generated to acquire more properties (as well as a yacht he rechristened after Savvy, the women's business magazine he later closed).
Mr. Riordan's greatest success came with The Ladies' Home Journal, which he purchased in 1982 from Charter for an estimated $8 million and sold to Meredith four years later for $92 million.
Industry executives trace the start of Family Media's problems to 1988, when the company spent lavishly to introduce two women's fashion titles, Taxi and Model. They were closed two years later after losing millions of dollars. And by that time, the ad recession was in full force.

HEADLINE: To Counter Tax Cynics, Florio's Party Tries Ads

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Amid indications that their $750 million property-tax rebate program is not winning as many friends as they had hoped going into the fall elections, New Jersey Democrats announced today a statewide radio advertising campaign to promote the program.
Some 2.2 million homestead rebate checks began going out last week, and while most recipients welcome the money -- up to $500 -- many are complaining that it does little to counter the record $2.8 billion tax increase that Gov. Jim Florio pushed through the Legislature last year. 
Nick Theodorakis, who remembers when his was the only hot-dog cart on the Morristown green and can now count four, was one of those unimpressed with his rebate check.
 
'No Business and No Money'
 He said that the $430 rebate he received was "better than nothing" but that it would not let him keep his home in Morristown. His property taxes are now $5,000, he said, and he plans to sell the house and become a renter.
"New Jersey is very expensive," he said. "There's no business and no money, and a lot of people are losing their homes and moving."
Ralph Antorello of Carteret, a safety officer with a utility company, put it this way in Union when asked about the Governor's rebates: "I think the rebate program stinks, and I think he stinks."
"I'm paying far more than I used to in taxes and getting back $191," he said. "If he thinks he's buying my vote with the rebate, then that's just ridiculous. I wouldn't vote for Florio if he was running against Mikhail Gorbachev."
To counter such sentiments, Democrats announced a radio advertising campaign featuring a Maplewood woman -- a Democratic committeewoman, they acknowledged -- expressing her pleasure over a $500 rebate, which she says will help with a grandchild on the way.
 
Legislative Control at Stake
 The Democratic advertising campaign comes on the heels of a Republican direct-mail and radio advertising effort begun last week to attack the rebates, the keystone of Democratic efforts to retain control of the Legislature next November.
Although there are no polling data yet to gauge the impact, random interviews with people on the street suggest that the rebates have done little to assuage voter anger over increases in both the state sales and income taxes.
Michelle Sellin, manager of a Bachrach Photographers studio in Morristown, said that she and her husband had just received a $100 rebate check and that "it didn't do anything."
"We're paying a lot more, especially for schools, than we got back," she said.
Ann Connor of Morris, a shopper, said that while she believed Mr. Florio was "trying to do the right thing" with the rebates, "it doesn't amount to a hill of beans."
Hoping to capitalize on such sentiments, New Jersey Republicans, in their radio and mail campaign, labeled the rebate checks "another Florio ripoff."
Brochures featuring a likeness of the Governor and the caption "In Florio We Trust?" on the envelope were mailed to 300,000 taxpayers across the state, timed to arrive just before the first rebate checks. Radio commercials accused the Governor of "making a very big deal over a very small rebate."
The property-tax rebate checks to some two million homeowners and renters in the state will total about $750 million, but Democrats say other tax relief will flow from the state's assumption of county welfare costs, new aid to public schools and ceilings on local spending.
Mr. Florio has repeatedly maintained that once the benefits of the $2.8 billion tax increase begin to be known, his popularity will rebound.
All 80 seats in the Assembly and all 40 in the Senate are at stake in November, and the record tax increase is the major issue. Democrats are banking heavily on the rebates to protect their majority in both houses.
The Governor personally delivered the first rebate checks to four New Jersey families last week, and on Saturday he took an hour of prime time on WWOR-TV in Secaucus to promote his new budget and the tax rebates.
The address was largely ignored, however. The station reported that only about 70,000 households, 1 percent of the potential market, tuned in. That was fewer even than the 112,000 who watched Prince Charles of Britain discuss architecture on a rival station.
Indeed, there were some citizens who knew nothing of the rebates, but were well aware of economic problems.
 
Squeezed by High Costs
 Teddy Koniarelis, behind the counter at the Hamburger Depot in Morristown, said he was unaware of the program but was highly aware of being squeezed by the cost of health and car insurance, despite a widely publicized program by Governor Florio to cut the auto insurance rate.
"I've got to have a car to get to work, so I paid my auto insurance," he said, "but I can't pay both, so I had to drop my health insurance. I couldn't do anything else. Everything is just too expensive."
With voter discontent high and the Republicans doing all they can to capitalize on it, Steve DeMicco, executive director of the Democratic State Committee, today played for reporters a new radio commercial in which a woman identified only as "Mrs. Romano of Maplewood" attacks Republicans for "sending out political junk mail making fun" of the rebates.
"I'm sick of politics," she says in the commercial praising the rebate program.
Pressed by reporters about Mrs. Romano's own political views, Mr. DeMicco conceded that she was a Democratic committeewoman.

HEADLINE: Heeding the Painful Signal of Insufficient Credit

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The last time Alan Greenspan spoke publicly about the economy, in mid-July, the Federal Reserve Board chairman optimistically reported that the recession appeared to be over, with a "solid economic recovery" on the horizon. The central bank's move yesterday to lower short- term interest rates suggests that some of the optimism has faded.
"The Fed took out an insurance policy that the recovery will continue," said Robert Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Hutton, expressing a sentiment that some Fed officials seem to share. 
 The bit of news that finally prompted the Fed's policy makers to push down interest rates for the first time since April 30 came on Friday, when the Labor Department reported that jobs continued to disappear in July. Until last week, the Fed had been sticking to a wait-and-see policy, not wanting to lower rates another notch for fear that this might result in too strong a recovery and a rise in the inflation rate.
But in the wake of Friday's weaker-than-expected job report, a weekend of telephone consultation produced what appears to have been a consensus among the Fed's policy makers to reduce the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for loans. The rate went to 5 1/2 percent yesterday from 5 3/4 percent.
 
Two Other Factors
 The ingredients for this decision, however, went beyond the poor employment numbers -- 51,000 jobs lost in July, mostly from layoffs -- and the desire for some insurance that a recovery will in fact materialize. Two other elements also played a role: the nation's low annual inflation rate -- less than 3 percent as measured by the Consumer Price Index -- and, above all, weak recent growth in the nation's money supply.
The alarming money supply numbers were a painful signal that the nation's banks and other lenders continued to hold back on credit. In turn, this lack of sufficient financing for new construction, for home and car purchases and for other activities has held back the economy, in the view of Fed officials and other economists.
"Any one of these four elements is not likely to be a strong enough reason to lower rates, but if you take all of them together, a stronger case can be made," said Roger Guffey, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.
Mr. Guffey has been among the policy makers most reluctant to lower rates, on the ground that too rapid a recovery might bring higher inflation. But his statement yesterday appeared to reflect a common concern among the Fed's policy makers that the recovery might be in danger. These policy makers are Mr. Greenspan, the four other sitting Fed governors and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks.
 
Exercising Power
 The Fed exercises its power over rates mostly through its control of the funds rate, which is a rough proxy for what banks pay for much of the money they take in and then lend out for things like car loans, home equity loans, construction financing and consumer credit. When the funds rate comes down, as it did yesterday, lenders in effect pay less for funds. As a result, the spread widens between what lenders pay for money and what they charge for loans.
This bigger profit should encourage banks to make more loans, and since new lending helps to increase the amount of money circulating in the economy, money supply should grow. But that has not happened, although the Fed has pushed the funds rate down in quarter-point steps from more than 7 percent in December.
Quite the contrary, in recent weeks, the Fed's favorite measure of money supply -- M2, a combination of currency and various forms of savings -- has fallen from a 3 percent annual growth rate to a disconcertingly small 2.7 percent. That is barely above what the Fed considers its lowest acceptable growth target: 2.5 percent a year.
 
Uniting Opinion
 More than any other development, weak money supply growth seems to unite Fed policy makers, tending to convince both the inflation-fighters and those more concerned about insuring the recovery of the need to lower interest rates.
Lyle Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association and a former Fed governor, explained the thinking this way: "You start with the recognition that this recovery, at best, will be a weak one; that is a widely held view, shared by the Fed. In the context of weak economic growth, you tend to listen harder to what M2 is telling you: that the credit crunch remains a severe problem."
The action yesterday came just two weeks before the Fed policy makers gather in Washington for one of their periodic meetings. That raised the question of why the Fed did not wait until after the meeting to lower the funds rate. One explanation, offered by economists outside the Fed, was that the latest developments were alarming enough to lower rates quickly.
Another explanation, offered by some Fed officials, was that the Fed sought to act in advance of the Treasury's auction this week of billions of dollars in new securities. If the rate cut had been postponed until next week, after the auction, the timing would have been close enough to the policy makers' meeting to wait until afterward before taking any action. And waiting until late August might indeed have been a hardship for the economy.

HEADLINE: Easing by Fed Helps Dow Rise 38.24

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Lifted mainly by news of an easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board, stock prices rose sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average landing just 8 points short of its record close two months ago. Some other indexes reached record levels.
The Dow rose by 38.24, or 1.3 percent, to 3,027.28. Trading was moderately heavy at 174.6 million shares. Advancing issues outpaced decliners by 1095 to 502. The stock exchange reported that 121 companies made new highs, while just 9 fell to new lows. 
 Indexes of large stocks soared to new highs, reflecting the broad strength of the advance. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.56, to 390.62, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index climbed 2.72, to 213.71. Both indexes ended the day less than a point over their previous records, set April 17.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index of smaller and more volatile stocks rose 2.59, to 505.20, with the Amex composite up 0.17, to 366.88.
In the morning, stocks drifted lower with many investors standing on the sidelines using the quarterly refunding as an excuse not to participate actively. Trading was choppy and investors showed little enthusiasm until the Fed added money to the banking system.
This was a major reason behind the market's rally yesterday including moderately higher bond prices that gave much needed support to the stock market.
According to Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trades by institutional investors, there were six sell programs and two sell programs yesterday, totaling nearly two hours. The six buy programs took up 82 minutes and during that time the Dow added 37.78 points, while the two sell programs ran a combined 28 minutes, with the Dow adding 11.64 points during that time.
Rao Chalasani, chief investment stategist for Kemper Securities Group in Chicago, said besides the Fed easing yesterday, the first leg of the Government quarterly refunding, the auction of three-year notes, went well and that added market support.
Among the most actively traded issues by volume was Philip Morris Companies, with 3.76 million shares traded. The stock rose 2 5/8 to close at 71 1/2.
Time Warner stock jumped 3 points higher in trading yesterday after completion of a rights offering that raised $2.76 billion. The stock closed at 88.
Motorola rose by 1 3/8, to 66 5/8. Lior Bregman, Oppenheimer analyst, recommended the stock on news that the company has developed a new cellular telephone weighing less than a half pound.
The First American Bank Corporation of Kalamazoo, Mich., saw its stock rise 1 point, to 30 1/2. It plans to buy the Champion Federal Savings and Loan Association of Bloomington pending approval of regulators.
Commodore International, a computer maker, saw its stock fall 1 3/8, to 11 7/8, after the company reported lower fourth-quarter earnings that were below Wall Street estimates.
Imcera Group Inc., a chemical company, rose 1 3/8, to 110 1/4, after reporting a 76 percent increase in its 1991 earnings.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
FEDERAL RESERVE MOVES TO REDUCE SHORT-TERM RATES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve pushed short-term interest rates down a notch yesterday, a move that analysts said was needed to stimulate the economy, which is making only a sluggish recovery from the recession.
By continuing to reduce interest rates -- a process the Federal Reserve started in mid-1989, when the economy began sliding into recession -- officials of the nation's central bank hope to encourage consumers and businesses to spend and borrow more money. 
 With inflation widely expected to remain below 4 percent, analysts said the Federal Reserve's primary concern now was to make sure that the economy grows more rapidly in coming months. By lowering the Federal funds rate, a closely watched rate for overnight bank loans, the Federal Reserve set the stage for declines in other interest rates, including home mortgages, other consumer loans and yields on certificates of deposit.
 
'An Insurance Policy'
 "This was an insurance policy taken by the Fed to help prevent the economy from sliding back into recession," said Irwin Kellner, chief economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Many economists said the pressure to cut short-term interest rates was increased by last Friday's announcement of a decline of 51,000 workers on payrolls of large companies during July.
The move suggested that some of the optimism expressed by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, in mid-July, that a "solid economic recovery" appeared to be on the horizon, had faded. [Page D8.]
"The inflation picture looks awfully good, and that gives the Fed more confidence that it can ease," said Donald Fine, chief market strategist for Chase Securities Inc., an affiliate of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
 
Decline in Yields Cited
 He noted that a modest decline in yields on 30-year Treasury bonds yesterday, to 8.17 percent from 8.22 percent on Monday, was a sign that investors also believed that there was little chance that inflation would rise.
Stock traders also responded enthusiastically to the easing of interest rates, bidding prices up. The Dow Jones industrial average rose by 38.24 points, or 1.3 percent, to 3,027.28, landing only eight points short of its record close two months ago. [Page D1.]
Yesterday's action by the Federal Reserve was a technical one that reduced some short-term interest rates only a quarter of a percentage point, but its effects will ripple throughout the financial system.
The central bank temporarily bought Treasury securities, supplying enough credit to the banking system so that the rate for overnight loans between banks in the Federal funds market fell to 5 1/2 percent from the 5 3/4 percent rate that has prevailed since late April. Since June 1989, the Federal Reserve has pushed the overnight loan rate down from 9 3/4 percent.
Because the overnight bank loan rate is a benchmark for other short-term rates, the Federal Reserve's action will soon be felt in broad segments of the economy. Banks, for example, will soon reduce the rates they pay to consumers on certificates of deposit, a move that would encourage consumers to spend money, rather than keep it invested at low interest rates.
 
Banks Slow on Rate Cuts
 As the interest rates paid by banks fall, the banks will eventually lower the rates they charge for loans, including the prime lending rate to which many other rates are pegged. Banks, many of which are saddled with bad real estate loans made in the late 1980's, have been slower than normal to reduce the prime rate, which is now at 8 1/2 percent.
"I doubt that this latest Fed move will be enough to cause the banks to reduce the prime, but it is a step in that direction," said Mr. Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover.
Interest rates on home mortgages will also come down to the extent that long-term interest rates continue to decline. Since July 26, Treasury bond yields have fallen nearly two-tenths of a percentage point, to their lowest levels since May. But mortgage rates remain well above the 9 percent level that economists say could be needed to stimulate an increase in the building and buying of homes.
Many analysts expect that the Federal Reserve may continue to push interest rates lower in coming weeks to guarantee that the economy does not falter. "With inflation falling to 3 1/2 percent, we are going to see a lot more Fed moves to lower rates before this is over," said Stephen D. Slifer, executive vice president at Lehman Brothers Inc., a securities firm that is a subsidiary of the American Express Company.
But bankers contended that lower interest rates alone might not be enough to encourage the increase in lending that is needed for a more robust economy. Bankers who asked not to be identified because of their need to keep good relations with regulators said they would be more able to issue new loans if bank examinations were less harsh and banks were given more time to solve the problems caused by bad real estate loans.
Although the Federal Reserve made no announcement or formal statement about easing its monetary policy when it temporarily bought Treasury securities at 11.30 A.M., it sent a clear signal to the financial markets.
Within minutes, interest rates on Treasury bills fell by a tenth of a percentage point and bond prices, which go up when yields go down, rallied by half a percentage point.
New York City was among the immediate beneficiaries of the Federal Reserve's move. It was able to reduce interest rates on $750 million of bonds by about a tenth of a percentage point, to 8.10 percent from 8.2 percent, for long-term bonds. The city was planning to reduce rates before the Federal Reserve's action, but securities dealers readily admitted that the central bank's move increased demand for the bonds.
California also benefited, as it cut interest rates to 4.75 percent from 4.85 percent on $2.1 billion of notes due next June. The notes were part of a $4.1 billion short-term financing by the state. Notes are shorter term than bonds, and typically carry lower yields as a result.
 
Below Expected Yield
 The Treasury was another immediate beneficary of the Federal Reserve's action, as it sold $14 billion of new three-year notes at an average yield of 6.92 percent, well below the yield of about 7 percent traders expected. A cut of a tenth of a percentage point in the note yield is equal to an annual savings of about $14 million for the Government.
In advance of today's auction of $12 billion of 10-year Treasury notes, the issue was trading among large institions on a when-issued basis with a yield of 7.95 percent, down from 8.02 percent. The 30-year Treasury bonds to be sold tomorrow were trading at about 8.15 percent, down from 8.21 percent, while the existing 8 1/8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2021 were offered at 99 17/32, or $9,953.13 per $1,000 bond, to yield 8.17 percent, up 19/32, or $5.94 per bond, from a day earlier, when the yield was 8.24 percent.
The modest decline in note and bond yields did not seem to disturb many investors. "Some people will be worried about buying into the market near the top of a rally," said Robert P. Andres, an owner of the Martindale Andres & Godshalkan investment advisory firm. "But I think inflation is going to stay down as the economy grows slowly, and eventually you will see a 7 1/2 percent bond yield."
 
Further Drops Predicted
 Leslie W. Finnemore, a portfolio manager at Colonial U.S. Government Trust, a mutual fund, noted that bond yields "remain attractive relative to inflation, and that the fundamentals of a weak economy and low inflation point to futher declines in yields."
The only people complaining about the Federal Reserve's move were securities firms in the Treasury market because their job of finding buyers for the new Treasury securities was made more difficult by the sudden decline in yields.
The dealers would have preferred the drop in rates to come after the auctions for Treasury notes and bonds were completed, when it would result in large, quick profits for buyers of the securities and the dealers who held them in inventory.

HEADLINE: Many Call, But Few Cancel After Cruise Ship's Sinking

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Travel agents said yesterday that they had received many telephone calls from worried customers after the sinking of a Greek cruise ship off South Africa, but that few had canceled their bookings.
The cause of the sinking of the Oceanos in the Indian Ocean on Sunday is under investigation, and several agents and cruise industry officials said they were hoping it was an accident. 
 Many noted that the industry was only just recovering from the 1985 hijacking of the Achille Lauro, an Italian cruise liner, by Palestinian terrorists, and from a recession that continues to bedevil most of the travel industry.
The Persian Gulf war briefly curtailed cruises to Europe and the Mediterranean earlier this year, but cruise lines scrambled to add more trips to the Caribbean, Alaska and Mexico, and stepped up advertising and promotion.
The strategy appears to have worked: The 860,000 cruise passengers during the first quarter of this year was a 14.2 percent increase over the corresponding period in 1990, according to Chris O'Neill, a spokesman for the Cruise Lines International Association. The association predicts a record 4 million passengers in 1991, up from 3.7 million last year.
"The whole cruise industry was affected for a couple of years by the Achille Lauro, because people were afraid," said Lou Garcia, whose Manhatan public relations firm represents the Epirotiki Lines, the Greek company that owns the Oceanos.
Mr. Garcia said Epirotiki received only "a couple" of cancellations yesterday and some bookings.
Bob Biege, who owns Admiral of the Fleet Cruise Center in Milwaukee, said his agency had calls but no cancellations. "It's nothing like after the Achille Lauro, when we got a lot of the 'tell me about the security' inquiries," he said.
Agents said that this time, most customers seemed to be making a distinction between an act of nature and an act of terrorism.
"An act of terrorism suggests a pattern of behavior, but this was apparently a fluke accident in high seas," said Jill Wall, co-owner with her husband of Vacations at Sea in New Orleans. "But that doesn't mean I'm not very disappointed at the crew's response, or lack thereof."
Other travel agents also criticized Yiannis Avranas, the captain of the Oceanos, who passengers said left his sinking ship before most of them were rescued. All 571 people aboard were saved, but questions remain about the seaworthiness of the 7,500-ton vessel.
"Try to picture a Norweigan captain leaving the ship early," Mr. Biege said. "The whole country would revolt. He'd have been tarred and feathered."
Mr. Garcia defended Captain Avranas. "I think he's been unduly maligned without a fair hearing," he said. "He wasn't running away. After he ordered the ship to be abandoned, he got into a helicopter to supervise the rescue operation."
Still, the sinking of the Oceanos is likely to increase demands for even greater safety regulations for foreign cruise ships that carry mostly Americans. All but two of about 115 cruise ships that operate in the United States are registered in foreign nations. Two years ago, the National Transportation Safety Board warned that many of those ships had serious safety deficiencies.
But Jack Estes, the president of the International Council of Cruise Lines, said yesterday that the safety board "is way off the mark."
"The safety standards of the foreign-flag cruise ships operating under the regulations of the International Maritime Organization, which all of them do," he said, "are as good and in many cases better than the U.S. standards."
 
Avoiding Epirotiki
 Even before the Oceanos sinking, some travel agents said they avoided Epirotiki Lines.
"Epirotiki is used to dealing more with Europeans, who aren't as demanding as Americans," said Steve Snider, a sales agent for Cruises Only in Portland, Ore.
But Americans account for about 40 percent of the passengers on the Mediterranean cruises of Epirotiki, Mr. Garcia said. "We're a major company with nine ships, not just one that went down and now we're out of business," he said.

HEADLINE: Seidman Resigning Banks Job

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
More than a year after the White House tried very publicly to remove him from office, L. William Seidman, the nation's senior bank regulator and a forcefully independent official, today announced his resignation.
The departure of Mr. Seidman promises a dramatic change in the way Washington supervises the banking and savings and loan industries at a pivotal time. In both style and substance, he has dominated the regulatory scene in recent years as a strong presence in Congress and with an alternately warm and cold and then warm again relationship with the Administration since he was named chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in 1985. 
 The Bush Administration has extensively relied on his assessments of the health of the industry, his recommendations for healing the banks and their rapidly deteriorating insurance fund, and his skills to encourage more money from Congress to rescue banks and savings associations. For their part, the banks have found in him a powerful ally who early on rejected any efforts to reduce deposit insurance coverage. The debate that has already begun both over his successor and a reorganization of the regulatory system reflects the void he is expected to leave.
 
An End to Speculation
 In a four-sentence letter to President Bush today, Mr. Seidman, who is 70 years old, said he would step down on Oct. 16, at the end of his terms as chairman of both the F.D.I.C., which oversees the nation's banks, and the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created in 1989 to manage the savings and loan bailout. His resignation, which had been expected for some time, lays to rest speculation he might seek to stay longer through reappointment or by taking advantage of an ambiguity in the law that some lawyers have read to extend his tenure through February 1993.
Mr. Seidman leaves a legacy as the senior banking regulator during one of the most tumultuous periods in the history of American finance, when the Government has committed hundreds of billions of dollars to two the banking and savings and loan crises, the ultimate depths of which are still unknown.
"I feel today as though somebody has removed a shot put from my gullet," he said in an interview today, in the characteristically blunt style that has become a hallmark of his six-year term at the F.D.I.C. "I'm now available for any kind of job that will pay a lot of money to do practically nothing."
President Bush has not decided who will succeed Mr. Seidman, although officials said William Taylor, the senior banking regulator at the Federal Reserve Board, was the leading candidate to head the F.D.I.C.
With the growing problems in the banking industry and the enormous workload facing the head of the savings and loan bailout, a consensus has emerged in Congress and the Administration that the jobs at the two agencies should be filled by two people.
"We'll try to find a successor as soon as possible," the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters. He added that Mr. Seidman had "done a good job in a very difficult time." A separate search for the newly created position of chief executive of the trust corporation has already been started by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
In an attempt to push Mr. Seidman out the door long before his term expired, President Bush said in May last year that he would name Mr. Taylor to succeed Mr. Seidman when Mr. Seidman stepped down. The announcement followed several disputes Mr. Seidman had had with Treasury officials and the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, over bank regulation. Mr. Seidman had indicated he would leave before the end of his term, but he never set a date.
Today, the White House and the Treasury Department declined to discuss Mr. Seidman's successor, sending a clear signal that President Bush is rethinking the appointment of Mr. Taylor and that the Administration may not be ready for another contentious confirmation proceeding this fall on top of the Senate hearings on the nominations of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court and Robert M. Gates to head the Central Intelligence Agency.
 
Questions on Rogue Bank
 In recent weeks, Mr. Taylor has come under sharp questioning in Congress for the Fed's handling of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and his apparently belated discovery, only this year, that for years the rogue bank secretly held ownership interests in several American banks.
Mr. Taylor, a career bank regulator who represented the United States in London last month when officials from around the world seized the banking company, is on vacation this week and could not be reached for comment.
"Given the B.C.C.I. scandal, any nominee who's been with the Fed will have to be checked out quite thoroughly, even someone with as top-notch a reputation as Bill Taylor," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn and a member of the House Banking Committee.
 
Delay Called Unimportant
 A senior Administration official involved in the selection process who insisted on not being identified said the President would likely stand by his earlier decision to appoint Mr. Taylor.
"I wouldn't read anything into the delay" in announcing a successor, the official said. "Seidman's announcement came on the same day that the President was going to Kennebunkport and it came without any forewarning."
Like Mr. Seidman, Mr. Taylor is widely regarded in the banking industry and is not likely to encounter serious opposition. But his confirmation hearing would provide an opportunity for lawmakers to examine how vigorously the Administration and the regulators have supervised B.C.C.I.
A few weeks ago, with Mr. Seidman's support, the Treasury Department began a search to find someone to take over the Government rescue of the savings and loan industry, which by some estimates could cost taxpayers $500 billion over 40 years. The Administration's search is widely seen as pre-emptive strike intended to prevent Congress from passing legislation that would drastically alter the way the Government is conducting the bailout, which was authorized by Congress in 1989.
The appointment of new heads of the insurance corporation and the trust corporation will come at the same time Congress is considering Administration requests totaling $150 billion to keep the fund that protects bank deposits afloat and continue the bailout of the savings industry. The House and Senate will also be debating legislation that could radically alter the landscape for banking, eliminating decades-old barriers that have restricted banks from expanding across state lines and into the securities and insurance businesses.
Under Mr. Seidman's leadership, the F.D.I.C. has grown to become one of the most powerful institutions in Washington, deciding the fate of hundreds of large and small banks around the nation, and doling out billions of dollars in contracts to manage the assets of failed banks and more than $600 million annually in legal fees. By some accounts, it has also run out of money and now threatens to become another large taxpayer burden.
 
Reward for Early Success
 Mr. Seidman's early successes in handling banks and his political popularity on Capitol Hill led Congress to give him the second post in 1989 as the senior regulator overseeing the bailout of the nation's savings and loans.
His tenure has also been punctuated by alternating close and distant relations with the Administration, which at some points has sought to rely upon him for political convenience and at other times has been frustrated by its inability to control his powerful assertions of independence.
"Seidman made his mark and will best be remembered for the fact that in the late 1980's, when others in the Administration swept the problems under the rug, he told the truth," Mr. Schumer said. "For that reason, he gained credibility and his integrity was impeccable."
Mr. Seidman's His influence in Congress remains strong. Both the House and the Senate banking committees recently adopted legislation that expands the authority of the F.D.I.C., moves described by one lawmaker as "a bouquet to Bill."
 
A Growth Agency
 When Mr. Seidman assumed his job as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in 1985, it was a backwater post overseeing an agency that handled a few dozen bank failures annually. It also ran an insurance fund that grew within two years to $18 billion, its greatest worth since its creation in 1934.
Before taking the F.D.I.C. job, he had been a senior economic adviser to President Gerald R. Ford, vice chairman of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, dean of the Business College of Arizona State University and a campaign adviser to former Gov. George Romney of Michigan.

The Fed pushed short-term interest rates down a notch, a move analysts said was needed to stimulate the economy, which is making only a sluggish recovery from recession. The Federal funds rate fell to 5 1/2 percent from the 5 3/4 percent. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: For Weicker, Today Is Day For Budget: Sign or Veto

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced today that he would sign or veto a budget without an income tax on Wednesday, and then spent the rest of the day gathering support for the veto his opponents in the legislature are expecting.
The legislators who put together the budget, which continues Connecticut's reliance on a sales tax, began a counterattack against the editorials and interest groups calling for a veto, pointing out that nearly all of the goods and services subject to the sales tax for the first time under their plan would also be taxed under proposals based on an income tax. 
 They also discussed for the first time the possibility of taking the question of an income tax to a public referendum if Mr. Weicker vetoes this budget, as he has two previous ones, and the legislature cannot override him.
 
Warning on Credit Rating
 "It's pretty clear at this point that if the Governor is going to continue to veto, and the legislature is going to continue to pass conventional budgets, then maybe the public should be given the chance to decide," said the State Senate president, John B. Larson, whose opposition to an income tax has blocked it in the Senate.
With Connecticut apparently headed for another deadlock that could leave it without money to operate, a bond-rating agency warned that its credit rating was threatened by its "continuing budget impasse and deteriorating financial condition."
The agency, Standard & Poor's, assigned a temporary SP1+ rating to $319 million of bond-anticipation notes and placed the rating on "credit watch," meaning that it was in danger of being revised downward. The agency also placed the state's AA rating on $3.7 billion of general-obligation bonds on a credit watch, saying those bonds could be downgraded to A because of the lack of a state budget.
 
Criticism From Budget Office

Governor Weicker's budget office has criticized the budget passed by the legislature not only for failing to cut the sales tax and business taxes, which he says is necessary to stimulate the economy, but also for failing to start repaying the state's accumulated deficit of $1.3 billion.
Connecticut is now the only state still without a budget. The state government has been kept going with temporary spending resolutions since the fiscal year began on July 1, and it is operating this week on the basis of an executive order issued by Governor Weicker on Sunday as the last temporary measure expired. Mr. Weicker, saying he would announce his decision at noon on Wednesday, spent the day meeting with business executives and economists today to get advice on whether to sign the budget and end the state's fiscal crisis, or veto it and fight on.
Through the afternoon his office distributed updates on the number of telephone calls being received (by day's end, 3,163 urging him to veto the budget, and 533 urging him to sign it) and samples of telegrams and faxes coming into the office.
Those calling for a veto ranged from retirees who may have to pay more under the state's high tax on dividends and interest, rather than less under an income tax, to the chief executives of businesses from the Stanley Works to People's Bank, as well as the League of Women Voters.
In addition, officials of state employee unions called a news conference to say again that the budget, known as Coalition III, would kill their offer to defer pay raises and make concessions in pension and health-insurance plans.
The unions agreed to the concessions, worth $327 million, in return for a pledge from Mr. Weicker not to lay off workers in this fiscal year. The budget sent to the Governor could require layoffs. "With Coalition III, the concessions deal is dead," said Robert Krzys, a spokesman for the unions.
 
'Came in Third'
 Mr. Weicker, when told of the referendum talk, said, "The guy who last suggested that came in third in the gubernatorial race." He was referring to Bruce A. Morrison, the Democrat in the race Mr. Weicker won last November, who had campaigned on a promise not to propose an income tax until the idea had been put to the voters.
"We're not going to run the state by referendum," Mr. Weicker said at the end of the day. "That comes every four years, and it's called an election."
Leaders of the coalition of Republicans and moderate Democrats that has put together, and passed, three budgets without an income tax were plainly irritated today by the barrage of calls for a third veto.
They complained that reporters, in scrutinizing their $7.6 billion budget and its new and higher taxes and fees, were not pointing out that income-tax plans would raise taxes even more, and in any case contained some of the same tax increases being criticized.
Under the most recent income-tax plan, for example, the sales tax would be applied for the first time to many new services, like house painting and other home repairs, just as in the coalition's budget. The income-tax plan, however, would cut the sales-tax rate to 6 percent from 8 percent.
Nearly all of the coalition members expected Mr. Weicker to veto their budget since it is essentially the same as two others he vetoed, one on July 1 and the other in May.
If the Governor does veto the budget, the House and the Senate will convene on Thursday and try to override it. If they fail, many legislators expect a shutdown of the state government because they have no plans to pass another temporary spending measure and they question Mr. Weicker's authority to keep the government going by executive order.
"We'll all test each other's powers," said Edward C. Krawiecki, the Republican minority leader in Albany, saying he would challenge the Governor's executive order if there is a veto and a vote to override it fails.
