HEADLINE: So Far, St. Louis Handles Arms Cuts

SERIES: Military-Industrial Upheaval -- Last of five articles.

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
As one of the first regions to confront weapons cutbacks and develop plans for dealing with them, the St. Louis area is emerging as a national laboratory for the post-cold-war economy.
For many individuals and companies, the rapid change has been bewildering and painful. But St. Louis has responded quickly with government and private efforts to help laid-off workers and further the diversification of the region's economy. 
 Few cities benefited more from the Pentagon's arms buildup during the 1980's than St. Louis, home to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the nation's largest military contractor. And although it is still too early to say how the big cuts in military spending expected in coming years will affect the region in the long run, the damage so far appears to be less severe than many had expected and the area's economy generally more resilient.
The city's experience is being closely watched in Washington and in areas facing similar problems, like Long Island, Fort Worth, Southern California and eastern Connecticut.
The nation's urban and economic experts say the region has, thus far, done things right. It recognized quickly that it had to act fast and aggressively, seeking to bring in new companies or production operations from outside, placing advertisements elsewhere, making phone calls, training workers in entirely new fields, helping military contracting companies convert to civilian products, seeking Federal funds wherever it could find them.
McDonnell Douglas laid off more than 9,000 workers last year -- nearly a quarter of its local work force -- from its sprawling complex of production lines, research labs and office buildings. Hundreds of subcontractors and other Pentagon suppliers in the area felt the effects.
The crisis was worsened by the timing, as the nation was sinking into recession. Workers and companies found it harder to find new jobs and business opportunties, and the regional economy was jolted by layoffs in other industries, at a Chrysler Corporation plant, for example, and at the Monsanto Company.
The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's second-largest military contractor, struck another blow recently when it announced that it would move its corporate headquarters from St. Louis to Falls Church, Va., to be closer to its chief customer -- the Pentagon. General Dynamics has no production plants in St. Louis, but the move will cost the city 300 executive and support jobs, not to mention a measure of pride.
These things were simply not supposed to happen in St. Louis. As Mark Serra, a 34-year-old plastics worker, put it: "I got a job at McDonnell Douglas two and a half years ago -- and I figured that was going to be the last job I'd ever have to look for." He is among those laid off, and has given up on finding a good job soon. Instead he has taken a part-time job and has returned to school to get a degree in electrical engineering. "I didn't expect this," he said.
For all the upheaval, though, the situation is not nearly as bad as many economists had first feared.
 
A Nice Surprise
Area Continues To Create Jobs
 "Over all, most people have been pleasantly surprised by how the economy has absorbed the shock so far," said Dennis G. Coleman, executive director of the St. Louis County Economic Council, which is spearheading the efforts by local government agencies to address the problem.
Unemployment in the region jumped from 4.9 percent in June 1990 to 7.3 percent in June of this year, reflecting not just the military-industry layoffs but the recession as well.
Although the rise was steep, it left the region's unemployment rate only slightly higher than the national average of 7 percent. Unemployment so far has not threatened to approach the double-digit rates St. Louis suffered during the recession of the early 1980's.
And the region actually got some good news in July when McDonnell Douglas agreed under pressure from local politicians to transfer some work for the Air Force's new C-17 transport plane from its plant in Long Beach, Calif., to St. Louis. The move could create 1,500 jobs and at the least will offset continuing employment declines expected in the combat-aircraft production known as Mac Air.
 
Housing Market Stable
 The region's housing market has remained relatively stable. Perhaps more important, the economy continues to create jobs, particularly in the service sector. Overall nonagricultural employment in the region last year averaged nearly 1.2 million, an increase from 1989 of nine-tenths of a percent, or 10,200 jobs, the Missouri Division of Employment Security said. The biggest gains have been in health care, reflecting St. Louis's growing role as a center of medical research.
For all the strains, the region has held up well so far, though officials said the worst might not yet be past. "Everything we hear from the Pentagon," Mr. Coleman said, "suggests that they are contemplating significant additional cuts over the next four to five years, and we have to anticipate that that is going to affect the local economy."
The region's cautious approach and continuing efforts to deal with the problem have led Federal officials to cite St. Louis as a model for other cities that want to minimize the economic pain accompanying the cutbacks.
 
Early Solutions
A Head Start Toward Diversity
 "A year ago St. Louis didn't think it had a problem," said Joseph Cartwright, an official with the Pentagon's Office of Economic Adjustment. "Since then the approach in St. Louis has been ideal as far as I can see in that they recognized that ultimately it is up to them to define what their problems are and what they can do about them."
In 1989, 84,688 people, or 3.4 percent of Missouri's work force, were employed in military contracting, most of them in the St. Louis area.
Among the major states, Missouri's dependence on military-related jobs ranked behind only Connecticut (4.7 percent), California (4.1 percent), Washington (3.9 percent) and Massachusetts and Maryland (3.7 percent each), according to the Defense Budget Project, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.
St. Louis officials are trying to attract new companies and industries to the area, using everythng from advertising to personal calls from politicians. But the region had somewhat of a head start on its effort to diversify. The number of manufacturing jobs, not only in military contracting but also in autos, barge-building and other ailing industries, has been declining steadily, from 267,900 in 1973 to 223,000 last year, a 16.7 percent decline. Over the same period, the number of service jobs increased from 614,400 to 904,400, a jump of 47 percent. Nationwide, manufacturing jobs declined by 5.2 percent in the period while service sector jobs more than doubled.
"We can do without the defense jobs if we can keep building on the strengths and the diversity we have," said Russell Signorino, an economist with the Missouri Division of Employment Security.
But engineers laid off from warplane programs cannot simply don a stethoscope and become doctors. Skilled metal workers are unlikely to move easily into jobs as X-ray technicians. For many people the diversified economy has not been much help.
So far, St. Louis and its workers have done without help from the primary Federal program to aid communities facing significant cutbacks. Congress last year appropriated $200 million to be spent on economic adjustment around the country over three years. Of the $200 million, $150 million is for worker retraining, with the balance for local economic-diversification strategies.
But the $200 million was tied up in a bureaucratic dispute involving the Pentagon and the Labor and Commerce Departments until June. The economic aid received by St. Louis so far -- primarily a $3.4 million grant from the Labor Department for worker retraining and $150,000 from the Commerce Department for an economic diversification study -- came from the general budgets of those departments.
Some 17,000 McDonnell Douglas workers nationwide and 4,000 in St. Louis lost their jobs last summer. "I was not bitter," said one, Milt Stauss, who is 60 years old. "But I would have liked to work longer."
That first round of layoffs came after Congress and the Pentagon decided to phase out two of the company's biggest programs, the Air Force's F-15 Eagle fighter and the Marine Corps' AV-8B Harrier combat jet. McDonnell Douglas was also being rocked by losses in its California-based transport aircraft division, which builds the MD-80 and MD-11 commercial jetliners and the Air Force's C-17 transport plane.
 
Received 60-Day Notice
 Mr. Stauss was lucky in some ways. After 36 years with the company, working as an engineer on aircraft simulators and other products, he qualified for a sizable pension.
Moreover, the layoffs fell under Federal legislation requiring that workers get a 60-day notice before losing their jobs. In those 60 days, state and local government agencies were able to put into action plans they had been working on with the Federal Government for six months to cope with just such an eventuality. The Pentagon assigned Mr. Cartwright to help, and, working with McDonnell Douglas, officials set up seminars on resume writing and interviewing skills, organizing job fairs and offering stress counseling.
The 60-day notice appeared to work well in allowing a good percentage of employees to find new work before losing their paychecks: Of the more than 4,000 people who lost their jobs in that first round of layoffs at McDonnell Douglas last summer, only 1,500 registered for unemployment benefits, suggesting that most of them found new jobs quickly, Mr. Signorino said.
"They had time to find new jobs at a time when the local economy was still growing slightly," Mr. Signorino said.
It is not clear, however, what kinds of jobs those workers found, or how many of them moved out of the area.
Mr. Stauss, like hundreds of other workers, enrolled in the small-business training course, and went on to start a consulting company with a partner. He has some optimism about his chances of success but is also realistic enough to know that it is too soon to tell whether his new business will make it.
"I can't say whether we're a success or a failure yet," he said.
 
A Second Wave
Dropping the A-12 Brings More Pain
 In January, more bad news for the local military-related industry, even as the nation was poised for war.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney canceled the Navy's A-12 bomber program, saying McDonnell Douglas and its partner on the plane, General Dynamics, had gotten behind schedule and over budget at a time the nation could no longer afford to bail out contractors on troubled programs. Mac Air quickly laid off 5,000 workers in St. Louis, in addition to the 4,000 of the previous summer. Other cutbacks occurred as the year progressed.
Workers laid off in that second wave got fewer breaks. Because the dismissals were the result of a contract cancellation, they were not entitled to 60 days' notice. And by now the recession was tightening.
At present, nearly eight months after the layoffs, as many as 150 unemployed workers a day visit a center at the edge of the sprawling McDonnell Douglas complex set up by the Worker Re-entry Program, administered by St. Louis Community College and supported by government and corporate grants. People are at work there on resumes, making phone calls, signing up for classes, exchanging job leads or simply talking.
 
Better Deal at Chrysler
 For some there is good news. Carla Johns, an industrial engineer, was being congratulated recently for landing a job at an Indiana chemical company. Others stared blankly at computer screens, worried, they said, about being without health insurance or about strains on their marriages. Many expressed frustration and bitterness that local auto workers laid off recently when Chrysler closed down a plant receive nearly two years of pay under their union contract while the McDonnell Douglas workers were already nearing the end of their unemployment benefits after six months.
"If you have car makers that give their employees one, two, three years at 85 or 90 percent of their salaries, then I feel that McDonnell Douglas should have done the same thing," said Frank Hutson, who lost his job in the A-12 layoffs. "If McDonnell Douglas couldn't do it on their own, then the Government should have stepped in and helped."
That kind of frustration, economists and local officials said, is just one indication of how the A-12 workers have not done as well in finding new jobs as those people who were laid off last year.
"Some of them are close to the end of their unemployment benefits and they're beginning to grasp at things," said Jane Boyle, who runs the center. "Unless something turns around in the defense industry, I'm very worried."
Mr. Hutson was laid off after 24 years with McDonnell Douglas, first in personnel and later in designing composite parts for the A-12 program. He is wondering whether he will be able to send his daughter to college next year as he had planned. As the months have passed, he has broadened his job search and lowered his salary expectations, so far with no luck.
"I have to be flexible," he said.
 
Some Fallout
Small Businesses Are Vulnerable
 Part of any diversification effort is luring new industries and companies to the region. But it also means encouraging companies already in the region to develop new products.
McDonnell Douglas is not expected to add much to the diversification effort here. It diversified long ago into commercial-aircraft manufacturing, but most of the work is done in Long Beach and at other locations around the country. McDonnell Douglas recently ruled out building a new commercial jet in St. Louis, a program that might eventually have employed 8,000 workers.
Many economists think helping smaller military contractors is among the region's most pressing priorities. "We've got skillions of machine shops and other small businesses that are vulnerable to downturns in defense and other areas," Fredric Q. Raines, an economics professor at Washington University in St. Louis, said.
 
Products Are Coming
 Some companies in St. Louis have weaned themselves from the Pentagon. Survival Technologies Inc., for example, is the primary supplier of nerve-gas antidote kits to the military; only two years ago 70 percent of its sales were to the Pentagon. Seeing the slowdown coming, the company has developed new products, like an automatic syringe filled with an antidote for bee stings. In its fiscal year ending July 31, it expects 45 percent of its $50 million in sales to have come from commercial customers, despite a surge in Pentagon orders because of the Iraq war. Its manufacturing and research employment has gone from 85 people to 450.
But many of the smaller companies have few obvious opportunities for new markets. Venki Palamand runs the Martak Machine and Tool Company with his father. Martak is tiny as military contractors go. Its annual sales of $300,000 come primarily for spare parts for planes and helicopters. The company's military business has remained healthy so far, but Mr. Palamand said, "If the Government doesn't make the purchases for defense work, I don't know where I'm going to turn."
 
Some Ideas
More Money Is Being Sought
 Some members of Congress are pressing for more money to help the workers, communities and companies.
Representative Ted S. Weiss, a Manhattan Democrat, has called for 1 percent to 2 percent of the Pentagon budget -- roughly $2.9 billion to $5.8 billion -- to be set aside each year to finance adjustment programs. But generally there seems to be little enthusiasm in Congress for any programs that expensive. Most legislative proposals now have a much narrower focus. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat from Connecticut, seeks legislation that would allow smaller military suppliers to set aside earnings tax free each year for investments in new machinery or worker retraining.
Local government officials in St. Louis said it was too soon to know whether the funds available to them would be sufficient for the long haul. But so far, they said, the funds have been adequate. Moreover, Federal officials said, there has been no important demand from other communities and states for additional funds, though that could change as more military bases close and weapons plants scale further back.
"There's no backlog of requests at this point," said Robert N. Colombo, the director of dislocated-worker programs at the Labor Department.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading; Gold Prices Post a Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted higher yesterday in light, uneventful trading mainly influenced by profit taking and technical factors. Gold was lower.
Gold slipped 10 cents on New York's Commodity Exchange, finishing at $356.60 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $356.65, 55 cents lower than Tuesday's late quote. 
 The dollar slipped in foreign trading but edged up in domestic dealings as traders consolidated their positions after a selloff on Tuesday brought about by the Federal Reserve's move to lower interest rates.
The dollar ended weakest against the German mark amid wide speculation that the Bundesbank would move next week to raise interest rates.
The Federal Reserve pushed short-term rates down a notch in an effort to reduce important consumer and business rates, with the hope of stimulating borrowing to help the economy.
 
Inflation Fear in Germany
 The German central bank, conversely, was widely expected to try to lift that nation's key 6.5 percent lending rate in an effort to control Germany's inflation rate.
The dollar is generally hurt by lower domestic rates and higher rates overseas because they make dollar-denominated investments less valuable.
"As long as the interest rate environment is fairly positive, the dollar will have a tough time rallying," said Ronald Holzer, chief currency dealer for the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell by 0.68 yen, to 136.00 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 135.80 yen, and in New York it also finished at 136.00 yen, up from 135.50 late Tuesday.
In London, the pound was unchanged at $1.7125, while in New York sterling fell to $1.7130, from $1.7145 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's, were: 1.7105 German marks, up from 1.7085; 1.4985 Swiss francs, up from 1.4930; 5.8180 French francs, up from 5.8125; 1,280.00 Italian lire, up from 1,279.00, and 1.14705 Canadian dollars, down from 1.4825.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $357 an ounce from $357.75 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, it fell to $356.80, from $357.50 late Tuesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold dropped $1.42, to $356.96.
Silver rose in New York, finishing up 1.4 cents an ounce, to $3.954, on the Commodity Exchange. It also rose in London, to $3.97, from $3.96 bid late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Lackluster Recovery Depicted in Fed Report

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The United States so far has seen a "slow, uneven" recovery from the recession with economic prospects dimmed by weak retail sales, lackluster factory demand and rising layoffs of state and local government employees, the Federal Reserve said today.
The Fed's survey of business conditions in July, called the "beige book," painted a picture of a lackluster economic recovery, which the Bush Administration says began in the spring. 
 "According to contacts around the country, national economic conditions continue to improve but at a slow, uneven pace," the Fed report said. "The pickup in home sales in the spring has lost some momentum, and commercial real estate markets and nonresidential construction remain weak."
 
Follows Rate Reduction
 The Fed's generally downbeat review of the economy, prepared by the system's 12 regional banks, was released one day after the central bank pushed down the Federal funds rate. The rate, which banks charge each other on short-term loans, was reduced by a quarter percentage point, to 5.5 percent, to keep the economy from dipping back into recession.
The central bank's move, under pressure from the Bush Administration, touched off a rally on Wall Street Tuesday, but there was no follow-through today.
"We think this is a very good course; it should be helpful to recovery," Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today.
Top policy makers at the Fed would have had access to the contents of the beige book when they acted Tuesday, although the document was not released until today.
 
Support for More Cuts
 The new survey will provide the basis for discussion by Fed policy makers when they meet on Aug. 20 and is likely to lend support to those who believe rates should be pushed down even more to spur economic demand.
The generally gloomy report was certain to increase fears of a possible double-dip recession, in which weak growth in the April-June quarter would be followed by future declines in the gross national product, as the economy slips back into recession.
The Fed survey found that retail sales, a critical element for any upturn, were actually declining in the New York, Cleveland and Richmond Federal Reserve districts in July, with many other regions reporting either flat sales or slight increases.
 
Some Layoffs Rising
 Some increase in activity was reported by American manufacturers, and widespread factory layoffs seemed to be easing off, the report said. However, the Fed also reported that layoffs were rising at state and local governments caught in budget binds, and among certain service industries. Last Friday, the Government reported that the economy had suffered a surprising loss of 51,000 jobs in July.
The beige book said that demand for business loans remained weak in most districts. In the farming sector, "hot dry weather threatens crops in several regions," it said.
Analysts said the release of today's report strengthened their belief that the central bank would move either later this month or in September to reduce interest rates further, and that banks would follow with reductions in consumer loan rates, including the prime lending rate.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Notes Sell Well At Auction

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Note and bond prices were little changed yesterday as the credit market readily digested a heavy supply of new issues, including $12 billion of 10-year Treasury notes and a flurry of corporate offerings totaling $1.43 billion.
The Treasury notes, the second leg of this week's three-part Treasury financing, totaling $38 billion, sold yesterday at an average yield of 7.94 percent. By late in the day, prices of Treasury notes had improved slightly and the yield on the new notes had fallen to 7.93 percent, down from 7.95 percent a day earlier and well below 8.13 percent a week ago. 
 In advance of today's $12 billion auction of 30-year Treasury bonds, dealers were trading the issue with a yield of about 8.15 percent. The outstanding 8 1/8 percent Treasury notes due in 2021 were offered at 99 12/32, down about 1/8 point, to yield 8.18 percent.
Securities dealers said the 10-year notes sold yesterday attracted good demand from a wide range of domestic investors, including many who had previously held money in lower-yielding securities with shorter maturities. Investors have become more willing to accept the risk of fluctuating prices that is inherent in longer-term issues because the Fed has pushed short-term interest rates down more than four percentage points in the last two years.
Japanese securities firms bid for only 10 to 15 percent of the 10-year issue, a level that would have been disastrous for the market a few years ago. But at a time when domestic demand is strong, the weak foreign participation caused little comment. Treasury data showed that during the first quarter of this year foreign investors increased their holdings of American bonds by only about $1 billion, a small fraction of the increases common in the late 1980's.
Among shorter-term issues, the three-year Treasury notes auctioned on Tuesday were trading yesterday with a yield of 6.90 percent, down from an average of 6.92 percent on Tuesday.
With interest rates on three-month Treasury bills down to 5.38 percent and 30-day commercial paper of good-quality companies at 5.60 percent, the loss of yield to investors in short-term securities has become acute.
 
Uneven Recovery Seen
 Expectations of low inflation a sluggish economic recovery and continued low short-term interest rates were reinforced yesterday when the Federal Reserve released a report of business conditions compiled by the 12 district Fed banks around the country during June and July. The report said the economy was recovering from recession at a slow and uneven pace.
Analysts at Ried, Thunberg & Company, an economic advisory firm, noted that the report probably encouraged the Fed to reduce short-term interest rates on Tuesday. While the report was optimistic that the economy would improve, it confirmed that current conditions were lackluster.
The recent decline in bond yields, plus reports from securities dealers that there was good investor demand for longer-term issues that were protected from early redemption, enticed several corporate treasurers to come to market with new securities. Yesterday's large new offerings of long-term issues included $400 million by Boeing, with a yield of 8.8 percent and a 2021 maturity, while a $300 million issue of the American Express Company was offered with a 8.65 percent yield and a 2001 maturity. A $250 million 40-year issue by the Mobil Corporation was offered at 8.72 percent. Other issues included $225 million by Pacific Bell, yielding 8.90 percent, to 2031; $150 million by Caterpillar at 9.43 percent, to 2011, and Dayton Hudson's $100 million, at 9.31 percent, to 2011.
Analysts also said that demand for Treasury issues and noncallable corporate bonds was good from investors who had been holding mortgage-backed securities. Although those securities yield roughly a percentage point more than 10-year Treasury notes, they do not have the potential for significant price increases if interest rates decline because of the risk that homeowners will refinance their mortgages, resulting in the prepayment of the mortgage-backed securities.
